lead_in: Bonus: Its section “Of Miracles” provides reasons for why human testimony might be reliable. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this philosophical book about epistemology which discusses the “missing shade of blue” in its section “Of the Origin of Ideas.” It is a revision of its author’s earlier work, A Treatise of Human Nature.

q2.quetsion_text: This Scottish philosopher wrote An Enquiry Concerning Human Understanding and discussed the “is-ought” problem.

q3.quetsion_text: David Hume also wrote a Natural History of and Dialogues Concerning the “natural” form of these systems of beliefs and practices, “organized” examples of which include Judaism and Islam.

lead_in: For 10 points each, name the following about jewelry in literature.

q1.quetsion_text: In this short story by Guy de Maupassant, Madame Loisel works for years to repay a lost piece of borrowed jewelry, only to ironically discover that it was fake.

q2.quetsion_text: Second Wife gives An-mei a pearl necklace that An-Mei crushes beneath her feet in this novel by Amy Tan. It centers on four women and their mahjong-playing mothers.

q3.quetsion_text: In this author's collection of short stories about the Vietnam War, Mary Anne Belle upsets the dynamic of Jimmy Cross's platoon after her sudden appearance wearing a necklace made of tongues.

lead_in: Bonus: Name these American poets who wrote about Abraham Lincoln, for ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: This poet of “Leaves of Grass” addressed Lincoln in the poem, “O Captain, My Captain!” and mourns his assassination in the poem, “When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d.”

q2.quetsion_text: This author examined Lincoln’s nature as a statesman during the Civil War in his book, Lincoln, the Man. He also included a poem about Anne Rutledge, one of Lincoln’s lovers, in his collection, Spoon River Anthology.

q3.quetsion_text: This author wrote a two-volume biography about Lincoln subtitled The Prairie Years and The War Years. He is also recognized for writing a poem about an entity that “comes/On little cat feet” in his poem, “Fog”.

lead_in: Name these Renaissance sculptors

q1.quetsion_text: This sculptor crafted the sarcophagi of Lorenzo and Giuliano de Medici. He also sculpted the statue of Moses for the tomb of Pope Julius II and the Pieta in St. Peter's Basilica in Rome.
q1.raw_answer: Michelangelo di Lodovico Buonarroti Simoni [accept either underlined name]

q2.quetsion_text: This Renaissance artist cast a bronze statue of St. John the Baptist for the Orsanmichele and crafted the Golden Doors of Paradise in the Baptistry, both in Florence. He was also famous for his rivalry with Brunelleschi.

q3.quetsion_text: This Renaissance artist created the equestrian statue of Bartolomeo Colleoni in Venice. He crafted a statue St. Thomas for the Orsanmichele and taught Leonardo da Vinci, who painted an angel for this artist's Baptism of Christ.
q3.raw_answer: Andrea del Verrocchio [or Andrea di Michele di Francesco de' Cioni]

lead_in: Given two heat reservoirs at a hot temperature of T1 and a cold temperature of T2, this quantity is given by one minus T2 over T1.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this dimensionless quantity usually symbolized by the Greek letter eta which represents the maximal useful output obtainable from a heat engine.

q2.quetsion_text: The maximum theoretical efficiency is achieved by this four-stage heat cycle developed by its French namesake in 1824, which does work via isothermal expansion at the hot reservoir temperature in its first stage.

q3.quetsion_text: The first stage of the Carnot cycle is traditionally taken to be the isothermal expansion stage; this term is used to describe the second expansion and fourth compression stages, which keep the heat to temperature ratio unchanged.
q3.raw_answer: isentropic or adiabatic or constant entropy [accept anything that implies that entropy is unchanged]

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this mental state embodied by the Greek Elpis and the Roman Spes, a good thing which remains unreleased after a parade of evils erupts out of Pandora's box.

q2.quetsion_text: Pandora's name is given only in this source, a didactic poem by Hesiod which gives farming advice and  recounts the "five ages of man."
q2.raw_answer: Works and Days [or Ergai kai Hemerai; or Opera et Dies]

q3.quetsion_text: The tale of this Arcadian tyrant is preceded by Ovid's version of the "ages of man" in Book I of Metamorphoses. This man's willingness to feed Zeus human flesh inspires a great flood survived by Pandora's daughter Pyrrha.

lead_in: MODERATOR NOTE: DO NOT READ THE ALTERNATE ANSWER TO THE FIRST PART These people were known for their handling of the barong and kris, knife-like objects, and liked to raid with vehicles called Proas.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this group that preyed on Spanish colonies like Cebu and burned down Balayan in 1764.

q2.quetsion_text: The Moro Pirates typically acted as raiders for this sultanate based in a namesake sea. This Islamic dynasty battled the Spanish and US for many years before signing the Carpenter Agreement.

q3.quetsion_text: The Moro Pirates were predominately from this island. This island is the southernmost island of the Philippines and the MILF and MNLF separatist groups are currently based on this heavily Islamic island.

lead_in: This part of the earth is nearest the surface at mid-ocean ridges. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this ductile section of the mantle that lies below the lithosphere.

q2.quetsion_text: This upper section of the lithosphere is the outermost layer of the earth. The continental type of this layer is primarily granite, while the oceanic type is mostly basalt.

q3.quetsion_text: The mesosphere, located in the inner mantle, is home to many minerals with this crystal structure, named for calcium titanate, which is itself  named after a 19th century Russian.

q1.quetsion_text: The festival of San Fermin in this Spanish city features the Running of the Bulls.

q2.quetsion_text: Chinese New Year ends with a festival named for these objects, which often have riddles written on them. They are also central to the Ti Peng festival in Thailand.

q3.quetsion_text: One popular festival in this country is the Battle of the Oranges in its town of Ivrea. Its most famous festival concludes with a contest deciding the most beautiful mask.

lead_in: Answer the following about Super Bowl 38,

q1.quetsion_text: This New England Patriots quarterback was named Super Bowl MVP. He had three touchdown passes during the game: one each to Deion Branch, David Givens, and Mike Vrabel.

q2.quetsion_text: The Patriots won the Super Bowl by defeating this team, which was led by quarterback Jake Delhomme and coached by John Fox at the time.

q3.quetsion_text: Super Bowl 38's "wardrobe malfunction" occurred during a performance of this Justin Timberlake song, which features the line "I'm gonna have you naked by the end of this song."

lead_in: A large one of these facilities is located at Andrews in Prince George's County, Maryland. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this type of facility, of which Camp Lemonnier is the only example in Africa. KAIA is a major one of these facilities located in Kabul.
q1.raw_answer: United States military bases [or obvious equivalents, such as U.S. army bases, U.S. naval bases, or U.S. air bases; prompt on "(military) bases" or other answers that lack a country]

q2.quetsion_text: Drones based at Camp Lemonnier often conduct strikes in this pirate-ravaged country, where government initiatives and foreign support have succeeded in pushing back al-Shabaab.

q3.quetsion_text: This customary law system native to Somalia and the Horn of Africa allows for a relatively functional judicial system despite the largely anarchic state throughout the country.

lead_in: The acceleration of the expansion of the universe means that this quantity's second derivative is positive, and the Hubble constant is this variable's time derivative over itself.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this parameter that measures the distance between two things in the universe as a function of time.
q1.raw_answer: Cosmic Scale Factor (or Robertson-Walker scale factor)

q2.quetsion_text: The square of the scale factor appears in front of the spacelike dimensions in this metric which describes a flat but expanding universe.

q3.quetsion_text: The scale factor is also equal to one over one plus this quantity which is an increase in wavelength often due to things receding. It's symbolized z and the Doppler effect is one source for it.

lead_in: The Oder-Neisse line is the boundary between this nation and its eastern neighbor.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this European nation which was divided into Eastern and Western regions after World War II.

q2.quetsion_text: This terrorist organization, also known as the Baader-Meinhof Group, was active during the 1970s and 80s in West Germany. This group conducted a series of kidnappings in 1977 which became known as the German Autumn.

q3.quetsion_text: In 1975 the RAF seized the West German embassy in this Scandinavian capital city where Prime Minister Olof Palme was later assassinated in 1986.

lead_in: This man eventually marries the Indian princess Aouda, whom he had saved from the custom of burning herself on a funeral pyre for her first husband. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this man who wins a bet after realizing that he has returned to the Reform Club a day earlier than he thought.

q2.quetsion_text: This speculative fiction author of Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea detailed Phileas Fogg's journeys with Passepartout in Around the World in Eighty Days.

q3.quetsion_text: This detective chases after Phileas Fogg, believing that Fogg recently robbed the Bank of England.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this person ridiculed for the film Bedtime for Bonzo by incumbent Pat Brown during an election which he won to become governor of California.

q2.quetsion_text: This man attempted to impress Jodie Foster by shooting Ronald Reagan, but he failed to kill the President. At trial, he was found not guilty by reason of insanity.

q3.quetsion_text: In the immediate aftermath, Alexander Haig showed his lack of constitutional knowledge by asserting that he was in charge, despite holding this cabinet post.

lead_in: With Ki, this figure was the father of a god who tore heaven and earth apart from each other, and he was also the consort of Nammu and Uras. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Sumerian sky god who formed a triad with Enlil and Enki.

q2.quetsion_text: Anu and Antu were the parents of the utukki, a group of this many evil demons. Ebisu was among the "lucky gods" of this number in Shinto, and this is also the number of Pleiades.

q3.quetsion_text: Anu and Uras were the parents of this goddess, the mother of Gilgamesh.

lead_in: Yevgeny Khaldei and Joe Rosenthal took iconic photographs of flags being raised over the Reichstag and Mt. Suribachi during this war. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this conflict whose end resulted in the Dancing Man film from Sydney and Alfred Eisenstaedt's photo of a sailor kissing a woman in a white dress, V-J Day in Times Square.
q1.raw_answer: World War II [or Second World War; or Great Patriotic War]

q2.quetsion_text: Robert Capa's The Magnificent Eleven series of photographs were taken during this Second World War engagement, where Robert F. Sargent's Taxis to Hell Â– and Back Â– Into the Jaws of Death was taken.
q2.raw_answer: D-Day [or Normandy landings/invasion; or Operation Overlord; or Operation Neptune]

q3.quetsion_text: An iconic photograph from this country shows one of its cathedrals standing amidst the smoke of burning buildings. Yousuf Karsh took both a smiling and a scowling portrait of its leader during the war.
q3.raw_answer: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland [or UK; or Great Britain; or England]

lead_in: Part 2 of this book, titled "Can Capitalism Survive," argues that capitalism will give way to socialism but in a different way than Marx envisioned. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this book that opens with "The Marxian Doctrine" and argues that the introduction of new products should force the collapse of existing businesses.

q2.quetsion_text: Capitalism, Socialism and Democracy was written by this Austrian economist.

q3.quetsion_text: Schumpeter advocated this two-word phrase to describe the tendency of capitalism to advance through learning from, or causing, business failures.

lead_in: This party attacked Carlist forces in the Begona incident. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this party that merged with the Monarchist factions after the Nationalist victory in its nation's Civil War. It was founded and initially led by Primo de Rivera.
q1.raw_answer: Falange Espanola Tradicionalista y de las Juntas de Ofensiva Nacional-Sindicalista [prompt on "Phalanx" or "Traditionalist Spanish Phalanx of the Juntas of the National Syndicalist Offensive"]

q2.quetsion_text: This general was the leader of the Nationalist side in the civil war and ruled until his death in 1975. He kept Spain neutral in the Second World War and is still dead.

q3.quetsion_text: Franco was the uncontested Nationalist leader after Mola and this other co-conspirator died in separate plane crashes. He said "I need to wear proper clothes as the new caudillo" and then overburdened his plane and crashed.

lead_in: The chorus of one song with this title begins "I was there for you in your darkest times," while the chorus of another repeats "they don't love you like I love you." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Give this shared  name of the biggest hit singles from the albums Fever to Tell and V.

q2.quetsion_text: This pop rock band recently released a single called "Maps." Their other hits include "This Love," "One More Night," "Moves Like Jagger."

q3.quetsion_text: This lead singer for Maroon 5 is a judge on the NBC show The Voice. He also had a recurring role in FX's American Horror Story: Asylum and was recently married to the Victoria Secret model, Behati Prinsloo.

lead_in: This poem's protagonist is betrayed by his stepfather Ganelon. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Old French poem in which the title paladin of Charlemagne blows a horn to call for aid against the Saracens until his temples burst. It fictionalizes the battle of Roncesvalles.
q1.raw_answer: The Song of Roland [or La Chanson de Roland]

q2.quetsion_text: The Song of Roland is one of these Old French poems about heroic deeds, which preceded the more courtly poems of the troubadours.

q3.quetsion_text: This Saracen king, who rules from Saragossa, sends the pagan army to Roncesvalles. This ally of Babylon's emir Baligant loses a hand and his queen Bramimonde as Charlemagne avenges Roland's death.

lead_in: The founder of this empire claimed to be able to turn himself into a vulture and make his armies invisible. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this African empire, which rose to power following the collapse of the Mali. It was centered at Gao and ruled by kings such as Sonni Ali.

q2.quetsion_text: This "great" ruler of Songhai usurped power from Sonni Ali's son. He was buried in a pyramidal tomb constructed from mud and timber.
q2.raw_answer: Askia the Great [or Askia Muhammad I; or Muhammad Ture]

q3.quetsion_text: Askia sponsored scholars in this city, which was the site of the University of Sankore. Disguised as a Muslim, Rene Caillie became the first European to visit this famously wealthy city in modern-day Mali.

lead_in: In this country, a group of people called "cockroaches" were massacred in a Polish church in Gikondo.  For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this African country where the downing of Juvenal Habyarimana's plane sparked a genocide of the Tutsis by the Hutus.

q2.quetsion_text: This country effectively helped many participants in the genocide to escape to Zaire by creating the Zone Turquoise. Earlier in the 20th century, this colonial power lost the Battle of Dien Bien Phu.

q3.quetsion_text: Along with the Impuzamugambi, this militia participated in the genocide. They used the RTLM radio station to track fleeing Tutsis and formed the ALIR after being forced out of Rwanda.

lead_in: Walter Benjamin said this person was the ideal inhabitant of the Parisian arcades who disappeared when those structures did. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this strolling figure of 19th-century Paris, who is engulfed by the crowd while remaining a detached observer of it.

q2.quetsion_text: The flÃ¢neur was described by this man in a Le Figaro essay focused on the career of "Monsieur G." This poet cried out against ennui in his collection Les Fleurs du Mal.

q3.quetsion_text: Baudelaire claims Monsieur G. tries to "distill the eternal from the transitory" by capturing this quality, which Baudelaire elsewhere defines as "the ephemeral, the fugitive, the contingent."

lead_in: Bonus: He dies when Roger drops a boulder on him. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this asthmatic and rather vulnerable character who acts as an adviser to Ralph and whose spectacles are used by Jack’s tribe to make a fire.

q2.quetsion_text: Piggy is a character in this novel, in which a group of children split into tribes lead by Ralph and Jack, who are stranded on an island. Later in this novel, a plane crash brings a mysterious figure known as the “beast” to the island.

q3.quetsion_text: This English author of The Lord of the Flies also wrote a book that reconstructs Neanderthal culture, The Inheritors.

lead_in: One of its three prongs requires legislation to have a secular purpose.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this test used to determine if a piece of legislation violates the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment. It shares its name with the plaintiff of a 1971 Supreme Court case about public school funds paying teachers that worked in private, religious schools.

q2.quetsion_text: The Lemon test was created while this man was Chief Justice. This man succeeded Earl Warren as Chief and cases like Roe v. Wade also occurred during his term.

q3.quetsion_text: Another set of Establishment Clause cases, Edwards v. Aguillard and Kitzmiller v. Dover, have dealt, broadly speaking, with this controversial practice. The Supreme Court has generally ruled it unconstitutional.
q3.raw_answer: teaching creationism in public schools [accept teaching creation science or teaching intelligent design or any other equivalents, prompt on religious education in public schools]

lead_in: Bonus: At the end of this procedure, an X-ray film is used to detects its results. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this procedure named after a British biologist, in which single-stranded radioactive DNA probes are added to DNA fragments in order to detect them.

q2.quetsion_text: Southern blotting is often performed after this procedure, which uses an electric current to move fragments of DNA, RNA, or protein through a matrix such as agarose.

q3.quetsion_text: Before being run through a gel, DNA is cut with the restriction type of these molecules. This term refers to any protein that catalyzes a biological reaction by lowering its activation energy.

lead_in: Charles-Louis Hanon wrote a series of these called The Virtuoso Pianist, and Charles-Valentin Alkan's set of twelve in all the minor keys ends with "The Feast of Aesop".

q1.quetsion_text: Name these technical studies of which Franz Liszt wrote "Transcendental" ones.

q2.quetsion_text: Liszt was a student of this Austrian composer and pianist who wrote several collections of etudes, such as 160 Eight-Measure Studies and The School of Velocity.

q3.quetsion_text: In 1812, Czerny gave the Vienna premiere of this piano concerto in E-flat major by his teacher, which begins with three cadenzas for the piano, punctuated by orchestral tutti chords.
q3.raw_answer: Ludwig van Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 5 in E-flat major, Op. 55 "Emperor" [accept either underlined part]

q1.raw_answer: Nights in the Gardens of Spain [or Noches en los jardines de EspaÃ±a]

q2.quetsion_text: Nights in the Gardens of Spain is by this Andalusian composer, who included the movement "Song of Will-o'-the-Wisp" in his gypsy-inspired piece, El amor brujo, or Love, the Magician.

q3.quetsion_text: This movement from El amor brujo, which opens with 23 bars of impassioned trilling, depicts the summoning of the ghost of Candela's husband. A piano transcription of this piece was popularized by Artur Rubinstein.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this novel which begins and ends with a fragment of the same sentence, and whose characters include Humphrey Chimpden Earwicker, his wife Anna Livia Plurabelle, and their children Shem, Shaun, and Issy.

q2.quetsion_text: Finnegans Wake is by this Irish Modernist creator of Stephen Dedalus, who appears in this author's Ulysses and Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this ruler who, along with her younger sister, was involved in the Affair of the Spanish Marriages when she was married to a French prince.

q2.quetsion_text: Isabella's rule was contested by her uncle in the first of these wars that occurred in nineteenth century Spain. The last of these wars started in 1872, four years after Isabella was deposed from the throne.

q3.quetsion_text: Isabella and her husband were both members of the House of Bourbon, which led Lord Palmerston to claim that the marriage broke this 1713 treaty that ended the War of the Spanish Succession.

lead_in: Answer some questions about post-WWII American poetry,

q1.quetsion_text: This poet of the "Wichita Vortex Sutra" begun his poem Howl with the line: "I saw the best minds of my generation destroyed by madness".

q2.quetsion_text: This poet described a girl who "cast herself into such a pure depth, / Even a father could not find her" when sad, in a poem he wrote for a student killed by a horse. One of his poems opens: "I knew a woman, lovely in her bones".

q3.quetsion_text: This poet imagined a world where humans need not labor any longer in his poem "All Watched Over by Machines of Loving Grace". The title poem of another of his collections, The Pill Versus the Springhill Mine Disaster, concludes "I think of all the people / lost inside of you."

lead_in: This effect is a consequence of Le Chatelier's principle. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this effect in which an ionic compound becomes less soluble in a solution that already  contains one of the ions in the compound.

q2.quetsion_text: If the pressure of the system is increased, Le Chatelier's principle predicts a shift in this direction for  a reaction that forms a mole of N2O2 from two moles of nitric oxide.
q2.raw_answer: to the right [or towards the products; or towards N2O2]

q3.quetsion_text: Le Chatelier's principle predicts what will happen to a reaction when this condition is disrupted. In  the dynamic type of this condition, there is no net change in the concentrations of the products or  reactants.

lead_in: Name these Knights of the Round Table

q1.quetsion_text: This "Knight of the Cart" was raised by the Lady of the Lake. He serves as King Arthur's greatest champion before his affair with Guinevere.
q1.raw_answer: Sir Lancelot du Lac [or Launcelot; or Lancelin]

q2.quetsion_text: This illegitimate son of Lancelot is the only knight pure enough to sit in the Siege Perilous and thus is able, after much questing, to see the Holy Grail.

q3.quetsion_text: While Chretien de Troyes was writing Lancelot, Knight of the Cart, he was also working on a romance about this "Knight of the Lion," the son of King Urien and Morgan le Fay.

lead_in: This series came to an end in 1970 with the publication of Last Things.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this eleven-novel cycle which also includes The Light and the Dark and The Corridors of Power, and which follows Lewis Eliot through the twentieth century.

q2.quetsion_text: The Strangers and Brothers series is the major fictional accomplishment of this author and physicist, whose concern with morality led him to be sarcastically dubbed "the greatest living nineteenth century author" during the 1960s. His lecture "The Two Cultures" condemned the "gulf of mutual incomprehension" between science and the humanities.

q3.quetsion_text: This literary critic, who wrote For Continuity and The Great Tradition, and advanced the "third realm" theory, delivered the widely mocked response lecture " Two Cultures? The Significance of C. P. Snow" in which he advocated for ignorance of science.

lead_in: Name some languages once used in the ancient Middle East,

q1.quetsion_text: This language, named for a polity ruled by Sargon the Great, was the lingua franca of the Babylonian empire. This Semitic language was written in cuneiform, and works in it include Gilgamesh, the Amarna Letters, and Enuma Elish.

q2.quetsion_text: This Semitic language was the official language of communication in the Persian Empire. Its Syriac dialect was a major liturgical language for early Eastern Christians, and the Pahlavi scripts were based on its alphabet.

q3.quetsion_text: This language was used by the Mitanni kingdom as well as its namesake Northern Mesopotamian invaders, and it is notably related to Urartian. The earliest known text in this language can be found on the Louvre Lion.

lead_in: We like special relativity because it explains stuff that actually happens.

q1.quetsion_text: We like special relativity because it explains stuff that actually happens.

q2.quetsion_text: Another demonstration of time dilation relies on shooting these particles at near-light speed and timing how long before they appear to decay. These particles have the longest known decay time besides the neutron.

q3.quetsion_text: The first verification of time dilation was this experiment, which fired hydrogen ions at a detector and measured the change in their wavelength. Its results demonstrated that the Lorentz factor needed to be included in the classical redshift equation.

lead_in: This family is commented upon sardonically by Cora and Vernon Tull, the latter of whom watches them cross a river in which Cash breaks his leg. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this dirt-poor family which seeks to bury its matriarch Addie in the county seat of Jefferson. It includes Darl and his illegitimate brother Jewel.

q2.quetsion_text: The Bundren family appears in this novel by William Faulkner, whose many point-of-view chapters include one from Addie Bundren beyond the grave.

q3.quetsion_text: Anse Bundren, the family patriarch, is largely motivated not by the need to bury his wife, but by his desire to obtain a new wife and buy these items for himself in Jefferson.

lead_in: The opening section of this work is dedicated to "The Elimination of Metaphysics."

q1.quetsion_text: Name this 1936 work by A. J. Ayer that argues for the verification principle in evaluating synthetic propositions. It also proposes that ethical sentences only express emotional attitudes.

q2.quetsion_text: Ayer's assault on metaphysics echoed that of this group of logical positivist philosophers, whose members included Moritz Schlick and Rudolf Carnap.

q3.quetsion_text: Language, Truth, and Logic was titled in homage to Friedrich Waismann, who helped articulate this concept from Wittgenstein's Philosophical Investigations. It is the spoken component of a "form of life," and a famous example is used by two builders.

lead_in: An essay by Martin Heidegger argues that great examples of these things both "give to things their look" and help historical communities understand what is noble and matters in life. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify these things, whose "aura" is sublimated in modern times because reproductions of them are outside the "sphere of authenticity" according to an essay by Walter Benjamin.
q1.raw_answer: works of art [or artworks; or obvious equivalents]

q2.quetsion_text: This American pragmatist developed his aesthetic theory, based on the exchange between the "live creature" of man and his environment, in Art as Experience. He also wrote Democracy and Education.

q3.quetsion_text: This long-time art critic for The Nation coined a term for what he called "an atmosphere of art theory" in his influential essay, "The Artworld."

q1.quetsion_text: Name this father of Hygieia and Panacea, the Greek god of healing.

q2.quetsion_text: Asclepius received this divine punishment for resurrecting the dead Hippolytus. This punishment, which used an implement forged by the Cyclopes, was also given to Salmoneus for trying to imitate Zeus.
q2.raw_answer: getting struck by Zeus's thunderbolt [or getting struck by lightning; accept reasonable synonyms such as "hit," "killed," etc. for "struck"; prompt on partial answers such as "getting killed by Zeus"]

q3.quetsion_text: Sick people came to this Argive town, a cult center of Asclepius, to sleep until a vision told them how to heal. While patients rested here, their families could watch dramas in a huge amphitheater.

lead_in: In 661, Ali was assassinated while praying at the Great Mosque in this city after he briefly made it the Rashidun capital.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this garrison city where the scholars Maytham al-Tammar and the Companion Kumayl ibn Ziyad spent most of their lives. This Iraqi city was the birthplace of Abū Hanīfah, the founder of the Hanafi school.

q2.quetsion_text: The growth of urban centers like Kūfa on the periphery of the Arabian Peninsula allowed these people, exemplified by Abū Hanīfah, to gain power. This Arabic term refers to non-Arab converts to Islam.

q3.quetsion_text: Andrew Watson proposed that Islamic urbanization was driven by an agricultural revolution, part due to the implementation of this practice, which ancient Egyptians accomplished with canals used to channel the Nile flood.
q3.raw_answer: basin/surface irrigation [prompt on any answers related to watering crops]

lead_in: Francois Fenelon wrote a novel about the adventures of this character as a critique of the reign of King  Louis XIV. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this character who lends his name to the first four sections of the poem in which he appears.  Several people tell this young man about the story of Orestes to urge him to take action.
q1.raw_answer: Telemachus [or The Adventures of Telemachus; or Les Aventures de Telemaque]

q2.quetsion_text: Telemachus is spurred on his quest and accompanied by this old man, who is actually Athena in  disguise. This character's name has developed into an English word meaning an experienced guide.

q2.raw_answer: Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

q3.quetsion_text: This other greenhouse gas is trapped in clathrates and released when arctic ice melts, forming a positive feedback cycle.

lead_in: 1. Just like the characters in the Kalevala, this man's tale is told in trochaic tetrameter. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this son of the wind Mudjekeewis, who bests the evil Pearl-Feather and tells his people to accept Christianity.

q2.quetsion_text: The Song of Hiawatha was penned by this 19th century American poet, who also wrote "Paul Revere's Ride."

q3.quetsion_text: In this other Longfellow poem, the title character is separated from her lover Gabriel when the Acadians are kicked out of their homeland. They re-unite just in time for him to die.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this indigenous people whose underworld featured torture houses such as the Cold House and the House of Bats, as well as a court for the sacred ball game.

q2.quetsion_text: Heroes with this relation to each other descend into the underworld of Xibalba in the QuichÃ© Mayan epic Popol Vuh. In Greek myth, Castor and Pollux had this relationship.

q3.quetsion_text: The Maya Hero Twins use this substance to replace the teeth of the villainous Seven Macaw. The Popol Vuh relates that mankind was created from this resource, which the Aztec Quetzalcoatl stole in the form of an ant.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this 1822 battle in which Antonio Jose de Sucre defeated Melchor Aymerich on the slopes of a namesake volcano.

q2.raw_answer: Republic of Ecuador [or Republica del Ecuador]

q3.quetsion_text: In July, following the battle, Simon Bolivar moved into this city to make sure it became a part of Colombia rather than Peru. Jose Joaquin de Olmedo protested, but was ultimately removed from his role as its president.

lead_in: Birefringent materials exhibit different refractive indices for light with different forms of this property. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this property of a wave oscillating in only one plane, used by Polaroid filters and glare-reducing sunglasses.

q2.quetsion_text: Polarized light is perfectly transmitted without reflection at this angle. Unpolarized light incident on a material boundary at this angle is perfectly polarized.

q3.quetsion_text: Light waves can be polarized because they are this type of wave, whose propagation is perpendicular to the displacement of the medium. They include standing waves on strings but not sound waves.

lead_in: The identity kind of these entities is square and has ones along its diagonal.

q1.quetsion_text: Name these mathematical constructs in which numbers or expressions are placed in a rectangular array with rows and columns.

q2.quetsion_text: A square matrix is invertible when this value is non-zero. Laplace's formula gives it in terms of minors or cofactors, and for a matrix with elements a, b, c, and d, it equals ad minus cb.

q3.quetsion_text: Eigenvalues of a matrix are the roots of this kind of polynomial, formed by taking the determinant of a matrix minus the identity times a variable, lambda.

lead_in: A 2014 examination by Tate Museum cataloguer Matthew Imms demolished the authenticity of a series of watercolors of this scene, which depicted a similar event seven years later. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this common scene of two oil paintings, one of which was painted by the artist on his boat near Waterloo Bridge. The more famous of these paintings of an 1834 event shows a throng of spectators gazing at the red reflection of water near Westminster Bridge.
q1.raw_answer: Burning of the Houses of Parliament [or Burning of the Houses of the Lords and Commons; or Burning of Parliament; be lenient with linking words in the titles]

q2.quetsion_text: This British artist of the Burning of the Houses of Parliament paintings celebrated the progress of the Industrial Revolution in Rain, Steam, and Speed.

q3.quetsion_text: Turner, who was also mindful of the horrors of the Industrial Revolution, symbolically represented them as grotesque creatures composed of red and pink swirls in this 1845 seascape.

lead_in: In a webcomic, this man has to drive a bus through a crowd of zombies demanding basic human rights.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this man, who in real life has been seen tranquilizing polar bears and swimming in Siberian rivers, typically bare-chested.

q2.quetsion_text: Like in real life, Putin's sidekick is this man nicknamed "Dima" who can turn into a bear at will.

q3.quetsion_text: Another sidekick of Putin is this man, who in Superputin is able to turn invisible and whose character is described as "completely insane". In real life, he was formerly the deputy Prime Minister of Russia and is a close ally of Putin.

lead_in: Identify these tools used by data scientists,

q1.quetsion_text: This programming language developed by Kiwi statisticians Ross Ihaka and Robert Gentleman is a variation on a similarly named language created by John Chambers. Tables in this language can be stored in data frames, and there are lots of great packages available at CRAN.

q2.quetsion_text: You might use one of R's built-in functions to display this kind of graph and see the shape of your distribution. These graphs break the data into bins, with vertical bars representing frequency of that bin. For instance, a graph of this kind representing bonus conversion at this tournament might have a bin for 10-12 PPB with 6 teams in that bin.

q3.quetsion_text: Weka, a popular machine learning tool, allows you to easily run this unsupervised clustering algorithm which keeps running and assigning its namesakes to the centroids of the clusters until none of the clusters change. The Forgy method picks random observations to pass as inputs to this algorithm.

lead_in: Answer the following questions about the early universe for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This period is the rapid initial expansion of the universe beginning ten to the negative thirty six seconds after the Big Bang.

q2.quetsion_text: In this epoch named for a unit of time, gravity may have been comparably strong to the other forces, all of which may have all been unified. It was, however, unstable, leading to symmetry breaking.

q3.quetsion_text: It is not understood how asymmetry arose between the number of these three-quark particles and their antiparticles. Andrei Sakharov proposed that their asymmetry requires three conditions, including violation of their namesake number, C-, and CP-symmetry.

lead_in: This novel's protagonist is married to Joe Starks, who becomes the mayor of Eatonville. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this novel, in which Janie Crawford shoots Tea Cake after he is bitten by a mad dog.

q2.quetsion_text: Their Eyes Were Watching God is a novel written by this African-American author.

q3.quetsion_text: Hurston is often identified as part of this cultural movement, named after a certain New York neighborhood. It included figures such as Claude McKay and Langston Hughes.

lead_in: "Chunking" can increase the capacity of this system, which is the second stage of the Atkinson-Shifflin three-stage model.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this system whose "magic number" is, according to George Miller, seven plus or minus two.
q1.raw_answer: short-term memory [or working memory; prompt on memory]

q2.quetsion_text: This condition does not affect short-term memory, since it is a disruption of long-term memory. Its "anterograde" form is an inability to consolidate new memories, and is "retrograde" form involves the loss of existing memories.

q3.quetsion_text: This kind of long-term memory is extremely vivid due to the stress of the circumstances. An example is the memory someone has of where they were on September 11.

lead_in: Note to moderator: Only read "Lucius Mummius" if a correct answer to the first part is not given. This man was the first novus homo to receive an agnomen for military service.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Roman general who defeated Diaeus of Megalopolis and subsequently sacked Corinth.

q2.quetsion_text: Lucius Mummius earned his agnomen from defeating this league of Greek city-states, which included Corinth. It consisted of a number of cities on the northern Peloponnessus and was formed by Aratus of Sicyon in 180 BC.

q3.quetsion_text: The Achaean League joined forces with this kingdom's ruler, Philip V, to fight the rival Aetolian League. Lucius Aemilius Paullus gained an epithet for defeating its ruler Perseus at the Battle of Pydna.

lead_in: When represented as coordinates, these entities can be thought of as the arrow connecting the origin to that coordinate.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify these things that, unlike scalars, have both a magnitude and a direction.

q2.quetsion_text: This function takes two vectors and outputs a single number by summing the products of their corresponding coordinates. If this function is zero, then the vectors are perpendicular.
q2.raw_answer: dot product [accept scalar product or inner product]

q3.quetsion_text: For a given linear function, this is the set of all vectors that get mapped to the zero vector. The dimension of this space plus the dimension of the image space equals the dimension of the domain space.

lead_in: mutation in one isoform of this protein causes a condition in which the sclera of the eyes turn blue and bones are easily broken.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this triple helical protein that is abundant in connective tissue. Vitamin C is required for the enzymes that hydroxylate its proline and lysine residues.

q2.quetsion_text: Collagen is a key component of this general structure, which includes the basement membrane. This structure, which contains fibronectins, integrins, and elastins, holds cells together in tissues.

q3.quetsion_text: A key component of the ECM, proteoglycans, consists of a core protein with a serine linkage to these polysaccharides, which include chondroitin sulfate and consist of repeating dimeric units.

lead_in: Charles Simic was the first Serbian-American to hold this post.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this position, also held by Robert Pinsky and Rita Dove, which serves as the official consultant on poetry to the United States Congress.

q2.quetsion_text: This man, who served as the US Poet Laureate in 1986 and 1987, wrote about the political rise of Willie Stark in the novel All The King's Men.

q3.quetsion_text: This other US Poet Laureate wrote that "They begin beating it with a hose to find out what it really means" in his "Introduction to Poetry", and wrote The Art of Drowning.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this organelle that modifies, packages, and exports proteins to different parts of a eukaryotic cell.
q1.raw_answer: Golgi body [or Golgi apparatus; accept word forms]

q2.quetsion_text: This structure encloses cells, and it consists of a phospholipid bilayer. This is described by the fluid mosaic model and is surrounded by a cell wall in bacteria, plants, and fungi.
q2.raw_answer: cell membranes [or plasma membranes; or cytoplasmic membranes]

q3.quetsion_text: These transmembrane proteins serve as channels to allow the movement of water molecules through the cell membrane. They were discovered by Peter Agre, who won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 2003.

lead_in: This reaction is usually followed by a reductive workup of DMS.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this reaction that cleaves an alkene to produce two carbonyls. This reaction proceeds by forming a diradical intermediate that reacts in a 1,3 cycloaddition to form a trioxolane.

q2.quetsion_text: The first step of ozonolysis forms this cyclic precursor to the Criegee intermediate by adding ozone across a carbon-carbon double bond. Unlike those of the more stable ozonide, all of its oxygen atoms are adjacent on the ring.

q3.quetsion_text: A modification of ozonolysis with a hydrogen peroxide workup can form this functional group. This functional group reacts with an alcohol to produce an ester under acidic conditions.

lead_in: This team's leading scorer for the season, Frank Kaminsky, broke Michael Finley's school record with a 43-point game.

One of these items caused an uproar when it appeared in an August 2014 promotional photo for Downton Abbey, and most uses of these items were banned by San Francisco in March 2014.

lead_in: The subject of this event was subsequently kept under house arrest until his death. For 10 points each:

q2.quetsion_text: Galileo was forced to recant this position, a mathematical model of which was presented by Nicolaus Copernicus and expanded upon by Johannes Kepler.

q3.quetsion_text: This 1610 pamphlet published by Galileo contains the first published scientific findings to come from observation through a telescope. It describes several "Medicean Stars" circling Jupiter.
q3.raw_answer: The Starry Messenger [or Sidereal Messenger; or Sidereus Nuncius]

q2.raw_answer: England and/or Portugal (do not accept "Britain" or "United Kingdom")

lead_in: Name these people who lived in Gaul in pre-Roman times, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: These Celtic religious officials allegedly trained for twenty years to learn all their rituals, such as a veneration of a sacred oak.

q3.quetsion_text: This tribe occupied the northernmost of the "three parts" into which Julius Caesar claimed Gaul was famously divided.

lead_in: This man performed the action that he is best-known for after his target uttered the words "She won't think anything about it" while watching Our American Cousin. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this actor, who planned a conspiracy with Dr. Samuel Mudd and Mary Surratt, and was later shot while trapped inside a burning barn.

q3.quetsion_text: John Wilkes Booth was involved in a larger conspiracy that also aimed to kill these two men. Lewis Powell bungled the assassination attempt on one of them, while George Atzerodt never attempted to kill the other one.
q3.raw_answer: William Seward and Andrew Johnson [accept answers in either order; prompt on "Johnson" for Andrew Johnson; do not prompt if only given one name]

lead_in: Your mission: to determine the strength of the magnetic field B generated by an electromagnet

q1.quetsion_text: If you have a conducting wire, you can determine B by exploiting the fact that the force exerted on the wire is equal to this quantity times L cross B. For a resistor, this quantity is equal to voltage divided by resistance.

q2.quetsion_text: You can also determine B using one of these devices which exploit Faraday's Law to determine the strength of even an inhomogenous B field from the induced EMF. Essentially small solenoids, they are first calibrated, then moved in or out of the B field.
q2.raw_answer: search coils [accept induction loops, induction sensors or induction coils]

q3.quetsion_text: To calibrate your search coil, you first have to know that the B field of a solenoid is equal to this quantity times the number of loops times current. This value is equal to 4 pi times 10 to the negative 7 tesla-meters per ampere.
q3.raw_answer: permeability of free space [accept vacuum permeability, magnetic constant, or mu naught; prompt on partial]

lead_in: Prove that you understand some Hegelian concepts,

q1.quetsion_text: Though it is debated whether he advocated this model, Hegel's dialectical triad is usually divided into the three stages of thesis, antithesis, and this stage, in which the best parts of the thesis and antithesis combine into one entity.
q1.raw_answer: synthesis [or sublation; or aufhebung; or aufheben]

q2.quetsion_text: In Elements of the Philosophy of Right, Hegel contrasts the individualistic moral concept of "Abstract Right", with this system of social customs that regulates moral behavior within civilization.
q2.raw_answer: ethical life [or ethical substance; or ethical order; or Sittlichkeit]

q3.quetsion_text: The "Objective Logic" section of Hegel's The Science of Logic is divided into books concerning "being" and this concept, which is defined as "being" that mediates with itself through negativity.

lead_in: According to an old joke, a kid asks an old man how to get to this place, to which the man replies "Practice!" For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this prestigious classical music venue in Manhattan that was established by a steel mogul.

lead_in: These coastal ecosystems, which were depicted in many of the landscape paintings of Martin Johnson Heade, were the subject of an energy flow study led by J.M. Teal in Georgia.
