q1.quetsion_text: The law of partial pressures is named for this English scientist.

q2.quetsion_text: The law stating that the rate of effusion is inversely proportional to the particle masses is named for this Scottish scientist.

q3.quetsion_text: The nonrelativistic probability distribution of speeds of gas molecules is named for these two scientists.
q3.raw_answer: James Clerk Maxwell and Ludwig Boltzmann (both answers in either order without prompting)

lead_in: In one play by this author, Otto Hogan dresses up as a spirit called "The Mysterious Stranger" to stop the construction of a highway.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this author of Beef, No Chicken who wrote about the arrest of Makak in his most famous play.

q2.quetsion_text: In this early poem by Walcott, the speaker imagines a body "fallen from evil days, from evil times" and senses the "smell of dead limes" and the "leprosy of empires" at the title place.

q3.quetsion_text: Walcott is best known for this Iliad-inspired epic in which Achille paints "In God we Troust" on his boat and sails to Africa.

lead_in: Answer some questions about stained glass, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: These strips of lead join and separate panes in a stained glass window.

q2.quetsion_text: These massive circular stained glass windows are often located above the West door of a church.
q2.raw_answer: rose window [or Catherine window; or wheel window]

q3.quetsion_text: The gigantic CavaillÃ©-Coll organ in this church had to be built around its famous, equally enormous  rose window. This large cathedral is located right in the center of Paris.

lead_in: Note to moderator: The answer lines to the first and third part are very similar. Please take extra caution when accepting answers for this bonus.  For two gases, the ratio of the rates of this process is equal to the ratio of the average velocities of the gas particles.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this process in which gas molecules enter an empty chamber via an opening smaller than the gas molecules' mean free path.

q2.quetsion_text: According to Graham's law of effusion, the ratio of the effusion rate for two gases can be found by taking the quotient of each gas's value for the square root of this quantity.

q3.quetsion_text: Effusion is not to be confused with this other process, which occurs when gas molecules move from an area of high concentration to low concentration without the presence of a small hole.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this dissolute French author who addressed the "hypocrite reader" in the prefatory poem of a book that also includes the sections "Parisian Scenes" and "Spleen and Ideal," Les Fleurs du Mal.

q2.quetsion_text: Another Baudelaire poem describes how the "opulent display" of these title objects make his otherwise-naked love look "like Moorish concubines." A Diderot novel is titled after some indiscreet ones.

q3.quetsion_text: "Les Bijoux" was written in the alexandrine meter, like the plays of this author of Bajazet and Andromaque.

lead_in: For 10 points each, name some religious subjects that appear frequently in artwork.

q1.quetsion_text: This dude is the child in various depictions of the Madonna and Child. He is seen in the house of his parents in a John Everett Millais painting, and he can be seen in his infancy in several takes on the Flight into Egypt.

q2.quetsion_text: The central panel of the Merode Altarpiece shows this scene, usually the first scene in series of the life of Christ. Versions by Fra Angelico and Jan Van Eyck both feature Gabriel on the right and the Virgin Mary on the left.

q3.quetsion_text: This term refers to the scene of an enthroned Madonna. Notable examples include one with St. Francis in Assisi by Cimabue, and one built as the altarpiece for the Siena Cathedral by Duccio.

lead_in: Identify the following about drawing Lewis dot diagrams, for 10 points each

q1.quetsion_text: While the octet rule is generally accurate for determining the bonding behavior of elements, this metalloid, symbolized B, can bond with only six electrons in its outer shell.

q2.quetsion_text: In a Lewis structures, this quantity is minimized for individual atoms, and can be found by subtracting the sum of nonbonding electrons and half the bonding electrons from the number of valence electrons it usually has.
q2.raw_answer: formal charge [do not accept or prompt on just "charge"]

q3.quetsion_text: In general, when a central halogen atom binds to three other halogen atoms, the central atom has this many lone pairs. In the sulfate ion, this the value of the formal charge of the central sulfur atom.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this process in which a population separates into new groups that are unable to interbreed and produce fertile offspring.
q1.raw_answer: speciation [prompt on word forms or things like "forming a new species"]

q2.quetsion_text: Parapatric speciation can lead to the formation of these species in which populations can breed only with immediately adjacent populations, but the "terminal" species can't interbreed. Larus gulls and California salamanders are common examples.

q3.quetsion_text: According to this hypothesis, evolution is principally driven by abiotic forces, not biotic ones. It's contrasted with the Red Queen hypothesis.

lead_in: This novel repeatedly returns to the phrase, "We crossed the river on horseback." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Mexican novel, a retrospective of a corrupt tycoon's life. The second person "tu" slowly bleeds into this novel as the narrator enters his final hours.

q2.quetsion_text: ] This Mexican author of Where the Air is Clear introduced modernist techniques to the Boom with The Death of Artemio Cruz.

q3.quetsion_text: In this sprawling novel by Fuentes, Pollo falls into the Seine and travels through the ages, witnessing the rise and fall of civilizations. Much of this novel is set around the construction of El Escorial by El Senor.

lead_in: For 10 points each, identify the following about realism in international relations.

q1.quetsion_text: Realists believe that the international system is characterized by this property, since it lacks a universal central authority. Because of this, uncertainty and self-help pervade the system.

q2.quetsion_text: Thucydides fictionalized a dialogue between realist Athens and this idealist island during the Peloponnesian War. This island refuses to surrender to the Athenians, who justify its destruction wih "might makes right".

q3.quetsion_text: This Italian realist diplomat emphasized the importance of virtu. In The Prince, he advised Lorenzo II de' Medici to be feared rather than loved or hated.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this type of mass. Verdi's was first performed on the one-year anniversary of the death of Alessandro Manzoni.
q1.raw_answer: requiem mass [accept "mass for the dead" or "missa pro defunctis"]

q2.quetsion_text: The Dies Irae is omitted from this composer's requiem, which features a soprano aria in its fourth movement Pie Jesu. He also composed the Dolly Suite, the Masques et Bergamasques, and a famous Pavane.

q3.quetsion_text: This Italian composer and contemporary of Beethoven is known for his operas, like Lodoiska, as well as his C minor requiem.

lead_in: Identify the following about the geography of Florida, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This wetlands region in southern Florida is home to a namesake national park. It is mostly fed by  water from Lake Okeechobee and is the target of many restoration efforts.

q2.quetsion_text: The Florida Keys are connected by the Overseas Highway, which is a portion of a US Route with this  number. A highway with this number runs around the entirety of Australia; another runs down the coast of California.

q3.quetsion_text: This river forms the easternmost part of the Florida-Georgia boundary, flowing from Okefenokee  Swamp into the Atlantic near Fernandina Beach. Like Florida's St. Johns River, it is frequently misspelled  with an apostrophe in its name.

lead_in: This man founded the Community of St. John with Adrienne von Speyr, a twice-married Protestant whose mystical experiences impressed this theologian.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Roman Catholic theologian from Switzerland who explored the resurrection of Christ in Mysterium Paschale and wrote the five-volume Theo-Drama.

q2.quetsion_text: Balthasar was a major expositor of this Neo-Orthodox theologian from Switzerland, best known for his thirteen-volume Church Dogmatics and the commentary The Epistle to the Romans.

q3.quetsion_text: Along with Dietrich Bonhoeffer and others, Barth became a leader in the Confessing Church, which fiercely opposed this regime. Ideologists of this regime, like Alfred Rosenberg, promoted Positive Christianity, which sought to deny Christ's Semitic origin.
q3.raw_answer: Third Reich [accept answers like Nazi Germany]

lead_in: Spirituals and African-American folk music inspired this composer to write Treemonisha. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this African-American pianist and composer who notably popularized a certain genre of piano music. He may be best known for his piano piece The Entertainer

q2.quetsion_text: Joplin was known as the "King of" this type of music, which was a precursor to jazz. It's characterized by heavily syncopated melodies and walking bass lines.

q3.quetsion_text: Joplin rose to fame with this rag named after a club in Sedalia, Missouri. It’s an example of what came to be known as “classic ragtime”.

lead_in: This substance is synthesized at rosette terminal complexes, and it consists of D-glucose units condensing to form beta-1,4 glycosidic bonds. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this indigestible polysaccharide that forms the cell walls of plants.

q2.quetsion_text: Cellulose is often used as a stationary phase in this form of chromatography, which is better at separating non-volatile mixtures than paper chromatography.

q3.quetsion_text: In paper, slide, membrane forms, this derivative of cellulose is commonly used to immobilize nucleic acids in Northern and Southern blots, and proteins in Western blots.
q3.raw_answer: nitrocellulose [or cellulose nitrate; or flash paper; or flash cotton; or guncotton; or flash string]

lead_in: The protagonist is transfixed by the image of his wife at the top of the stairs. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this short story in which Gabriel Conroy muses about his own mortality after his wife Gretta tells him about Michael Furey's fate. It concludes with the image of snow blanketing all of Ireland.

q2.quetsion_text: This novel consists of 18 episodes, each titled after a different section of the original Greek hero's voyage. Its final episode is a stream-of-consciousness "yes" soliloquy given by Molly Bloom.

q3.quetsion_text: "The Dead" is the final story in Dubliners, a collection by this modernist author of Ulysses and the dauntingly experimental Finnegan's Wake.

lead_in: Bonus: Anson Burlingame challenged him to a duel that he later chickened out of. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this South Carolina Congressman, whose uncle Andrew Butler was insulted in a May 1856 speech.

q2.quetsion_text: Several days after the speech, Preston Brooks assaulted this senator with a cane. During Reconstruction, this man led the Radical Republicans in the Senate.

q3.quetsion_text: Sumner was beaten after he gave a speech decrying the “Crime Against” this territory, where the votes of border ruffians resulted in a proslavery government and violence led to it being nicknamed “Bleeding”.

lead_in: Bonus: Her son Parthenopaeus was one of the Seven Against Thebes. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this daughter of Iasus who was loved by Meleager. She and Hippomenes were eventually turned into lions for disrespecting Cybele’s temple.

q2.quetsion_text: Atalanta was the first to wound the Calydonian one of these animals. Heracles captured the Erymanthian one as part of his labors, and Ares gored Adonis to death in the guise of one of these animals.

q3.quetsion_text: Hippomenes won Atalanta’s hand in marriage after he defeated her in a footrace with the help of three of these objects, which were given to him by Aphrodite.

lead_in: This process occurs via the TNF or FAS paths, with the latter producing the DISC complex that then triggers the caspase pathway. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this process of programmed cell death, during which cells undergo blebbing.

q2.quetsion_text: This protein, sometimes nicknamed the "guardian angel of the genome," can promote the expression of p21 to arrest interphase and repair genetic damage. However, it can also induce apoptosis if the DNA cannot be repaired.

q3.quetsion_text: Studies of apoptotic pathways have used this technique, in which one of an organism's genes is inactivated to study the effects of its loss. One method of performing this technique is via Cre-lox recombination.
q3.raw_answer: gene knockout [accept knocking out; accept KO]

lead_in: This globular cluster is so weird that astronomers think it isn't a globular cluster at all, but a dwarf galaxy stripped of its outer stars that has a black hole in its center. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this globular cluster that is the biggest and brightest the Milky Way has to offer. A Hubble picture of this object that you can download as a wallpaper is titled "Colorful Stars Galore Inside Globular Star Cluster [it]".

q2.quetsion_text: The equally weird Mayall II cluster takes the crown for the brightest globular cluster in the Local Group and orbits this nearest spiral galaxy to the Milky Way and largest galaxy in the Local Group.

q3.quetsion_text: A type of the colorful stars that are galore inside Omega Centauri are the stragglers named for this color, which is the color of class O stars.

lead_in: Bonus: A gigantic tuned mass damper is suspended from its 92nd to 87th floors. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this earthquake- and typhoon-resistant skyscraper whose two-part name describes the city it lies in and the number of floors it contains. It was the world’s tallest building until the opening of the Burj Khalifa in 2010.

q2.quetsion_text: Taipei 101 is located in this country that lies across the Formosa Strait from the People’s Republic of China

q3.quetsion_text: Taiwan is one of the claimants to the Spratly Islands, which are located in this sea to Taiwan’s southwest. Other claimants include China, Vietnam, the Philippines, and Malaysia, all of which border this sea.

lead_in: Bonus: Diseases affecting this organ include emphysema and silicosis. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these respiratory organs, which contain tiny sacs called alveoli that are the site of gas exchange.

q2.quetsion_text: The trachea branches off into these two tubes, one for each lung. They are Generation 1 on the respiratory tree and name a disease that results from the inflammation of the lower respiratory tract.

q3.quetsion_text: The lungs are surrounded by two of these structures. When the thoracic cavity expands or contracts, the surface tension that holds these two membranes together causes the lungs to expand or contract as well.

lead_in: Multiplying their wavevector k with h-bar gives the crystal momentum. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these quasiparticles which represent vibrations in a crystal structure. They always have 3 acoustic modes and 3N minus 3 optical modes.

q2.quetsion_text: Phonons were originally posited by Debye to show that this quantity has a T cubed dependence at low temperatures. This quantity is the amount of heat needed to raise the temperature of an object by one degree.

q3.quetsion_text: Van Hove singularities arise when this function of the phonons is not differentiable. This quantity in general is the number of available energy states in a given energy interval.

lead_in: This theorem was derived by showing that the classical correlation of two spin measurements cannot be as high as the quantum correlation.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this no-go theorem that showed that local hidden variable theories can't reproduce the predictions of quantum mechanics.

q2.quetsion_text: This Austrian physicist's experiments on the foundations of QM include closing loopholes for Bell experiments as well as teleporting a qubit and entanglement of three particles and more.

q3.quetsion_text: Another researcher on the foundations of quantum mechanics is Anthony Leggett, who won the 2003 Nobel Prize with Ginzburg and Abrikosov for studying these materials, in which electrons match up into Cooper pairs according to BCS theory.

lead_in: Answer some questions about music in which phrases or procedures are repeated ad nauseam.

q1.quetsion_text: This Alvin Lucier tape piece involves recording a short monologue, then recording the recordings over and over. The resonant frequencies of the title location, which is "different from the one you are in now," dissolve the words into pure sounds.
q1.raw_answer: I am sitting in a room

q2.quetsion_text: This composer may or may not have instructed performers to repeat a tritone-heavy phrase 840 times in his Vexations. He also wrote the music for Jean Cocteau's Parade and coined the term "furniture music."

q3.quetsion_text: Maurice Ravel wrote this orchestral piece in which a snare drum ostinato accompanies a melody that gets passed around between instruments, including tenor and soprano saxophones, in a continuous crescendo.

lead_in: Bonus: The Simba Rebellion was part of a 1960s crisis in this modern-day country. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this former Belgian colony whose first post-independence prime minister, Patrice Lumumba, was executed in its breakaway region of Katanga.
q1.raw_answer: Democratic Republic of the Congo [or DRC; or Congo-Kinshasa; do not accept “Republic of the Congo”; prompt on “Congo”]

q2.quetsion_text: Dag Hammarskjöld died in a plane crash while en route to mediate a cease-fire in the Congo Crisis. Hammarskjöld was the secretary-general of this organization, which was later led by U Thant and Kofi Annan.

q3.quetsion_text: The Congo Crisis ended with the rise of this US-backed dictator, whose Authenticity Campaign included renaming the Congo to Zaire, and who wore a signature leopard-skin hat. He was finally ousted from power in 1997.

lead_in: Emperors had basically no authority during this period and were confined to the city of Gondar.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this period, which traditionally began with the deposition of Iyoas I and was ended by Kassa Hailu, who was crowned shortly after the Battle of Derasge.
q1.raw_answer: Zemene Mesafint [or Era of Princes; or Era of Judges; accept Age and similar for "Era"]

q2.quetsion_text: Kassa Hailu, who would later commit suicide at the fortress of Magdala, took this name and number when he became emperor of Ethiopia. This regnal name and number is shared by the current Patriarch of Alexandria and a Tsar who was the son of Boris Godunov.
q2.raw_answer: Theodore II [or Tewodros II; or Theodoros II; or Feodor II; or various cognates]

q3.quetsion_text: Tewodros II imprisoned several diplomats at Magdala on suspicion that he had received an insult from this ruler, whose empire sent Robert Napier on a military expedition to deal with the resulting crisis.

lead_in: Subjects in this experiment have a book of matches and a box of thumbtacks and are asked to fix another object to the wall.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Karl Duncker experiment used to test for functional fixedness. The trick is to dump the tacks out of the box, tack the box to the wall, and hold the title object in that.

q2.quetsion_text: This general principle says that out of all possible perceptual interpretations, people tend to perceive things as ordered and continuous.

q3.quetsion_text: Karl Duncker worked with Wolfgang Kohler and Max Wertheimer, founders of this school of psychology that emphasized pragnanz. Thinkers in this school believed people perceived the world as a complete whole that was different than the sum of its parts.

lead_in: A rebellion of these people was defeated by Gaius Suetonius Paulinus.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this tribe whose rebellion was defeated at the Battle of Watling Street. Unlike their neighbors', coins produced by this tribe have the tribal name inscribed on them.

q2.quetsion_text: This pro-Roman husband of Boudica and leader of the Iceni named the emperor co-heir to his lands, along with his two daughters. When he died, his will was ignored and his daughters were raped, prompting his wife to rebel.

q3.quetsion_text: Prasutagus submitted to this emperor, who ordered the conquest of Britain in 43 CE. This emperor came to power after the death of his insane nephew Caligula.
q3.raw_answer: Tiberius Claudius Drusus Nero "Caesar Augustus Germanicus"

lead_in: Bonus: For ten points each, answer some questions about the interesting properties of cyclic quadrilaterals.

q1.quetsion_text: Because two pairs of adjacent sides subtend two arcs that add up to form a circle, opposite angles satisfy this property where they sum to 180 degrees.

q2.quetsion_text: Ptolemy’s theorem equates the product of these two constructs with the sum of the products of opposite sides. In a rectangle these structures form diameters of the circumscribed circle.

q3.quetsion_text: This formula computes the area of a cyclic quadrilateral as the square root of the products of the difference between the semiperimeter and each side. It is a corollary of Bretschneider’s formula.

lead_in: In this play, Beatrice hires Olimpio and Marzio to kill her father Francesco. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this play which ends with Beatrice walking to her execution.

q2.quetsion_text: In this play by the author of The Cenci, the title Titan is reunited with Asia after being freed by Hercules.

q3.quetsion_text: The Cenci and Prometheus Unbound are by this poet, who also wrote "Adonais" and "Ozymandias."

lead_in: Razumikhin, this character's good-natured friend, marries his sister Dunya.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this character who murders a pawnbroker and her sister in Dostoevsky's Crime and Punishment.
q1.raw_answer: Rodion Romanovich Raskolnikov [or Rodion Romanovich Raskolnikov; or Rodya]

q2.quetsion_text: Sonya eventually sways Raskolnikov to confess his crimes after reading him the story of this Biblical character, which inspires Raskolnikov to be redeemed.

q3.quetsion_text: Raskolnikov nearly doesn't confess when he finds out that this nihilist has committed suicide. This character attempted to rape Dunya while she worked for him.
q3.raw_answer: Arkady Ivanovich Svidrigailov [or Arkady Ivanovich Svidrigailov]

lead_in: Bonus: One of its leaders complained that his illiterate constituents could see Nast cartoons. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Democratic political machine famous for the graft and corruption it experienced under the leadership of Boss Tweed.
q1.raw_answer: Tammany Hall [or Tammany Society; or Society of St. Tammany]

q2.quetsion_text: Tweed was particularly influential in the politics of this city, where a courthouse project in Manhattan wound up costing $12 million due to graft and embezzlement.

q3.quetsion_text: This Democratic faction opposed Tammany Hall and advocated a laissez-faire economic policy. It gained its name when supporters lit candles after Tammany members shut off the gaslights to drive them away.

lead_in: This man got into a spat with the White House in October 2014 by claiming that opposing settlements goes against American values. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this current Israeli prime minister who oversaw Operation Protective Edge in early 2014.

q2.quetsion_text: This is the political party to which Netanyahu belongs and which received a plurality of votes in the 2013 legislative election. It was founded by Menachem Begin and holds a center right position.

q3.quetsion_text: Daniel Wultz died in 2006 in a suicide bombing partially funded through this institution. Netanyahu created a headache by refusing to allow Israeli officials to testify in Wultz's murder trial since that could endanger financial ties to this institution.

lead_in: At the end of this opera, Canio faces the audience and exclaims "La commedia e finita!"

q1.quetsion_text: Name this opera by Ruggero Leoncavallo, which is about some clowns. Its arias include "Vesti la giubba."

q2.quetsion_text: Leoncavallo is from this country, the birthplace of opera. Claudio Monteverdi, also from here, wrote the early operas The Coronation of Poppea and L'Orfeo.

q3.quetsion_text: Pagliacci is often performed with this other opera by Pietro Mascagni, in which Turridu's affairs with Santuzza and Lola lead to trouble. Its Intermezzo is often performed separately.

lead_in: A library for this language called jQuery supports JSON ["Jason"] parsing.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this language often used in HTML pages, whose code is often stored in .js files.

q2.quetsion_text: JavaScript, like Python and other scripting language, uses a dynamic system for handling these entities.  Although C# generally requires that you statically declare these entities to be, say, an integer or an object, the language's var keyword allows for dynamic forms of these entities.

q3.quetsion_text: JavaScript code used to be executed by an interpreter, but most modern browsers use a just-in-time version of this process for faster execution. This is the process of turning source code into machine-readable code so that the program can be executed.

lead_in: Gregory Vlastos's 1954 paper on this argument is considered definitive. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this argument outlined in the Parmenides, which states that if the namesake organism has a particular form of that organism, then another form would be required to explain that relationship, ad infinitum.

q2.quetsion_text: The third man argument throws a wrench into the theory of forms of this philosopher, who also outlined the Euthyphro dilemma in another one of his namesake dialogues.

q3.quetsion_text: Parmenides is accompanied by this student of his in the dialogue. The dialogue begins with this person reading from one of his books in front of a crowd. He asked how many grains of millet must be dropped to make a sound.

lead_in: Answer the following about pesticides and herbicides,

q1.quetsion_text: This organochlorine pesticide acts upon the sodium channels in insects, causing uncontrollable firing of neurons and eventual death. It was widely criticized in Silent Spring for its effects on bird eggs, in particular those of the bald eagle.

q2.quetsion_text: Organophosphate pesticides are preferable to organochlorine compounds in that they degrade faster, however, they pose a greater risk because they affect this neurotransmitter, which is deficient in myasthenia gravis.

q3.quetsion_text: This herbicide marketed as "Roundup" binds to the EPSP synthase enzyme instead of phospho-enol-pyruvate, inhibiting amino acid synthesis.

lead_in: Bonus: Isolated outcroppings of rock in this region are called kopjes. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this grassland region of eastern Africa, which sees an annual migration of millions of wildebeest, zebras, and gazelles.

q2.quetsion_text: The word “serengeti” means “endless plains” in the language of the Masai people, who inhabit both Kenya and this country south of the Serengeti. Mount Kilimanjaro is located in this country.

q3.quetsion_text: The Serengeti lies west of a “great” one of these geographical features that stretches from the Dead Sea to Mozambique and formed Lake Victoria.

lead_in: This period saw the issuance of the land reform law, Decree 900, which threatened the interests of Samuel Zemurray.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this period of liberalization and democracy. This period began when the October Revolutionaries overthrew a dictator who had ruled since 1931.
q1.raw_answer: Ten Years of Spring [or Diez aÃ±os de primavera; prompt on "Arbenz' reforms" and similar]

q2.quetsion_text: The Ten Years of Spring in this country were brought to an end by operation PBSUCCESS, which resulted in the ouster of its president, Jacobo Ãrbenz.
q2.raw_answer: Republic of Guatemala [or RepÃºblica de Guatemala]

q3.quetsion_text: The October Revolutionaries overthrew this leader in order to begin the Ten Years of Spring. During the tenure of this admirer of Napoleon, the United Fruit Company became the most important company in Guatemala.

lead_in: This mathematician's namesake circuit traverses every edge of a graph once. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this mathematician who basically invented graph theory in order to solve the Seven Bridges of  Konigsberg problem. His namesake characteristic is 2 for a polyhedron.

q2.quetsion_text: A graph consists of points referred to by this name, which are connected by edges. This term also is  used to describe the points at the "corners" of polygons.

q3.quetsion_text: The sum of this quantity at each vertex equals twice the number of edges. It is the number of edges  that are incident to a given vertex, and it is the same for all vertices in a regular graph.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this tale in which the tour guide described a rainbow that he compared to the pathway between Time and Eternity at the vortex of the title event.

q2.quetsion_text: In this story, William Legrand describes the title object as having three black spots on its back. The object was used in lieu of a bullet to find the hidden treasure of Captain Kidd.

q3.quetsion_text: "A Descent into the Maelstrom" and "The Gold-Bug" were written by this author. He wrote of a murdering orangutan in "The Murders in the Rue Morgue."

lead_in: The Federal Rules governing this stuff do not include the "exclusionary rule," which, at least in theory, renders this stuff inadmissible if it was gathered in violation of the Fourth Amendment. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this component of trials, which is admitted to the record to help establish proof of facts. It may include testimony or exhibits, but not hearsay.

q2.quetsion_text: This important protection, by which a plaintiff or defendant may keep confidential all information shared with their lawyer, is explicitly enshrined by Rule 502 in the Federal Rules of Evidence.

q3.quetsion_text: Rule 401 governs this property, by which evidence makes a "fact that is of consequence ... more probable or less probable." Admission and exclusion of evidence, per Rules 402 and 403, assume that this property is established.
q3.raw_answer: relevance [or relevancy; accept any answer indicating that a given piece of evidence is relevant to the case at hand]

lead_in: This character becomes terrified after accidentally grabbing George Willard's shoulders while giving an impassioned speech.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this berry-picker, who was formerly a schoolteacher named Adolph Myers, before one of his mentally disabled students falsely accused him of molestation.

q2.quetsion_text: Wing Biddlebaum is the protagonist of "Hands" the first story of Winesburg, Ohio, by this American author.

q3.quetsion_text: Near the end of this short story by Sherwood Anderson, a hunter happens upon the corpse of the longsuffering Mrs. Grimes, who died while carrying meat home from the butcher while accompanied by some dogs.

lead_in: This country's orthodox church is called Tewahedo, or "unified," and it broke off from the Coptic church in 1959. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this country for which Abu Rumi translated the Bible into Amharic. St. Frumentius is credited with bringing Christianity to this modern-day African nation.

q2.quetsion_text: This term refers to the Jewish community of Ethiopia. Many members of this group were airlifted out of Ethiopia in Operation Solomon.

q3.quetsion_text: St. Frumentius brought Christianity to this Ethiopian kingdom, whose king Ezana declared  Christianity the state religion. This kingdom was centered on a northern Ethiopian city on the Red Sea.

lead_in: For 10 points each, answer these questions about women from the Ulster Cycle of Irish myth.

q1.quetsion_text: This hero of the Ulster Cycle defeats the evil queen Medb at the Cattle Raid of Cooley.

q2.quetsion_text: This woman became pregnant with Cu Chulainn after staying in the house of the sun god Lugh, where her kinsmen were resting while hunting a flock of birds.

q3.quetsion_text: Dechtire's brother, Conchobar mac Nessa, marries this beautiful woman and kills her true love Naoise. She smashes her head on a stone.

lead_in: This composer's two Romances for violin and orchestra were attempts to write a slow movement for his violin concerto. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this deaf German composer of a Fantasy for piano, chorus, and orchestra, as well as the Eroica and Pastoral symphonies. He set Schiller's Ode to Joy in the last movement of his ninth symphony.

q2.quetsion_text: Beethoven wrote five of these pieces, the G-major fourth one of which unusually begins with the soloist, not the orchestra. His fifth one of these pieces is an E-flat-major work nicknamed "Emperor."

q3.quetsion_text: Besides his violin concerto and his five piano concerti, Beethoven also wrote a concerto for this unusual group of instruments. His other works for this group include one nicknamed "Ghost."
q3.raw_answer: piano trio [or piano, violin, and violoncello (in any order); accept Concerto in C Major for  Violin, Cello, and Piano, Opus 56 or Triple Concerto or obvious equivalents]

lead_in: In a photograph by Joe Rosenthal, it is being hoisted by soldiers on Iwo Jima. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this object. James Monroe clutches an early version that rises vertically behind George Washington in an Emanuel Leutze painting.
q1.raw_answer: American flag [or flag of the United States; or equivalents; prompt on flag]

q2.quetsion_text: This contemporary artist of Target with Four Faces used newspaper and collage to create the American flag in Three Flags and White Flag.

q3.quetsion_text: Jasper Johns built up the texture of his flag paintings using collage and this technique. It uses pigment suspended in melted beeswax to achieve a mixture of sculpture and painting.

lead_in: "On Wednesdays we wear pink" is one of the rules of this clique at North Shore High School.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this clique led by Regina George, whose other rules include not wearing sweatpants and only wearing your hair in a ponytail once a week.

q2.quetsion_text: North Shore High School is the setting of this film starring Lindsay Lohan, which was written by Tina Fey. Its title is an apt description of the behavior of the Plastics.

q3.quetsion_text: The principal of North Shore was played by this co-star of Fey's on Saturday Night Live, who also portrays Black Republican P.K. Winsome on The Colbert Report.

lead_in: This author wrote about the travels of Mendel, a Soviet artilleryman, across Nazi-ruled Europe as part of  a group of partisans in a novel whose title is a quote by Rabbi Hillel. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this author of If Not Now, When? whose numerous memoirs include Moments of Reprieve  and If This Is a Man.

q2.quetsion_text: If This Is a Man recalls Levi's imprisonment in this place, to which he was sent after being captured  as a rebel fighter during World War II. Salvatore Quasimodo wrote a poem describing this place, "far  from the Vistula," as a "pit of ashes."
q2.raw_answer: Auschwitz [or Auschwitz-Birkenau or Auschwitz-Monowitz; prompt on "Birkenau" or  "Monowitz"]

q3.quetsion_text: Primo Levi and Salvatore Quasimodo were both authors from this European country, which is also  the birthplace of Umberto Eco.
q3.raw_answer: Italy [or Italian Republic; or Repubblica Italiana]

lead_in: This onomatopeic poem tells of how the title objects "tinkle, tinkle, tinkle / In the icy air of night!".

q1.quetsion_text: Name this poem in which the author coins the term "tintinnabulation" to describe the rhythm of the title objects.

q2.quetsion_text: The speaker of this other poem by Edgar Allan Poe remembers his lover as a child when they both lived "in a kingdom by the sea and he blames angels for 'chilling and killing' this woman out of envy.

q3.quetsion_text: Two answers required in the correct order. In another poem, Edgar Allan Poe compares the beauty of Helen to "those Nicean barks of yore" and "the glory that was [this place], and the grandeur that was [this other place]."
q3.raw_answer: Greece and Rome (Must be in order!)

lead_in: In 2007, Hoekstra and Coyne criticized the evo-devo hypothesis that the modularity allowed by these regions is the major driver of evolutionary novelty by attacking the classic example of yellow, which is involved in the patterning of Drosophila wing spots.

q1.quetsion_text: Name these non-coding sequences of the control region that bind transcription factors in order to regulate gene expression. The transposon-based ZED vector is used to detect these sequences in zebrafish.
q1.raw_answer: CREs [or cis-regulatory elements; accept cis-elements or CEs; accept cis-regulatory modules or CRMs accept cis-acting elements; accept enhancers or silencers; prompt on "promoters"]

q2.quetsion_text: Transcription factors encoded by Hox genes bind to CREs in order to pattern these divisions of the AP axis after their polarity is established. These repeated sections divide the bodies of chordates, arthropods and annelids.

q3.quetsion_text: Many of the genes involved in segmentation underwent duplication events, producing multiple copies related by this form of homology. These genes often evolve divergent functions despite their common ancestry.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this document that condemned eighty propositions and was issued at the same time as the encyclical Quanta Cura.

q2.quetsion_text: This pope was responsible for the Syllabus of Errors in 1864. This pope served longer than any other, lasting 32 years from 1846 until 1878.
q2.raw_answer: Pius IX [or Giovanni Maria Mastai-Ferretti; prompt on "Pius"]

q3.quetsion_text: Pius IX was disillusioned with liberalism early in his reign by the revolutions that started in this year and spread throughout Europe, forcing Pius into exile in Gaeta for more than a year.

lead_in: Its composer claimed this work was inspired by his study of 18th-century works under Nikolai Tcherepnin.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this symphony written in 1917 in the style of Haydn. It replaces the traditional scherzo with a very short gavotte, as its third movement.
q1.raw_answer: Prokofiev's Symphony No. 1 in D, Op. 25 "Classical" [accept either underlined part]

q2.quetsion_text: The"Classical" Symphony is by Sergei Prokofiev, who is best known, by children at least, for this work in which the title characters are represented by the string section and by three French horns, respectively.
q2.raw_answer: Peter and the Wolf [or Petya i volk]

q3.quetsion_text: classic example of Prokofiev's gift for humorous orchestration was his decision to give the solo part in the "Romance" movement of the Lieutenant KijÃ© suite to this instrument.
q3.raw_answer: double bass [or contrabass, or bass fiddle]

q1.quetsion_text: Name these tables that give the locations of celestial bodies at various points in time to high accuracy and precision.
q1.raw_answer: ephemerides [or ephemeris; accept things like ephemeris charts or ephemeris tables]

q2.quetsion_text: This astronomical coordinate, measured as an hour angle, is analogous to longitude on earth. This coordinate plus declination constitute the equatorial coordinate system in which ephemerides are typically reported.

q3.quetsion_text: In ephemerides, times are typically given in terms of time since an epoch like J2000.0 ("J two thousand point oh"), in units of years named for this pre-Gregorian calendar, in which the average year length was 365.25 days.

lead_in: The title character of this work turns into sea foam at the end.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this fairy tale in which the title character gives up her tongue in exchange for becoming human so that she can meet the prince with whom she is in love.

q2.quetsion_text: "The Little Mermaid" was written by this Danish author who also wrote "The Steadfast Tin Soldier," "The Emperor's New Clothes" and "The Princess and the Pea."

q3.quetsion_text: In another Hans Christian Andersen fairy tale, eleven princes are turned into these creatures, and their sister weaves shirts for them to turn them back into humans. Yeats wrote a poem about these creatures "at Coole."

lead_in: Answer the following about Plutarco ElÃ­as Calles,

q1.quetsion_text: This political party has its roots in the earlier PNR founded in 1929 by Plutarco Calles. One of its later leaders, Luis EcheverrÃ­a, initiated the "Friendship Operation," which led him to be accused of genocide.
q1.raw_answer: Institutional Revolutionary Party [or Partido Revolucionado Institucional]

q2.quetsion_text: This term is applied to the period of Plutarco Calles' utter dominance as the chief of the PNR and Mexican politics from 1928 to 1935, even though he was no longer in office.

q3.quetsion_text: Plutarco Calles promulgated a number of policies against this institution in Mexico, leading to the Cristero War. This organization's leader, Pius XI, opposed those policies in the bull, Iniquis Afflictisque.
q3.raw_answer: Catholic Church [or the Holy See or equivalents]

lead_in: This 1950s war is sometimes referred to as the "Forgotten War." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this war in which Morocco's Army of Liberation attempted to take a Spanish exclave in Morocco and failed horribly. Spain did, however, end up ceding Cape Juby to Morocco after this war.

q2.quetsion_text: This long-time dictator of Spain controlled the country during the Ifni War. His other actions in Morocco include defeating Abd el-Krim during the Rif War in the 1920s.

q3.quetsion_text: This series of agreements between the United Kingdom and France, which established an alliance prior to World War I, allowed Spain to keep Morocco.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this movement whose name is French for wild beasts.

q2.quetsion_text: Another leading Fauvist [FOH-vist] was this painter, some of whose pictures feature naked people dancing in a circle.

q3.quetsion_text: This French painter switched from Fauvism to Cubism [KYOOB-is-um] once he befriended Picasso. His works include Man With A Guitar and The Billiard Table.

lead_in: Bonus: This element is triple bonded to carbon to form the cyanide anion, and it also triple bonds with itself to form a diatomic gas. For ten points each,

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this element, the most abundant gas in the Earth’s atmosphere. Bacteria also fix this element for biosynthesis.

q2.quetsion_text: Nitrogen bonds with three hydrogen atoms to form ammonia, a compound industrially produced in this process. It uses an iron catalyst, and yield can be increased by removing ammonia from the system.

q3.quetsion_text: Nitrogen amides can easily link together to form compounds with high tensile strength, such as this product developed by DuPont and used in tires and body armor.

lead_in: According to Mishkat al-Masabih's account of this event, Muhammad's wife was visited by an angel, who told her of the demise of Hussein ibn Ali. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this 680 CE battle in the Middle East, one cause of the division between Sunni and Shi'a Islam. The Banu Hashim tribe was destroyed here.

q2.quetsion_text: The Battle of Karbala took place in Iraq, near the city of Najaf and this major river. The ancient city-state Ur was supplied with water from this Mesopotamian river that roughly parallels the Tigris River.

q3.quetsion_text: At Karbala, Yazid I of this Muslim Caliphate defeated a small army belonging to Muhammad's grandson, who refused to recognize its legitimacy. This Caliphate controlled Spain and was defeated at Tours by Charles Martel.

q3.quetsion_text: Lamar infamously called out a ton of other rappers on "Control," a collaboration with Big Sean and this other rapper of Eternal Sunshine and "Exhibit C."

lead_in: In one work by this author, Nikolai cheats with Sasha Lebedev and shoots himself right as the rest of the cast jumps to his defense against the doctor Eugene Lvov.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this author of Ivanov who also wrote about the affair between Dmitri and Anna in his short story "The Lady with the Dog".

q2.quetsion_text: In this play by Chekhov, Lyuba Ranevsky returns home to Russia after living in France for five years. This play concludes with Lyuba selling her family's estate to Lopakhin after refusing to build cottages on it.

q3.quetsion_text: This other author both praised and criticized Chekhov's prose writings in his Lectures on Russian Literature. The planet of Anti-Terra provides the setting to a novel by him in which Van Veen falls in love with his sister.

lead_in: In this experiment, Phosphorus-32 and Sulfur-35 labelled T2 bacteriophages were used in turn to infect E coli, with the dead bacteria centrifuged.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this 1952 experiment that showed that DNA, rather than protein, was the genetic material passed on by the bacteriophages.
q1.raw_answer: Hershey-Chase experiment [prompt on anything to do with a "blender"]

q2.quetsion_text: Hershey and Chase came to their conclusions when they noticed the Phosphorus-32 sink to the bottom with the infected bacteria in the pellet region while the Sulfur-35 remained suspended in this liquid region.

q3.quetsion_text: This other experiment occurred 8 years prior to the Hershey-Chase experiment and saw rats injected with virulent strains of Streptococcus pneumoniae. It determined that the "transformative agent" in Griffith's experiment was DNA.

lead_in: Although the forestry in the background varies among copies of this painting, each version contains a small red schoolhouse.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this 1872 genre painting which depicts several children holding hands while playing the titular game. Depending on the version, one or more of those children fall down on its left side.

q2.quetsion_text: Snap-the-Whip is a work of this Maine-based American artist, a member of the Tile Club whose other works include Breezing Up and The Gulf Stream.

q3.quetsion_text: This fellow member of the Tile Club was an American Impressionist who was probably the most famous member of the Ten besides Childe Hassam. This artist of A Modern Magdalen and A Friendly Call founded a namesake school that later became known as Parsons The New School for Design.

lead_in: A cook named Christine advises this play's title character against pursuing her dream to open an inn near  Lake Como. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this play in which Jean decapitates a pet canary after having an affair with the title aristocratic  woman, who commits suicide with a razor.

q2.quetsion_text: Miss Julie was written by August Strindberg, who hails from this home country of 2011 Nobel  Laureate Tomas TranstrÃ¶mer. This country's Astrid Lingdren created Pippi Longstocking.

q3.quetsion_text: Julie's lover Jean is a person with this profession. Bertie Wooster employs one of these men named  Reginald Jeeves in many of P.G. Wodehouse's stories.

lead_in: This man disowned his satire of anti-Chinese racism "Plain Language from Truthful James" when it became popular with actual racists. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this author, who wrote from the point of view of a bullet anxious why a man does not "answer to my kiss" in "What the Bullet Sang."

q2.quetsion_text: Harte wrote this short story about the selfless behavior of people like John Oakhurst and "the Duchess" who are exiled by a secret committee for immoral behavior.

q3.quetsion_text: Ah Sin and the narrator take part in this activity in "Plain Language from Truthful James." John Oakhurst is disliked by many in Poker Flats for his proficiency at doing this.

lead_in: This property holds for impure functions that do not cause side effects.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this property of some programming languages where a function can be replaced with its value.

q2.quetsion_text: Referential transparency is provided in languages in this programming paradigm, examples of which include Haskell and Scheme. These languages are contrasted with imperative languages like C.

q3.quetsion_text: Referential transparency makes this process easier, which is performed by tools like lint and FxCop. Although a perfect form of this process in impossible due to the decision problem, it can be used to detect things like poor code style and security bugs without executing the code.
q3.raw_answer: static code analysis [or static program analysis or static validation]

lead_in: The speaker must enter "the round / Zion of the water bead / And the synagogue of the ear of corn" in this author's poem "A Refusal to Mourn the Death, by Fire, of a Child in London."

q1.quetsion_text: Name this author who claimed that "seasons must be challenged or they totter" in "I See the Boys of Summer." This author's poem "Do Not Go Gentle into That Good Night" repeats, "rage, rage against the dying of the light."

q2.quetsion_text: Thomas's "The Force That Through the Green Fuse Drives the Flower" claims that "the lips of" this entity "leech to the fountain head." The speaker of his poem "Fern Hill" says that this entity "held me green and dying."

q3.quetsion_text: Thomas's poem "And Death Shall Have No Dominion" predicts, "Faith in their hands shall snap in two" and "the evils" of this type of animal "shall run them through."

lead_in: This man described an early seven-caste incarnation of the caste system in his Indica.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this ambassador sent by Seleucus I Nicator to the Mauryan empire along with Deimakos.

q2.quetsion_text: Megasthenes served as an ambassador to this founder of the Mauryan empire, known to the Greeks as Sandrakottos. This ruler gave 500 war elephants to Seleucus Nicator as part of a peace treaty.

q3.quetsion_text: Chandragupta Maurya allied with a Himalayan ruler to defeat this Nanda ruler. This ruler employed the prime minister Shaktar and was described as addicted to hoarding treasure.

lead_in: Answer the following about jazz as it relates to a certain adjective,

q1.quetsion_text: Jazz was influenced by this style of music, which is often associated with a namesake "twelve-bar" chord progression.

q2.quetsion_text: This jazz trumpet player recorded the album Kind of Blue, which features the songs "So What" and "Freddie Freeloader." His other albums include Sketches of Spain and Bitches Brew.

q3.quetsion_text: This man composed the "Blue Rondo a la Turk," which appears on his namesake quartet's album Time Out along with "Take Five."

lead_in: Maurice Merleau-Ponty extended this philosopher's work in a book arguing for the "primacy of perception." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this German philosopher who described analytical methods like "bracketing" and eidetic reduction of one's experiences in his lecture series, Cartesian Meditations. He also wrote Logical Investigations.

q2.quetsion_text: Husserl's theory of intentionality argues that this concept is defined by its possession of intentions. Qualia are experiences that are perceived thanks to this quality of self-awareness.

q3.quetsion_text: Husserl was the founder of this school of philosophy that studied the experiences of consciousness. Hegel also used this term in the title of his most important book.

lead_in: Bonus: It begins by contrasting the public torture of Robert-François Damiens and a prison in Mettray. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this work, subtitled “The Birth of the Prison,” which describes Bentham’s Panopticon and distinguishes between cellular, organic, genetic, and combinatory characteristics of individuality.
q1.raw_answer: Discipline and Punish: The Birth of the Prison [accept Surveiller et punir: Naissance de la Prison]

q2.quetsion_text: This French philosopher wrote Discipline and Punish and discussed the concept of “medical gaze” in his work, The Birth of the Clinic.

q3.quetsion_text: This other French philosopher was a proponent of existentialism and wrote Being and Nothingness. He also criticized Foucault’s book The Order of Things.

lead_in: In November 2013, an agreement between these two powers that would have required one to gradually adopt the other's policies protecting certain food names suddenly stalled.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify these two powers, which would have formed a "Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area". One party sought reforms to create an independent judiciary in the other as a precondition to the signing of the agreement.
q1.raw_answer: the European Union [or EU] and Ukraine

q2.quetsion_text: This recently-ousted president of Ukraine backed out of negotiations with the EU, sparking the Euromaidan protests. He was previously a target of the Orange Revolution.

q3.quetsion_text: Yanukovych was supported by this political party, which is led by former prime minister Mykola Azarov. In the 2012 election, it derived its support primarily from the Russian-speaking areas of eastern Ukraine.
q3.raw_answer: the Party of Regions [or Partiya Regionov]

lead_in: This religion is studied by the scholarly group KOSANBA. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this syncretic, Haitian religion which believes in spirits called loas, some of which include Papa Legba and Baron Samedi.

q2.quetsion_text: Voodoo adherents worship this supreme god, who is nevertheless unreachable, which means practitioners must pray to the loas instead.

q3.quetsion_text: As opposed to a houngan or mambo, these are black magic sorcerers in voodoo who are usually linked to the creation of zombies.

lead_in: In the center of this painting, George Augustus Eliott extends his right arm to point at some Spanish soldiers in the water, who are being rescued by British ships.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this painting, showing the aftermath of a British victory at the namesake stronghold during a conflict in the European theater of the Revolutionary War.
q1.raw_answer: The Defeat of the Floating Batteries at Gibraltar [accept The Siege and Relief of Gibraltar or The Repulse of the Floating Batteries at Gibraltar]

q2.quetsion_text: Morro Castle appears in the background of this other painting by the same artist, in which a man points a harpoon towards one title character and a black man in an orange scarf looks at the rescue of the other.

q3.quetsion_text: The Defeat of the Floating Batteries at Gibraltar and Watson and the Shark are both paintings by this artist, who also did a celebrated portrait of Paul Revere.

lead_in: Bonus: This painting was one of many destroyed during the firebombing of Dresden. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Gustave Courbet painting which depicts a young man on the left holding a basket of the title objects while an older man holds a sledgehammer as they help build a road.
q1.raw_answer: The Stone Breakers [or Les Casseurs de pierres]

q2.quetsion_text: The painter of The Stone Breakers, Gustave Courbet, was friends with this other artist, who painted Arrangement in Grey and Black and used gold leaf for his work Harmony in Blue and Gold: The Peacock Room.

q3.quetsion_text: One of James Whistler’s depictions of the model Joanna Hiffernan is sometimes referred to as “Symphony in” this color. In Hokusai’s The Great Wave Off Kanagawa, crests of this color are on top of the blue waves.

lead_in: This character often spends hours crouched on a shelf across from a stuffed buzzard.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this character who discusses his "Treatise on Tailors' Dummies" and is afraid of being tickled by the maid Adela. He is a major character in The Street of Crocodiles.

q2.quetsion_text: The Street of Crocodiles is a collection by this Polish author of Sanatorium Under the Sign of the Hourglass who was shot by a Gestapo officer during World War II.

q3.quetsion_text: The title story of The Street of Crocodiles begins with a discussion of one of these items. One of these items that is marked with red crosses appears in Robert Louis Stevenson's Treasure Island.

lead_in: This composer, who once carried out an improbable rescue in Dresden during the May Uprising, included a slow 6/8 nocturne in F major in the collection Soirees musicales. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this nineteenth-century musician of a Mendelssohn-inspired piano concerto, three Romances, and a G-minor piano trio, who stopped composing new pieces at the age of thirty-six to focus on a fruitful career as concert pianist.
q1.raw_answer: Clara Schumann [or Clara Josephine Wieck; prompt on Schumann]

q3.quetsion_text: Clara is depicted in the C minor piece "Chiarina," which is part of this collection of twentyone solo piano pieces by her husband Robert, which uses musical cryptograms such as A-S-C-H in "Sphinxes" and other movements depicting revelers at the title festival.

lead_in: In the background of this painting, the sun rises over the horizon of a seascape, and in this painting's foreground, two men load an orange chest onto a boat.

q1.raw_answer: Seaport with the Embarkation of the Queen of Sheba

q3.quetsion_text: Claude Lorrain was called "the most perfect landscape painter the world ever saw" by this painter of Dedham Vale and The Hay Wain.

lead_in: This quality was possessed by Pollux, but not Castor. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this quality conferred by nectar and ambrosia. Possessed by the gods of Olympus, it makes the gods unchanging in their imperfections.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this poem, in which passions are inflamed by the flight of the many-feathered Gossip's visit to Iarbas.

q2.quetsion_text: The Aeneid is by this Roman author, who also talked a lot about farming in his Georgics.

q3.quetsion_text: This other work by Virgil was inspired by a similarly-titled work of Theocritus. It's likely that its fourth section was Virgil sucking up to Augustus, not predicting the coming of Christ.

lead_in: This playwright wrote a play where Don and Dawn speak the made-up language Unamunda, as well as another play where three monkeys try to type out Hamlet. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this author of "Words, Words, Words" and the one-act collection All In The Timing, an American comic playwright whose "Sure Thing" depicts a flirty conversation that frequently resets after someone screws up.

q2.quetsion_text: In Ives' "Sure Thing," this instrument is heard every time the scene resets. John Hersey wrote a novel about Major Victor Joppolo trying to obtain one of these objects for a Sicilian town, and John Donne is pretty confident that it "tolls for thee."
q2.raw_answer: a bell [accept A Bell for Adano]

q3.quetsion_text: In another Ives play, Allan Chase and Mark are trapped in a world of this name, where people have to ask for the opposite of what they want. William Wharton's novel Birdy, about a war veteran who wants to turn into a canary, is set in this city.

lead_in: One of these deities gives the prologue in Plautus' play Aulularia.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify these Roman deities, whose familiaris variety protected the household. Each city had a praestites version of these deities.

q2.quetsion_text: Outside of cities, the Lares were typically honored at these places. The Compitalia was a festival devoted to the gods of these places, where criminals and suicide victims were often buried in Christian Europe.

q3.quetsion_text: These deities, particularly worshipped at the marriage bed, guarded over a man's life and were analogous to Juno for women. They could personify man's creative power and were proclaimed sanctus et sanctissimus deus on a man's birthday.

lead_in: In her parents' house there is a duplicate of almost every item of furniture, most notably the two clocks, so that this character will never want for furniture upon her marriage.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this character whose arrival prompts the local vicar to stop the extant fiddle based choir and replace it with organ music. Her great secret is that she accepted a second engagement while already affianced.

q2.quetsion_text: Fancy Day was created by this British author Tess of the D'Urbervilles and The Return of the Native.

q3.quetsion_text: Fancy Day and Dick Dewy's relationship is the central action of this early novel by Thomas Hardy, which he considered titling for the town of Mellstock's church choir.

lead_in: This musician's jazz standard "Epistrophy" was first recorded under the name "Fly Right" and contains a section with alternating chords a half-step apart. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this jazz pianist who produced jazz standards such as "Well, You Needn't" and "'Round Midnight". He may be best known for his album Straight, No Chaser.

q2.quetsion_text: Monk's music is often characterized by chords with unstable intervals, leading to this tone property. Contrasting with consonance, intervals with this property include the minor second and tritone.

q3.quetsion_text: Monk influenced this genre of jazz music characterized by quick tempo and improvisation. Named for syllables used in scat singing, other notable musicians of this genre include Charlie Parker and drummer Kenny Clarke.

q1.quetsion_text: The Western Wall is the last remnant of this holy structure. Commandments relating to animal sacrifice no longer apply since it was destroyed in 70 CE by the Romans.
q1.raw_answer: Second Temple [or Beit Ha-Mikdash Sheni; or Herod's Temple; do not accept "First Temple"]

q2.quetsion_text: Before bringing down the walls of Jericho, Joshua served in this role with Caleb at Moses's behest. While Jericho was being circled, two Israelites carrying out this role were saved by the harlot Rahab.
q2.raw_answer: spies within the Promised Land [or spy; or scouts]

q3.quetsion_text: In Orthodox synagogues, this barrier separates the women in the congregation from the men during services.
q3.raw_answer: mechitzah [the "ch" is a guttural h̥ sound as in "Chanukah"]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this longest river in the United States. Its major tributaries include the Ohio and Missouri.

q2.quetsion_text: This lake in Minnesota is often cited as the source of the main length of the Mississippi River.

q3.quetsion_text: Near the Gulf of Mexico, the Bonnet CarrÃ© Spillway directs excess floodwater from the Mississippi towards this lake.

lead_in: This orchestra became known for its performances of French music, under the direction of Pierre Monteux during the early 1920's and Charles Munch during the 1950's.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this one of the "Big Five" American orchestras, which commissioned Stravinsky's Symphony of Psalms
q1.raw_answer: Boston Symphony Orchestra [or BSO; prompt on "Boston"]

q2.quetsion_text: The Boston Symphony Orchestra plays summertime concerts in the Koussevitzky Music Shed at this venue in Massachusetts, the orchestra's summer home. This venue is known for its Contemporary Music Festival.

q3.quetsion_text: Serge Koussevitzky commissioned this Hungarian composer's Concerto for Orchestra for the Boston Symphony Orchestra. He also composed Music for Strings, Percussion, and Celesta.
q3.raw_answer: BÃ©la (Viktor JÃ¡nos) BartÃ³k [accept names in either order]

lead_in: The narrator of this novel sorts his fellow patients into "Chronics" and "Acutes".

q1.quetsion_text: Name this novel narrated by Chief Bromden, in which Randle Patrick McMurphy feuds with Nurse Ratched over the treatment of mental ward patients.
q1.raw_answer: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

q2.quetsion_text: This member of the Merry Pranksters wrote One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest.

q3.quetsion_text: Another author who explored the counterculture was this woman, who described the Haight-Ashbury district of San Francisco in her essay "Slouching Towards Bethlehem".

lead_in: Identify the following about physics you might use while playing Kerbal Space Program, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: All rockets operate according to this law, which implies that propellant expelled in one direction pushes the rocket in the opposite direction with an equivalent force, thus allowing motion to occur in a vacuum.
q1.raw_answer: Sir Isaac Newton's third law [accept any answer saying "Newton" and "3"]

q2.quetsion_text: This quantity tells you how much force can be obtained per unit of propellant per unit time. Its use allows the Tsiolkovsky rocket equation to be written linearly.
q2.raw_answer: specific impulse [or I_sp ["I sub s-p"]; prompt on "impulse"; do not accept "total impulse"]

q3.quetsion_text: KSP fails to effectively model this atmospheric phenomenon. Stokes's Law gives its value on spherical objects, and, since its value is proportional to velocity, it produces a first-order term when damping a harmonic oscillator.

lead_in: This phenomenon may be explained as a sorites paradox, as people may be uncomfortable demarcating at which point something is no longer human. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this hypothesis, which holds that people are comfortable with things that are barely human or fully human, but experience revulsion when human features move similarly to, but not exactly like, those of actual humans.
q1.raw_answer: the uncanny valley [or bukimi no tani gensho; prompt on "uncanny"]

q2.quetsion_text: Masahiko Mori, the coiner of the term "uncanny valley", was from this country. Advanced lifelike human robots from this country are often cited as examples of the uncanny valley in popular culture.

q3.quetsion_text: The concept of the "uncanny valley" was based on the work of this social scientist, who developed the work of Ernst Jentsch in his essay "The Uncanny."

lead_in: This city was the capital of a kingdom in Asia Minor ruled by the Attalid Dynasty. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this city that contained a namesake altar showing the Gigantomachy. Its library was second only to that of Alexandria. In 133 BCE, it was bequeathed to Rome by its last ruler, Attalus III.

q2.quetsion_text: Like Attalus III, Bithynia was bequeathed to Rome after the death of its last ruler, who was the fourth Bithynian king to hold this name. The second Bithynian king of this name rebuilt his capital and named it after himself.

q3.quetsion_text: This scholar from Pergamon documented the Antonine Plague, which is sometimes named for him. Vesalius and Harvey disproved this physician's theories on anatomy and circulation after millennia of acceptance.
q3.raw_answer: Aelius Galenus [or Claudius Galenus; or Galen of Pergamon]

lead_in: This work argues that the highest truths are inherently paradoxical notions believed through a process of "passionate inwardness" and that therefore "truth is subjectivity".

q1.quetsion_text: Name this work whose title reflects its status as a follow-up to its author's Philosophical Fragments. It was one of three works published under the name of Johannes Climacus.
q1.raw_answer: Concluding Unscientific Postscript to Philosophical Fragments [or Afsluttende uvidenskabelig Efterskrift til de philosophiske Smuler]

q2.quetsion_text: The Concluding Unscientific Postscript is by this Danish existentialist philosopher, who included "The Diary of the Seducer" in his Either/Or.

q3.quetsion_text: In Either/Or, Kierkegaard discusses how Don Giovanni's pursuit of the aesthetic ideal is an avoidance of this concept, while Judge Wilhelm's ethical approach misconstrues this concept as "sameness". This term also titles a Kierkegaard work written under the pseudonym Constantin Constantius.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this site of the cities Fukuoka and Nagasaki. It is the third largest Japanese island after Honshu and Hokkaido.

q2.quetsion_text: This body of water lies between the islands of Kyushu, Shikoku, and Honshu. It is home to the famous Itsukushima shrine and has long been a vital part of trade in Japan.

q3.quetsion_text: Okinawa is the largest island in this chain that trails southwest from Kyushu.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this historical group of women that included Xi Shi and Yang Guifei, who caused problems for the powerful men they attracted.
q1.raw_answer: Four Beauties [or Four Great Beauties; or Si Da Meiren; or Si Da Mei Nu]

q2.quetsion_text: The last of the Four Beauties, Yang Guifei, was the consort of Emperor Xuanzong of this Chinese dynasty, which was weakened by the An Lushan Rebellion.

q3.quetsion_text: The first beauty, Xi Shi, lived near the end of this period of Chinese history named for a Confucius-authored chronicle, which itself is named for two seasons.
q3.raw_answer: Spring and Autumn Period [or Chunqiu Shidai]

lead_in: Memnon of Heraclea claims that this kingdom's ruler King Bas defeated Calas, one of Alexander's generals. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this kingdom whose ruler Nicomedes I founded the city of Nicomedia. Its last king, Nicomedes IV, bequeathed the kingdom to Rome at his death.

q2.quetsion_text: After defeating Nicomedes IV and his Roman allies, this man slaughtered Roman settlers in the massacre of the Asiatic Vespers. This king of Pontus fought a series of three wars with the Romans.

q3.quetsion_text: Mithridates VI was eventually defeated by this member of the First Triumvirate. He was killed in Egypt and his head was presented to Caesar.
q3.raw_answer: Pompey the Great [or Gnaeus Pompeius Magnus]

lead_in: Later members of this philosophical tradition, such as Proclus, practiced theurgy, as described in On the Egyptian Mysteries by Iamblichus.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this philosophical tradition founded by Plotinus which posits a first principle called the One, which is simple and beyond being. Its other members include Plotinus's student Porphyry, who compiled the Enneads.

q2.quetsion_text: Neoplatonism was an influence on some Italian Renaissance humanists, including this friend of Marsilio Ficino who wrote the "Oration on the Dignity of Man" to introduce 900 theses called the Conclusions.
q2.raw_answer: Giovanni Pico della Mirandola [prompt on partial answer]

q3.quetsion_text: Pico della Mirandola influenced this German philosopher, who claimed God must be understood through a coincidentia oppositorum between rational and supernatural understanding in On Learned Ignorance.
q3.raw_answer: Nicholas of Cusa [accept Nicolas Cusanum; prompt on partial answer]

lead_in: One writer from this country wrote "Sunstone," a poetry collection with 584 sections to correspond to the Aztec calendar.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this country home to Juan Rolfo and Octavio Paz.
q1.raw_answer: Mexico [or United Mexican States; or Estados Unidos Mexicanos]

q2.quetsion_text: This work by another Mexican author chronicles the last moments of the title tycoon as he reflects on the events of his life.
q2.raw_answer: The Death of Artemio Cruz [or La muerte de Artemio Cruz]

q3.quetsion_text: This author of The Death of Artemio Cruz also wrote The Old Gringo, which was inspired by the disappearance of Ambrose Bierce during the Mexican Revolution.

lead_in: Answer the following about air combat in poetry,

q1.quetsion_text: This author of "The Second Coming" wrote "Those that I fight I do not hate / Those that I guard I do not love" in "An Irish Airman Foresees His Death."

q2.quetsion_text: This Randall Jarrell poem mentions that the title character was washed out "with a hose" after waking to "black flak and the nightmare fighters" "six miles from earth."
q2.raw_answer: "The Death of the Ball Turret Gunner"

q3.quetsion_text: In his most famous poem, this American serving in the Canadian Air Force wrote that he has "done a hundred things / You have not dreamed of" after slipping "the surly bonds of Earth" and touching "the face of God."

lead_in: This work was compiled from index cards, the last of which consisted only of unconnected words like "efface", "expunge" and "erase".

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this novel centering on the enormously fat neurologist Philip Wild, who doesn't love his younger, attractive wife, Flora. It was published in 2009 despite instructions by its author to destroy it after his death.
q1.raw_answer: The Original of Laura [or Dying Is Fun or The Opposite of Laura]

q2.quetsion_text: The Original of Laura is an incomplete novel by this author of Pale Fire.

q3.quetsion_text: It's a bit unclear the relationship between the real and fictional elements of Nabokov's relationship with this Swiss-French governess, who titles a short-story by the author likely originally written in French. Nabokov re-used the story about this woman for a chapter in Speak, Memory.

lead_in: Bonus: Polyneices used one of this woman’s possessions to bribe Amphiaraus’s wife Eriphyle. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this daughter of Ares and Aphrodite who was presented with a divinely forged necklace at her wedding to Cadmus.

q2.quetsion_text: Harmonia’s husband, Cadmus, founded this city, which was ruled by Laius and Oedipus. Oedipus’s son Polyneices led a group of seven who fought against this city.

q3.quetsion_text: This sister of Polyneices buried his body and was sentenced to death for violating Creon’s decree that forbade Polyneices’ burial.

lead_in: This man rejected asceticism and indulgence in favor of a "Middle Way" and described the Noble Eightfold Path to ending personal suffering.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this man, who founded a world religion that has Mahayana and Theravada branches.
q1.raw_answer: Gautama Buddha [accept either underlined portion; or Siddhartha Gautama; or The Buddha; or Shakyamuni]

q2.quetsion_text: In Mahayana Buddhism, this name is given to beings who have achieved enlightenment and work for the enlightenment of all beings. One such is Guanyin, an aspect of Avalokitesvara.

q3.quetsion_text: This is the name for the celestial realms inhabited by Buddhas and boddhisatvas. One of these realms named Shambhala is the inspiration for the Shangri-La myth.
q3.raw_answer: Pure lands [or buddha-kṣetra or Buddha fields; or jingtu]

lead_in: Adherents of this school of thought sought to found the legitimacy of the state on the guarantee of economic freedom.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this school of thought promoted by Franz BÃ¶hm and Walter Eucken, which derives its name from a journal they edited. It emphasized the importance of competition and the idea that the "social market economy" grew out of it.

q2.quetsion_text: This man enacted Ordoliberal policies in West Germany during his tenures as Minister for Economics under Konrad Adenauer and Chancellor, achieving what was called the Wirtschaftswunder, or economic miracle.

q3.quetsion_text: Eucken's ideas influenced the Mansholt Plan, which sought to reduce the number of people working in this industry by modifying the "Common Policy" governing this industry in Europe.

lead_in: Fernanda comes to the setting of this novel in order to compete to be the Queen of the Carnival.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Gabriel Garcia Marquez novel in which Remedios is a stunningly beautiful member of the Buendia family in Macondo.
q1.raw_answer: One Hundred Years of Solitude [or Cien anos de soledad]

q2.quetsion_text: Garcia Marquez also wrote this novella in which the protagonist awaits a pension check from the army. Its title character is torn over whether to enter his son's prizefighting cock into a contest or sell it.
q2.raw_answer: No One Writes to the Colonel [or El coronel no tiene quien le escriba]

q3.quetsion_text: This other Garcia Marquez character has a "soulless grandmother" who forces her to become a prostitute after she accidentally burns down their home.
q3.raw_answer: (The Incredible and Sad Tale of) Innocent Erendira (and Her Heartless Grandmother)

lead_in: This piece's first theme is first played by the bassoon and violas, which uses the notes F, E-natural, D-flat, and C to descend to the tonic note of B-flat. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this single-movement patriotic piece written after the onset of the Serbo-Turkish War, which quotes "God Save the Tsar" and no other national anthems.

q2.quetsion_text: This Russian composer of Marche Slave included cannons firing blank shells in his 1812 Overture.

q3.quetsion_text: This Tchaikovsky symphony opens its B-flat minor Andantino second movement with an oboe melody and has an entirely pizzicato 3rd movement. Its Allegro con fuoco finale is interrupted by the same brass fanfare on repeated A-flats which opens this symphony.
q3.raw_answer: Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 4 in F minor, Op. 36

q1.quetsion_text: Name this type of language. These languages make extensive use of "higher-order" forms of their namesake constructs.

q2.quetsion_text: This ubiquitous higher-order function repeatedly applies a function to successive elements of a recursive data structure and accumulates the results. As every category theoretician knows, this function is a catamorphism.
q2.raw_answer: fold [or reduce; or foldr; or foldl]

q3.quetsion_text: Since pure functions cannot cause any side effects, this task is difficult in purely functional languages, and requires eldritch things like monads and continuations. In C, this task is accomplished with functions like putchar and getchar.
q3.raw_answer: input and output [accept either underlined part; or I/O; or reading and writing data; or obvious equivalents]

lead_in: Name some fabulists, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This author's "The Unicorn in the Garden" appears in his collection Fables for Our Time. He is better known for his New Yorker cartoons and for the short story "The Secret Life of Walter Mitty."

q2.quetsion_text: This ancient Greek slave wrote fables like "The Boy Who Cried Wolf" and "The Fox and the Grapes."

q3.quetsion_text: This Frenchman's Fables, published in the late 17th century, includes many adaptations of Aesop's fables.

lead_in: A character in this play has a craving for cucumber sandwiches.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this play in which Jack Worthington pursues the hand of Gwendolyn and discovers his aunt is Lady Bracknell after Miss Prism admits to misplacing a baby in a handbag at a railway station.
