q1.quetsion_text: Name this son of Poeas and gifted archer of the Trojan war.

q2.quetsion_text: Philoctetes was a disciple of this Greek hero, from whom he received his bow and poison- tipped arrows.

q3.quetsion_text: The serpent bit Philoctetes on this non-Delos island sacred to Apollo. In the Aeneid, the Greeks keep their fleet on this island while pretending to have left for home.

lead_in: This style of jazz is exemplified by Horace Silver's album Song for My Father and Art Blakey's Moanin'.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this style of jazz that incorporated R&B and gospel influences into the fast jazz style that it extended.
q1.raw_answer: hard bop [prompt on "bop"; do NOT prompt or accept "bebop"]

q2.quetsion_text: Walkin' is a hard bop album by this jazz musician who included Manuel de Falla's "Song of the Will-o-the-Wisp" as the second track on his Sketches of Spain and also released the album Kind of Blue.

q3.quetsion_text: Miles Davis collaborated on albums like Quiet Nights with Gil Evans, a player of this instrument, whose other hard bop practitioners include Horace Silver and Tadd Dameron.

lead_in: For 10 points each, identify the following related to animal communication.

q1.quetsion_text: Communication is often facilitated by the secretion of these chemicals, which manifest as odors in humans. They can indicate alarm, sexual availability, or territory boundaries.

q2.quetsion_text: Certain animals use this figure-eight dance to communicate the location of food. The angle of this dance in relation to the sun translates to direction, while the magnitude relates to distance.

q3.quetsion_text: The waggle dance is performed by these organisms. Karl von Frisch extensively studied their sensory perception and means of communication.
q3.raw_answer: honeybees [or Apis; accept worker bees; do not accept "wasps" or "hornets"]

lead_in: For diamond, this value is around 0.34 because covalent bonds don't take up much space. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this value, which is equal to the number of particles times the volume of each particle over the volume of the unit cell. For a body-centered cubic structure, it is equal to 0.68.
q1.raw_answer: atomic packing factor [or packing efficiency; or packing fraction; or apf]

q2.quetsion_text: A close-packed structure achieves an atomic packing factor of this number. You need two decimal places to get points.

q3.quetsion_text: The atomic packing factor is used to describe these substances, which are solids with repeating unit cells in an ordered pattern.

lead_in: William Wordsworth's preface to Lyrical Ballads criticized a sonnet by this poet for using imagery of the god Phoebus. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this alumnus of Eton College, who reminded readers that "all that glisters [is not] gold" in an ode for a cat that drowned in a tub of goldfish.

q2.quetsion_text: Gray wrote that "the paths of glory lead but to the grave" in this poem, which opens as "the curfew tolls the knell of parting day" near the title gloomy locale.

q3.quetsion_text: After noting that "Some mute inglorious Milton here may rest," Gray writes that someone like this leader, "guiltless of his country's blood," might rest in the churchyard.

lead_in: Cinchona alkaloids and quaternary ammonium salts can act as these substances by carrying reactants to a single phase, and a key parameter characterizing porous ones is the Thiele modulus. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these substances that decrease the activation energy of a reaction.

q2.quetsion_text: Speaking of moving things from one phase to another, this procedure uses a separatory funnel, pipet, or other device to selectively remove one phase. Phenol-chloroform is used to do this to DNA.

q3.quetsion_text: A type of supramolecular catalysis relies on this macrocyclic molecules, which are condensation products of a phenol and an aldehyde. They get their name from their chalice-like shape.

lead_in: Its third "Entr'acte" was re-used by its composer for his Impromptu in B-flat and for the slow movement of his String Quartet No. 13.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this set of incidental music for an 1823 play by Helmina von ChÃ©zy. It is often paired with its composer's overture to Die Zauberharfe, which is consequently named for this piece.
q1.raw_answer: Incidental music to Rosamunde, FÃ¼rstin von Zypern, Op. 26

q2.quetsion_text: Parts of this composer's incidental music to Rosamunde is sometimes used to "complete" his twomovement Unfinished Symphony.

q3.quetsion_text: Schubert wrote his Fantasy in F minor and three Marches Militaires for this combination of performers
q3.raw_answer: piano duet [or piano four-hands; prompt on "two pianists", until they make clear that this is two pianists and one piano; do NOT prompt on or accept "piano duo" or "two pianos"]

lead_in: Answer some deep questions,

q1.quetsion_text: This country is supposedly secretly controlled by the so-called "deep state" and its nationalistic interests. Its first president was the reformist Mustafa Kemal Ataturk.

q2.quetsion_text: The "deep image" school of poetry includes this poet whose book Iron John is a foundational text in the mythopoeic men's movement. He has translated the work of Kabir, Francis Ponge, Ibsen, and other writers.

q3.quetsion_text: Jeremy Bentham's concept of "deep play" was adopted by Clifford Geertz in an essay from this book, which recommended that anthropologists engage in "thick description."

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Florentine Renaissance thinker who split all regimes into republics and principalities, covering the former in Discourses on Livy and the latter in The Prince.

q2.quetsion_text: Machiavelli's The Prince likens this aspect of life to a river which the prince must dam, or a woman he must beat. Lady Philosophy allegorizes this other thing as a woman in Boethius's The Consolation of Philosophy.
q2.raw_answer: Fortune [or Fortuna; do not accept synonyms]

q3.quetsion_text: This Chicago professor's Thoughts on Machiavelli focused on anticlericalism. This political theorist got a cult following in the 50s as he studied al-Farabi and Spinoza and supported "esoteric writing" as the philosopher's defense against persecution.

lead_in: In a vulnerable moment, he admits he feels like Adam, "staggering beneath the piled centuries since Paradise". For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Give this captain of the Pequod who obsessively chases a white whale to his and his crew's deaths.

q2.quetsion_text: Ahab's chase after the whale is the focus of this American author's novel Moby-Dick. In "Bartleby the Scrivener", he created a man trapped by walls who repeats, "I would prefer not to".

q3.quetsion_text: The only survivor of the Pequod's chase is the narrator Ishmael, who survives in the sea by hanging onto this object. Reconfigured as a life buoy, it was built under the instruction of a feverish Yojo-worshipping harpooner.

lead_in: This character is told "As flies to wanton boys are we to the gods. They kill us for their sport," and later leads a blind character to some imaginary cliffs. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this character from a Shakespeare play. He is the son of the Earl of Gloucester and the halfbrother of Edmund, who he fatally wounds in the final scene.

q2.quetsion_text: Edgar appears in this Shakespearean tragedy. The title character goes mad after dividing his kingdom and losing the respect of his children.

q3.quetsion_text: Near the beginning of the play, King Lear's daughters are given a chance to tell him how much they love him, in order to inherit land. Cordelia refuses to speak; name either of her two sisters who choose to lie and get estates.

lead_in: Bonus: Members of this group committed the Mountain Meadows Massacre. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this religious group that was led by Brigham Young to Utah following the death of its founder in Nauvoo, Illinois.
q1.raw_answer: Mormons [or Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints; or LDS Church]

q2.quetsion_text: This aforementioned founder of the Mormon church received a pair of golden plates from the angel Moroni and translated them into the Book of Mormon.

q3.quetsion_text: The Book of Mormon is one of the four “standard works” of the Mormon church, along with the Bible, the Doctrine and Covenants, and this book, which is named after an object that demonstrates the value of the Kingdom of Heaven.

lead_in: The first poem in this collection begins by asking, "Who, if I cried out, would hear me among the Angelic  Orders?" and later says that "Every Angel is terror." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this collection of ten poems written at an Italian castle while its author was under the  patronage of Princess Marie von Thurn und Taxis.

q2.quetsion_text: This German poet of the Duino Elegies also wrote The Book of Hours and a collection of fifty-five  Sonnets to Orpheus.

q3.quetsion_text: A Rilke poem describing an "Archaic Torso" of this god ends with the words "You must change your  life." John Keats wrote a "Hymn to" this Greek god of light and music.

lead_in: The head of this organization is currently Elizabeth II.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this organization which generally consists of former members of the British Empire.

q2.quetsion_text: In some Commonwealth countries, the monarch is represented by this position's holder. In Australia, the holder of this position has the power to dismiss the PM and dissolve government.
q2.raw_answer: Governor-General [do not accept or prompt on partial answers]

q3.quetsion_text: After 1858, the British Raj was created and the Governor-General of India received this additional title, to signify he was there in the monarch's place.

lead_in: This man succeeded Khrushchev as leader of the Soviet Union.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this leader, who presided over the Era of Stagnation and whose namesake doctrine justified military intervention in order to end the Prague Spring.

q2.quetsion_text: While Brezhnev succeeded Khrushchev as First Secretary, this man became the next Premier of the Soviet Union. This man also started some namesake economic reforms in 1965 that never really went anywhere.

q3.quetsion_text: Kosygin briefly met with this foreign politician, who ordered Operation Power Pack, at the Glassboro conference. This politician announced a last-minute deal in 1968 in an early instance of an "October surprise" speech.

lead_in: The plot of this story is set in motion when the Saro University scientist Beenay 25 discovers some irregularities regarding Onos. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: The plot of this story is set in motion when the Saro University scientist Beenay 25 discovers some irregularities regarding Onos. For 10 points each:
q1.raw_answer: Name this 1941 story that describes what happens when the inhabitants of the planet Lagash see stars, an unpredicted phenomenon, for the first time.

q2.quetsion_text: "Nightfall" was written by this author of an excellent Guide to Shakespeare, who is undoubtedly more famous for science-fiction works like I, Robot and the Foundation trilogy.

q3.quetsion_text: Many of Asimov's robot stories involve this misanthropic robopsychologist. The stories in I, Robot are framed as the reminiscences of this woman.

lead_in: This denomination adheres to a set of texts called the "Twenty-Five Articles". For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Christian denomination founded by John Wesley. It focuses on the personal relationship with God rather than a formal theology.

q2.quetsion_text: Another influential early Methodist preacher was George Whitefield, who was a leader of the first of these widespread religious revivals in America.

q3.quetsion_text: Wesley was influenced by this religious movement that emphasized the saving nature of grace for all humans. Its rise to prominence was condemned by the Dutch Reformed Church in the Synod of Dort.

lead_in: The Mongol Empire in the 1200s was the largest contiguous land empire in history. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this unifier of the Mongolian tribes and the founder of the Mongol Empire, also known as Temujin. He developed the tumen system, subdividing forces into units of 10, 100, and 1,000 soldiers each.

q2.quetsion_text: The Mongol armies were mostly composed of this ranged cavalry unit. These lightly armored troops could turn around and fire backwards in a "parting shot", and Mongols paired these mounted units with lancers.
q2.raw_answer: horse archers [grudgingly accept mounted archers, do not accept "kashik" or "keshig"]

q3.quetsion_text: The Ilkhanate suffered a defeat at Ayn Jalut to this monarchy ruled by former slaves, finally halting the Mongols' advance. They had previously taken over the Ayyubid Sultanate.

lead_in: This phenomenon vanishes above the Curie temperature when domains lose their alignment and become disordered.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this phenomenon, in which domain alignment in the same direction results in a net magnetic moment. It is often seen in metals like nickel and cobalt.

q2.quetsion_text: This simple model of ferromagnetism models domains as points on a lattice, with the Hamiltonian consisting of nearest-neighbors that are either aligned or anti-aligned. A formal solution to the two dimensional version of this model was developed by Lars Onsager.

q3.quetsion_text: The Curie-Weiss law from which the Curie temperature is obtained is actually an expression for this quantity, which becomes infinite when the Curie temperature is reached. It represents the magnitude of the magnetization in response to an applied field.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this force that is paired with electricity to make one of the four fundamental forces.

q2.quetsion_text: This S.I.-derived unit of magnetic flux density is used to measure the strength of magnetic fields. It is equivalent to a weber per square meter.

q3.quetsion_text: This constant equal to four pi times ten to the negative seven henries per meter for a vacuum measures the ability of a material to support a magnetic field.
q3.raw_answer: permeability of free space (accept mu naught)

lead_in: The PTT is extended in this disease, but not the PT. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this disease in which patients are missing blood clotting factors, resulting in even small cuts being potentially fatal. This disease is most often caused by mutations in factor VIII and factor IX.

q2.quetsion_text: Factor VIII is produced in cells derived from these organs in Chinese hamsters. Cancer of these organs often show elevation of CA125, and they're not breasts, but BRCA2 mutations increase the probability of cancer of this organ.

q3.quetsion_text: This protein is responsible for degrading factor V and factor VIII. Factor V Leiden occurs because the activated form of this protein can't cleave it, resulting in aberrant clotting.

lead_in: This novel opens by describing how "Stink Harris woke up screaming one night with a leech on his tongue".

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this novel where Paul Berlin and his company pursue the title character, who has deserted and says that he's going to walk by foot to Paris.

q2.quetsion_text: Going After Cacciato was written by Tim O'Brien, best known for this collection of stories about soldiers who fought in Vietnam. Letters from Jimmy Cross' lover Martha constitute some of the title objects in the first story in this collection.

q3.quetsion_text: An entry in The Things They Carried is titled for how to perform this action and sees the narrator get angry at a "dumb cooze" after recalling an incident where he shot a baby water buffalo. A photograph of a Machiguengan man who performs this activity triggers memories of the narrator's friend Saul Zuratas in a Mario Vargas Llosa novel.
q3.raw_answer: telling a true war story [or telling stories or storytelling]

lead_in: Identify the following about modern string quartets, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This composer included a soprano singing a Stefan Georg poem in his second string quartet, which was one of the first atonal pieces ever. He also wrote the string sextet Transfigured Night and the song cycle Pierrot Lunaire.

q2.quetsion_text: Beethoven's thirteenth string quartet originally ended with this intense piece, which was published separately. Stravinsky famously said that it is "an absolutely contemporary piece of music that will be contemporary forever."
q2.raw_answer: Grosse Fuge [accept Great Fugue or Grand Fugue]

q3.quetsion_text: Elliott Carter, a composer from this country, may be best known for his second and third string quartets. Both of those works won the Pulitzer Prize for Music, which is awarded to composers from this country.
q3.raw_answer: USA [or US; or United States of America; accept equivalents, including just "America"]

lead_in: The prologue of this work is titled "The Book of the Grotesque".

q1.quetsion_text: Name this collection of short stories titled after a Midwestern town. Its story "Hands" concerns the suspected child molester Wing Biddlebaum.

q2.quetsion_text: Winesburg, Ohio was written by this author, whose novel Dark Laughter was parodied by the Hemingway story "Torrents of Spring."

q3.quetsion_text: This newspaper reporter appears in many of the stories in Winesburg, Ohio, and leaves the town in "Departure."

lead_in: The first of these events targeted a group of engineers from Shakty who were believed to be "wreckers." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these events that began after the assassination of Sergei Kirov. These events, which were a central part of the Great Purge, were led by Andrei Vyshinsky and targeted people like Lev Kamenev.

q2.quetsion_text: The show trials were part of this person's efforts to consolidate power. This mustachioed Soviet dictator also orchestrated a famine called the Holodomor and led the USSR through World War II.
q2.raw_answer: Joseph Stalin [or Iosif Vissarionovich Stalin; or Ioseb Besarionis Dze Jughashvili]

q3.quetsion_text: Along with Kamenev, this politician was executed after the Trial of the Sixteen. A letter purportedly sent by this man to the British Communist party may have cost Ramsay Macdonald's Labour party the 1924 election.

lead_in: Spiegler partly generalized this result to even dimensions using the Arnold energy-Casimir method. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this result which states that rotating around the axis with the largest or smallest moment of inertia results in stable rotation, but rotating around the other one results in tumbling.

q2.quetsion_text: The tennis racket theorem can be proven using Euler's equation in the absence of this quantity. This quantity, symbolized tau, is the rotational analogue of force and is divided by moment of inertia to give angular acceleration.

q3.quetsion_text: This other result states that the difference of the moment of inertia between two axes that don't intersect is equal to the mass of the object times the distance between the two axes squared.

lead_in: Despite his incompetence, this man was a royal favourite until he was killed in 1628.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this man, who was in charge of negotiating the marriage of the future Charles I to Infanta Maria Anna of Spain. This man also led a failed expedition to aid the Huguenots in 1627.
q1.raw_answer: George Villiers, 1st Duke of Buckingham [accept either underlined portion]

q2.quetsion_text: The Duke of Buckingham primarily negotiated with this Galician diplomat, who led an embassy in England from 1613 to 1622. This man was caricatured as the Black Knight in Thomas Middleton's play, A Game at Chess.
q2.raw_answer: Diego Sarmiento de AcuÃ±a, Count of Gondomar [accept either underlined portion]

q3.quetsion_text: Charles I ended up marrying Queen Henrietta Maria of France, after whom this Catholic named the Province of Maryland in North America.

lead_in: Bonus: It was home to an institution that translated works such as the Almagest as part of the Translation Movement. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this city where the House of Wisdom was established by Harun al-Rashid and his son al-Ma’mun to aid the work of scholars during the Islamic Golden Age.

q2.quetsion_text: The House of Wisdom was established during the rule of this caliphate, which overthrew the Umayyads in 750 CE.

q3.quetsion_text: The House of Wisdom was destroyed during the 1258 sack of Baghdad, which was perpetrated by an army of these people led by Hulagu. Another leader of these people was Genghis Khan.

lead_in: This notation can be used to circumvent the need for parentheses, as a plus b multiplied by c is  expressed differently from a plus b all multiplied by c. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this notation in which the operation is placed after the operands, in contrast to the more usual  infix notation.
q1.raw_answer: Reverse Polish Notation [or postfix notation; or RPN; do not accept or prompt on "prefix  notation" or "Polish Notation"]

q2.quetsion_text: These data structures can be used to implement Reverse Polish Notation by popping the operands,  performing the operation, and pushing the answer back onto them.

q3.quetsion_text: Data in stacks is stored in this order, which is why only their topmost element is accessible. This  order is contrasted with that used by queues.
q3.raw_answer: last in, first out [or first in, last out; accept equivalents like last come, first served; accept  abbreviations like LIFO or FILO or LCFS; do not accept or prompt on "first in, first out" or "last in, last  out" or "FIFO" or "LILO"]

lead_in: Henry Theurer developed the "float" kind of this technique by passing a vertical silicon rod through a heating coil and relying on surface tension to keep the molten phase in place.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this method invented by Bill Pfann to purify crystals by progressively heating them so that impurities concentrate in the molten phase.
q1.raw_answer: zone melting [or zone refining; accept word forms; accept answers preceded by "float"]

q2.quetsion_text: Zone melting and the Czochralski process are both methods often used to purify these materials, such as silicon and germanium. The introduction of impurities into these materials is called doping.

q3.quetsion_text: Doping with acceptor impurities, such as boron and gallium in silicon, can be used to create this kind of semiconductor, which have more electron holes than electrons.

lead_in: This thinker discounted the idea that a "malicious demon" could deceive literally all of his senses, since there was no way for him to doubt his own thinking existence.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this French author of Meditations on Philosophy and Discourse on Method, who wrote "I think, therefore I am."

q2.quetsion_text: Descartes also held this view, that the immaterial 'substance' of the mind was a distinct thing from the material body.
q2.raw_answer: mind-body dualism [or Cartesian dualism; or substance dualism; or dualist]

q3.quetsion_text: More recently, Hilary Putnam argued against the idea that we could just be these objects, receiving electrical stimuli to perceive an external world that isn't there.
q3.raw_answer: brain[s] in a vat [prompt on partial answer]

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this leader who fell out with Pompey following the death of Crassus at the hands of the Parthians.

q2.quetsion_text: Suetonius [swee-TOE-nee-us] wrote that Julius Caesar saw an apparition that convinced him to cross this river. Doing so sparked a civil war with Pompey, which Julius Caesar won.

q3.quetsion_text: Pompey subsequently fled to Egypt to evade capture, but Julius Caesar was presented with Pompey's head upon arriving in this Egyptian city.

lead_in: Bonus: The value of a good produced in the US by a French firm counts towards it. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this quantity calculated by adding up the value of all final goods and services produced in a given country. Unlike the gross national product, ownership does not matter.

q2.quetsion_text: Real GDP constitutes the X-axis of a model that graphs this quantity and its counterpart. The long-run curve of this quantity is vertical, and cost-push inflation is caused by a leftward shift of this.
q2.raw_answer: aggregate supply [do not accept or prompt on “supply”]

q3.quetsion_text: Because the population of a country affects its GDP, dividing GDP by the population of the country is a more accurate indicator of its economic health. That value is denoted by this Latin term.

lead_in: This "paramount leader" shared powers with Bo Yibo and the other "Eight Elders", and promulgated the "one country, two systems" ideology. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this world leader who once stated that it doesn't matter if a cat is black or white, as long as it catches mice, as an analogy for his advocacy of a mixed economy.

q2.quetsion_text: Deng Xiaoping was the paramount leader of this nation. It is currently headed by a member of the "princelings", named Xi Jinping.
q2.raw_answer: People's Republic of China [or PRC; or Zhonghua Renmin Gongheguo; do not accept "Republic of China"]

q3.quetsion_text: Deng Xiaoping was purged during the Cultural Revolution after being accused of being the "Number 2" one of these people. This term refers to anyone who attempts to subvert the communist goal by bowing to bourgeois forces.
q3.raw_answer: capitalist roader [or Zou zipai; or Zhouxiang ziben zhuyi de paibie]

lead_in: This piece begins with a tutti E-flat chord from the orchestra, followed by a quasi-cadenza for the soloist, a tutti A-flat chord, another quasi-cadenza, a tutti B-flat chord, and one last quasicadenza before it gets moving. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this piece in E-flat major for solo piano and orchestra that was composed in 1811 as the last such piece by its composer.
q1.raw_answer: Emperor Concerto [or Ludwig van Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 5 in E flat]

q2.quetsion_text: The B-major second movement of Beethoven's "Emperor" concerto is given this Italian tempo marking, meaning "slowly," modified with the extra instruction "un poco mosso." Samuel Barber wrote a piece of this tempo for Strings

q3.quetsion_text: This Hungarian-born longtime conductor of the Cleveland Orchestra made recordings of all five Beethoven piano concertos with Leon Fleisher as the soloist.

lead_in: The famous charge of the Rough Riders during this battle actually took place at Kettle Hill.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this July 1898 battle, a decisive battle of the Spanish-American War in Cuba. The press played up the role of the Rough Riders, ignoring the work of African-American soldiers.
q1.raw_answer: The Battle of San Juan Hill

q2.quetsion_text: This future President was a member of the Rough Riders. This man, who said "speak softly and carry a big stick," succeeded the assassinated William McKinley as President.

q3.quetsion_text: This man served as Secretary of State for both McKinley and Roosevelt. He negotiated three treaties related to the Panama Canal, including one with Panama's Jean Bunau-Varilla.

lead_in: A trap is used while using this laboratory instrument to prevent bumping. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this device which quickly removes solvent from a compound through a combination of a heat bath, a vacuum pump, and a motor that spins the flask containing your product.

q2.quetsion_text: Along with evaporation, this is the second kind of liquid vaporization into a gas. This phase transition occurs for water at 100 Celsius.

q3.quetsion_text: This part of a rotovap cools gases back into liquid form and allows them to drop into a waste container. This same device is used in a reflux to prevent gases from escaping at the top of the apparatus.

lead_in: John Marston fights these beings in a Red Dead Redemption downloadable pack. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these beings who drop rotten flesh in Minecraft and name a special mode in the Call of Duty series. They are the principal enemies in Left 4 Dead, Resident Evil, and The Walking Dead.

q2.quetsion_text: This video game follows Joel and Ellie, who fight Cordyceps-infected zombies as they traverse a post-apocalyptic landscape to find the Fireflies.

q3.quetsion_text: Infection by Cordyceps also inspired tochukaso, which grow on the back of this orange Bug and Grass type Pokemon found in Mt. Moon. It evolves into a large sightless Pokemon fully controlled by the mushroom on its back.

lead_in: The speaker of one of her poems is advised by an "iridescent-throned" deity that a love interest will soon reciprocate her affections. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Aeolian ("ay-OHL-ee-an") Greek poet, whose Hymn to Aphrodite exhorts the goddess to "fight as [her] comrade." She was born on the island of Lesbos.

q2.quetsion_text: Sappho characterizes the beauty of Helen in a recovered excerpt called Fragment 16, and illustrates the wedding and Hector and Andromache. All of those characters were originally depicted by this blind Greek epic poet.

q3.quetsion_text: This institution at an Egyptian city purportedly contained nine books of Sappho's poetry, organized by meter. It may have been destroyed in one of Caesar's invasions.
q3.raw_answer: Library of Alexandria [accept Library at Alexandria, prompt on either underlined part]

lead_in: A protest song by Peter Gabriel in honor of this man contains the Xhosa lyrics "Yihla Moja!", roughly meaning "Come to me, spirit!" For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this founder of the Black Consciousness movement, a South African activist who was beaten by police and then left to die in prison in 1977.

q2.quetsion_text: This system of anti-black laws and restrictions was the primary cause opposed by Steven Biko, who helped organize the Soweto riots to draw attention to its anti-indigenous language laws.

q3.quetsion_text: This man was prime minister of South Africa during Biko's death. This man, who pushed Ian Smith to cede power in Rhodesia, had previously been Minister of Justice during the Rivonia trial of Nelson Mandela.
q3.raw_answer: B.J. Vorster [or Balthazar Johannes Vorster; or John Vorster]

lead_in: Legislation passed to make sure that an event of this type never happen again led to John Company essentially becoming defunct. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this conflict partly caused by the unpopularity of Lord Dalhousie's Doctrine of Lapse, as well as by religiously motivated controversy over the fat used to grease bullets.
q1.raw_answer: Sepoy Mutiny [or Indian Rebellion of 1857, Indian Mutiny; or anything about the 1857 Revolt in India]

q2.quetsion_text: This other rebellion took place in the forests of Jalpaiguri in Bengal and was triggered by the oppressive tax collection after the Bengal famine of 1770.

q3.quetsion_text: This British joint-stock company was responsible for most of the conquest of India, and dealt with the Sannyasi and Sepoy rebellions. Originally, it had a monopoly on trade of silk, tea, cotton, and spices.
q3.raw_answer: British East India Company [or BEIC; prompt on "John Company"]

lead_in: Name some tributaries of the Mississippi River, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This longest river in North America rises in the Rocky Mountains before flowing into St. Louis.

q2.quetsion_text: This tributary of the Missouri River is a major river of Nebraska and helped form many trails during westward expansion. It is sometimes known as "The Shallow River," as it is too shallow and muddy to be navigable

q3.quetsion_text: This tributary joins the Mississippi just north of Vicksburg in the state of Mississippi. Lands along it were fraudulently sold in a major scandal of early American history.

lead_in: This field secretary for the NAACP was assassinated in his driveway in 1963, and his assassin Byron De La Beckwith was finally convicted in 1994.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this D-Day veteran, who tried to integrate his state's public law school in 1954.

q2.quetsion_text: Evers was from this state, which was also where Emmett Till was murdered. James Meredith eventually integrated its flagship state university.

q3.quetsion_text: Evers supported the cause of this man, a former UChicago student who tried to enroll at Mississippi Southern College, in return for which he was subjected to years of judicial harassment and frame-ups by the State Sovereignty Commission.

lead_in: On December 16, 1773, angry American colonists boarded the HMS Dartmouth after local officials refused to return the ship to Britain. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this event led by Samuel Adams in which the Sons of Liberty boarded British merchant ships in Boston and dumped a certain good into the harbor.
q1.raw_answer: Boston Tea Party [accept any answer mentioning destruction of tea in Boston]

q2.quetsion_text: In response to the Boston Tea Party, Parliament passed this series of acts to punish Boston. It included provisions that stripped Massachusetts of its charter and closed the port of Boston until the tea was paid for.

q3.quetsion_text: After receiving reports that New England was rebelling in 1775, Lord North issued this resolution that removed tax obligations from any colony that contributed to the colonial defense and provided support to the Crown.

lead_in: A prisoner in this story escapes from his buddies, who are chained up in front of a fire so that they can only see shadows in front of them.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this story told by Socrates to Glaucon, whose title locale is an analogy for humans' inability to see the ideal Forms.
q1.raw_answer: allegory of the cave [or Plato's cave]

q2.quetsion_text: This Plato dialogue includes the allegory of the cave. It discusses the nature of justice and the government of the title ideal city-state.

q3.quetsion_text: This ruling class is the highest of three major social classes in Plato's Republic. This set of people tells the "noble lie" that its members have gold in their blood to justify its rule.

lead_in: Leone Leoni created massive depictions of Charles V and Philip II using this material. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this material, often employed by sculptors using the lost-wax method, that was used for Verrocchio's equestrian statue of Bartolomeo Colleoni and for Cellini's Perseus with the Head of Medusa.

q2.quetsion_text: Donatello's bronze sculpture of this man, the first free-standing male nude since antiquity, shows him posing with his foot on Goliath's head.

q3.quetsion_text: This man, who often signed his artworks with his brother Piero, produced several bronze sculptures of mythological subjects, such as Hercules and Antaeus, but is best known for his engraving Battle of the Nudes.

lead_in: In a dream, he embraces and kisses the body of a mare that was beaten to death. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this protagonist of Crime and Punishment who murders Alyona and Lizaveta Ivanovna.

q2.quetsion_text: This Russian author of Demons and Crime and Punishment described a kiss from Christ in a parable from The Brothers Karamazov.

q3.quetsion_text: Raskolnikov commits murder because he thinks he is one of these people. Exemplified by Napoleon, they are distinguished from their counterparts by their right to transgress the law to fulfill their ideas.
q3.raw_answer: extraordinary men [or supermen; or neobyknovenny; or ubermensch]

lead_in: This character becomes terrified after accidentally grabbing George Willard's shoulders while giving an impassioned speech.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this berry-picker, who was formerly a schoolteacher named Adolph Myers, before one of his mentally disabled students falsely accused him of molestation.

q2.quetsion_text: Wing Biddlebaum is the protagonist of "Hands" the first story of Winesburg, Ohio, by this American author.

q3.quetsion_text: Near the end of this short story by Sherwood Anderson, a hunter happens upon the corpse of the longsuffering Mrs. Grimes, who died while carrying meat home from the butcher while accompanied by some dogs.

lead_in: Identify the following about documentary filmmaker Alex Gibney,

q1.quetsion_text: Gibney's most recent documentary began as a project titled The Road Back but changed to focusing on the "Lie" of this man. The film contains footage of this man's teammates like Johan Bruyneel and George Hincapie.

q2.quetsion_text: This institution was the subject of a Gibney documentary subtitled "The Smartest Guys in the Room". A whistleblower and one-time Time person of the year named Sherron Watkins once worked for this notorious energy company.

q3.quetsion_text: This Gibney film won the 2007 Academy Award for Best Documentary Feature. It centers on the United States' use of torture, especially on an Afghan chauffeur named Dilawar.

lead_in: The answer to this question mentions the "usual cabal," including "the woman he knew" and "the woman he did not know."

q1.quetsion_text: Give this four word question prompted by the death of a character who is found with a stone in his mouth at the bottom of a harbor. It is shouted at the Brazen Head during a performance by Magnus Eisengrim.

q2.quetsion_text: Boy Staunton was born in this town, as was Dunstan Ramsay. A series named for this town begins when Boy throws a snowball that hits Mary Dempster and causes her to give birth prematurely.

q3.quetsion_text: Robertson Davies, the author of The Deptford Trilogy, is from this country, also home to a woman who wrote a novel about Offred and the Commander.

lead_in: Answer these questions about Samuel Beckett's Waiting for Godot, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This member of the cast is led on a leash by Pozzo. He stays silent except for a single, long nonsense monologue delivered while his bowler hat is on.

q2.quetsion_text: Though Godot never comes, this object suddenly appears close to the end of both acts, right after the Boy exits in each instance. In Oscar Wilde's Salome, two guards watch this object become "red as blood."

q3.quetsion_text: In both acts, Godot's Boy messenger inexplicably addresses Vladimir by this name.

lead_in: With Hans Queisser, this scientist discovered that the efficiency of a basic solar cell is limited at about 34%, and he developed a four-layer device that would turn on or off at a breakover voltage.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this scientist whose namesake semiconductor laboratory was funded by Arnold Beckman. His autocratic leadership style caused the "traitorous eight" to leave his lab.

q2.quetsion_text: The "traitorous eight" founded this company, which spun off into dozens of companies, including AMD and Intel. This company developed the first commercial mesa transistors.

q3.quetsion_text: With Jack Kilby of Texas Instruments, Robert Noyce of Fairchild developed the first integrated circuit, resulting in this nickname for the Bay Area computing industry. Fairchild incubated many early startups here.

lead_in: In a critical study on this author "and his World," Russian literary theorist Mikhail Bakhtin developed the concept of the "grotesque." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this early French author who often ventured into crude humor in his tales of the giants Gargantua and Pantagruel.

q2.quetsion_text: Upon arriving in Paris for his education, Gargantua climbs Notre Dame and performs this action, which kills many people below.
q2.raw_answer: urinates on the crowd below [or obvious equivalents; prompt on flooding the city or similar answers]

q3.quetsion_text: In the third book, Pantagruel and Panurge set sail in search of this person, whose wisdom can determine whether Panurge ought to marry or not.
q3.raw_answer: the Oracle of the Holy Bottle [or the Oracle of Bacbuc]

lead_in: This work was compiled in part using a 1,847 questionnaire that asked respondents, "If somebody always eats a considerable amount of food, you say he's a [blank]".

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this work, whose fifth volume covering Sl through Z was published in 2012. Frederic G. Cassidy edited its first volume, which was published in 1985.
q1.raw_answer: Dictionary of American Regional English [or DARE]

q2.quetsion_text: This other dictionary was once edited by James Murray of the Philological Society. William Chester Minor made large contributions to the first edition of this dictionary from within a lunatic asylum.

q3.quetsion_text: After this publisher won a case allowing it to publish a dirty version of Lady Chatterley's Lover, it then published one of the first dictionaries in Great Britain to include obscenities.

lead_in: This thinker argues that shareholder influence has given way to managerial power, a form of "accepted fraud" in his final essay The Economics of Innocent Fraud. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Canadian-American economist who authored The New Industrial State and coined the term "conventional wisdom" in The Affluent Society.

q2.quetsion_text: Chapter 11 of The Affluent Society concerns this phenomenon, in which consumers desire increase to the point that luxuries become necessities. Hayek criticized it in his essay "The Non Sequitur of [this effect]".

q3.quetsion_text: Galbraith also wrote an economic history of the "Great Crash" in this year. Galbraith argued that the stock market crash of October 28th and 29th of this year played a major role in the onset of the Great Depression

lead_in: This man rose to prominence after defending a National Guardsman who fired on a lynch mob outside an Ohio courthouse.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this man who succeeded A. Mitchell Palmer as U.S. Attorney General and was himself replaced by Harlan Fiske Stone after a series of scandals during the Harding administration.

q2.quetsion_text: Daugherty was forced to resign by this man, Harding's successor and a famously "silent" President. While taciturn and fiscally conservative, this man was praised for his honesty.

q3.quetsion_text: Harding's more capable Secretary of State, Charles Evans Hughes, led a 1921-1922 Washington conference in which the United States pledged to reduce its number of these objects to 30 if countries like Great Britain or Japan also reduced their numbers.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this common solvent that at standard pressure boils at 100 degrees Celsius and freezes at 0 degrees Celsius.

q2.quetsion_text: This name is given to water that contains a lot of mineral salts. One way to determine whether water should be classified as this is to check for magnesium and calcium.

q3.quetsion_text: One way to soften water is to use this process in which a molecular ring is formed combining a metal with at least two nonmetals. EDTA is often used in this process.

lead_in: A cut can both end and begin. For 10 points each, answer the following about kire or cutting in Japanese aesthetics.

q1.quetsion_text: In this genre of Japanese drama, actors cut off the natural walking gait to represent the episodic nature of life. Preceding kabuki, it is notable for utilizing stylized masks and is often performed alternating with kyogen plays.

q2.quetsion_text: These landscapes are minimalist arrangements of water and stones that are cut from their surrounding environment by a low perimeter wall.

q3.quetsion_text: Much of Japanese aesthetics including kire derives from this religion popular in Japan. It advocates cutting oneself from excess and embracing emptiness through meditation and koans.

lead_in: The wife of the title character may represent the author of this work.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this novel by Murasaki Shikibu, which details the adventures of the title "shining" prince, the illegitimate son of a Japanese emperor, who has an affair with the Empress Lady Fujitsubo among other adventures.
q1.raw_answer: The Tale of Genji [or Genji Monogatari]

q2.quetsion_text: The Tale of Genji was written during this period of Japanese history, in which katakana and hiragana were developed and The Pillow Book was written by Sei Shonagon.

q3.quetsion_text: Genji apparently dies in a chapter with no text, whose title indicates that he has "vanished into" these entities.

lead_in: During this city's Golden Age in the early 14th century, it was ruled by a rotating group of aristocrats known as the Nine.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this Italian city state whose armies won the Battle of Montaperti. A tyrant of this city named Pandolfo Pertrucci ordered the assassination of NiccolÃ² Borghese in 1500.

q2.quetsion_text: From 1399 until 1404, Siena was ruled by Gian Galeazzo Visconti, the duke of this other city. It was later ruled by Francesco Sforza.

q3.quetsion_text: Siena was home to Saint Bernadino, who went on an 80-day preaching marathon after this pope witnessed Bernadino successfully defend himself from heresy charges. This pope had trouble with Braccio da Montone until the 1424 Battle of Aquila and convened the Council of Pavia-Siena.
q3.raw_answer: Martin V [or Oddone Colonna or Oddo Colonna]

lead_in: The first version of this artwork was hung in the upper corner of the gallery when it was first exhibited in the 0.10 show.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Suprematist painting which was proposed as a possible model for the backdrop to Victory Over The Sun, and spawned a series of similarly titled works by its artist.

q2.quetsion_text: This Russian artist, the leading Suprematist, painted Black Square, White and White, and the cubist work Knife-Grinder.

q3.quetsion_text: Malevich exhibited with this group, which Natalia Goncharova left to form the Donkey's Tail group. They purportedly chose their namesake figure for its associations with youth and seething blood.
q3.raw_answer: Jack of Diamonds [or Knave of Diamonds or Bubnovyi Valet]

lead_in: In this novel, Antoine's body is so saturated with liquor from a lifetime of alcoholism that one day he just spontaneously combusts. Holy shit!

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this novel in which Clotilde begins an incestuous romance with her uncle, a scientist obsessed with constructing a gigantic family tree to validate his theories of heredity.

q2.quetsion_text: Doctor Pascal is the twentieth and final novel in the Rougon-Macquart series by this author, who railed against the treatment of Alfred Dreyfus in his letter J'accuse.
q2.raw_answer: Emile Zola [or Emile Edouard Charles Antoine Zola]

q3.quetsion_text: This novel by Zola tells the story of a woman who starts out as a streetwalker, ruins the lives of many suitors, such as Steiner and Fauchery, and finally dies, "a heap of pus and blood, a shovelful of putrid flesh," of smallpox.

lead_in: The penultimate act of this opera includes a set of Oriental dances, consisting of an "Arabian Dance," a "Persian Dance," and the pan-ethnic lezginka. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Glinka opera that uses a dissonant whole tone scale to represent the magic cast by the sorcerer Chernomor, who aims to separate the title pair of lovers of a fairy tale epic by Pushkin.
q1.raw_answer: Ruslan and Lyudmila [or Ruslan i Lyudmila]

q2.quetsion_text: This character from Ruslan and Lyudmila conceals a cursed sword that was destined to kill him and his brother Chernomor. Naturally, Ruslan spears this character and takes the sword with him.

q3.quetsion_text: Glinka's other major opera, A Life for the Tsar, broke ground by using quintuple meter in a musical number of this kind. A better-known operatic excerpt of this kind is sung by women accompanying Elsa in Lohengrin, and is often used with a march from Mendelssohn's incidental music for A Midsummer Night's Dream.
q3.raw_answer: bridal chorus [or wedding march; or equivalent answers such as marriage song]

lead_in: The narrator of this story declares, "A man sometimes devotes his life to a desire which he is not sure will ever be fulfilled. Those who laugh at this folly are, after all, no more than mere spectators of life."

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this short story centering on Goi, a low-ranking official who desires to consume a larger share of the title substance.

q2.quetsion_text: "Yam Gruel" is a story by this author of "Hell Screen" and "In a Grove".

q3.quetsion_text: Akutagawa drew his inspiration for this protagonist of "Hell Screen" from a painter of the same name from the third scroll of the Uji Shui. This man watches his daughter Yuzuki burn to death in the carriage he uses as inspiration to paint the title object.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this technique in which the solid organic product is dissolved at high temperatures, then cooled back down so that it crashes out, leaving impurities in the solution.

q2.quetsion_text: After recrystallization, you can collect your solid product using the "vacuum" form of this process, which draws liquids but not solids through a Buchner funnel. Sieving is another type of it.

q3.quetsion_text: Crystallization can be used in this process, the separation of a racemic mixture into pure enantiomers. Common reagents used for it include Mosher's acid and tartaric acid, which form separable diastereomers as intermediates.
q3.raw_answer: chiral resolution [or chiral resolving agents; or word forms; or chiral derivatization; or word forms]

lead_in: Bonus: He signed the Treaty of Ryswick with the League of Augsburg. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this long-reigning Sun King of France, a member of the Bourbon dynasty who promoted royal absolutism.

q2.quetsion_text: Louis XIV sought to control this class of people by requiring them to stay at Versailles for a period of time. They made up the Second Estate and those “of the sword” were differentiated from those “of the robe”.

q3.quetsion_text: This series of rebellions in Louis XIV’s youth sparked his desire to pacify and control the nobles. They were named for a slingshot weapon used in the revolt and began due to the unpopularity of Cardinal Mazarin.

lead_in: Early modern examples of these events took place in North Berwick and in Fulda.

q1.quetsion_text: Name these events targeting people suspected of using sorcery. Gottfried Christian Voigt estimated that nine million women were killed in these events in Europe.

q2.quetsion_text: This treatise on witches by Heinrich Kramer contributed to the obsession with witch hunts.
q2.raw_answer: Malleus Maleficarum [or The Hammer of Witches; or Der Hexenhammer]

q3.quetsion_text: Another treatise supporting witch hunts was Daemonologie, which was written by this King of Scotland and England, the target of the Gunpowder Plot.
q3.raw_answer: James VI of Scotland [or James I of England]

lead_in: Note to moderator: SNARE and CAG are pronounced like they sound, SNCA is spelled out. This protein helps support SNARE complex formation and possibly inhibits phospholipase D, but we don't know much else about its function.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this protein coded for by the SNCA gene and famous for its aggregation in Lewy bodies, a hallmark of Parkinson's.

q2.quetsion_text: Alpha-synuclein deposits in Lewy bodies appear in this brain structure, which is the main site of degradation in Parkinson's disease.

q3.quetsion_text: This other neurodegenerative disease is characterized by a CAG trinucleotide repeat in the HTT gene. Probably the most famous symptom of this disease is involuntary twitching, its namesake chorea.

lead_in: Homer's mention of "Potnia Theron," a goddess of animals, is believed to be a reference to this deity.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Greek goddess of virginity and the hunt who was the equivalent of the Roman Diana. She and her twin brother Apollo were the children of Leto.

q2.quetsion_text: Apollo and Artemis killed the children of this woman in response to her boast that her twelve children were superior to Leto's two.

q3.quetsion_text: Artemis tricked the giants Otus and Ephialtes into killing each other by turning into one of these animals and running between them. In another story, she turned Actaeon into one.

lead_in: Bonus: This pirate held Samuel Wragg hostage during his blockade of Charleston harbor. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this captain of the Queen Anne’s Revenge who lit fuses in his namesake facial feature to terrify his enemies while raiding the Atlantic seacoast in the 1710s.

q2.quetsion_text: This pirate sailed the Barbary Coast with his brother Aruj before becoming an admiral in the Ottoman navy and defeating the Holy League at the Battle of Preveza. He shares his name with a Holy Roman Emperor killed in the Third Crusade.

q3.quetsion_text: This Scottish pirate may not have been a pirate at all. Despite claiming that he was privateering in the Indian Ocean under a British commission, he was hung and then re-hung in a botched execution in 1701.

lead_in: It ran through the "Valley of the tears" in its Southern portion, and the supply depot of Sepon was situated along it.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this complex system of thoroughfares in Vietnam. Attempts to defoliate the canopy cover for this route using Agent Orange were unsuccessful.
q1.raw_answer: Ho Chi Minh trail [or Truong Son Strategic Supply Route; accept equivalents for "trail"]

q2.quetsion_text: The VietCong used the Ho Chi Minh trail to build up its forces in South Vietnam for this offensive, which occurred during the 1968 celebration of the Vietnamese New Year.
q2.raw_answer: Tet Offensive [or Tet mau than or Su kien tet mau than 1968]

q3.quetsion_text: The CIA had recruited members of this ethnic group in Laos to counter the influence of VietCong and the Pathet Lao. The "Secret Army" of this ethnic group was led by Vang Pao.

lead_in: In South Asia, members of this denomination perform musical poetry called qawwali. And six suprasensory organs called the lataif-e-sitta are distinguished by this sect.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Muslim denomination whose turuq include the Bektashi and Mevlevi orders., and which emphasizes mystical practices like the whirling performed by dervishes.

q2.quetsion_text: The Darqawa order led a revival of ascetic Sufism in this country, which Clifford Geertz contrasted with Indonesia in Islam Observed. Fatima al-Fihri founded the madrasa al-Karaouine in this country in 859.

q3.quetsion_text: Many Muslims in the Maghreb undertake pilgrimages to the tombs of these Sufi leaders, who originally lived in monastic fortresses called ribats. These possess high levels of baraka and effectively serve as saints.

lead_in: As a commonwealth, this country’s first black governor was Joseph Jenkins Roberts, who, upon its independence in 1848, also served as its first president. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this country established in the nineteenth century in Africa as a place where free blacks and former slaves from America could be settled.

q2.quetsion_text: This group established in 1817 by Robert Finley was responsible for setting up Liberia. Joseph Jenkins Roberts worked for this company when he served as governor.
q2.raw_answer: American Colonization Society [or ACS; or American Society for Colonizing the Free People of Color of the United States]

q3.quetsion_text: Before the establishment of the ACS, this half-Native American, half-African Quaker used his ship Traveller to try and open up trade relations for Sierra Leone, and he also transported 38 immigrants to the colony in 1816.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this process in which one cell nucleus becomes two cell nuclei.

q2.quetsion_text: This stage of mitosis just before cytokinesis involves the re-formation of the nuclear membranes.

q3.quetsion_text: The cyclin [SIE-klin]-dependent types of these enzymes involved in phosphorylation [fos-FOR-uh-lay-shun] regulate a cell's progression through mitosis.

lead_in: Bonus: One analogue of this statement used to find the expectation value for momentum is Ehrenfest’s theorem. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this law which states that force equals mass times acceleration.

q2.quetsion_text: One can integrate the equation F = ma to find this quantity equal to force multiplied by the time interval of the applied force. This quantity also equals change in momentum.

q3.quetsion_text: For a simple harmonic oscillator, one equates Newton’s Second to Hooke’s law to find this quantity whose square equals the coefficient k divided by m. It is also the coefficient of t in the sinusoidal position function.
q3.raw_answer: angular frequency [accept omega; do NOT accept just “frequency”] <EC>

lead_in: Bonus: This dynasty’s founder took mercury pills hoping to become immortal, but died instead. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this first imperial dynasty of China which began construction of the Great Wall. Despite promising to last ten thousand generations, this dynasty was replaced by the Han after only fifteen years.

q2.quetsion_text: In order to suppress independent thinking among the common people, the Qin chancellor Li Si began a campaign to kill scholars and do this. The surviving materials of this action were preserved in the imperial library.
q2.raw_answer: burning books [accept equivalents; or biblioclasm; or libricide; accept words like “destroying” in place of burning; accept synonyms of books like “texts” or “bamboo strips bound together”]

q3.quetsion_text: Qin Shihuangdi, the first Qin emperor, was buried in a mausoleum surrounded by pits containing this collection of sculptures of chariots, warriors, and horses.
q3.raw_answer: Terracotta Army [accept equivalents of army like “warriors” and “soldiers”] <JD>

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this political party that was formed in 1954 by Lee Kuan Yew, and which has been in power since 1959.

q2.quetsion_text: The PAP is a party in this Southeast Asian country, which separated from Malaysia in 1965. Its namesake capital city was founded in 1819 by Stamford Raffles.

q3.quetsion_text: In 1992, this substance's sale in Singapore was banned after it caused problems for the Mass Rapid Transit system. In 2004, that ban was relaxed, allowing approved forms of this substance to be prescribed by dentists.

lead_in: This operator's namesake used it in the study of gravitational potentials. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this differential operator, denoted by del-squared, which is the divergence of the gradient.

q2.quetsion_text: Functions whose Laplacian is zero are referred to by this term. In math, partial sums of a series of this  name can be used to find the Euler-Mascheroni constant.

q3.quetsion_text: The electric potential due to one of these entities is a harmonic function. The force two of these  entities exert on each other falls off with distance-squared, according to Coulomb's Law.
q3.raw_answer: point charges [prompt on partial; anti-prompt, i.e. "Can you be less specific?," on "proton"  or "electron"]

lead_in: For 10 points each, answer the following about secret communication during World War II.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this cipher machine used by the Germans during the war. It had multiple rotors and was complexified with additional rotors and settings for military use.

q2.quetsion_text: The scientists Zygalski, Rozycki, and Rejewski from this nation first cracked the Enigma cipher. Those men from this faked strikes to test the recipient's resolve.
