lead_in: The surface gravity of one type of these entities is equal to one over four times its mass, and they get their name from the fact that light can't escape them. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these objects that are created after a spherical mass distribution is compressed to smaller than the Schwarzschild radius. Their namesake information paradox was recently solved by introducing a firewall.

q2.quetsion_text: This theorem states that a black hole can be completely characterized by mass, charge, and angular momentum.

q3.quetsion_text: The aforementioned calculation of the surface gravity of a black hole relies on the use of members of one of these vector fields, which preserve the metric of a Riemannian manifold.

lead_in: Identify the following about Tennessee during the Civil War, for 10 points each

q1.quetsion_text: This Tennessee battle resulted in the defeat of General Beauregard and the death of Albert Sidney  Johnson after Confederate forces were stalled by Benjamin Prentiss, who had established position in the "Hornet's Nest."
q1.raw_answer: Battle of Shiloh [accept Battle of Pittsburg Landing]

q2.quetsion_text: Grant earned the nickname "Unconditional Surrender" after forcing John Floyd, Simon Bolivar Buckner, and Gideon Pillow to give up this Tennessee fort.

q3.quetsion_text: Tennessee was the birthplace of war criminal Nathan Bedford Forrest, who founded this organization after the Civil War and served as its Grand Wizard.

lead_in: Identify some mythical plants that are less hilarious than vampire watermelons,

q1.quetsion_text: The dragon Nidhoggr and four male deer are among the creatures that chew on this huge Norse world tree. Famed mythological squirrel Ratatosk carries gossip up and down it.

q2.quetsion_text: Hermes brings this black-and-white herb to the island of Aeaea in order to allow Odysseus to protect himself from Circe's magic.

q3.quetsion_text: Zoroastrians use this plant, which according to the Yasna features a "pliable asu", to produce a namesake soma-like ritual drink. It's probably a relative of ephedra.

lead_in: This concept does not envy, does not boast, and is not proud. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Give the English translation of this concept from First Corinthians 13. That oft-recited passage says this concept is "patient," "kind," and "keeps no record of wrongs."

q2.quetsion_text: First Corinthians was written by this prolific apostle, who also penned Romans and Galatians, among many other epistles.

q3.quetsion_text: This contemporary of Paul is mentioned in First Corinthians several times. Paul says he planted and this man watered. Hailing from Alexandria, he had been educated by Priscilla and Aquila.

lead_in: The mountain KÃ¶k TÃ¶be is the highest point of its largest city. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this large central Asian country with largest city Almaty. This country home to the saline lake Balkhash; in it, the Syr Darya river flows into the rapidly drying-up Aral Sea, which is to the south of this country.

q2.quetsion_text: This city replaced Almaty as the capital of Kazakhstan in 1997.

q3.quetsion_text: Kazakhstan is also home to Baikonur, the oldest one of these Soviet sites. Another major one of these sites is located in French Guiana.

lead_in: This planet's orbital axis lies very near to the plane of its rotation about the sun, so it rotates "sideways."  For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this planet, whose slightly anomalous orbit is due to the gravitational pull of its neighbor  Neptune. This ice giant is the seventh from the sun.

q2.quetsion_text: This man, whose day job as a composer didn't stop him from dabbling in astronomy, discovered  Uranus. He also stumbled across infrared light in the sun's rays.

q3.quetsion_text: This probe is the only one to have visited Uranus, passing by in 1986. It was launched before its  similarly-named sister probe, though that that sister probe has since passed this probe.

lead_in: Bonus: He is born with a bright piece of jade in his mouth. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this character who, despite once having loved Lin Daiyu, eventually marries his cousin Xue Baochai, whose golden locket complements his jade. He is the heir to the Rongguo House.

q2.quetsion_text: Jia Baoyu is the central character of this novel written by Cao Xueqin. It describes the various misfortunes of the Jia family.
q2.raw_answer: Dream of the Red Chamber [or Hóng Lóu Mèng]

q3.quetsion_text: Dream of the Red Chamber is one of the four great classical novels of this country. Other novels from this modern nation include Romance of the Three Kingdoms and Water Margin.

lead_in: Answer the following about the history of skulls in painting, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This painting by Hans Holbein the Younger depicts a diagonally-distorted skull at the feet of the two title professionals.

q2.quetsion_text: This subgenre of Dutch still-life paintings often depicted skulls on tables as a symbol of the emptiness of life.

q3.quetsion_text: This artist and member of Les Vingt depicted two skulls playing tug-of-war over a pickled herring with their teeth in one of his skeleton paintings. He also created a large crowd scene in which Jesus visits his nation's capital, in which a large red banner reads "VIVE LE SOCIALE."

lead_in: The Greek letter pi is commonly used to represent this economic quantity. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this quantity that is the dependent variable of the downward-sloping Phillips curve, with  unemployment rate serving as the independent variable. It refers to an increase in price level and  decrease in purchasing power.

q2.quetsion_text: This University of Chicago economist, the author of A Monetary History of the United States,  asserted that the Phillips curve is only valid in the short term. He advocated free market policies in the  book Capitalism and Freedom.

q3.quetsion_text: This equation defines inflation rate as equal to the nominal interest rate minus the real interest rate.  It is named after an American economist who is also known for a namesake separation theorem.

lead_in: Identify the following about the namesake of the most boring comet, Edmond Halley, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: Halley's calculations of the comet probably relied on the work of this fellow scientist, who built the first reflecting telescope. Halley also persuaded this man to publish the Principia.

q2.quetsion_text: Halley used a method developed by James Gregory to calculate the sun's mean parallax. The method involved observations of these events, which occur in pairs of 8 years followed by 121 year gaps.

q3.quetsion_text: This man is said to have observed the transit of Venus in 1032, though you may better know this Persian for writing The Canon of Medicine
q3.raw_answer: Abu Ali al-Husayn ibn Abd Allah ibn Sina [or Avicenna]

lead_in: Bonus: Answer the following about advances in space programs, for ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: In December 2013, this Chinese lunar exploration mission landed China’s first rover on the Moon.

q2.quetsion_text: This Mars rover landed in Gale Crater in 2012 after “Seven Minutes of Terror”. Its current mission involves investigating the Martian climate and any signs of possible life on the planet.

q3.quetsion_text: In July 2013, the New Horizons spacecraft photographed Charon, a moon of this dwarf planet, for the first time. New Horizons will pass Neptune’s orbit in 2015 and reach this dwarf planet in 2016.

lead_in: One faction of this political party reacted to a reptilian nickname by cutting the head of liberty out of pennies and wearing them. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this party that included the Copperhead faction during the Civil War and saw a split between Northern and Southern wings in the 1860 election, which allowed the Republicans and Abraham Lincoln to win instead.

q2.quetsion_text: This Democratic representative was a prominent leader of the Copperheads and ran for governor of Ohio in 1864 despite being expelled to the Confederacy in 1863 after delivering a speech at Mount Vernon.

q3.quetsion_text: Some Copperheads also belonged to this secret society that wanted to annex slavery-friendly territory surrounding the Caribbean. They sold fake coupons promising protection from Confederate raiders to Pennsylvania farmers.
q3.raw_answer: Knights of the Golden Circle [prompt on "KGC"]

lead_in: A man with this surname examined the mythology of the early Teutons in German Mythology. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Give this surname of Jacob, who described a process of consonant shifts in Germanic languages in his namesake law, and who also created a notable compilation of fairy tales with his brother Wilhelm.

q2.quetsion_text: Grimm's law describes the transition of voiceless stops into voiceless varieties of these consonants, which are produced by placing two articulators close together. Examples of these consonants from English include the sounds produced by the letters v and f.

q3.quetsion_text: Verner's Law, which describes apparent exceptions to Grimm's Law, only occurs when a voiced fricative immediately follows this kind of syllable.

lead_in: A section of this book categorizes works of literature according to the archetypal mythoi of Comedy, Romance, Tragedy, and Satire. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this 1957 collection of four essays, which includes a historical approach to the modes of literature and a rhetorical approach to the genres of literature.

q2.quetsion_text: Anatomy of Criticism is by Northrop Frye, who is also known for Fearful Symmetry, a study of this Romantic poet, whose poem "The Tyger" provides the title.

q3.quetsion_text: This English poet and critic characterized Blake as a rebel against Christianity in his William Blake: A Critical Essay. His Poems and Ballads includes "The Triumph of Time" and "Hymn to Proserpine".

lead_in: Answer these questions about abuses that French peasants suffered or allegedly suffered under the Ancien Regime,

q1.quetsion_text: Poor French peasants were especially burdened by the mandatory gabelle, a tax on this item. In Ghana, this item was often traded for gold.

q2.quetsion_text: While working for this "Sun King" of France, Jean-Baptiste Colbert increased the efficiency of the onerous taxation process that unfairly shifted the burden towards peasants.

q3.quetsion_text: In feudal France, this term denoted the alleged right of the manor lord to sleep with a peasant bride on her first wedding night.
q3.raw_answer: droit du seigneur [or jus primae noctis; prompt on "right of the first night"]

lead_in: This woman returned to life after Heracles defeated Thanatos in a wrestling match. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this wife of Admetus, who offered to die after the Fates offered to spare Admetus's life in exchange for the life of another person.

q2.quetsion_text: Out of all the daughters of this man, Alcestis was the only one who did not participate in his accidental killing. This king of Iolcus sent his nephew to retrieve the Golden Fleece.

q3.quetsion_text: This daughter of Aeetes and lover of Jason convinced the daughters of Pelias that they could rejuvenate him by chopping him up and throwing his remains in a boiling cauldron.

lead_in: This poem notes that the "eyes of nations" eagerly watch the "scales" of an ongoing war as "in their hopes Columbia's arm prevails" and "Anon Britannia droops the pensive head." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this poem which regales the title commander as "first in peace and honors," asking "Thy every action let the Goddess guide."

q2.quetsion_text: This female poet wrote "To His Excellency, George Washington." She rationalized her enslavement because it taught her "That there's a God" in "On Being Brought from Africa to America."

q3.quetsion_text: This later African-American author, himself a fugitive slave, addressed slavery in his novel about a mixed-race daughter of the U.S. President, Clotel. He shares most of a name with the author of The Power of Sympathy.
q3.raw_answer: William Wells Brown [or William Hill Brown]

lead_in: This quantity is equal to the enthalpy minus the entropy times temperature. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this quantity whose change is less than zero for a spontaneous reaction.

q2.quetsion_text: The equilibrium constant for a reaction is equal to the negative exponential of the Gibbs free energy at standard state divided by this two term constant.
q2.raw_answer: temperature times universal gas constant [or RT; or obvious equivalents, such as temperature times R]

q3.quetsion_text: Gibbs derived this statistical ensemble used to describe a system in contact with a heat bath, but not a particle bath.
q3.raw_answer: canonical ensemble [do not accept "grand canonical ensemble" or "microcanonical ensemble" or other wrong answers]

lead_in: Karl Barth gained fame by rejecting humanistic views of scripture in a 1916 commentary on a text that this man wrote with the help of his assistant Tertius. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this apostle from Tarsus who wrote many of the Epistles.
q1.raw_answer: Saint Paul the Apostle [or Saul of Tarsus]

q2.quetsion_text: Paul criticized this other apostle for an "incident at Antioch" in which this man refused to share a meal with Gentiles. This man was martyred on an upside-down cross, and shares a feast date with Paul.

q3.quetsion_text: The incident at Antioch is recounted in this Pauline epistle addressing adherence to the Law of Moses. This epistle to a group in central Anatolia includes the line "There is neither Jew nor Gentile, neither slave nor free."

lead_in: This novel's protagonist first encounters the title characters when he is racing to confront the Comte de Rochefort.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this novel by Alexandre Dumas in which Athos, Porthos, and Aramis join d'Artagnan in foiling the plans of Cardinal Richelieu.
q1.raw_answer: The Three Musketeers [or Les Trois Mousquetaires]

q2.quetsion_text: D'Artagnan suggests this phrase as the motto of the Musketeers. It alludes to the fact that the musketeers look out for each other in any circumstance.
q2.raw_answer: "one for all and all for one" [accept variants like "one for all, all for one"; accept conjuncts in either order]

q3.quetsion_text: D'Artagnan is constantly attempting to thwart this woman's plans. She is a spy for Cardinal Richelieu and is eventually revealed to have once been married to Athos.

lead_in: This man's rule is occasionally referred to as the second "Infamous Decade."

q1.quetsion_text: Name this man with glorious sideburns who privatized the YPF as part of his Convertibility Plan as president of Argentina during the 1990s.

q2.quetsion_text: Menem pursued the Convertibility Plan due to the occurrence of this terrible phenomenon. This phenomenon was also experienced in Peru under Alan Garcia and most famously in the Weimar Republic.

q3.quetsion_text: Menem frequently had to deal with strikes by this massive labor union in Argentina. Led throughout the Peron years by Jose Rucci, this party had supported Raul Alfonsin's UCR Party, leading to animosity with Menem's regime.
q3.raw_answer: CGT [accept General Confederation of Labor of the Argentine Republic; accept Confederacion General del Trabajo de la Republica Argentina]

lead_in: The Burji clique of these people was of Circassian origin, and an army of these people defeated the Mongols at the Battle of Ayn Jalut.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify these slaves who received extensive military training and thus formed much of the armies of Islamic empires such as the Ayyubids.
q1.raw_answer: Mamluks [or Mamluqs or Mamlukes or Mameluks or Mamelukes or Mamalukes or Marmelukes]

q2.quetsion_text: The Mamluks established a sultanate with this city as a capital. Saladin constructed a magnificent citadel in this city, which lies in the Nile Delta.

q3.quetsion_text: Mamluks led by Qutb-ud-din Aybak also formed one of the ruling dynasties of a sultanate in this city. That sultanate in this city was later ruled by the Khiljis, the Tughluqs, and the Lodis.

lead_in: Answer the following about a concept in physics that conspiracy theorists love to talk about, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This energy is required for a bound system to remain bound even at the point at which kinetic energy is zero. It is one-half h-bar times the circular frequency for a quantum harmonic oscillator.

q2.quetsion_text: Zero-point energy is often used in the explanation of this effect, in which an attractive force exists between two parallel uncharged plates in a vacuum.

q3.quetsion_text: The Casimir effect is predicted by this relativistic field theory, which interprets the interaction of charged particles as being carried out by virtual photons.

lead_in: This theory very accurately predicts the magnetic dipole moment of the electron and magnitude of the  Lamb shift. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this theory, which describes interactions between charged particles and photons. It is a  fusion of quantum mechanics and special relativity.

q2.quetsion_text: This man's work on QED won him the 1965 Nobel, along with Tomonaga and Schwinger. He is the  namesake of diagrams used to visualize interactions in QED.

q3.quetsion_text: Feynman was dismayed that this particular piece of mathematical "hocus-pocus" had to be used in  QED. Generally, this technique is used to make infinities go away.

lead_in: During an attempted coup against this man, the Air Force killed hundreds by bombing the Plaza de Mayo. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this leader who was supported by the Descamisados and was represented during the Rainbow Tour by his popular wife, Evita.

q2.quetsion_text: Peron was the president of this South American country, whose current president is Cristina Kirchner.
q2.raw_answer: Argentina [or Argentine Republic; or Republica Argentina]

q3.quetsion_text: At one of these places, right wing Peronists opened fire on left-wing Peronists in the Ezeiza massacre. A raid codenamed Operation Thunderbolt and led by Yonatan Netanyahu targeted another of these places.
q3.raw_answer: international airports [or obvious equivalents like airfields]

lead_in: This branch places special emphasis on fitra, or intuitive recognition of God and virtue, and they try to activate the six latifa as part of their spiritual development.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this mystical branch of Islam whose turuq, or schools, include the Mevlevi Order, whose sama ceremony involves whirling. Al-Ghazali defended it in The Revival of Religious Sciences.

q2.quetsion_text: This early 13th century author of The Meccan Openings and The Ringstones of the Wisdoms was called the "Great Master" of Sufism. In discussing the role of imagination, he used the concept of barzakh to describe how things simultaneously unite and divide.
q2.raw_answer: Ibn Arabi [or Abu 'Abd Allah Muhammad ibn Ali ibn Muhammad ibn al-Arabi al-Hatimi at-Ta'i]

q3.quetsion_text: Unlike other Sufi turuq, the Naqshbandi school traces its teachings back through this first Caliph, a father-in-law of Muhammad.
q3.raw_answer: Abu Bakr [or Abdullah ibn Abi Qhuhafa]

lead_in: Bonus: Her father Thiazi was killed after he kidnapped Idunn. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this wife of Njord, who was allowed to choose a husband among the gods by looking at their feet.

q2.quetsion_text: Skadi chose the god with the most beautiful feet in the hopes that it would be this god of light and beauty, but ended up with Njord instead. This god died after being struck by a mistletoe spear thrown by his brother Hodr.

q3.quetsion_text: This Norse trickster god persuaded Hodr to throw the mistletoe spear, after which he was punished by being bound to rocks while snake venom dripped on his face.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: This Indian sculptor collaborated with Cecil Balmond on ArcelorMittal Orbit and sculpted Cloud Gate for Chicago's Millennium Park.

q2.quetsion_text: Claes Oldenburg's Lipstick (Ascending) on Caterpillar Tracks is on the campus of this university. This site of two Louis Kahn art galleries has a building which was flanked by massive stylized fake trees by Robert Venturi.

q3.quetsion_text: Graffiti artist Banksy painted "We're Bored of Fish" in the penguin enclosure of this city's zoo. Kapoor's ArcelorMittal Orbit was created for its 2012 Summer Olympics.

lead_in: Federalist 39 evaluates whether the proposed Constitution adheres to this concept.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this concept, which that paper defines as "a government which derives all its powers directly or indirectly from the great body of the people, and is administered by persons holding their offices during pleasure, for a limited period, or during good behavior."

q2.quetsion_text: Federalist 10 defines this concept as "a number of citizens...who are united and actuated by some common impulse of passion, or of interest, adverse to the rights of other citizens."
q2.raw_answer: faction [or, I suppose, equivalent word forms like factions or factionalism]

q3.quetsion_text: In Federalist 10, the dangers of faction are used to argue in favor of this position, which would create "a greater variety of parties" and thereby prevent "factious combinations." Federalist 14 deals with opposition to this position.
q3.raw_answer: that the United States be a large country [or that it have a large population or a large territory; accept equivalent descriptions including "that the US should not split into more than one country," ]

lead_in: Its borough of Steglitz-Zehlendorf contains two bodies of water known as the greater and lesser Wannsees. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this German capital city that contains the locality of Spandau and the Brandenburg Gate.

q2.quetsion_text: To the southeast of Berlin is this capital of the state of Brandenburg that once served as the official seat of the Kaiser. A namesake declaration from this city called for Japan's unconditional surrender.

q3.quetsion_text: Both Potsdam and the Greater and Lesser Wannsees are accessible via this light rail system. It serves all of Berlin and many of its suburbs, and is not to be confused with the U-Bahn.

lead_in: Bonus: He designed the TWA Flight Center terminal for New York City’s JFK International Airport. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this architect of the Kresge Auditorium at MIT and designer of the Tulip Chair.

q2.quetsion_text: Eero Saarinen is perhaps best-known for designing the Gateway Arch to this Midwestern city.

q3.quetsion_text: Saarinen served in the jury overseeing the construction of this building, which was designed by Jørn Utzon and consists of several white sail-shaped shells.

lead_in: The anthropologist Ruth Behar's first book concerns the peasantry in a village in this European country, where a "web of use rights" survived the formal disentailment that caused recurrent civil strife during the 19th century.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this country, where Julian Pitt-Rivers did fieldwork for The People of the Sierra.

q2.quetsion_text: Pitt-Rivers argued that this Spanish pastime linked a well-defined, millenia-spanning Mediterranean culture dating back at least to ancient Crete.

q3.quetsion_text: Julian Pitt-Rivers was the great-grandson of the founder of the Pitt-Rivers Museum in Oxford, which contains an exhibit of these controversial objects. These objects, all of which come from Jivaroan tribes in the western Amazon, were supposed to force a beaten enemy's spirit into service.

lead_in: This composer's six Opus 20 string quartets helped define the Classical notion of the string quartet.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Austrian composer, whose twelve "London" Symphonies include symphonies nicknamed "Clock" and "Surprise".

q2.quetsion_text: This last complete set of string quartets by Haydn include the "Fifths" Quartet and the "Emperor" Quartet. The opening motif of the fourth of these is sometimes called the "sunrise" motif.
q2.raw_answer: "ErdÃ¶dy" String Quartets, Op. 76 [accept either underlined portion]

q3.quetsion_text: The melody of the second movement of Haydn's "Emperor" Quartet was later used as one of these pieces. Alexander Alexandrov, Claude Joseph Rouget de Lisle, and John Stafford Smith are best known for pieces of this kind.
q3.raw_answer: national anthem [accept clear equivalents like "national hymn" or "national song"]

lead_in: Two answers required. Irving Lorge found that students agreed with the phrase "a little rebellion, now and then, is a good thing" when attributed to a leader of one of these countries, but opposed it when attributed to a leader from the other country. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these two countries. Solomon Asch criticized Lorge's study by suggesting that students viewed the phrase as having different meanings when said by leaders of either of these countries.
q1.raw_answer: the United States of America AND the Soviet Union [or equivalent answers like "the USA and the USSR"; prompt on "Russia" in place of the Soviet Union; the two leaders referred to were  Thomas Jefferson and Vladimir Lenin]

q2.quetsion_text: Solomon Asch is best known for his experiments on this phenomenon. Asch found that people modified their judgment of the length of a line when a group of confederates all shared another opinion.

q3.quetsion_text: An earlier study on conformity utilizing peoples' judgment of the autokinetic effect was conducted by this psychologist. This man also conducted the Robbers' Cave experiment.

lead_in: The Angevins maintained a claim on the throne of this kingdom, prompting Charles VIII to invade after the death of its ruler, Don Ferrante.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this kingdom, whose de jure suzerainty was recognized in the Treaty of Gaeta by Skanderbeg in return for support against the Ottomans. Its ruler, Frederick IV, was succeeded by a ruler from the house of TrastÃ¡mara.
q1.raw_answer: Kingdom of Naples [or Regno di Napoli; accept other names for Naples like Neapolis]

q2.quetsion_text: Skanderbeg was a Kastrioti nobleman from this modern-day Balkan nation.

q3.quetsion_text: Skanderbeg formed this alliance of Albanian principalities in 1444 against the Ottoman Empire. This alliance had its capital in a namesake city, and it is typically considered the first unified Albanian state.
q3.raw_answer: League of LezhÃ« [accept similar answers; accept Lidhja e LezhÃ«s; accept generalis consilium since "League of Lezhe" is a term invented by later historians]

lead_in: This quantity can be calculated as the square of the momentum divided by twice the mass. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this type of energy that an object possesses due to its motion. For a non-rotating object this quantity can be calculated as one half mass times velocity squared.

q2.quetsion_text: This operator in classical mechanics is equal to the sum of kinetic energy and potential energy.

q3.quetsion_text: This man names a theorem in Hamiltonian mechanics which states that the density of particles in phase-space is a constant. This French mathematician also proved that every bounded, entire complex function is constant.

lead_in: Ann Leckie won this prize and the Nebula Award in 2014.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this award that is given to the best science fiction or fantasy novel of the year.

q2.quetsion_text: This writer's The Dispossessed won the award in 1975. Another work set in the Hainish Universe by this child of anthropologist Alfred Kroeber is The Left Hand of Darkness.

q3.quetsion_text: This writer was one of the two recipients who won the Hugo Award in 1993 for his novel about the four Zones of Thought A Fire Upon the Deep. His wife Joan has also won the Hugo for The Snow Queen.

lead_in: This denomination includes the House for All Sinners and Saints founded by emerging church pastor Nadia Bolz-Weber, and in 2013, Guy Erwin was chosen as its first openly gay bishop.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this largest Lutheran denomination in the United States. This church is less conservative than both the Missouri Synod and the Wisconsin Synod.
q1.raw_answer: Evangelical Lutheran Church in America [or ELCA]

q2.quetsion_text: e Evangelical Lutheran Church accepts the unaltered version of this document, which was written by Philipp Melanchthon after Martin Luther was banned from accepting Charles V's invitation. Its 28 articles include salvation by faith alone.

q3.quetsion_text: Of course, the Evangelical Lutheran Church accepts the sacramental union, the Lutheran version of this doctrine which states that Jesus Christ is actually in sacramental bread and wine, not just metaphorically.
q3.raw_answer: Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist

lead_in: Bonus: For ten points each, answer the following about unusual assassinations:

q1.quetsion_text: The KGB assassinated the dissident Georgi Markov by shooting a pellet of this poison with an umbrella. In April 2013, a man from Mississippi mailed letters containing this poison to Barack Obama and Roger Wicker.

q2.quetsion_text: This Russian mystic and advisor to Nicholas II did not eat the cyanide-laced cakes that he was given, so he was then shot and thrown into a river. According to legend, he died by drowning and hypothermia.

q3.quetsion_text: The 210 isotope of this radioactive metal was used to poison the former FSB agent Alexander Litvinenko in 2006.

lead_in: This man credited Thomas Hobbes and Robert Boyle with creating the modernist outlook that separates society and nature in We Have Never Been Modern.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this man, whose first major field work was conducted with Steve Woolgar at the Salk Institute.

q2.quetsion_text: Latour and Woolgar observed this process happening at the Salk Institute. A 1987 Latour work about it "in action" stresses the social aspect over more abstract criteria like falsifiability.

q3.quetsion_text: Another sociologist of science, Robert Merton, wrote a very weird book about this five-word phrase. R.W. Southern uses this phrase to describe the conception medieval cathedral schools had about their relationship with antiquity.

lead_in: This equation contains an exponential term multiplied by a frequency factor, denoted A.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this equation developed by a Swedish chemist that calculates an equation's rate constant based on its frequency factor, activation energy, and temperature.

q2.quetsion_text: The potential energy of the reactant-product system is at a maximum when the reaction is in this state.

q3.quetsion_text: Consider the reaction A plus B forms C. If doubling the concentration of A doubles the reaction rate and changing the concentration of B has no effect, what is the order of the reaction?

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this set of approximation schemes that is used to derive the state of a system following a minor disturbance to an exactly-soluble system.

q2.quetsion_text: Perturbation theory must be handled with care when it is used on states that have this property. Two states have this property if they have the same energy.

q3.quetsion_text: One way of lifting degeneracy of atomic states is by applying a magnetic field, which causes this effect in which the energy levels of states with different angular momenta are split.

q1.quetsion_text: Weaver translated Baudolino, Foucault's Pendulum, The Name of the Rose, and many other works by this author.

q2.quetsion_text: Weaver translated The Monkey's Wrench, this author's novel about the rigger Libertino Faussone. He also translated this author's novel about Mendel Dajcher's participation in the resistance movement, If Not Now, When?

q3.quetsion_text: Weaver translated A Man, a novel based on this journalist's  relationship with Alexandros Panagoulis. She is better known for her interviews, many of which are collected in Interviews with History, and for her criticism of Islam.

lead_in: Bonus: This god gave Midas the golden touch. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Greek god of wine, whose female followers were known as maenads.

q2.quetsion_text: This mother of Dionysus was killed when she persuaded Zeus to show himself in his full glory. Dionysus later retrieved her from Hades, after which she became a goddess on Olympus.

q3.quetsion_text: In his youth, Dionysus turned some pirates into these animals after they kidnapped him and attempted to sell him into slavery. These animals also saved the life of the legendary musician Arion after he jumped from his ship.

lead_in: This novel ends with a description of Greta stretching her lithe and young body. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this novel in which Gregor Samsa wakes up to find himself transformed into a bug.

q2.quetsion_text: This German expressionist author of The Metamorphosis and The Trial wrote about suffering as art and entertainment in "A Hunger Artist".

q3.quetsion_text: This American postmodernist writer of Brief Interviews with Hideous Men explored Kafka's puns in "Laughing with Kafka". He also wrote the heavily-footnoted novel Infinite Jest.

lead_in: This device was technically invented by Hero of Alexandria two thousand years ago, though the aeliopile had no practical usage.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this device, which was refined by Thomas Savery and first used by Thomas Newcomen to pump water out of mines.

q2.quetsion_text: This process transformed many of England's open grazing fields into private plots of land during the sixteenth through eighteenth centuries, and put many farmers out of work.

q3.quetsion_text: The introduction of the steam engine for use in factories and the increased labor supply brought by the enclosures helped usher in this revolution in Britain.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name these false revelations which allegedly allowed Muslims to seek the intercession of pagan deities likened to "high-flying cranes." These passages are no longer in the Qur'an.

q2.quetsion_text: Sura 53, which the "Satanic verses" affected, is named for one of these objects. A poisonous one named Wormwood falls in the book of Revelation. Mormons believe one of these named Kolob is physically close to God.
q2.raw_answer: stars [or Surat al-Najm; do not accept "planets"]

q3.quetsion_text: Name any one of the three pagan goddesses mentioned in the Satanic Verses, who were worshipped along with the male god Hubal by pre-Islamic Arabs.

lead_in: This writer claimed that Johann George Hamman was the first to understand human cognition as a linguistic rather than purely rationalist process in his Three Critics of the Enlightenment.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this historian of ideas who divided thinkers into those whose worldviews are defined by a single idea and those whose worldviews aren't in his The Hedgehog and the Fox.

q2.quetsion_text: This founder of the "Cambridge School" of historiography and author of The Foundations of Modern Political Thought built on Berlin's concept of "negative liberty" in attempting to define the "neo-Roman" concept of liberty, as understood by Renaissance and Reformation thinkers such as Machiavelli.

q3.quetsion_text: This historian of ideas criticized contemporary America's approach to intellectualism in his The House of Intellect. He chronicled the history of Western culture from 1500 to the present in his From Dawn to Decadence.

lead_in: The third of these states that the square of the orbital period is proportional to the cube of the orbit's semi-major axis.

q1.quetsion_text: Name these laws formulated by a German astronomer to describe the movement of bodies in the solar system, the first of which states that the orbits are ellipses with the Sun at one focus.
q1.raw_answer: Johannes Kepler's laws of planetary motion [accept either underlined part]

q2.quetsion_text: Kepler's laws of planetary motion supported this model of the universe, in which the earth revolved around the sun, which was the center of the universe.

q3.quetsion_text: This Danish astronomer combined the Copernican and Ptolemaic models of the universe to form a model in which the earth is the center of the universe, but the planets move around the sun.
q3.raw_answer: Tycho Brahe [accept either underlined name; or Tyge Ottesen Brahe]

lead_in: One of this band's founders, Brian Jones, was dismissed from the band in 1969 and died shortly after.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this British rock band, which takes its name from a song by Muddy Waters. Mick Jagger leads this band, whose songs include "Sympathy for the Devil."

q2.quetsion_text: This band from Boston, led by Steven Tyler, hit it big with their 1975 album Toys in the Attic. That album features the song "Walk This Way," which was later covered by Run-D.M.C.

q3.quetsion_text: This British-American band's 1977 debut album featured "Feels Like the First Time" and "Cold As Ice." Their only U.S. #1 hit was the 1984 song "I Want to Know What Love Is."

lead_in: Derivatives of this compound are commonly synthesized using EAS-type reactions. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this aromatic molecule with formula C6H6. Its structure originally came to Kekule in a dream and nowadays it's commonly notated by a circle inside a hexagon.

q2.quetsion_text: Fusing benzene rings together end to end in various ways creates this class of molecules, which includes naphthalene, pyrene, and phenanthrene. They are commonly found in fossil fuel deposits.

q3.quetsion_text: In electrophilic aromatic substitution reactions, sulfonation is used to block this position on the ring, which allows selective ortho substitution.

lead_in: One of the title characters of this novel uses a wish to liberate a woman cursed to wake up every day next to the handkerchief that was used to suffocate her child.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this novel in which the other title character pens a manuscript on Pontius Pilate.

q2.quetsion_text: This vodka-loving demonic black cat is part of the demented retinue of Woland in The Master and Margarita. In a hilarious scene, he beheads Bengalsky and reattaches his head as part of an act for the crowd.

q3.quetsion_text: This Russian novelist wrote The Master and Margarita and The White Guard.

lead_in: This book's protagonist forms a band called Kafkatrakterne with his brother, with whom he later travels to their father's apartment after their father drinks himself to death.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this sensational and much-lauded autobiographical work in six volumes by Karl Ove Knausgaard, published from 2009 to 2011.

q2.quetsion_text: Knausgaard is from this European country. Immigrants to America from this country are the subject of Giants of the Earth.

q3.quetsion_text: My Struggle is titled after a work by this German politician, who is the subject of a 400-page essay in its final book. Jack Gladney studies this man in White Noise.

lead_in: Two notable commentators of this work were Rouge Inkstone and Odd Tablet. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this novel by Cao Xueqin, which chronicles the two branches of the Jia family. The  protagonist Jia Baoyu ends up marrying Xue Baochai, causing the sickly Lin Daiyu to die of grief.
q1.raw_answer: The Dream of the Red Chamber [or Hong Lou Meng; or The Story of the Stone; or Shitou  Ji]

q2.quetsion_text: The Dream of the Red Chamber is framed as a story of this stone, which begs a priest and a monk to  return it to the world after it goes unused in repairing the Dome of Heaven. Baoyu is born with this stone  glowing in his mouth.

q3.quetsion_text: The Jia family builds one of these locations named for its "Grand View" when their daughter First  Spring becomes an Imperial concubine. Later in the novel, that structure symbolically falls to ruin.

lead_in: Answer the following about the bloodier aspects of the Civil War, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: 5600 men lay dead across along the 800-yard long "Bloody Lane" of this 1862 battle.

q2.quetsion_text: Although the adjectives of the Bloody Pond and Sunken Road from this other 1862 battle may be inaccurate, a ton of people, such as Albert Sidney Johnston, still died here.
q2.raw_answer: Battle of Shiloh [or Battle of Pittsburg Landing]

q3.quetsion_text: This member of Quantrill's Raiders, a Confederate guerrilla known as "Bloody Bill," ordered the execution and scalping of twenty-three unarmed Union soldiers in the Centralia Massacre.

lead_in: One painting by this artist sees two men surrounding a mound of dirt while a woman in white holds a sapling. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this artist of Arbor Day who also depicted a woman in green showing her chicken to a finely dressed woman in the painting Appraisal.

q2.quetsion_text: Wood is most famous for this painting of a pitchfork-wielding farmer and his daughter standing in front of a barn.

q3.quetsion_text: Wood's painting Daughters of Revolution depicts three women standing in front of this painting by Emanuel Leutze, in which a lieutenant carries a billowing American flag.

lead_in: Calomiris and Pritchett used data from these institutions to construct an index of political risk, and Walter Johnson argued that a price surge in them in the late 1850s reflected precautionary hoarding in his book Soul by Soul.

q1.quetsion_text: What are these institutions, whose pricing dynamics other scholars have explained with reference to perceptions about the promise of cotton-growing innovation?
q1.raw_answer: slave markets [accept alternatives: "slave auctions," for example, though the data referenced isn't from auctions per se.]

q2.quetsion_text: The slave-trading firm of Franklin & Armfield conducted its northern, exporting operations in this municipality, the usual trans-shipment point for slaves sent to the Lower South.

q3.quetsion_text: F&A had its southern offices in Natchez, Mississippi and this other municipality, by far the largest slave market in the US. Antoine Dubuclet was a sugar plantation-owner and leader of the black aristocracy in this city.

lead_in: For 10 points each, name some things associated with pillars of Islam.

q1.quetsion_text: This pillar of Islam, which takes place during the last month of the Islamic calendar, is a ritual pilgrimage to Mecca.

q2.quetsion_text: This other pillar of Islam involves giving alms to the poor and needy. Its non-Muslim equivalent is the Jizyah tax.

q3.quetsion_text: By not declaring that Allah is the only god, one would be failing to uphold the pillar Shahadah and committing this sin. This sin also encompasses idolatry and polytheism, in general.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this son of Simon who was reminded of his youth by a dog carcass rolling in the surf. While studying to become a priest, he drew ire for not signing a petition for world peace.

q2.quetsion_text: Stephen Dedalus was created by this author of Finnegan's Wake and Dubliners.

q3.quetsion_text: In this novel, Stephen is a schoolteacher who pals around with Buck Mulligan. At one point, he flashed back to when he refused to pray for his mother on her deathbed.

lead_in: This leader ended Balcha Safo's revolt by getting him drunk at a feast and bribing his soldiers. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this emperor revered as a messiah by Rastafarians. He was deposed by Italy's 1935 invasion of his country.
q1.raw_answer: Haile Selassie I [or Tafari Makonnen Woldemikael]

q2.quetsion_text: Haile Selassie ruled this African country. Once home to the Christian Axumite kingdom, this country's current capital, Addis Ababa, was founded by Menelik II.

q3.quetsion_text: This emperor ruled Ethiopia between 1889 and 1913. He rejected the terms of the Treaty of Wuchale, after which his forces defeated those of Italian General Baratieri at Adowa in 1896.
q3.raw_answer: Menelik II [prompt on "Menelik"; accept Sahle Maryam]

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this class of processes by means of which carbon dioxide is removed from the atmosphere and stored in some sort of reservoir.
q1.raw_answer: carbon capture and sequestration [or word forms; prompt on "(carbon) capture"]

q2.quetsion_text: One way of achieving carbon sequestration is by seeding the ocean with this metal, which promotes the growth of carbon dioxide-consuming phytoplankton.

q3.quetsion_text: Iron fertilization of the ocean may help prevent this process, which occurs when atmospheric carbon dioxide dissolves, forming bicarbonate. This process has already resulted in significant coral bleaching in some areas.
q3.raw_answer: ocean acidification [or word forms; or anything that refers to the ocean becoming more acidic]

lead_in: This kind of material consists of atoms in two different phases of matter: liquid and BoseEinstein condensate. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this type of material first discovered by Heike Kammerlingh Onnes

q2.quetsion_text: Kammerlingh Onnes first discovered superfluidity in the liquid form of this element, whose 3 and 4 isotopes have, respectively, one and two neutrons.

q3.quetsion_text: At the lambda point, there is a discontinuity in the graph of this quantity vs. temperature. The lambda point is so named because of the shape when this quantity is plotted vs. temperature.
q3.raw_answer: heat capacity [or specific heat capacity; or thermal capacity]

lead_in: The prices of these things were so insane that some sold for the value of 10 years' labor from a skilled craftsman in 1637. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these items, which caused what is generally considered the first speculative bubble in modern history when their prices reached astronomical levels and then collapsed in the Early Modern Netherlands.
q1.raw_answer: tulips [or tulip bulbs; or Tulipa; prompt on "bulbs"]

q2.quetsion_text: Tulips became a fad in Europe after an ambassador to this empire's ruler, Suleiman the Magnificent, brought them back to Ferdinand I of the Holy Roman Empire.
q2.raw_answer: Ottoman Empire [or Turkish Empire; or Turkey; or Osmanli Imparatorlugu]

q3.quetsion_text: This journalist discussed tulipmania, alchemy, and Nostradamus in Volume I of his book, Extraordinary Popular Delusions and the Madness of Crowds.

lead_in: Rock songs often have great organ parts. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: This song, which begins with a distinctive organ solo by Ray Manzarek, was the biggest hit for The Doors.

q2.quetsion_text: This Beatles song prominently features organist Billy Preston. The first verse of this song is about a man named Jojo who "thought he was a loner" and "left his home in Tucson, Arizona for some California grass."

q3.quetsion_text: This band included massive organ riffs in the song "Intervention" on their 2007 album Neon Bible. In 2014, this Canadian band released the album Reflektor, produced by former LCD Soundsystem frontman James Murphy.

lead_in: In this place, it is Sunday seven days a week, clover is in season all year round, and linseed cake grows on hedges.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this locale which is up in the clouds. Moses the raven, an old pet of Mr. Jones, talks frequently about this locale without working, much to the chagrin of the pigs.

q2.quetsion_text: Tales of Sugarcandy Mountain distract the barnyard creatures in this George Orwell novella, an allegory for Stalinism.

q3.quetsion_text: A plan to build one of these machines to ease the animals' labor leads Napoleon to chase his pig rival Snowball from Animal Farm with dogs.

lead_in: Organophosphate pesticides inhibit this enzyme, which can be re-activated by pralidoxime. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this protein found in a post-synaptic membrane that is responsible for cleaving a neurotransmitter in the neuromuscular junction. This enzyme is notably inhibited by several different chemical weapons.
q1.raw_answer: acetylcholinesterase [or AchE; do not accept "ACh" or "acetylcholine"]

q2.quetsion_text: Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors are often used to treat this autoimmune disease which targets acetylcholine receptors in the neuromuscular junction.

q3.quetsion_text: A disease similar to myasthenia gravis, called Lambert-Eaton syndrome, targets voltagegated channels that conduct this element. The plus-two ion of this element is stored in the sarcoplasmic reticulum and is responsible for activating protein kinase C.

lead_in: In one of this author's stories, a monk places a sign in front of a lake that says a dragon will rise up from it on the third day of the third month.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Japanese author of many short stories, such as "The Nose" and "Rashomon"

q2.quetsion_text: The Lord of Horikawa commissions the title artwork from Yoshihide in this Akutagawa story, which ends with Yoshihide's suicide after Horikawa has Yoshihide's daughter burned alive to inspire him.

q3.quetsion_text: This other Japanese writer appears on the 5,000 yen note. She died at the age of 24 and authored a total of 21 stories, such as "The Thirteenth Night," about a woman who escapes from her abusive marriage and "Flowers at Dusk"

lead_in: This war included the first and only helicopter-to-helicopter dogfights ever and the gassing of Kurds at Halabja. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this 1980-88 war that had many operations called Dawn and Karbala. It was fought between two namesake Persian Gulf states led by the Ayatollah Khomeini and Saddam Hussein.
q1.raw_answer: Iran-Iraq War [or First Persian Gulf War; or Persian/Arabic translations; prompt on "Persian Gulf War"]

q2.quetsion_text: The Iranian embassy in this city was occupied by the Iraqi-backed DRFLA in 1980 before they were ejected by special forces. This city also suffered bombings later in the 90s at Bishopsgate and the Canary Wharf.

q3.quetsion_text: The DRFLA, or the Democratic Revolutionary Front for the Liberation of Arabistan, sought independence for this oil-rich Southwestern province of Iran.

lead_in: Kill da wabbit, kill da wabbit! For 10 points, answer the following questions related to a certain piece of music.

q1.quetsion_text: This excerpt from The Ring of the Nibelung opera cycle is particularly notable for its use of low brass in its main melody. It was popularized in the film Apocalypse Now.
q1.raw_answer: "The Ride of the Valkyries" [or Ritt der WalkÃ¼ren]

q2.quetsion_text: This German composer of The Valkyrie scored his namesake instrument in "The Ride of the Valkyries." He also wrote the opera TannhÃ¤user and is noted for the prelude to his Tristan und Isolde.

q3.quetsion_text: Wagner also wrote this opera about the son of Parzival, which is best known for its Bridal Chorus in Act III.

lead_in: These constructs are entirely described by a matrix whose entries are all non-negative, which is the transition matrix. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these constructs that consist of a series of states and a bunch of transition probabilities between those states. Processes described by these constructs are memoryless.

q2.quetsion_text: These states in a Markov chain are inescapable. For example, when modelling gambling, the state where you run out of money is one of them.

q3.quetsion_text: Markov chains describe Markov processes with this property, rather than continuous processes. Data of this type is counted as distinct and separate rather than measured.

lead_in: The so-called "Era of Good Feelings" was really anything but, as natural political disagreement found no organizing principle in the absence of formal parties.

q1.quetsion_text: This Supreme Court case established the battle lines for future conflict over the role of the federal government. It held that Congress had implied powers to regulate interstate commerce that states could not impede, in this case by taxing bank notes.

q2.quetsion_text: This man managed to serve as Attorney General for all of Monroe's two terms, and he split with the Democrats thereafter. He represented the Cherokee in Worcester v. Georgia, successfully but to little avail.

q3.quetsion_text: This man, Monroe's Secretary of the Treasury, would have been the consensus Democratic-Republican candidate in 1824, but he had a stroke in 1822 and by the time he'd recovered, the party had effectively splintered.

lead_in: This country's avant-garde art movements at the beginning of the 20th century included the Suprematists. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this country, home to painters like Kazimir Malevich, El Lissitsky, Varvara Stepanova, and Liubov Popova.
q1.raw_answer: Russia [accept Soviet Union or USSR, since many of these people were active when that was a thing; accept any obvious equivalents]

q2.quetsion_text: Malevich was a pioneer of paintings with this quality, especially in his works named after geometric shapes. Yves Klein's paintings featuring IKB almost always had this feature.
q2.raw_answer: monochrome [accept word forms and equivalents like "it only has one color"]

q3.quetsion_text: For instance, Malevich created a painting called "[this color] on [this color]." Whistler created a portrait of Joanna Hiffernan standing on a wolf skin called "Symphony in [this color]" or "the [this color] girl."

lead_in: This psychologist developed "puzzle boxes" to test whether animals could learn from trial and error. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this man, sometimes called the father of educational psychology, who formulated a "law of effect."

q2.quetsion_text: This man created a namesake "taxonomy" of educational objectives that lists knowledge as the bottom tier, and evaluation and synthesis on the top tier.

q3.quetsion_text: Besides researching how people learn, educational psychologists also are interested in measurement of this concept, whose "quotient" is purportedly measured by the Stanford-Binet and Wechsler tests.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this substance-specific quantity used in Lee-Kesler generalized correlations for virial coefficients. The SRK and PR equations of state include this quantity, which is normally symbolized omega, and is 0 for ideal gases.

q2.quetsion_text: The reduced temperature is equal to the temperature divided by the temperature of this state. Fluids beyond this point no longer can exist in multiple phases.

q3.quetsion_text: Generalized correlations are used to calculate this quantity, which is equal to an infinite power series for pressure by the virial equation. It equals PV over RT, and is 1 for ideal gases.
q3.raw_answer: compressibility factor [or compression factor ;or Z; prompt on partial answer]

lead_in: This essay opens with a brief overview of the approach to science taken by such figures as Bacon, Kepler, and Darwin.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this essay which ends with a comparison of the methods of "tenacity" and "authority" with the scientific method, suggesting the last of these as the best way of achieving the title overcoming of doubt.

q2.quetsion_text: "The Fixation of Belief" is by this American pragmatist polymathic philosopher and semiotician, who also wrote "How to Make Our Ideas Clear".

q3.quetsion_text: Peirce's semiotics divides signs into three classes: icons, which resemble their object; symbols, which are connected to their object only through convention; and these signs, which are connected to their object by existential or physical connection.

lead_in: The left-hand side of the time-independent form of this equation is just E times psi.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this differential equation, which describes a system's wavefunction. Its namesake also came up with a thought experiment involving a cat in a box.

q2.quetsion_text: Because the electron-electron interaction adds a term to the Hamiltonian in this system, its Schrodinger equation has no closed-form solution. This is the smallest neutrally-charged system for which the Bohr model fails.

q3.quetsion_text: Harold Jeffreys is sometimes also credited in this approximation to solve linear PDEs, such as the time-independent SchrÃ¶dinger equation. It sets the function equal to the exponential of an asymptotic series denoted phi.

lead_in: The Lake Poets were a part of this movement. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this 19th-century artistic movement that reacted to the Industrial Revolution by advocating a return to nature and spontaneous imagination. Its British members include Lord Byron and the Shelleys.

q2.quetsion_text: A motif in Romantic literature is this time, representing a pre-societal innocence, wonder, and intimacy with nature. The speaker of Wordsworth's "Ode: Intimations of Immortality" recollects his experience during this time.

q3.quetsion_text: Romantics cast this Greek figure as an archetypal hero tragically trying to save humanity. Mary Shelley portrayed Frankenstein as a modern version, while Percy described his unbound mercy stripping Jupiter's power.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this type of constraint that can be written as a function only of generalized coordinates, possibly with explicit time dependence.

q2.quetsion_text: For holonomic systems, the equations of motion can be derived using this man's principle of stationary action. He also names a function that is the Legendre transform of the Lagrangian and is equal to total energy in many simple cases.

q3.quetsion_text: In the quantum-mechanical Hamiltonian for a free particle in three dimensions, the kinetic energy operator is proportional to this second-order differential operator. Loosely speaking, it measures local deviations from an average value.
q3.raw_answer: Laplacian [or Laplace operator; or del squared; or del dot del; or div grad]

lead_in: During this period, the cell increases its number of mitochondria and ribosomes to prepare for cell division.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this phase of the cell cycle that occurs after DNA replication. DNA damage can cause cells to be arrested in this stage.
q1.raw_answer: G2 phase [or G2 stage; prompt on "interphase"]

q2.quetsion_text: Cells cannot exit the G2 phase to enter mitosis without this protein complex, a heterodimer of CDK1 and cyclin B.

q3.quetsion_text: MPF was originally discovered in this allotetraploid organism with a large brood size known for the ease at which its embryo stage can be manipulated for research.
q3.raw_answer: Xenopus laevis [accept Xenopus tropicalis; prompt on "frog"]

lead_in: This member of the Royal Academy painted a pair of landscapes titled The Harvest Wagon.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this painter of a portrait of Mrs. Richard Brinsley Sheridan, as well as Mr. and Mrs. Andrews.

q2.quetsion_text: Gainsborough also created this painting, which is possibly of Jonathan Buttall. Its subject stands in a suit of the title color and holds a black hat next to his side.

q3.quetsion_text: Gainsborough had a feud with this other painter, who was the president of the Royal Academy at the time. His paintings include Sarah Siddons as the Tragic Muse.

lead_in: This novel begins with Toni and Brenda agreeing to help the main character get back on his feet in Utah. For 10points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this novel in which Nicole Baker has a brief affair with Gary Gilmore, a man who murders two men and then demands his death penalty be delivered as soon as possible.

q2.quetsion_text: This author won a Pulitzer for The Executioner's Song and wrote about officers in the Vietnam War in The Naked and the Dead.

q3.quetsion_text: This essay by Mailer, which was eventually collected in Advertisements for Myself, describes the title figure as a "philosophical psychopath," because of his adoption of vernacular and music of another culture.
q3.raw_answer: "The White Negro: Superficial Reflections on the Hipster"

lead_in: The speaker of this poem attacks the rich man's "loads of freighted ore" by claiming, "This wealth is but a name / That leaves with useful products still the same" before concluding, "The country blooms a garden and a grave."

q1.quetsion_text: Name this poem that describes "those poisonous fields with rank luxuriance crowned." The speaker of this poem laments, "Amidst thy bowers the tyrant's hand is seen" and "trade's proud empire hastes to swift decay."

q2.quetsion_text: "The Deserted Village" is an attack on the enclosure movement by this author, who compared the problems of various nations in The Traveller. He also wrote The Vicar of Wakefield and She Stoops to Conquer.

q3.quetsion_text: The title She Stoops to Conquer was possibly inspired by the lines "Despise the man that lays a Tyrant's Claim / To what he ought to conquer by submission" from this Restoration comedy by Aphra Behn, in which Willmore and his gang of Englishmen visit Naples for Carnival.

lead_in: This poem cycles around the image of a snaking river arriving forever. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Spanish-language poem whose 584 lines parallel 584 days in the Aztec calendar. It opens by invoking "willow of crystal, a poplar of water / a pillar of fountain by the wind drawn over".

q2.quetsion_text: This Nobel-winning poet of "Sunstone" drew on his diplomatic experience to author The Bow and the Lyre and a novel that follows Hanuman, The Monkey Grammarian.

q3.quetsion_text: Paz's The Labyrinth of Solitude discusses the "invisible history" and machismo of this home country of Paz's. Esperanza leads an easy and wealthy life in this country before her father's death in Esperanza Rising.

lead_in: Answer some questions about bits of the Jewish prayer service for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This prayer, one kind of which is said by mourners, is used to split up sections of a prayer service. It needs 10 Jewish adults present to be said.

q2.quetsion_text: This prayer, traditionally said twice a day, is a restatement of three passages from the Bible, starting with "Hear O Israel, the LORD is God, the LORD is one." Along with the Amidah, it is one of the central prayers in Judaism.

q3.quetsion_text: The Kol Nidre prayer is said during this Jewish Day of Atonement, which occurs during the month of Tishrei.

lead_in: According to one model, these proteins became widespread due to their utility in catalyzing anabolic reactions in hydrothermal vents.

q1.quetsion_text: Name these proteins that include HiPIP electron shuttles. The scaffold IscU and an enzyme that converts cysteine to alanine are required for the assembly of these proteins, which often contain FCL motifs.
q1.raw_answer: iron-sulfur proteins/clusters [or Fe-S proteins/clusters; antiprompt on specific iron-sulfur proteins such as Rieske proteins or the infamous aconitase]

q2.quetsion_text: Iron is also found in this thermodynamically unstable mineral that is formed by the anaerobic corrosion of iron in the hydrogen-evolving Schikorr reaction. This mixed-valence compound coats steel in the "bluing" process.
q2.raw_answer: magnetite [or Fe3O4 or equivalents; or ferrous-ferric oxide; or iron(II, III) oxide; or Fe(II, III) oxide; prompt on iron oxides; do not accept Magnemite, which is a PokÃ©mon]

q3.quetsion_text: In an alternative to the magnetite model of magnetoception, these molecules are formed from cryptochromes. Fishhook arrows represent the flow of unpaired electrons in reactions of these molecules.

lead_in: Bonus: This woman is “the best singer in Tasmania with teeth” and has “wrestled crocodiles and dingoes simultaneously.” For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this character portrayed by Rebel Wilson who screams, “I’ve been shot” after getting hit by flying Mexican food. She also specializes in “mermaid dancing” and “horizontal running.”

q2.quetsion_text: Fat Amy is a character from this movie featuring an a cappella competition between the Treblemakers and the Barden Bellas, who are trying to regain popularity after senior member Aubrey Posen vomited on stage.
