q1.quetsion_text: Name this Eastern European capital city that during World War II was the site of a 1943 Ghetto Uprising and a 1944 uprising led by Bor-Komorowski.

q2.quetsion_text: During the uprisings, these places were used by resistance fighters to get around the city unseen. In Lviv, Leopold Socha used these places to hide a group of twenty-one Jews.
q2.raw_answer: sewers [prompt on "tunnels" or answers related to being underground]

q3.quetsion_text: This young man likely committed suicide to avoid capture in 1943 after he organized the Jewish Fighting Organization and led the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising.

lead_in: A popular technique in this field of chemistry is the "temperature jump", in which a capacitor is discharged in a conducting solution. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this field of study in chemistry pioneered by Gulberg and Waage with their law of mass action, and furthered by the equations of Eyring and Arrhenius.

q2.quetsion_text: Kinetics concerns itself with the laws governing this property of a reaction, a measure of how fast it is.

q3.quetsion_text: In reactions of this type, the rate is wholly dependent on the ability of the reactants to traverse the solvent and run into one another. An example is the conversion of CO2 and H2O into H2CO3, catalyzed by carbonic anhydrase.

lead_in: The storage and loss moduli describe this type of system and are respectively proportional to cosine and sine of the phase difference between stress and strain.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this property of a material to exhibit characteristics of both liquids and solids when exposed to different deformation rates.

q2.quetsion_text: This model for viscoelasticity is modeled by a Newtonian damper and a Hookean elastic spring connected in series. Its namesake also has a set of equations that relate mixed partials of thermodynamic quantities.

q3.quetsion_text: This measure of stiffness applies to strictly elastic materials and is defined as the ratio of the stress to the strain.

lead_in: This woman was once accused of adultery when she left her caravan to search for a missing necklace. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this last wife of the Prophet Muhammad who, at age 18, commanded troops on the losing side of the Battle of the Camel.

q2.quetsion_text: Aisha was the daughter of this first Caliph, who launched the Ridda wars against those subjects that refused to pay taxes.

q3.quetsion_text: Like this group of people, Aisha's name is often spoken with the honorific "May Allah be pleased with her." This word refers to the companions of the prophet, which included Anas bin Maalik and the physician Harith Ibn Kalada.

lead_in: This man once said, "If one morning I walked on top of the water across the Potomac River, the headline that afternoon would read 'President Can't Swim'".

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this president who had earlier earned the sarcastic nickname "landslide" following his extremely close victory over Coke Stevenson to be elected Senator from Texas for the first time.

q2.quetsion_text: Johnson is the subject of a multi-volume biography by this man, who also chronicled the life of New York City's master builder Robert Moses in The Power Broker.

q3.quetsion_text: Johnson's only electoral defeat came against this one-time radio personality and state governor who wrote songs with a group originally called the Light Crust Doughboys.

lead_in: One member of this group wrote the oratorio King David with Paul Claudel. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this group of composers that included Arthur Honegger and Georges Auric.

q2.quetsion_text: Les Six were a group of six composers who were all inspired by Erik Satie and were active in this European country.

q3.quetsion_text: This member of the Les Six composed the jazz-influenced La crÃ©ation du monde, Scaramouche, and The Ox on the Roof.

lead_in: Identify the following about the paintings of Diego VelÃ¡zquez, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: VelÃ¡zquez depicted himself in this painting that includes a dwarf standing next to a dog. In this  painting, a reflection shows Philip IV watching his daughter, the Infanta Margarita.
q1.raw_answer: Las Meninas [or The Maids of Honor]

q2.quetsion_text: This painting is sometimes called Las Lanzas for the numerous lances in its upper right corner. It  depicts Justin of Nassau giving the key to the title Dutch town to the Spaniard Ambrogio Spinola during  the Eighty Years' War.
q2.raw_answer: The Surrender of Breda [or La RendiciÃ³n de Breda]

q3.quetsion_text: Francis Bacon has painted several reinterpretations of VelÃ¡zquez's portrait of one of these people. In  Bacon's version, this person is screaming.

lead_in: This country is in free association with self-governing states like Niue and the Cook Islands. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: [10] Name this Pacific island nation that governs the Kermadec islands, as well as two much larger islands just called the North Island and the South Island. Most of the world's Maori people live in this country.

q2.quetsion_text: This archipelago is also a dependent territory of New Zealand. These islands lie in the far north of New Zealand, just north of Samoa.

q3.quetsion_text: This Polynesian island nation lies just north of the Kermadec islands. It is the only kingdom in Polynesia
q3.raw_answer: Kingdom of Tonga [or Puleʻanga Fakatuʻi ʻo Tonga]

lead_in: Scherbaum et. al used this property to stabilize an incredible coordination complex containing a carbon atom with six bonds.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this interaction similar to hydrogen bonding, which causes complexes containing the element with atomic number 79 to aggregate at an equilibrium distance of about three angstroms.
q1.raw_answer: aurophilicity [accept word forms; prompt on "metallophilicity" or word forms; do not accept Gold Bond, which is a foot powder]

q2.quetsion_text: Aurophilicity can be explained by this theory, which also offers reasons for the inert pair effect and mercury being a liquid at STP. This theory uses changes in electron mass to explain the properties of heavy nuclei like gold.
q2.raw_answer: theory of special relativity [or relativistic effects]

q3.quetsion_text: By expanding f orbitals, relativistic effects may also augment the "contraction" named for these elements that along with scandium and yttrium make up the rare earths. They appear above the actinides in the periodic table.

lead_in: The speaker of this poem declares "I am large, I contain multitudes".

q1.quetsion_text: Name this poem that begins "I celebrate myself", the longest poem included in Leaves of Grass.

q2.quetsion_text: "Song of Myself" was written by this American poet, who also wrote "O Captain! My Captain!" about the death of Abraham Lincoln.

q3.quetsion_text: This other Whitman poem says "Flood-tide below me! I watch you face to face" and describes "crowds of men and women attired in the usual costumes" on the title conveyance.

lead_in: These compounds are produced from the reaction of alkylaluminum with titanium tri or tetrachloride. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these catalysts that can link up terminal alkenes such as propylene, and confer tacticity on the product.

q2.quetsion_text: Ziegler-Natta catalysts catalyze the production of these kinds of compounds, which consist of repeating units and are made by step-growth and chain-growth mechanisms. They typically constitute plastics.

q3.quetsion_text: Polyacetylenes, polypyrroles, and polyanilines and their copolymers often have this property, which have a bunch of contiguous Pz orbitals with delocalized electrons that are doped by oxidation.
q3.raw_answer: conductive polymer [or word forms; accept things like they conduct electricity]

lead_in: Donald Cram successfully observed this molecule by photochemically degrading alpha-pyrone inside a hemicarcerand.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this molecule that rapidly dimerizes by acting as both a diene and dienophile in the Diels-Alder reaction at temperatures as low as 35 K. This unstable molecule is the simplest [n]-annulene.

q2.quetsion_text: Cyclobutadiene is known for possessing this property, which can be identified by the presence of nonbonding electrons on Frost circles. Cyclooctatetraene avoids this property as it takes on a non-planar tub conformation.
q2.raw_answer: antiaromaticity [accept word forms; do not accept "aromaticity"]

q3.quetsion_text: Antiaromatic molecules have 4n of these electrons, which are named for and contained in bonds formed from p orbitals. These electrons are delocalized in stabilized conjugated systems of double bonds.

lead_in: This deity is also known as the Gitche Manitou or Wakan Tanka.

q1.quetsion_text: Give this common English term for the supreme deity or mysterious essence of the world in American Indian mythologies.

q3.quetsion_text: Spider Grandmother's provision of a reed passage to the Fourth World is the origin myth of these people, who are the source of most myths about Kokopelli.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this programming language paradigm, which is contrasted with imperative and declarative. Languages in this paradigm, like Haskell, focus on entities that produce an output for each input.

q2.quetsion_text: Many concepts in functional programming draw on the rules of a calculus named for this letter. In general, anonymous functions are designated by this Greek letter.

q1.quetsion_text: In 1529, the Ottoman army besieged and ultimately failed to capture this capital city of modern-day Austria.

lead_in: Bonus: It is produced by the beta cells of the Islets of Langerhans. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this hormone secreted by the pancreas, whose deficiency causes diabetes.

lead_in: Name these short speeches, for 10 points each.

lead_in: This structure accounts for the majority of the eye's refractive power, and its components include the protective Bowman's layer and Descemet's membrane.

lead_in: Answer some questions about the evolution of language,

q1.quetsion_text: The two amino acid differences between humans and other apes in this gene are presumed crucial for the evolution of spoken language. A mutation in this gene, which codes for a highly conserved transcription factor, caused verbal dyspraxia in members of the KE family.

lead_in: The name of this edict was taken from a spell in the ring cycle, and it was expanded by Wilhelm Keitel to include anyone who survived for eight days in custody. For 10 points each:

lead_in: This philosopher used the term "biopower" to denote the ways in which states achieve control over bodies in The History of Sexuality.

q3.quetsion_text: In the full quantum mechanical treatment, phonons are typically modeled as modes of the quantum version of this type of system; a mechanical example is a mass on a spring whose restoring force is described by Hooke's Law.

lead_in: Answer some questions about ways to find the electric field due to a charge configuration

q1.quetsion_text: For symmetric systems, one might use Gauss's law to relate the charge inside an area to the electric type of this quantity through the boundary. This quantity measures the amount of a field flowing through a surface and the magnetic type adds up to zero for closed surfaces.

q2.quetsion_text: In the case of a point charge and an infinite conducting sheet, one would use this method, which involves replacing the conductor with an imaginary charge of the opposite value on the other side of the plane.
q2.raw_answer: method of images [or method of image charges]

q3.quetsion_text: To calculate the potential due to two cylinders, one might use this kind of angle preserving map to transform to a space where the cylinders are concentric. There, the problem is easy, and one can map the solution back to the original space.

lead_in: Following the Age of Imperialism, nations shifted their attention from grabbing land to securing their possessions. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: The Anglo-German naval race was sparked by the construction of this British vessel in 1906. It changed naval warfare with its heavy, uniform main battery and fast steam turbines.

lead_in: His most famous contribution to evolutionary biology posits that the majority of genetic changes at the molecular level have no overall effect.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Japanese biologist who devised the "neutral theory" of molecular evolution.

q3.quetsion_text: A consequence of Kimura's "neutral theory" is that the majority of evolutionary changes happen via this process, the random variation of allele frequencies in a population.

q1.quetsion_text: While the script and text of the Voynich manuscript is completely unreadable, it might be one of these languages. These kinds of languages, exemplified by Klingon and Esperanto, are entirely man-made.

q2.quetsion_text: The Voynich manuscript is sometimes hypothesized to be written in an Asian language, as it lacks these parts of speech. In English, these kinds of adjectives include “a”, “an”, and “the”, and show the definiteness of a noun.

lead_in: This man wrote a 1980 article with Sanford Grossman entitled "On the Impossibility of Informationally Efficient Markets."

q3.quetsion_text: Prerogative writs are sometimes called this kind of writ. This term refers to a type of law defined by  judges in respect of precedent, following the principle of stare decisis. It is distinguished from civil law,  and is followed in the U.S. and Britain.

lead_in: This term was created to differentiate the works of artists like Kenneth Noland and Morris Louis, who favored "openness of clarity," from an earlier style that predominated in the 1950s. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this term coined by Clement Greenberg to refer to an exhibit he curated for the Los Angeles County Museum of Art in 1964.

q2.quetsion_text: Noland, Louis, and many abstract expressionists created many paintings in this style, which used simple stripes and geometric shapes to depict the environment. Mark Rothko's Yellow, Cherry, Orange is one example.

lead_in: Everyone in quizbowl knows what the Lotka-Volterra equations are, but how deep is your knowledge of ecological field methods?

q1.quetsion_text: Ecologists usually catch wild birds and bats with these large traps containing loose nylon pockets that prevent injury to organisms. While time-consuming to set up, they allow easy observation and banding of common species.
q1.raw_answer: mist nets [accept word forms; accept dho-gazza; prompt on "nets" or synonyms; prompt on "trammels"]

q2.quetsion_text: Mist nets trap organisms for mark-recapture, a technique whose estimates of population size have been applied to written records in this field. SIR models describe population interactions in this field, which is founded on Hill's criteria of causality.
q2.raw_answer: epidemiology [prompt on medicine or medical science]

q3.quetsion_text: The Shannon-Wiener and Simpson indices are used to estimate this trait, whose alpha form refers to the number of species in an area. The loss of this trait, especially in "hotspots," is the major focus of conservation biology.
q3.raw_answer: biodiversity [accept biological diversity; accept species, genetic, habitat or ecosystem diversity; accept species richness]

lead_in: One essay says that this movement "reveals that violence is normal behavior for the suffering."

q1.quetsion_text: Name this film movement discussed in the essay "The Aesthetics of Hunger." This movement was led by directors like Carlos Diegues and Glauber Rocha.

q3.quetsion_text: In the end of Glauber Rocha's seminal film Black God, White Devil, the two main characters run toward this type of place which is shown in the last few shots. Antoine Doinel runs to this type of place at the end of The 400 Blows.

lead_in: Members of this group include possible murder victim Jesse Smith, who was inexplicably nicknamed "Jess." For 10 points each:

q3.quetsion_text: This alumnus of the Ohio Gang and campaign manager for Harding in the 1920 election became the first president of the predecessor to the MPAA, in which role he approved a moralistic code governing films.

lead_in: This work's first movement in 5/4 time repeats an ostinato in the bass to represent The Bringer of War. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this orchestral suite which portrays certain celestial bodies through their deities, such as Mercury, the Winged Messenger. The final movement, Neptune, ends with a fading female chorus.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this final major step in aerobic respiration, in which the energy from negatively charged particles is used to generate a proton gradient across the inner mitochondrial membrane.
q1.raw_answer: the electron transport chain [or the ETC; accept "transfer" for "transport" and "system" for "chain", and thus the associated acronyms as well]

q2.quetsion_text: High-energy electrons are shuttled to the ETC by NADH and this derivative of riboflavin, which is reduced during the conversion of succinate to fumarate during the citric acid cycle.
q2.raw_answer: FADH2 [or flavin adenine dinucleotide; or FAD+]

q3.quetsion_text: This final enzyme in the mitochondrial electron transport chain converts a molecule of oxygen into two molecules of water. Its activity can be inhibited by the cyanide ion, accounting for that ion's toxicity.

lead_in: One of these compositions marked by fast descending and ascending runs in the left hand is named "Revolutionary." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this type of short, difficult composition meant to help practice technique. Notable ones include a series in all major and minor keys by Alkan, and ones named "Winter Wind" and "Black Keys."

q2.quetsion_text: The "Black Keys" Ã©tude was written by this Polish composer of Fantasie Impromptu and twenty-one nocturnes. He is also known for his "Funeral March" and "Minute Waltz."

lead_in: The committee that oversees these actions determines the federal funds target rate. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Give this term which refers to the sale or purchase of government bonds by the central bank for the  purpose of interest rate targeting.

q2.quetsion_text: The Open Market Committee is a group within this body. This body is the central bank of the United  States, and it was established by a 1913 act.

lead_in: One of this tournament's editors has a poster of this artist's Inlet at Awa Province above his bed. Guess which one!

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Edo-period artist, who was famous primarily for landscape series like The Fifty-three Stations of the Tokaido, The Sixty-nine Stations of the Kiso Kaido, and One Hundred Famous Views of Edo.

q2.quetsion_text: Hiroshige and the rest of the Utagawa school produced woodblock prints made in this style, whose Japanese name literally means "pictures of the floating world".

q3.quetsion_text: Fellow Utagawa school member Kunisada produced many of these ukiyo-e portraits of beautiful women. Examples include Three Beauties of the Present Age, a work of Kitagawa Utamaro, the leading artist in this genre.

lead_in: Bonus: Enclosing a number x in curly brackets, which computes the fractional part of x, denotes subtracting this function of x from x itself. For ten points each,

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this step function that computes the greatest integer less than or equal to the input.

q2.quetsion_text: The floor function does not satisfy this property because the y values jump at the integers. Generally, a graph satisfies this property if it can be drawn as a single, unbroken curve.

q3.quetsion_text: Continuity along an interval is one of the requirements for this theorem which states that if “f of a” equals “f of b,” then the first derivative equals zero somewhere along the interval from a to b.

lead_in: The kinetic energy of a rotating body is equal to one half times this quantity times angular velocity squared. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this rotational analogue of mass, symbolized I. For a thin rod rotating through an axis perpendicular to its length and through its center of mass, it is equal to one twelfth m l squared

q2.quetsion_text: The moment of inertia for a thin disk rotating through an axis perpendicular to the plane of the disk and through its center of mass is equal to its mass times its radius squared times this constant.

q3.quetsion_text: This theorem can be used to find a body's moment of inertia through an axis coplanar with the one through its center of mass given its mass, moment of inertia about its center of mass, and the distance between the axes.
q3.raw_answer: parallel axis theorem [do not accept "perpendicular axis theorem"]

lead_in: At the end of this novel, the protagonist imitates a police siren after escaping from a riot at a movie premier. For 10 points each:

lead_in: Robert Axelrod got hundreds of social scientists to submit computer programs to play an iterated version of this game in two tournaments.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this game in which two players can independently choose to either remain silent of turn the other in. Though cooperation among players is Pareto-optimal, the expected payoff for defection is higher.

q2.quetsion_text: Introduced by Anatol Rapoport, this winning strategy in Axelrod's tournaments cooperates in the first move and then does what the other player did the previous move. Axelrod and W. D. Hamilton claim that this strategy is evolutionarily stable in The Evolution of Cooperation.

q3.quetsion_text: Cooperation is a focus of this perspective in international relations theory, whose proponents, including Joseph Nye and Robert Keohane, emphasize the ways that states can minimize the anarchy of inter-state relations.

lead_in: This city's Mediterranean Revival architecture was inspired by the industrialist James Deering's nearby Villa Vizcaya.

q2.quetsion_text: The development of Coral Gables followed the tenets of this progressive movement that sought to inspire civic virtue through the power of Beaux-Arts architecture. Its ideas influenced monuments in D.C. via the McMillan Plan.

q3.quetsion_text: The City Beautiful movement was first manifested on a large scale in the "White City" of the 1893 World's Columbian Exhibition in this city. Edward H. Bennett and Daniel Burnham created 1909 urban plan for this city.

lead_in: When a system is in this state, photons perturb excited electrons, which then release more photons as they relax back to the ground state.

q2.quetsion_text: A saturable absorber is used in the passive type of this technique, where the phases of the various waves that oscillate within the laser are fixed to periodically interfere constructively, allowing the laser to emit short, periodic pulses of light.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this quantity, usually symbolized "tau," which in simple situations gives the number of e-fold reductions in the number of photons in a beam due to scattering or absorption by the medium through which the beam propagates.
q1.raw_answer: optical depth [or optical thickness; prompt on partial answer]

q2.quetsion_text: Using the Eddington approximation, one can derive that this layer of a star, generally taken to be the visible surface, lies at an optical depth of two-thirds. Above this light-emitting portion lies the chromosphere.

q3.quetsion_text: Eddington also names a stability limit on this property of a light-emitting object. When this property of a body exceeds the Eddington limit, radiation forces exceed gravitational forces, generally resulting in powerful radiation-driven winds and rapid mass loss.

lead_in: In post-unification Italy, this belief manifested in calls to annex South Tyrol from Austria-Hungary. For 10 points each:

lead_in: This god is depicted as the Lord of the Dance in the Nataraja form.

lead_in: This assembly was the site of Patrick Henry's speech, "If this be treason, make the most of it". For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this colonial legislative assembly in Virginia, the first of its kind in America.

lead_in: When a function is equal to this in a given range, that function is called an analytic function. For 10 points each:

lead_in: One of her novels climaxes with a masquerade at which the hunchbacked dwarf Herr Glocken wears a tie painted with the words "Girls, follow me!" For ten points each:

lead_in: This technique is also referred to as "direct painting." For 10 points each:

lead_in: In some versions of her story, Artemis replaced this girl with a deer and whisked her off to Tauris at the moment when she would have died. For 10 points each:

lead_in: This religion holds that Ezekiel witnessed a flying "wheel" that was built in Japan and carries thousands  of bombs. For 10 points each:

lead_in: Credited with founding the Lausanne School of Economics, this man lends his name to an auction where the auctioneer yells out a price and then buyers and sellers agree on what quantities they want to buy or sell. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this nineteenth-century French economist, the author of Elements of Pure Economics.

q2.quetsion_text: This Italian economist succeeded Leon Walras as Chair of Political Economy at the Lausanne School. His namesake efficiency describes a condition when no one can be made better off without someone being made worse off.

q3.quetsion_text: This English economist developed his marginal utility independently of Carl Menger and Leon Walras, and preceded fellow English foundational figure Alfred Marshall. This author of 1871's The Theory of Political Economy incorrectly predicted coal prices would rise in The Coal Question.

lead_in: A more recent painting depicts three cross-dressing founding fathers standing in front of this painting. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this huge Emanuel Leutze painting. It includes anachronisms like an old version of the American flag.

q2.quetsion_text: Washington Crossing the Delaware hangs in the background of Daughters of Revolution, which was painted by this American artist. He depicted his sister and his dentist in front of the Dibble House in American Gothic.

q3.quetsion_text: Wood was a member of this American art movement, along with John Steuart Curry and Thomas Hart Benton. This movement focused on realistic depictions of the Midwest.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this ratio of the moles of solute and the liters of solution.
q1.raw_answer: molarity (or molar concentration, do not accept "molal"ity)

q2.quetsion_text: Molarity is divided by an equivalence factor to get this measure of concentration associated with gram equivalents.

q3.quetsion_text: In Raoult's law, vapor pressure is multiplied by this measure of the concentration of solute in a solvent.

lead_in: The third movement of this work begins with a duet between an English horn and an offstage oboe. For  10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this musical work. Its last movement includes a grotesque fugue centering around the Dies  Irae, depicting a "Dream of a Witches' Sabbath."

q2.quetsion_text: This French Romantic composer combined symphony and opera with works like the "Dramatic  Legend" La damnation de Faust, as well as writing the Symphonie Fantastique.

q3.quetsion_text: Berlioz's other sacred works include an enormous piece in this choral genre. That work in this genre  includes four brass bands on top of a mammoth orchestra with eight bassoons, twelve horns, and ten  timpanists.
q3.raw_answer: a Requiem Mass [or Grande Messe des morts; or Mass for the dead; or Mass of the dead;  prompt on "Mass" or "Messe"]

lead_in: These symbols were often used in neumatic and mensural pieces and are called box or oblique based on their shape.

q1.quetsion_text: Name these symbols used in musical notation of the Middle Ages and Renaissance that represent at least two notes performed on the same syllable. Ones with two notes are called binaria.

q2.quetsion_text: These extensions of the musical staff are used to notate pitches that are higher or lower than those on the staff.

q3.quetsion_text: This clef uses two dots, one above and one below the line, to denote F below middle C on the staff. It is the standard clef for the bassoon, tuba, and the left hand of piano parts.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this alias which titles a novel by Alexandre Dumas.

q2.quetsion_text: DantÃ¨s also adopts the name of this legendary character, who defeats the Old Man of the Sea.

q3.quetsion_text: A chief target of the revenge of the Count is this prosecutor, who condemns Edmond to the Chateau d'If to avoid implicating the treason of his father.

lead_in: Name some things about optics, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This value is defined as the negative object distance times the height of the image, all divided by the product of image distance and the height of the object. It is the ratio of an object's size as you see it to its actual size.

q2.quetsion_text: This quantity for a spherical lens is obtained by setting either the object or the image distance to infinity. For a spherical mirror, it is simply half the radius.

q3.quetsion_text: This important principle in optics states that light will traverse a path which minimizes the time it takes to travel.

lead_in: This character's death, foreseen by an astrologer to occur at the hand of Whitmore, is hastened when he is captured at sea and boasts of his high birth to his captors. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this character who is exiled for his part in ordering the murder of Gloucester. In a famous scene, his severed head is cradled by his lover Margaret, whom he had captured on a battlefield.
q1.raw_answer: William de la Pole, 1st Duke of Suffolk

q2.quetsion_text: Suffolk appears in the first two plays in a trilogy about this king. The second part of this trilogy has the largest cast of all of Shakespeare's plays.

q3.quetsion_text: The Henry VI plays are examples of this type of play by Shakespeare, published alongside his tragedies and comedies in the First Folio.

lead_in: The low voltage drop across the Schottky type of this device enables faster switching. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this circuit element, which ideally only allows current to flow one way. They are often made from doped semiconductor material.

q2.quetsion_text: Diodes can be used to help perform this process, in which alternating current is converted to direct current. The most common devices that perform this process are three-phase.

q3.quetsion_text: A very common type of diode is formed at the junction between doped semiconductors of these two types. These two types are distinguished based on whether they have more electrons or holes carrying charge.
q3.raw_answer: p and n semiconductors [or p-n junction diodes, accept any answer with those two letters]

lead_in: According to Stesichorus, a shepherd of this name informed Geryon of the theft of his cattle.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this name, which was also borne by a hubristic son of Iapetus who was banished to Tartarus after Zeus struck him with a thunderbolt.

q2.quetsion_text: Another Menoetius in mythology was the father of this Trojan War hero. He and Menoetius took shelter with Peleus after he killed Clysonymus, and this man became very good friends with Peleus' son.

q3.quetsion_text: Patroclus died on the battlefield of Troy while impersonating this hero, whose mother Thetis had earlier done a poor job of properly dipping him in the river Styx.

lead_in: Organic chemists have developed a variety of unconventional ways to perform simple tasks.

q1.quetsion_text: In accordance with the principles of green chemistry, a great way to reduce waste and cut costs is to run reactions without using these substances, common examples of which include toluene, ether, and water.

q2.quetsion_text: Often in introductory labs, this kind of environment is created using balloons filled with nitrogen gas and attached to a flask. Sensitive reactions are run in this kind of environment, typically with nitrogen or argon gas.
q2.raw_answer: inert environment [or air-free environment, prompt on non-reactive, oxygen-free or water-free environment]

q3.quetsion_text: These machines accelerate chemical reactions by heating them, much like oil baths or hotplates, but use electromagnetic radiation instead, greatly decreasing the necessary time.
q3.raw_answer: microwave ovens [or anything that heats the reaction using microwaves]

lead_in: Bonus: Kevyn Orr became emergency manager of this city after the governor declared a state of financial emergency. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this city which recently filed for bankruptcy in July 2013.

q2.quetsion_text: This state’s governor, Rick Snyder, was the one who declared Detroit to be in a state of financial emergency.

q3.quetsion_text: This former mayor of Detroit was convicted of fraud and racketeering in 2013, and resigned as mayor after he was convicted on other felony charges.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this British family whose members Christabel and Emmeline founded the WSPU in 1903.

q2.quetsion_text: Emmeline Pankhurst was a leading member of this movement in Britain. In the United States, this movement achieved its goal with the passage of the Nineteenth Amendment.
q2.raw_answer: suffragettes [or suffragism; accept answers that describe getting women the right to vote]

q3.quetsion_text: ] In 1913, this WSPU member threw herself in front of Anmer, the horse of George V running in the Epsom Derby. This suffragette may only have been trying to pin a WSPU banner to Anmer rather than commit suicide.

lead_in: Identify the following about some recent films shot in black and white,

q1.quetsion_text: This Oscar winner mostly eschewed dialogue, except in a dream sequence where Valentin, played by Jean Dujardin, hears people talking but is himself unable to speak.

q2.quetsion_text: This indie film directed by Noah Baumbach drew frequent comparisons to Girls. Sophie moves out of an apartment she shared with the title character, a New York dancer, at the start of this film.

q3.quetsion_text: This director used black and white to chronicle Woody Grant's quixotic attempt to redeem a million dollar prize from a magazine subscription company in 2013's Nebraska. He also directed Election and Sideways.

lead_in: This leader used BBC radio to broadcast a speech called the Appeal of 18 June. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this leader of French resistance during World War II who later served as the first president of the Fifth Republic.

q2.quetsion_text: Graffiti depicting de Gaulle as "the shit-in-the-bed" appeared during student protests in May of this year. The Prague Spring also occurred in this year.

q3.quetsion_text: As president, de Gaulle also faced the Algerian war of independence, which was ended by this treaty. These "accords" were opposed by the right-wing OAS.

lead_in: In one dimension, it says that d-squared phi over dx-squared equals 1 over v-squared times d-squared  phi over dt-squared. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this second-order linear partial differential equation, which describes oscillations in a given  space.

q2.quetsion_text: The wave equation can be used in one dimension to model the oscillations of these simple harmonic  oscillators, which are also modeled by Hooke's Law.

q3.quetsion_text: Wave equations can sometimes be solved by making use of this function, which maps a function f to  the integral of f times the exponential of 2pi i x times the input of the new function.

lead_in: This company exported a lot of tallow and controlled trade around Archangelsk.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this company that was expelled from much of its namesake region after outrage following the beheading of Charles I.

q2.quetsion_text: This tsar booted the Muscovy Company from everywhere but Archangelsk. Patriarch Nikon caused the Raskol controversy during this man's reign and Stenka Razin's revolt was also during this man's time as tsar.

q3.quetsion_text: Stenka Razin, a member of this ethnic group, led an uprising during Alexius's reign. Many of these people lived near the Don River, they were led by hetmen and they liked horses a lot.

lead_in: Identify the following Edgar Allan Poe stories, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: Rats attracted by meat and the French Army under General Lasalle, respectively, rescue a prisoner of the Spanish Inquisition from death at the hands of this story's two title objects.

q2.quetsion_text: This story's narrator's second wife Lady Rowena dies, then returns to life and transforms into his first wife, the title character. This story also includes the poem "The Conqueror Worm".

q3.quetsion_text: The narrator of this story is unable to prevent himself from confessing to committing a murder using a poisoned candle. It was adapted from an essay about a spirit that tempts people to do things entirely "because we feel that we should not".

lead_in: This man was forced to let his daughter Marie Louise marry his worst enemy, the Emperor of the French. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Austrian monarch, the last Holy Roman Emperor and first Emperor of Austria.
q1.raw_answer: Franz I [accept "Franz II" or "Francis" instead of "Franz" for either]

q2.quetsion_text: Franz I was notably not the ruler of this later polity, established by the Compromise of 1867 to give greater autonomy to the Lands of the Crown of St. Stephen. Its Diet met in Budapest.

q3.quetsion_text: This first Austro-Hungarian Kaiser und Koenig ruled for 68 years. The assassination of his heir Archduke Ferdinand led to his invasion of Serbia and the start of World War I.

lead_in: Bonus: In this work, Esteban knocks out Blanca’s front teeth after discovering her relationship with Pedro Tercero. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this novel set in the Las Tres Marías hacienda, which describes Estaban’s marriage to Clara del Valle.
q1.raw_answer: The House of the Spirits [or La casa de los espíritus]

q2.quetsion_text: This Chilean author wrote The House of the Spirits and also wrote about a character who lives with Huberto Naranjo before falling in love with the journalist Rolf Carle in Eva Luna.

q3.quetsion_text: In The House of the Spirits, Clara’s sister Rosa the Beautiful and her granddaughter Alba both have hair of this color. In The Great Gatsby, Jay sees a light of this color at the end of Daisy’s dock.

lead_in: Terrence McNally wrote two short plays about this author's namesake "syndrome," by which people collapse upon being overwhelmed by art. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this author who wrote about Fabrice del Dongo's imprisonment during and after the Napoleonic wars in The Charterhouse of Parma.

q2.quetsion_text: In Stendhal's The Red and the Black, Julien Sorel has to choose between two institutions symbolized by the title colors. Specify which institution is symbolized by each color.
q2.raw_answer: red represents the French army AND black represents the Catholic church [prompt on answers such as the army and the clergy which do not specify which color is which]

q3.quetsion_text: At the end of The Red and the Black, Mathilde does this to a specific part of Julien Sorel's dead body.
q3.raw_answer: she kisses his severed head on the brow [prompt on kissing]

lead_in: This unit fought at the extreme left wing of the victorious side at the Battle of Leuctra. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this elite fighting whose members are commemorate by a stone lion at the site of their destruction during the Battle of Chaeronea. It was composed of 150 pairs of lovers.
q1.raw_answer: Sacred Band of Thebes [or Hieros Lokhos; do not accept answers with "Carthage" since that's a completely different group]

q2.quetsion_text: The Sacred Band was from this Boeotian city. One of its rulers, Epaminondas, used an oblique order to smash Spartan hegemony at Leuctra. It shouldn't be confused with an Egyptian city of the same name.

q3.quetsion_text: This friend of Epaminondas and a fellow boeotarch freed Thebes from Sparta in 379 BCE and led the Sacred Band at Leuctra. He arbitrated a Macedonian succession dispute, after which he took Philip II as a hostage and eromenos.

lead_in: Samuel Preston showed this variable for newborns increases concavely with income.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this value, which for a given age is the average total years of life.

q2.quetsion_text: This economist claimed increased life expectancy and other physiological changes were due entirely to public health factors in The Escape from Hunger and Premature Death, 1700-2100. He more controversially argued slavery was efficient and profitable in Time on the Cross, co-authored with Stanley Engerman.

q3.quetsion_text: This two-word concept refers to the multi-stage process by which life expectancy increases with economic and social development, giving rise to lower birth and mortality rates. Investment in public health and the adoption of contraception are both components of this concept.

lead_in: This republic was proclaimed after the Bracceschi family was driven out. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Italian republic whose law-making body was called the Captains and Defenders of Liberty. It eventually descended into the autocratic rule of Carlo Gonzaga.
q1.raw_answer: Golden Ambrosian Republic [or Aurea Repubblica Ambrosiana; prompt on "Milan"]

q2.quetsion_text: This capital of the Ambrosian Republic was ruled by the Visconti beforehand and afterwards by the family of the man who betrayed it, Francesco I Sforza. This northern Italian city is the capital of Lombardy.

q3.quetsion_text: Milan was also the capital of this Napoleonic client state. This republic took its name from the Roman province in northern Italy that itself took its name from its position in Gaul relative to the nearby mountains.

lead_in: This activity is performed by those who perform an "aliyah," and it is traditional that the first person called to do this be a Cohen. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this central activity of the Saturday morning service in a Jewish congregation.

q2.quetsion_text: In modern synagogues, this raised area at the front of the congregation is home to the ark where the Torah is stored and the podium from which it is read.

q3.quetsion_text: On Shabbat, the Torah service comes between shacharit and this segment of the service, whose Hebrew name means "additional." It often ends with the Aleinu and Adon Olam prayers.

lead_in: A mural on a Mississippi River bluff in this state depicts a winged dragon with antlers called the Piasa.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this state, which was also the location of an alleged thunderbird attack in Lawndale in 1977. Another legend from this state places the blame for an 1871 fire on Mrs. O'Leary's cow.
q1.raw_answer: Illinois [accept Land of Lincoln, Prairie State and other goofy nicknames]

q2.quetsion_text: A Miami-Illini legend from Illinois describes how this animal gave Rabbit a split lip. Folklore claims that it gives birth through its nose, while Cherokee myth relates the origin of its bare, prehensile tail.

q3.quetsion_text: Miami-Illini myths include versions of these scaly, aquatic underworld creatures from Ojibwe myth that guard the copper of the Keweenaw Peninsula. One may be depicted by the Alligator Effigy Mound in Ohio.
q3.raw_answer: underwater panthers [or mishipeshu or similar answers; accept underwater lynxes; accept Great Lynxes; prompt on generic answers about any North American species of cat]

lead_in: Identify the following about unique roles some species have in their environment, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: The apex type of these animals are usually at the top of the food web and help control the  population of consumers lower on the chain. The Lotka-Volterra equations model their interaction with  prey.

q2.quetsion_text: Robert Paine used members of this starfish genus, particularly the ochraeus species, to demonstrate  that keystone species have a disproportionate impact on their ecosystem.

q3.quetsion_text: Pioneer species like mosses and lichens help pave the way for the growth of more complex plants  during this process, which often takes place after a wildfire or volcanic eruption clears existing plant life.
q3.raw_answer: ecological succession [or primary succession or secondary succession]

lead_in: This man's government has links to the hardline anti-Muslim group Bodu Bala Sena, or Buddhist Power Force. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this despotic president of Sri Lanka whose family controls between 50-75% of the country's budget. He defeated the Tamil Tigers in 2009 and is the current Chairperson-in-Office of the Commonwealth of Nations.

q2.quetsion_text: In this country, Ashin Wirathu's 969 Movement urges Buddhists to oppress the marginalized Rohingya Muslim ethnic group. The Rohingyas are concentrated in this country's Arakan valley in Rakhine state.

q3.quetsion_text: Nissho Inoue, a Nichiren Buddhist monk in this country, started the League of Blood incident. Aum Shinrikyo, a pseudo-Buddhist syncretic cult from this country, released sarin gas on subways in Tokyo.

lead_in: Bonus: Edmund Ross refused to convict a president of a violation of this law. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this law, passed during Reconstruction, that forbade the president from removing Senate-confirmed officials without the Senate’s consent. Andrew Johnson flouted it with his removal of Edwin Stanton.

q2.quetsion_text: The Tenure of Office Act was retroactively ruled invalid in the Supreme Court case Myers v. United States, which was presided over by this Chief Justice. This man had earlier served as President after Theodore Roosevelt.

q3.quetsion_text: Andrew Johnson allegedly violated the Tenure of Office Act by attempting to replace Edwin Stanton with Lorenzo Thomas in this Cabinet post, which was later merged with another post in 1947.
q3.raw_answer: Secretary of War [do not accept “Secretary of Defense”] <BZ>

lead_in: The Agricola series by this artist repurposes old farm machinery to depict farmers. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this modernist American sculptor who welded stainless steel cubes and cylinders together in his Cubi series. The eleventh and twenty-sixth entries in that series can be found in the National Gallery of Art.

q2.quetsion_text: The "Cubes and Anarchy" exhibition of David Smith's work occurred in the Whitney Museum in this city. This city is also home to the Guggenheim and the Museum of Modern Art.

q3.quetsion_text: The Whitney also contains a sculpture of a giant BLT sandwich by this artist, whose other works include Lipstick (Ascending) on Caterpillar Tracks at Yale.

lead_in: Although he claimed neutrality during World War II, he supported Germany by sending the Blue Division to fight against communism. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: What military leader participated in a coup by JosÃ© Sanjurjo and Emilio Mola to become the dictator of Spain in the 20th century?

q2.quetsion_text: Franco established the political party that came to rule Spain by merging the Carlists and this namesake fascist group, organized by Primo de Rivera.

q3.quetsion_text: Franco's plan for succession drastically changed course following the dramatic 1973 assassination of this prime minister by the ETA, in which his Dodge was propelled entirely over a building by a car bomb and landed on a second-floor balcony on the next street.

lead_in: The protagonist of this work auctions off a copy of Faust for a tin lice comb and receives a Red Cross postcard from his mother.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this novel in which Leo Auberg is deported to a Soviet gulag and spends five years in a coke processing plant where one shovel load of coal is worth one gram of bread.

q2.quetsion_text: This German author of The Hunger Angel won the 2009 Nobel Prize for Literature. She also wrote about Irene, who struggles to find love after emigrating to West Berlin, in Traveling on One Leg.

lead_in: This man wrote an article promoting charity called "The Gospel of Wealth."

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Scotsman who founded a powerful Pittsburgh based steel company. His philanthropy funded numerous libraries and universities across the country.

q2.quetsion_text: This other philanthropist and business magnate was known as the "Commodore" for his railroad and shipping investments. He is the namesake of a Tennessee university.

q3.raw_answer: Gibbons v. Ogden [accept either part and in reverse order]

lead_in: On the right side of one painting by this man, two aristocrats examine a painting filled with nudes, while a painting of Louis XIV is being stowed away in a box on the left. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this French artist of The Shop Sign of Gersaint who depicted a Pierrot in baggy white clothing calmly looking at the viewer in his Gilles.

lead_in: For 10 points each, name these groups of people from Latin American history.

lead_in: This man wrote, "A foolish consistency is the hobgoblin of little minds."

q1.quetsion_text: Name this leader of the American transcendentalist movement, who wrote Self-Reliance and discussed humanity's disconnect with natural beauty in his essay Nature.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this linguist, whose ideas laid the foundation for the field of metalinguistics. With Sapir, he conames a hypothesis of linguistic relativity, which states that language affects how we conceptualize the world.

q2.quetsion_text: In Roman Jakobson's six functions of communication, this word describes the metalinguistic use of language. In Saussurian semiotics, this word denotes the set of conventions that allows signs to acquire meaning.

q3.quetsion_text: Whorf also invented this phonological term for different sounds that are treated as variants of one phoneme. For example, in English, the letter "p" is more aspirated in "pin" than in "spin", but we treat them as the same phoneme.
