lead_in: One common example of this proof technique in combinatorics establishes a lower bound for Ramsey numbers by considering random colorings of complete graphs.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this nonconstructive proof technique which can be used to show an object with a given property exists by, for example, considering the expectation of an associated indicator random variable.

q2.quetsion_text: This eccentric Hungarian mathematician was a pioneer of the probabilistic method. He also famously collaborated with hundreds of other mathematicians and popularized the idea of "proofs from the book."

q3.quetsion_text: This useful result in probability theory says that the probability of at least one event in a collection is no greater than the sum of their individual probabilities.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Aztec god of creativity and the night sky. This antagonist of Quetzalcoatl was often represented as a jaguar or a smoking obsidian mirror.

q2.quetsion_text: At these man-made locales, Tezcatlipoca could appear in the night to test the skill of warriors. Other beings who preside over these man-made locales include Eshu and Hecate.
q2.raw_answer: crossroads [or intersections, I guess; accept any answer indicating the point where two, three, or more roads meet at a point; accept trivia; prompt on "roads"]

q3.quetsion_text: Tezcatlipoca once abducted this goddess of love and flowers. She was accompanied by a retinue of butterflies.

lead_in: A pulsar-driven cloud of energetic electrons trapped within this structure's magnetic field emits synchrotron radiation. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this thousand-year old supernova remnant whose radiation is used to study the Sun's corona and Saturn's moon Titan with a namesake pulsar in its center, also known as Messier 1.

q2.quetsion_text: The Crab Nebula is located in this constellation which marked the Sun's location in the spring equinox and which forms a complex with Auriga.

q3.quetsion_text: The Crab Nebula is often used to calibrate instruments that detect photons in this range, which is often emitted by binary stars that have matter moving from a donor to an accretor.

lead_in: Answer some questions about periods of fasting in the Eastern Orthodox Church,

q1.quetsion_text: The most important fasting time is this 40-day period stretching from Clean Monday till the vigil on Easter churches. In Western Christianity, this period begins on Ash Wednesday.

q2.quetsion_text: A two-week fast precedes this Orthodox holiday, which commemorates the death of the Theotokos. An Epitaphios of Mary is paraded on this holiday.
q2.raw_answer: Dormition of the Virgin [or Koimesis Theotokos; or Uspenie Presvetia Bogoroditsi]

q3.quetsion_text: Besides Lent and the Dormition, the other two main fasts are the Nativity Fast, and this fast, which honors the fast that the title group observed for the ten days after Christ's Ascension, in preparation for receiving the Holy Spirit.
q3.raw_answer: Apostles' Fast [or Fast of the Holy Apostles; or Fast of Peter and Paul; or St. Peter's Fast]

lead_in: Series of spectral lines of this element are named after Lyman, Balmer, Paschen, and Brackett.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this element whose spectrum was predicted using a model developed by Niels Bohr. The Bohr model did not work for any other elements with more electrons.

q2.quetsion_text: In the Bohr model, a hydrogen atom is said to be in this state if the electron is in the second or any higher energy orbital. This state is contrasted with the ground state.

q3.quetsion_text: This formula, named after its Swedish developer, can be used to calculate the wavelengths of spectral lines of the hydrogen atom.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this field of physics which is concerned with systems in which the relation between polarization and electric field is not simply described by a constant of proportionality.

q2.quetsion_text: In spontaneous parametric downconversion, a single photon is converted into a pair of photons that have this property. A pair of particles with this property is considered in the EPR paradox.

q3.quetsion_text: The photons produced by spontaneous parametric downconversion are matched with respect to this property, whose shift is the value phi in a sinusoid of the form "sin of (f t plus phi)." A different usage of this term denotes diagrams such as PV diagrams that show states of matter.
q3.raw_answer: phase [accept phase shifts or phase diagrams]

lead_in: One of these structures located in the city of Segovia contains niches displaying the Virgin of Fuencisca. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify these marvels of Roman engineering, such as the Anio Novus in Rome and the Pont du Gard in Nimes. Frontinus also called these water-transporting objects more useful than the "idle Pyramids" or anything the Greeks made.

q2.quetsion_text: The eleven aqueducts that went into Rome were eventually fed into this gigantic sewer underneath the city.

q3.quetsion_text: These apartment buildings in ancient Rome, which had running water and sanitation, primarily housed the plebs. More elite families lived in domus instead of these buildings, whose Latin name literally means "island."

lead_in: This man shared power with his brother Carloman and later engaged in military campaigns to spread Christianity, conquering the Lombards, Saxons, and Bavaria. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this Frankish king who was crowned Emperor of the Romans in 800 AD by Pope Leo III.
q1.raw_answer: Charlemagne [or Charles the Great; or Charles I; or Carolus Magnus; or Karl der Grosse]

q2.quetsion_text: Charlemagne commissioned the construction of the octogonal Palatine Chapel in this city. This city's cathedral also contains the cross of Lothair as well as Charlemagne's Throne as was used for many later coronations.

q3.quetsion_text: Charlemagne put down several revolts of these Germanic peoples who had earlier martyred St. Boniface. Pepin of Herstal defeated their king Radbod at Dorestad though Charles Martel suffered his only defeat to them at Cologne.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this common mafic and fine-grained extrusive igneous rock that is low in silica.

q2.quetsion_text: Basalt is fine-grained because it forms in this place, allowing it to cool quickly. This gives basalt its designation as "extrusive."
q2.raw_answer: on the Earth's surface [or above ground; or outside the Earth's crust; or obvious equivalents; accept in the ocean or underwater or obvious equivalents]

q3.quetsion_text: Mid-ocean ridge basalts are heavily depleted in elements with this property, since they have gone through many melt-recrystallize cycles. This term describes elements that are preferentially excluded from a mineral's crystal structure.

lead_in: One of this man's two surviving books is divided into sections like Against the Arithmeticians, Against  the Musicians and Against the Physicists. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this second or third century philosopher and physician. His Outlines of Pyrrhonism is a  comprehensive account of a philosophy that attempts to find an equally convincing counter-argument  for any available argument.

q2.quetsion_text: Pyrrhonism is a school within this broad philosophical belief, which generally questions the  possibility of knowing anything for certain.

q3.quetsion_text: Carnaedes led a contemporaneous school of skepticism with this name. It shares its name with an  institution that Plato led in Athens, where Aristotle studied before founding the Lyceum.
q3.raw_answer: the Academy [or Akademia; or Academic skepticism]

lead_in: Due to the unique layout of the stars depicted on this diagram, parts of it have been assigned colorful names like the "main sequence", "horizontal branch", and "instability strip". For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these diagrams with vertical axes of luminosity and absolute magnitude, horizontal axes of spectral class and color, and on which are plotted an assload of stars.

q2.quetsion_text: Because a star's luminosity is related to its surface area and temperature, anyone, even Chris Ray, can calculate this quantity given said measurables and the Stefan-Boltzmann equation, where it's squared.

q3.quetsion_text: All of a star's properties can be determined from its chemical composition and mass according to this unproven but widely accepted theorem. It's the reason stars fall into groups on the HR diagram, and thus the only reason HR diagrams are of any use at all.

lead_in: In this painting, Celia Birtwell is shown standing in a dark purple and red dress on the left. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this painting, which shows a man in a blue shirt and jeans with a white cat on his lap.
q1.raw_answer: Mr and Mrs Clark and Percy

q2.quetsion_text: Mr and Mrs Clark and Percy was painted by this British artist, who explored homosexual love with We Two Boys Together Clinging. He painted many scenes of swimming pools, such as A Bigger Splash.

q3.quetsion_text: David Hockney was a contributor to this art movement, whose major practitioners in America included Roy Lichtenstein and Andy Warhol.

lead_in: An autoimmune condition in which there are antibodies to this substance's receptors is called Myasthenia Gravis.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this neurotransmitter which carries signals across the neuromuscular junction. Sarin and other nerve agents block the enzyme that breaks it down.

q2.quetsion_text: This type of acetylcholine receptor is present on skeletal muscle and neurons, as opposed to muscarinic receptors, which exist in the heart.

q3.quetsion_text: The flow of an ion of this element is controlled by the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor, which is exchanged for potassium in a very common active transporter.

lead_in: Though she won second place in the 1908 Prix de Rome for her cantata La Sirene, she is not mainly remembered for her own compositions.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this legendary French music teacher. Her students include such diverse figures as Virgil Thomson, Philip Glass, Joe Raposo, and Quincy Jones.

q2.quetsion_text: Boulanger taught this Argentinian composer and bandoneon player whose fusion of tango with Baroque counterpoint and jazz harmony was called nuevo tango.

q3.quetsion_text: Boulanger also taught this legendary Harvard composition professor, whose students included Leonard Bernstein. He wrote the most famous American textbooks on harmony, counterpoint, and orchestration, and his own pieces include Three New England Sketches and the ballet The Incredible Flutist.

lead_in: Bonus: It mentions how “yonder all before us lie/ Deserts of vast eternity.” For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this metaphysical poem which begins with the line, “Had we but world enough, and time,” and whose speaker hears “Time’s winged chariot hurrying near.”

q2.quetsion_text: “To His Coy Mistress” is a work written by this English poet, whose other poems include “Upon Appleton House” and “The Garden.”

q3.quetsion_text: This member of the Modernist school of poetry wrote “You, Andrew Marvell,” but is perhaps more famous for a work in which Nickles loses a bet with Zuss that J.B. will curse God if he loses his property and wealth.

lead_in: This decree was issued at an imperial diet held in Nuremberg in 1356. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this decree, which set a procedure whereby seven electors from different regions would choose the next Holy Roman Emperor upon a vacancy of that office.

q2.quetsion_text: The secular electors included the margrave of this northeastern German state, which merged into Prussia in the 1600s.

q3.quetsion_text: The Golden Bull was promulgated under Charles IV of this house, which held the Holy Roman Emperorship under Sigismund prior to the Habsburgs.

lead_in: This philosopher summarized relations between de re modal sentences in his octagon of opposition and streamlined the theory of supposition in his Summulae de dialectica.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this French medieval philosopher who developed the idea of impetus. His moral philosophy was satirized in a thought experiment in which an eponymous "ass" starves to death, unable to choose between equidistant bales of hay.

q2.quetsion_text: Buridan's ass is a paradox about this concept, which denotes an agent's ability to make unimpeded choices. Compatibilists believe it is compatible with determinism.

q3.quetsion_text: Like many medieval logicians, Buridan commented on this commentary on Aristotle's Categories by Porphyry, which Boethius translated into Latin. It contained a famous tree of dichotomous divisions called the Arbor Porphyriana.

lead_in: Answer some questions about the strong force, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This structure, which is held together by the strong force, consists of protons and neutrons.

q2.quetsion_text: This theory of color-charged particles is used to describe the action of the strong force. According to this theory, the strong force becomes weaker as the distance decreases and the energy increases.

q3.quetsion_text: These baryons, which have a spin and isospin of 3/2, decay into a nucleon and a pion via the strong force. Their four types form an isospin quartet.

lead_in: Name these leaders of South American countries, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: After being jailed for an unsuccessful 1992 coup against Carlos Andres Perez, this Venezuelan president, who died in 2013, was elected with the support of the Fifth Republic Movement.

q2.quetsion_text: This half-Bulgarian leader of the Workers' Party succeeded Lula as president of Brazil.

q3.quetsion_text: This woman served as a pediatrician before defeating Sebastian Pinera in a 2006 election, but lost a 2010 rematch.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this quantity, which equals the algebraic mean of the values one would observe if the operator were applied to each member of a large ensemble of identical states.
q1.raw_answer: expectation value [or expected value; prompt on "mean"]

q2.quetsion_text: This term describes pairs of observables whose corresponding Hermitian operators have a simultaneous eigenstate and are not restricted by the Heisenberg uncertainty principle.
q2.raw_answer: compatible [or word forms; prompt on commuting or word forms]

q3.quetsion_text: The simultaneous eigenstates of the operators corresponding to the square and z-component of this classical kinematic quantity are spherical harmonics. Classically, it is equal to "omega" times the moment of inertia.
q3.raw_answer: angular momentum [or rotational momentum; do not prompt on or accept "momentum"]

lead_in: The protagonist of this poem has a vision of the future, according to which"the kindly earth shall slumber, lapt in universal law". For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this poem in which a soldier passing by the title edifice, his childhood home, angrily reminisces about losing the love of his cousin Amy.

q2.quetsion_text: "Locksley Hall" was written by this Victorian poet of "Ulysses" and "Tithonus", who described a ride "into the Valley of Death" in his "Charge of the Light Brigade."
q2.raw_answer: Alfred, Lord Tennyson [or Alfred Tennyson, 1st Baron Tennyson]

q3.quetsion_text: The title figure of this short romantic poem by Tennyson "clasps the crag with crooked hands" and "watches from his mountain walls", the latter from which "like a thunderbolt he falls."

lead_in: Bonus: The Venturi effect explains the reduction in this as fluid flows through a constricted section. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this property, which can be computed as density times gravitational acceleration times height for a fluid. It can be measured in pascals, torr, or atmospheres, and equals force per unit area.

q2.quetsion_text: This statement, named after a Swiss scientist, explains how an increase in fluid speed results in a decrease in pressure.

q3.quetsion_text: Bernoulli's principle generally only holds for these types of fluids in which the density is constant and the divergence of the fluid velocity vector equals zero.

lead_in: This group was also known as the Greengrocers for their strictly vegetarian habits.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this group of syncretic Shi'a Ismailis who set up a utopian state in what is now Bahrain. This group originated in Salamiyyah and its state was at one point led by Abū-Tāhir Sulaymān

q2.quetsion_text: The Qarmatians openly revolted against this caliphate, the first to establish its capital at Baghdad. This caliphate's fifth ruler, Harun al-Rashid, established the House of Wisdom.

q3.quetsion_text: The Qarmatians sacked this city in 930 CE. The Banu Umayya of this city were part of a tribe that had earlier signed the Treaty of Hudaybiyyah with a northern rival.
q3.raw_answer: Mecca [or Makkah al-Mukarramah; accept Faran or Bakkah if they want to give weird/old names]

lead_in: Bonus: Photons are shown as a wave on these plots, while fermions such as quarks are represented by straight lines. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify these pictorial diagrams that model the behavior of subatomic particles, named after an American physicist.

q2.quetsion_text: These bosons are shown as a spiral helix on Feynman diagrams. They have color charge and mediate the strong force.

q3.quetsion_text: Photons are produced during annihilation when electrons collide with positrons, which are these types of particles denoted by an overline. Compared to their regular counterparts, they have equal mass, but opposite charge.

lead_in: This city was built on Mount Mithridat, and in later times it would be known as Kerch.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this city, from which the Archaeanactids and Spartacids ruled the Bosporan kingdom. It was heavily damaged by an earthquake in 70 CE and destroyed by the Huns in 370 CE.

q2.quetsion_text: Pantikapaion and the Bosporan kingdom were located on this peninsula jutting out into the Black Sea. The ruins of Chersonesos can be found in the city of Sevastopol on this peninsula, which was known as Taurike to the Greeks.

q3.quetsion_text: The Bosporan kingdom conducted trade with these Iranic peoples, many of whom served as cavalry in Bosporan armies. These people originally displaced the Cimmerians and would later be displaced by the Sarmatians.
q3.raw_answer: Scythians [or Skythoi; or Scythi; or Iskutae]

lead_in: Bonus: The speaker of this work claims, “An aged man is but a paltry thing.” For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this poem which states that a certain place is “no country for old men” and whose speaker asks sages to “consume my heart away”.

q2.quetsion_text: “Sailing to Byzantium” was written by this Irish poet, who also wrote that “Things fall apart; the centre cannot hold” in his poem, “The Second Coming.”

q3.quetsion_text: This poem by W.B. Yeats describes some “Chinamen” carved in the title blue stone that have “ancient, glittering eyes” and over whom “flies a long-legged bird”.

lead_in: This island saw the Siege of Drogheda led by Oliver Cromwell.  For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this European island, nicknamed the Emerald Isle, where Elizabeth I imposed the Protestant faith and the Anglican Church on native Catholics. That was most successful in an area around Dublin, this island's Pale.

q2.quetsion_text: Elizabeth I subjugated Ireland by giving these lands to English farmers, settlers, and explorers. Undertakers, servitors, and freeholders ruled these monocultural agricultural plots after swearing an Oath of Supremacy.

q3.quetsion_text: This largest plantation was established in Northern Ireland by James I in 1609, and Lord Chichester made Belfast its capital. In the English Civil War, Scots and Irish rebelled here until the New Model Army restored order.

lead_in: Name some things relating to groups with eight members, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: The bases of this extension of the complex numbers can be treated as a group. This system adds j and k to i as square roots of negative one and is non-commutative.

q2.quetsion_text: Another group with eight members is the set of symmetries of the square. Symmetries of ngons are these types of groups, usually written D-sub-n or D-sub-two-n.

q3.quetsion_text: The quaternion and dihedral group possess this property, as do all groups by definition. In objects with this property, parentheses may be moved without affecting the outcome of the operations.

lead_in: One document supporting this movement was the manifesto "Revolt Against the City".

q1.quetsion_text: Name this movement championed by Grant Wood and Thomas Hart Benton that advocated realistic painting and a focus on rural subject matter. It was closely associated with WPA mural painting.

q2.quetsion_text: This Regionalist painter is best-known for his mural for the Kansas State Capitol of John Brown looking especially wild-eyed and holding a rifle; that work by him is Tragic Prelude.

q3.quetsion_text: In the foreground of this Curry painting, a woman in a yellow floral print dress stands in the crowd gathered in front of a red barn around a round tank of water, in which a man in a suit holds up a woman wearing white.

lead_in: Like the Warsaw Pact, this organization's alternate name of Manila Pact reflected its founding in Manila. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this organization aimed at combating communist influence in South Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia, the Phillipines, Australia and New Zealand, whose main architect was John Foster Dulles.

q2.quetsion_text: Thailand joined SEATO after learning of the creation of the "Thai Autonomous Region" in this province of China, although it does not even border it. Mao Zedong first studied politics in its capital of Chansha, which was later entirely burned to the ground after Chiang Kai-Shek thought it was about to fall to the Japanese.

q3.quetsion_text: SEATO did not have a mutual defense clause in case of attack, unlike this other organization between the United States and most countries in Western Europe, on the opposite side of the Warsaw Pact.

lead_in: James Stockdale was inspired by this philosopher during his stint as a POW in Vietnam. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this philosopher from Hierapolis, whose Discourses were recorded by his student Arrian. This man inspired, and was repeatedly quoted in, the Meditations of Marcus Aurelius.

q2.quetsion_text: Epictetus was, like Marcus Aurelius after him, a practitioner of this school of philosophy, which emphasized virtue, reason and freedom from emotions.

q3.quetsion_text: Epictetus also wrote a book with this title, which translates as "Manual" or "Handbook." Erasmus also wrote a book with this word in the title addressed to a Christian knight.

lead_in: A committee that opposed this movement adopted Jingo the Dinosaur as a mascot.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this movement that centered on the "Plattsburgh idea" of providing military training camps for civilians. Charles Mooney was accused of bombing a parade celebrating this movement's day in San Francisco.
q1.raw_answer: Preparedness Movement [or Preparedness Day; or the Preparedness Controversy]

q2.quetsion_text: The Preparedness movement was a response to this war. The US eventually entered this war thanks in part to the Zimmerman Note and the sinking of the Lusitania.
q2.raw_answer: World War I [or the Great War]

q3.quetsion_text: This general was a leading figure of the movement. He had earlier allowed the Moro Crater Massacre and organized the Rough Riders along with Teddy Roosevelt.

lead_in: Identify the following about geographically unexpected sharks,

q1.quetsion_text: Bull sharks can be found in this freshwater lake, the largest in Central America, which they enter by jumping over the rapids of the San Juan River. Unfortunately, a waterfall prevents the sharks from entering the nearby Lake Managua.
q1.raw_answer: Lake Nicaragua [or Lake Cocibolca; or Lake Granada; or Mar Dulce; accept "Lago" for "Lake" in all instances]

q2.quetsion_text: Flooding on the Logan and Albert rivers made Carbrook Golf Course in this state the home of several bull sharks. This state is home to the Cape York Peninsula, which borders the Torres Strait and the Gulf of Carpentaria.

q3.quetsion_text: Jaws was inspired in part by a series of unexpected 1916 shark attacks that took place 15 miles from the ocean in this state's Matawan Creek, which drains into Raritan Bay.
q3.raw_answer: New Jersey [prompt on answers like "the Jersey Shore"]

lead_in: This philosopher went mad two years after he derided the Christian "slave morality" in On the Genealogy of Morals.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this German, who wrote that "God is dead" in The Gay Science. He also wrote that a post-human ubermensch would come soon in Thus Spake Zarathustra.

q2.quetsion_text: This book, Nietzsche's first, describes how the dreamy, bright Apollonian impulse blended with the frenzied Dionysian to give ancient Greek art and drama their power.
q2.raw_answer: The Birth of Tragedy Out of the Spirit of Music [or Die Geburt der TragÃ¶die aus dem Geiste der Musik]

q3.quetsion_text: Nietzsche wrote on this depressive German thinker "as Educator." This man argued that people should turn towards art, and away from the thing-in-itself, in The World as Will and Representation.

lead_in: Bonus: Its Kazan Cathedral lies on Nevsky Prospekt. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this city at the mouth of the Neva on the Gulf of Finland that was constructed by its namesake as the new capital of Imperial Russia.

q2.quetsion_text: Bartolomeo Rastrelli designed this St. Petersburg palace and official residence of the tsars, which was ransacked during the Russian Revolution and has since been converted into the Hermitage Museum.

q3.quetsion_text: Outside the Winter Palace in Palace Square stands one of these monuments dedicated to Alexander I. Other ones of these monuments include one dedicated to Horatio Nelson in Trafalgar Square and one built by Trajan.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this 1998 film in which the mathematician Max Cohen repeatedly encounters a 216 digit number spit out by his computer Euclid.

q2.quetsion_text: Pi is the first film of this American director of Black Swan and Requiem for a Dream.

q3.quetsion_text: In this other Aronofsky film, Mickey Rourke plays Randy "The Ram" Robinson, who meets Marisa Tomei and plans for a rematch with his old rival "The Ayatollah."

lead_in: People observing this holiday may perform "long confession," called al chet, or "short confession,"  called vidui. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Jewish Day of Atonement on which the Kol Nidre is recited.

q2.quetsion_text: Yom Kippur concludes a period of repentance in Judaism that lasts this many days at the start of the  month of Tishrei. That period of this many days begins with Rosh Hashanah.
q2.raw_answer: ten [or Ten Days of Repentance; or Aseret Yemei Teshuva]

q3.quetsion_text: In this other Jewish holiday in Tishrei, blessings are recited over the lulav and etrog. This holiday is  meant to commemorate the forty years the Jewish people spent in the desert, and the fragile tents in  which they slept.
q3.raw_answer: Sukkot [or Sukkos; or the Feast of Booths; or the Feast of Tabernacles]

lead_in: This painting hung in the monastery at San Giorgio Maggiore for 235 years before it was plundered by Napoleon and shipped off to Paris. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this massive oil painting, which shows Suleiman the Magnificent among numerous historical figures seated at a massive table, at whose center Jesus sits.

q2.quetsion_text: Paolo Veronese, the painter of Wedding at Cana, created a version of this scene which he later retitled Feast in the House of Levi at the Church's request. Da Vinci made notable use of perspective in his depiction of this scene.
q2.raw_answer: The Last Supper [or Il Cenacolo; or L'Ultima Cena]

q3.quetsion_text: This man appears anachronistically dressed in pink Renaissance-era clothing in a Veronese painting of people kneeling before him. Another anachronistic depiction of this man is a "world landscape" that shows a massive fictitious mountain near Cyprus in the background.
q3.raw_answer: Alexander the Great [or Megas Alexandros; or Alexander III of Macedon]

lead_in: As part of his effort to get a "New Deal" for these animals, C. C. Little was able to secure Congressional funding for the National Cancer Institute.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify these creatures, made popular in research by the Jackson Laboratory, an institute who today houses an extensive genomic database of these animals.

q2.quetsion_text: C. C. Little worked with W. E. Castle, who helped popularize this friar's work on the genetics of pea plants in the United States.

q3.quetsion_text: Working at Jackson Laboratory, Elizabeth Russell performed one of these procedures on anemic mice in order to cure them of their anemia. Georges Mathe was unsuccessful in curing some irradiated Hungarian nuclear workers with this technique in the 1950s, although the development of the drug cyclosporine increased this procedure's odds of success.
q3.raw_answer: bone marrow transplantation [or Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation or HSCT]

lead_in: Bonus: Arthur Evans excavated a fresco in the Palace of Knossos that depicted this action. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this action that might have been used as a religious ritual by a certain Mediterranean civilization, whose performers used the namesake animals to receive momentum for their acrobatic feats.
q1.raw_answer: bull-leaping [accept answers that mention both “bulls” and synonyms of leaping, like “jumping”]

q2.quetsion_text: Bull-leaping was practiced by this ancient Mediterranean civilization that was based on the island of Crete. Its Linear A writing system was later adapted by the Mycenaeans into Linear B.

q3.quetsion_text: The Minoan civilization is believed to have been wiped out by one of these events that happened on the island of Thera. Another notable one of these events happened in 79 AD and buried the town of Pompeii.

lead_in: This man was sent to London on an education scholarship by the Umuofia Progressive Union, and returned to Lagos after getting a degree in English. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this man, a fictional Nigerian who is arrested on bribery charges after he persuades his lover Clara Okeke to get an abortion.

q2.quetsion_text: This Nigerian author of No Longer at Ease wrote about Obi's grandfather Okonkwo in Things Fall Apart

q3.quetsion_text: In this other postcolonial novel by Sudanese author Tayeb Salih, Mustafa Sa'eed recounts how his Western education in London led into racially-charged seductions of white women.
q3.raw_answer: Season of Migration to the North [or Mawsim al-Hi'ra'il ash-Sham'l]

lead_in: Two fat women with slitted eyes play cards in a painting in this series called Rose and Amelie, while another of its paintings depicts a redhead clutching a man and was originally called Love and Pain.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this series of paintings including Vampire and a depiction of his own family mourning his sister Sophie called Death in the Sickroom.
q1.raw_answer: The Frieze of Life - A Poem About Life, Love, and Death [or Livsfrisen]

q2.quetsion_text: The Frieze of Life was painted by this Norwegian artist of some topless Madonnas and The Scream.

q3.quetsion_text: This other painting in the Frieze of Life depicts the aftermath of a tryst between a woman whose white top is still not fully buttoned and a man in black who is hunched over in the bottom left.

lead_in: This adjective is the first of two applied to ensembles which are open and in thermal equilibrium with  some reservoir. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this adjective which is applied to systems defined by mu, V, and T. It is not applied to closed  NVT ensembles.
q1.raw_answer: grand [or grand canonical ensemble, do not accept canonical]

q2.quetsion_text: Mu stands for this quantity, the derivative of free energy with respect to particle number. It is the  change in energy of a system when one more particle is added.

q3.quetsion_text: The probability of a given microstate in the grand canonical ensemble equals an exponential of a  fraction with this German's namesake constant, symbolized k, in the denominator. He names a particle  speed distribution with Maxwell.

lead_in: This politician defended a man accused of killing several police officers in the Carrickshock Massacre.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this founder of the Catholic Association and leader of the Catholic Emancipation movement.

q2.quetsion_text: O'Connell signed this agreement with the Whig Party. This compact helped lead to the fall of Peel's government and to the beginning of Melbourne's six-year term as Prime Minister.

q3.quetsion_text: O'Connell was also influential in the abolition movement where he probably met this leader of the movement. This very religious dude co-founded the ASS and was a leader of the Clapham Sect.

lead_in: This man married the white feminist Helen Pitts.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this African-American activist. After escaping slavery, he became a prominent abolitionist and wrote such books as My Bondage and My Freedom.
q1.raw_answer: Frederick Douglass [or Frederick Augustus Washington Bailey]

q2.quetsion_text: Douglass was also a supporter of women's rights and attended this 1848 conference in New York. This landmark convention produced the Declaration of Sentiments.

q3.quetsion_text: From 1847 to 1851, Douglass published this anti-slavery newspaper. This abolitionist publication eventually merged with Gerrit Smith's Liberty Party Paper.

lead_in: This time period is the focus of the book And Their Children After Them. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this time period that is also the focus of much of Walker Evans' photographs, as collected in the book Let Us Now Praise Famous Men. Roy Stryker chaired an agency that took photos during this time period.
q1.raw_answer: Great Depression [or Dust Bowl; prompt on 1930s]

q2.quetsion_text: This woman took a famous photograph during the Depression called Migrant Mother.

q3.quetsion_text: This other Depression era photographer is best known for his photo entitled American Gothic, Washington, D.C., which shows a black cleaning woman holding a broom and mop in front of the American flag. He also directed the seminal blaxploitation film Shaft.

lead_in: Bonus: Like the related Aymaras, the women of this ethnic group often wear bowler hats. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this ethnic group that is indigenous to the Andes. The language of this ethnic group was used by the Incans to record messages on quipus.
q1.raw_answer: Quechua [accept more specific groups such as Runakuna, Kichwas, or Ingas]

q2.quetsion_text: The men of the Quechua people often wear these garments on their upper body. These pieces of fabric were also worn by gauchos and people seeking to keep dry from the rain.

q3.quetsion_text: Ponchos are traditionally made from the wool of sheep, alpacas, or this other domesticated species of the Andes. During Incan times, these animals could not be hunted, and instead were sacrificed in large numbers.

lead_in: A member of this school distinguished between "the way of truth" and "the way of opinion" in his philosophical poem On Nature. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this ancient school of philosophy that believed that everything was composed of one universal pantheistic substance. Its members included Parmenides and Zeno.

q2.quetsion_text: Zeno of Elea was famous for creating many of these scenarios that result in absurd conclusions. An example of one of them is the claim that since an arrow must not be moving at any given instant, it cannot move at all.

q3.quetsion_text: Another of Zeno's paradoxes states that this hero can never overtake a tortoise in a footrace in which the tortoise has a head start, since he will always need some time to reach the tortoise's previous position.

lead_in: Bonus: The Mantoux test can detect this disease. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this highly contagious lung disease abbreviated TB, which was called consumption in the past.

q2.quetsion_text: In the Mantoux test, if this structure forms an induration fifteen millimeters or wider after being injected with tuberculin, the person is considered positive for tuberculosis.

q3.quetsion_text: Like the pathogenic agent of leprosy, the bacterium that causes tuberculosis belongs to this genus. Drugs like rifampicin are effective against members of this genus, which was named due to its similar appearance to fungi.

lead_in: This author wrote about a sinister clown named Jerry Cobbold and an obsessive brute Jobber Skald in a novel set in Dorset, Weymouth Sands.

q1.quetsion_text: George Steiner singled out what writer's quartet of novels, which include A Glastonbury Romance, Wolf Solent, Maiden Castle and the aforementioned Weymouth Sands, as the only fictions comparable to Dostoyevsky?

q2.quetsion_text: In John Cowper Powys's Confessions of Two Brothers, Casanova, Rousseau, and this diarist who described the Great Fire of London, are named his most influential literary models.

q3.quetsion_text: Wolf Solent is partly set in Wessex, which shares its name with a fictional county that is the setting of many of this author's novels, such as The Return of the Native.

lead_in: A useful mnemonic notes that the signal from this technique is BOLD, or blood oxygen level dependent, since it effectively shows areas where higher concentrations of oxygenated blood are. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this imaging technique whose "functional" variant can be used to roughly show brain activity in real time without any danger of radiation.

q2.quetsion_text: At Harvard, Joshua Greene does fMRI studies of people considering this ethical problem to isolate brain areas related to moral reasoning. It considers a choice to kill one person or let five die as the title object approaches.

q3.quetsion_text: fMRI images are limited in precision to the width of these units of 3D graphical output, which in the sharpest fMRI images correspond to roughly 27 cubic millimeters of brain tissue.
q3.raw_answer: voxels [or volume pixels; do not prompt on "pixel"]

lead_in: Identify the following things from number theory, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this lemma which states that a polynomial with integer coefficients that factors into two polynomials with rational coefficients, factors into two polynomials with integer coefficients.

q2.quetsion_text: Euclid's algorithm is used to find this quantity by recursive division.
q2.raw_answer: greatest common divisor [or gcd; or greatest common factor; or gcf; or highest common factor; or hcf]

q3.quetsion_text: Wolstenholme's theorem states that for a prime p greater than three, this operation applied to two p minus one for p minus one is congruent to one mod p cubed. This operation is used to compute binomial coefficients and is contrasted with the permutation.
q3.raw_answer: k-combinations [or n choose k; or other variables in place of "k", such as "r"]

lead_in: This philosopher cited the examples of the ancient kings Yao and Shun as virtuous leaders. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this man whose school of philosophy is called the school of "ru," and whose thought dominated East Asian culture for millennia. Later followers of this man's philosophy included Mencius.
q1.raw_answer: Confucius [or Kongzi; or Kong Fuzi; or Kong Qiu]

q2.quetsion_text: This book, published posthumously by Confucius's disciples, collects his aphorisms. This work is one of the "Four Books" of Chinese classics.

q3.quetsion_text: Confucius also wrote a commentary called the Ten Wings on this religious text. This work is often used for divinations and it contains sixty-four hexagrams.
q3.raw_answer: I Ching [or Book of Changes; or Classic of Changes; or Zhouyi; or Yijing]

lead_in: Romeo and Juliet were not the only star-crossed lovers.

q1.quetsion_text: These two Babylonian lovers can only talk to each other through a crack in the wall. They appear in Ovid's Metamorphoses, and Bottom hilariously butchers a play version of their story in A Midsummer Night's Dream.
q1.raw_answer: Pyramus and Thisbe [accept names in either order]

q2.quetsion_text: These lovers in Arthurian legend fall in love as the man is bringing back the woman for his uncle King Mark, who later kills him after discovering their affair. Their story was adapted into an opera by Wagner.
q2.raw_answer: Tristan and Iseult [or Tristan und Isolde; or Drustanus or Tristram instead of Tristan; accept names in either order]

q3.quetsion_text: Arthurian legend also features an affair between Queen Guinevere and this Knight of the Round Table. King Arthur reluctantly banishes this man for the affair, and he becomes a monk after Arthur's death.

lead_in: In this opera, Arline, kidnapped sweetheart of the Polish noble Thaddeus, dreams "that you loved me still the same" while reminiscing about her childhood in the court of her father, Count Arnhelm.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this opera by Michael William Balfe most famous for its aria "I Dreamt I Dwelt in Marble Halls."

q2.quetsion_text: Balfe was from this island, the home of John Field, who wrote the first nocturnes. Victor Herbert was born on this island, which is also home to flautist James Galway.

q3.quetsion_text: Four of Balfe's friends, including Luigi Lablache, premiered this Vincenzo Bellini opera, whose "Credeasi, misera" contains an absurd high F as Arturo, a Cavalier, pleads to be with Elvira.

lead_in: One exponent of this movement, Mario Luzi, wrote a poetic sequence in which the title painter travels from Avignon to Siena in The Earthly and Heavenly Journey of Simone Martini.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this poetic movement that venerates using challenging words to convey obscure ideas, and whose exponents include Salvatore Quasimodo and Eugenio Montale.

q2.quetsion_text: The Joy of Shipwrecks and The Feeling of Time are poetry collections by this third major figure of the Hermetic movement, who wrote many of his works while living in Brazil.

q3.quetsion_text: Giuseppe Ungaretti's The War contains pro-war poems like "Brothers," a view espoused by this group of poets and artists who praised the beauty of speed. Its manifesto was written by Filippo Marinetti.

lead_in: This man's popular works include "Hark! the Herald Angels Sing" and "O for a Thousand Tongues to Sing." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this man who wrote thousands of hymns for a fledgling church founded by his brother.

q2.quetsion_text: Charles Wesley and his brother John were leaders of this Christian denomination, which prioritized careful Bible study and open air preaching.

q3.quetsion_text: Phillis Wheatley memorialized this early leader of the Methodist movement. This leader of the First Great Awakening looked like a giant baby.

lead_in: This leader freed the hektemeroi by instituting a "shaking-off of debts." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this leader who wrote a new law-code to replace a harsher one written by Draco.

q2.quetsion_text: This friend of Solon led the hyperakrioi and ruled Athens as a tyrant for 33 years; he was succeeded by his sons Hippias and Hipparchus.

q3.quetsion_text: These two men became known as the "tyrannicides" for killing Hipparchus and beginning the restoration of Athenian democracy.
q3.raw_answer: Harmodius and Aristogeiton [either order, but don't accept or prompt on just one]

lead_in: A school of economic thought named after this man was founded by Piero Sraffa and attempted to improve this man's labor theory of value. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this British political economist who wrote Principles of Political Economy and Taxation. He opposed the Corn Laws and came up with the theory of comparative advantage.

q2.quetsion_text: This other 19th century British economist wrote about the supposedly-inevitable overtaking of the food supply by exponential population growth in his An Essay on the Principle of Population.

q3.quetsion_text: This British economist made key contributions to the theory of marginal utility. He is also known for suggesting that coal extraction would reach a peak level in his book The Coal Question.

lead_in: The earliest of these lined the springs of lakes Xochimilco and Chalco.

q1.quetsion_text: Name these so-called "floating gardens" used by inhabitants of the Valley of Mexico to grow crops in shallow lake beds and similar locations.

q2.quetsion_text: There were an awful lot of chinampas in this Aztec capital city located on Lake Texcoco, where they were created by fencing in sections of the lake bed. This city was the site of the Templo Mayor.

q3.quetsion_text: The Aztec Empire was composed of the alliance of Tenochtitlan, Texcoco, and this other city, which participated in the conquest of Azcapotzalco. Following that conquest, this city's ruler took the title, "Lord of the Tepanecs."

lead_in: The "clever slave" is a prominent stock character in this man's plays.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this ancient Roman comic playwright of Pseudolus and Miles Gloriosus. Like Terence, he drew on the Greek comedies of Menander in his works.

q2.quetsion_text: This Plautus play begins with a household god explaining how Phaedria's father, the miser Euclio, found the title treasure under his house. Euclio is later robbed by the slave of Lyconides.

q3.quetsion_text: In this Shakespeare play, based on Plautus's Menaechmi, hilarity ensues when Antipholus of Syracuse and his slave Dromio are both mistaken for their long-lost twin brothers.

lead_in: This equation gives the heat flux as proportional to the temperature gradient.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this basic equation of heat conduction named for the French scientist who postulated it.

q2.quetsion_text: Fourier's law is a particular example of Fick's law, which models this process by relating a flux current to a concentration gradient via the constant of proportionality. This process occurs for particles suspended in a fluid via Brownian motion.

q3.quetsion_text: Fourier's law can be used to derive the heat equation, which sets the time derivative of the temperature proportional to its Laplacian; that makes the heat equation this type of partial differential equation named after a conic section.

lead_in: This poem's speaker mentions the title features being "ancient as the world and older than the / flow of human blood in human veins."

q1.quetsion_text: Name this poem, whose speaker "bathed in the Euphrates when dawns were young" and "heard the singing of the Mississippi when Abe Lincoln / went down to New Orleans."

q2.quetsion_text: "The Negro Speaks of Rivers" is by this Harlem Renaissance poet who authored the collection Fine Clothes to the Jew.

q3.quetsion_text: Hughes' poem "The Weary Blues" discusses a man who played "by the pale dull pallor of an old gas light." After he stops playing, that man, "while the weary blues echoed through his head" goes to sleep like one of these two objects.
q3.raw_answer: "a rock or a man that's dead" [both underlined answers required, order doesn't matter.]

lead_in: Versene contains a sodium salt of this compound that was discovered by Ferdinand Munz, a Nazi scientist who was searching for a cheap alternative to citric acid. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this hexadentate ligand commonly used for complexometic titrations. It has four carboxylic acid moieties.
q1.raw_answer: EDTA [or ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid; or diaminoethane-tetraacetic acid; or edetic acid; or ethylenedinitrilo-tetraacetic acid]

q2.quetsion_text: Metals chelated by EDTA usually adopt this molecular geometry, which consists of six ligands and no lone pairs.

q3.quetsion_text: Metals that adopt an octahedral geometry will have the d orbitals split into two classes: those with e-sub-g symmetry, and those with this other symmetry. These orbitals correspond to the dxy, dyz, and dxz atomic orbitals.

lead_in: One of these compounds forms a bond with a boronic acid in the Liebeskind-Srogl coupling. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this sulfur-containing functional group which is found in acetyl-CoA and other derivatives of coenzyme A. This kind of bond also is formed between ubiquitin and its substrate.

q2.quetsion_text: Speaking of sulfur, thiols are sometimes named for the fact that they can bind to this element. Its dimethyl form is a really poisonous NMR standard that killed Karen Wetterhahn, and it is also present in the preservative thimerosal.

q3.quetsion_text: An amalgam of zinc and mercury is used as a reducing agent in this reaction, which is used as a gentler, acidic alternative to the Wolff-Kishner reduction. It is used to transform ketones to alkanes.

lead_in: Part of the proof of this theorem can be used to show that any compact subset of a Hausdorff space is closed.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this theorem that states that subsets of Euclidean space are compact if and only if they are closed and bounded.

q2.quetsion_text: The actual definition of compact is that every cover of the space has one of these.

q3.quetsion_text: The Arzela-Ascoli theorem says that a bounded equicontinuous sequence will have this kind of subsequence. This property for a sequence roughly means that it gets arbitrarily close to some point.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this author of What Price Glory?, an American playwright who wrote about the trial of Socrates in Barefoot in Athens and fictionalized the Sacco and Vanzetti trial in Winterset.

q2.quetsion_text: In this Anderson play with a title taken from Romeo and Juliet, Alan McLean attempts to fight a costly House resolution, but his plan to add nonsensical amounts of pork to it to ensure a veto backfires when it passes with a supermajority.

q3.quetsion_text: Van van Dorn, the protagonist of Anderson's High Tor, encounters a group of ghostly Dutchmen very similar to the ninepins enthusiasts who put the protagonist of this Washington Irving story to sleep for twenty years.

lead_in: The interaction between the oscillating liquid and a pressure gradient creates the Bjerknes forces that contribute to this effect.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this phenomenon in which the collapse of a cavitation bubble causes the conversion of sound waves into light.

q2.quetsion_text: Sonoluminesence can be modeled by this equation which relates the pressures both within and outside the bubble to its radius over time.

q3.quetsion_text: This American scientist believes that the Casimir effect is directly responsible for sonoluminesence. With Feynman and Tomonaga, this scientist won the Nobel Prize in Physics for his work on QED.

lead_in: Answer these questions about the moons of Jupiter.

q1.quetsion_text: One possible home for extraterrestrial life is this icy moon in 2-to-1 orbital resonance with Io.

q2.quetsion_text: Europa and Io are two of the four moons in this group, named for their discoverer.

q3.quetsion_text: E.E. Barnard discovered this moon in a closer orbit than the Galilean moons. This moon, like Thebe, has a namesake faint ring around Jupiter.

lead_in: Bonus: For ten points each, answer the following about recent deaths among world leaders:

q1.quetsion_text: This former president of Venezuela died in March 2013 and was succeeded by his Minister of Foreign Affairs, Nicolas Maduro, as President.

q2.quetsion_text: The funeral of this former Prime Minister took place in April 2013. Cristina Kirchner was not invited to that funeral due to tensions over the Falkland Islands brought on by this female British Prime Minister.

q3.quetsion_text: A former dictator of this country named Jorge Videla was sentenced to life in prison for kidnapping children, where he died in May 2013.

lead_in: A pre-Columbian culture named for this river traded its distinctive shell-tempered pottery as far away from it as Etowah, Georgia, and built the Monks' Mound earthwork at the Cahokia site around 1000 CE. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this river, which was the US's western border prior to the Louisiana Purchase and then became the eastern border of the Louisiana Purchase.

q2.quetsion_text: This Spanish explorer, the first European to cross the Mississippi river, saw living descendants of the Mississippian culture as he met the Natchez tribes in what's now the Deep South of the US.

q3.quetsion_text: The Mississippian culture grew a triad of crops that were dubbed the "Three Sisters" or "Holy Trinity" of Indian agriculture because they helped each other grow and provided all twenty standard amino acids. Name all three.
q3.raw_answer: corn, beans, and squash [accept in any order]

lead_in: The narrator of one work sees this man's name upon the cross's horns, and this man is chosen to command after the hermit Peter responds to his speech in the first book of another work.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this man who Dante sees after William of Orange and a Saracen named Renouard in the Cross of Souls in Purgatorio. In another work, Tancredi begs him not to arrest another character for the murder of Prince Gernando.
q1.raw_answer: Godfrey of Bouillon [or Goffredo di Buglione or Godefroy de Bouillon]

q2.quetsion_text: Godfrey of Bouillon leads the First Crusade in Jerusalem Delivered, by this 16th century poet, who worked for the Duke of Ferrara until he threw a temper tantrum at the Duke's wedding and got thrown into a madhouse.

q3.quetsion_text: In Jerusalem Delivered, Armida's spell over Rinaldo is ended by one of these objects. M.H. Abrams argued that Neoclassical aesthetics conceived as literature as one of these objects, as opposed to the Romantic conception of illumination.
q3.raw_answer: mirror [prompt on "shield", since the mirror in Jerusalem Delivered is used as a shield]

lead_in: This formation was frequently employed to advance to walls during sieges. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Roman infantry formation, in which scuta were used to cover all sides and the heads of the infantry formation, thus deflecting most enemy missiles harmlessly.

q2.quetsion_text: These large Roman infantry units were subdivided into cohortes of 480 men after the Marian reforms. Most people call the iconic roman miles by a word derived from these units, to whom an equal number of auxiliaries were attached.

q3.quetsion_text: At this battle during the Second Punic War, the legion was able to open up its maniples and let the Carthaginian elephants pass harmlessly through, allowing them to be defeated by light troops called velites.

lead_in: The petroleum at Manantiales on this archipelago is the only oil field in Chile. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this archipelago located just south of the mainland of South America.

q2.quetsion_text: This channel separates the main island of Tierra del Fuego from the southern islands of Navarino and Hoste. A dispute over the islands of Picton, Nueva, and the Lennox Islands in this channel nearly led to a 1978 war between Chile and Argentina.

q3.quetsion_text: Cruises tracing the voyage of Charles Darwin's HMS Beagle depart from this Argentine city, which is the capital of the province of Tierra del Fuego.

lead_in: In this novel, the seminary director Monsieur Pirard resigns because of his disgust for church politics. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this novel in which Julien Sorel is executed for shooting Madame de Renal.
q1.raw_answer: The Red and the Black [or Le Rouge et le Noir]

q2.quetsion_text: The Red and the Black is by this author, who also wrote the excellently named novella Vanina Vanini.

q3.quetsion_text: This woman becomes engaged to Monsieur de Croisenois despite her love for Julien Sorel. Julien makes her jealous by pretending to court Madame de Fervaques.
q3.raw_answer: Mathilde de la Mole [prompt on "de la Mole"]

lead_in: The Implicit Function Theorem is satisfied when the determinant of this matrix is non-zero.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this m by n matrix consisting of the partial derivatives of a function F from R n to R m.

q2.quetsion_text: The Jacobian is also used when changing variables while doing this. The fundamental theorem of calculus says that it is the opposite of differentiation.
q2.raw_answer: integration [accept word forms; accept more specific things]

q3.quetsion_text: The Lebesgue measure is defined as this element for the set of every possible countable union of boxes that covers a set. For a partially ordered set, this element is the largest element which is still less than or equal to every member of the set.

lead_in: For 10 points each, name the following terms related to protein folding

q1.quetsion_text: A protein's structure is determined by the sequence of these molecules with carboxyl and nitrogen-containing functional groups. Glycine is the smallest one, with a hydrogen side chain.

q2.quetsion_text: This numerical level of protein structure includes alpha helices and beta sheets formed by hydrogen bonding.

q3.quetsion_text: These proteins aid in the folding of other proteins. One type consists of two stacked rings, each with eight subunits in humans.

lead_in: The original pronunciation renders this poem's oxymoron "fatal loins" as the meta-reference "fatal lines". For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this sonnet by Shakespeare about a pair of "star-cross'd lovers" that opens, "two households, both alike in dignity" before describing what will be "two hours' traffic".
q1.raw_answer: prologue to Romeo and Juliet [do not accept "Romeo and Juliet"]

q2.quetsion_text: This character from Romeo and Juliet calls for "a plague o' both your houses" after he is fatally stabbed by Tybalt. He jokes, "ask for me tomorrow and you will find me a grave man".

q3.quetsion_text: In Act I, scene IV of Romeo and Juliet, Mercutio gives a speech about this fairy whose chariot is "drawn with a team of little atomies / athwart men's noses as they sleep", compelling people to dream.

lead_in: One work in this language comprises 1330 couplets divided into three sections about paals about virtue, wealth, and love.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this language of the Thirukkural. Ilango Adigal wrote about Kovalan's wrongful execution due to accusations he stole the queen's anklet, and his wife Kannagi's quest for revenge, in one of this language's five epics, the Silappatikaram.

q2.quetsion_text: Another medieval Indian poet was this Sanskrit writer. He described a yaksha's attempt to convey a message to his wife in The Cloud Messenger and also wrote The Recognition of Sakuntala.

q3.quetsion_text: Dushyanta gives Sakuntala one of these objects so that she can later take her rightful place as queen, but she loses it in the river.

lead_in: Answer the following about the geography of Antarctica, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This largest ice shelf of Antarctica is named for the British explorer who discovered it.

q2.quetsion_text: This district is divided into areas such as Sabrina Land and Knox Land. Bordering on AdÃ©lie Land, it is claimed by Australia.

q3.quetsion_text: This mountain, which is part of the Ellsworth mountains, is the highest mountain in Antarctica.

lead_in: Bonus: This effect is exhibited by rubbing a glass rod with silk. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this effect by which a material gets charged after coming in contact and transferring electrons with another object.

q2.quetsion_text: The triboelectric effect is greatly enhanced by this force that is generated when two rough surfaces slide past each other.

q3.quetsion_text: Friction is proportional to this force directed perpendicular to a surface. It can be found for an inclined plane by taking the force of gravity multiplied by the cosine of the angle of inclination.

lead_in: In the first story of this book, the narrator imagines his fox-like uncle devouring live chickens and piglets.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this collection of autobiographical stories that includes "Peaches." It was written by Dylan Thomas and has a Joyce-inspired title.
q1.raw_answer: Portrait of the Artist as a Young Dog

q2.quetsion_text: Dylan Thomas also wrote this poem in which the speaker urges his father to "Rage, rage against the dying of the light" and argues that "Old age should burn and rave at close of day."
q2.raw_answer: "Do not go gentle into that good night"

q3.quetsion_text: Thomas urges "Oh, keep his bones away from that common cart" in a poem describing the death of "a man aged a hundred" in one of these events.
q3.raw_answer: a dawn raid [or air raid; or bombing; or obvious equivalents]

lead_in: This collection contains short stories such as "The Unicorn in the Garden" and "The Rabbits Who Caused All the Trouble," which had previously appeared in The New Yorker.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this collection of stories, which also includes "Famous Poems Illustrated," such as John Greenleaf Whittier's "Barbara Frietchie."
q1.raw_answer: Fables for Our Time and Famous Poems Illustrated

q2.quetsion_text: Fables for Our Time and Famous Poems Illustrated was written by this man and cartoonist, who also wrote "The Secret Life of Walter Mitty."

q3.quetsion_text: James Thurber and E.B. White collaborated on this parody book that dismisses scientific and Freudian views of the title subject. It imagines a condition called "Recession Knee" in which a man reflexively pulls his knee away from a woman, since he is afraid of the title subject.

lead_in: This island contains Havelock, the greenshell mussel capital of the world. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this island also home to the wine-producing Marlborough region. Other wine-producing regions on this island include the Central Otago region and the Canterbury Plains region near Christchurch.

q2.quetsion_text: This country's South Island-driven wine industry overtook its wool industry in exports in 2008. You can drink flat white here in Auckland or eat some kiwifruit, which was first commercially cultivated here.

q3.quetsion_text: The Marlborough Region and New Zealand in general is best known for this variety of white wine, which was introduced to the world by Cloudy Bay Vineyards.

lead_in: The oldest lighthouse in this state is the Portland Head Light, while the most amusingly-named one is either Ladies Delight Light or The Cuckolds Light.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this state, in which Mount Katahdin serves as the northern terminus of the Appalachian Trail. It's the northeasternmost state in the continental U.S.

q2.quetsion_text: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. designed and financed a series of carriage trails in this National Park in Maine, which is located largely on Isle au Haut and Mount Desert Island.

q3.quetsion_text: The University of Maine is located in Orono, a suburb of this Maine city on the Penobscot river. It suffered a "Great Fire" in 1911, and in The Handmaid's Tale, Offred's tapes were discovered in the ruins of this city.

lead_in: For EDTA, which has six donor atoms, this quantity is six.
