q3.quetsion_text: This machine invented in the 18th century, which is not a simple machine, uses two weights hanging from a pulley to measure gravitational field strength.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this island invaded a century later by Oliver Cromwell, whose Protestant forces massacred the inhabitants of Wexford on this mostly-Catholic island west of England.

q2.quetsion_text: In 1495, Henry VII had Ireland placed firmly back under English control through this law, whose namesake he had made Lord Deputy of Ireland the year before.

q3.quetsion_text: Poynings's Law is sometimes named the Statute of this Irish city. Like Wexford, this city experienced a Cromwell massacre, during which its commander Arthur Aston was bludgeoned to death by his own wooden leg.

lead_in: This story's title character greets people by saying, "Hello, shell shock!"

q1.quetsion_text: Name this short story about Marjorie's socially awkward cousin who, after performing the title action, cuts off Marjorie's pigtails and leaves town.

q2.quetsion_text: "Bernice Bobs Her Hair" is by this Jazz-age author who wrote about Dick Diver in Tender Is the Night and about the ill-fated James Gatz in The Great Gatsby.

q3.quetsion_text: This first novel by Fitzgerald is about Amory Blaine, who befriends Monsignor Darcy and falls in love with Rosalind Connage, who spurns him for a wealthy man.

lead_in: This man was blinded and crippled after falling onto the plains of Aleion during an ill-fated and hubristic attempt to reach the top of Mount Olympus.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this hero of Greek mythology who married Philonoe after successfully completing an ostensible suicide mission set by King Iobates at the behest of Proetus of Tiryns.

q2.quetsion_text: Bellerophon's most famous accomplishment is the slaying of this fire-breathing Lycian creature, which had a snake for a tail. It also had the heads of a lion and a goat.

q3.quetsion_text: Bellerophon defeated the Chimera with the help of this divine winged horse.

lead_in: If this quantity is less than point oh-five, it is customary to use one asterisk; less than point ohone, two asterisks; less than point oh-oh-one, three asterisks, and so on. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this quantity which indicates the probability of observing a test statistic as extreme, or more extreme, than the measurement. Unlike alpha, it should only be calculated after the measurement is made.

q2.quetsion_text: A p-value of point oh-five corresponds to two standard deviations on this distribution, according to the empirical rule. According to the central limit theorem, the mean of a large number of random variables forms this distribution.
q2.raw_answer: normal distribution [or Gaussian distribution; prompt on bell curve]

q3.quetsion_text: Another method to test statistical significance, ANOVA, uses this test statistic. It is calculated as the variance between treatments divided by the variance within treatments, where the variances follow a chi-squared distribution.

lead_in: A character in this poem begins writing a history of the so-called "Battle of the Saints" while recuperating from a wound gained in North Africa working as a pig farmer with his wife Maud. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Major Plunkett appears alongside a blind man named Seven Seas in which twentieth-century epic poem, whose other major characters include the maid Helen and her suitors, the fishermen Achille and Hector?

q2.quetsion_text: This poet of "A Far Cry from Africa" and "Ruins of a Great House", a native of St. Lucia, wrote Omeros.

q3.quetsion_text: This book-length Walcott poem, which begins by describing people who "stroll on Sundays down Dronningens Street", relates the story of Camille Pissarro's move to Paris and includes 26 of Walcott's own paintings.

lead_in: An excess of this neurotransmitter's activity is associated with schizophrenia. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this neurotransmitter, which is associated with pleasure and reward-seeking behavior. It is a  precursor to norepinephrine.

q2.quetsion_text: Dopamine is part of this class of monoamine neurotransmitters, which contain a di-hydroxylated  phenyl group. Epinephrine and norepinephrine are also examples of this type of neurotransmitter.

q3.quetsion_text: All catecholamines are derived from this amino acid. Insulin binds to a receptor that causes kinases  to phosphorylate this amino acid.

lead_in: This story's title character begins to cry after noticing the people around her greedily eating their food, reminding her of how she had earlier offered them a basket of food. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this short story in which a group of people escaping from the Franco-Prussian War convince the title prostitute to sleep with a Prussian officer.
q1.raw_answer: "Ball of Fat" [or "Boule de Suif"; accept alternate translations like "Butterball" or "Ball of Lard"]

q2.quetsion_text: "Ball of Fat" is a short story by this French author of the stories "The Necklace" and "Mademoiselle  Fifi."
q2.raw_answer: Guy de Maupassant [or Henri RenÃ© Albert Guy de Maupassant]

q3.quetsion_text: In this Maupassant novel, Madeleine Forestier helps Georges Duroy write articles for the newspaper La Vie Francaise. Duroy has affairs with numerous women while rising through the ranks of Parisian society.
q3.raw_answer: Bel-Ami; or The History of a Scoundrel

lead_in: The calculus of variations was developed partially to help solve this problem.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this problem from physics, which asks what curve will fastest transport a mass only acted on by gravity.
q1.raw_answer: brachistochrone problem [do not accept tautochrone problem]

q2.quetsion_text: The solution to the brachistochrone problem is this curve, which can be generated by tracking the motion of a point on the circumference of a rolling circle. An ideal time-keeping pendulum would swing in this path.

q3.quetsion_text: The calculus of variations can also be used to solve this class of second-order linear ODEs, which can be recast as eigenvalue problems for self-adjoint operators. Regular examples have an infinite, ordered spectrum of real eigenvalues.
q3.raw_answer: Sturm-Liouville equations or problems or theory

lead_in: Bonus: This work contains a series of “Idols” that criticize the many ways humans have impeded objective reasoning. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this work by Francis Bacon that advocates using inductive reasoning and experimental procedures to reach a conclusion.

q2.quetsion_text: Bacon pioneered this mode of inquiry followed by researchers, whose steps include making observations, formulating hypotheses, designing experiments, and validating results.

q3.quetsion_text: Contrary to the rules of the scientific method, this man notably left out several data points when he measured the charge on an electron in his oil-drop experiment. Comments in his notebook include "Error high will not use."
q3.raw_answer: Robert Andrews Millikan [accept Millikan's oil drop experiment] <EC>

lead_in: Bonus: Answer these questions related to integration in calculus, for ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: One can take the integral of the function "1 divided by the quantity 1 plus x squared" using the inverse of this trigonometric function. In a right triangle, this function equals the ratio of the opposite side over adjacent side.

q2.quetsion_text: This method of integration involves splitting up the integrand to obtain an easier antiderivative to work with. It applies the product rule for differentiation, and can be used to find the integral of natural log of x.

q3.quetsion_text: The method of decomposition is often used to simplify rational functions in this form by splitting a larger one into a sum of smaller ones.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Give the general term for mental exercises which help the performer towards nirvana. It's often accompanied by breath control, mindfulness, focus, or the recitation of a mantra.

q2.quetsion_text: In Japanese Zen Buddhism, this pre-nirvana state of sudden enlightenment is the goal of zazen meditation. It is sometimes distinguished from kensho by its longer duration.

q3.quetsion_text: This form of Theravada meditation, sometimes called "insight meditation" or "analytic meditation," has a name meaning "seeing clearly." In contrast to samatha, which focuses on an outside object, it involves observing one's own mind in the present moment.

lead_in: Bonus: Le Chatelier’s principle can be applied to predict how these systems respond to change. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this state in which the forward and reverse reactions proceed at the same rate.

q2.quetsion_text: These substances increase the speed at which a system obtains equilibrium, but does not ultimately affect the equilibrium concentration.

q3.quetsion_text: These catalysts differ in phase from the reactants, such as a solid interacting with a gaseous reactant. Notable examples include Ziegler-Natta catalysts, Raney nickel, and iron oxide in the Haber-Bosch process.

lead_in: A magazine entitled "Today" published in this nation often featured the works of the Misty Poets. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this nation, whose other important literary figures included the author of a story about a man who begins to see the order to "eat people" in the lines of old texts, entitled "A Madman's Diary."

q2.quetsion_text: Lu Xun, the author of "A Madman's Diary," wrote the "true story" of this character, who convinces himself that he has won "spiritual victories" when in reality he keeps losing.

q3.quetsion_text: This other Chinese novel's protagonist is the compulsive gambler Xu Fugui, who loses his entire family and buys an ox as a companion. It was written by Yu Hua.

lead_in: The earliest known marketing pun was found in a wine advertisement discovered in this city. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this city, home to the Villa of the Mysteries, which was uncovered by Rocque Joaquin de Alcubierre. It, along with Herculaneum, suffered from a rather unfortunate natural disaster on August 24th.

q2.quetsion_text: This was the largest and richest house in Pompeii, probably owned by the rich Satria family. It is named for the statue standing in its rainwater basin, and it features the Alexander Mosaic, depicting the Battle of Issus.

q3.quetsion_text: The House of the Faun featured two of these rooms, one decorated with a mosaic of a boy riding a panther and the other with an aquatic theme. These rooms were Roman dining rooms named after the arrangement of their couches.

lead_in: Answer the following about prominent uses of the double bass in jazz, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This composer had a bass soloist pluck eight notes in D-Dorian, followed by a 2-note band response, then pluck 9 more notes, then get another 2-note response, in the head of "So What," the first track on his album Kind of Blue.

q2.quetsion_text: This ill-tempered bassist attacked a segregationist governor in "Fables of Faubus," and included a "Love-Chant" on his album Pithecanthropus Erectus. He also released an album titled for his surname followed by Ah Um.

q3.quetsion_text: The bass line to this jazz standard opens with the ascending half-steps G, A-flat, A, B-flat, then leaps up a seventh to play another A-flat and B-flat. It's the first track on the album Head Hunters.

lead_in: This man's namesake dichotomy makes a distinction between institutions and technology.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this economist, the author of Theory of the Leisure Class. He also names a type of good whose demand is proportional to its price, such as a luxury handbag or fancy wine.

q2.quetsion_text: Veblen worked at this university for 14 years, during which he published Theory of the Leisure Class. Other economists from this school include Ronald Coase and Milton Friedman.

q3.quetsion_text: One of Veblen's contributions to economics was this concept, which can be 'invidious' when done to provoke envy and has recently been applied to large public charity donations.

lead_in: The title character states that his goal for justice is to "make the punishment fit the crime," such as having the teeth of quack doctors extracted by amateurs.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this operetta in which Nanki-Poo disguises himself as a minstrel in order to court Yum-Yum.
q1.raw_answer: The Mikado (or The Town of Titipu)

q2.quetsion_text: These two men, a librettist and a composer, teamed up to write The Mikado, as well as other comic operas like The Pirates of Penzance and HMS Pinafore.
q2.raw_answer: William S. Gilbert and Arthur Seymour Sullivan

q3.quetsion_text: In The Mikado, all the town officials resigned when Ko-Ko became Lord High Executioner, so this character stepped in to fill their roles as Lord High Everything Else.

lead_in: Paintings in this style, which came in "analytic" and "synthetic" phases, usually use multiple perspectives  and break figures down into geometrical shapes. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this movement in early 20th-century painting that was pioneered by Pablo Picasso. Paintings in  this style include Three Musicians.

q2.quetsion_text: This other French painter was the other major pioneer of Cubism. He painted Houses at L'Estaque.

q3.quetsion_text: Many cubist works depict this musical instrument; a famous Braque painting pairs this instrument  with a candlestick.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this criminal syndicate which murders Astorre's adopted father Aprile in Omerta, the final book in a trilogy by Mario Puzo.

q2.quetsion_text: One of the earliest literary portrayals of the Sicilian Mafia was "The Gold Key," a story by this writer who is also known for a novel about Padron Ntoni and his family, including Bastianazzo, who dies in a shipwreck.

q3.quetsion_text: This author wrote about Mafia thievery of cattle in "The Dissolution of the League" and wrote a play in which Count de Nolli pays actors to pretend to be court subjects of his uncle, who thinks he's a Holy Roman Emperor.

lead_in: One of these things pertaining to eating prevented different sexes from dining together and was eliminated by a monarch who took power in 1819.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify these restrictions which helped protect the manna of a person or place. Violating one of these things was sometimes punishable by death.

q2.quetsion_text: The kapu system was used in these islands, until the kapus were mostly abolished by King Kamehameha II.

q3.quetsion_text: These high priests ranked below the ali'i mo'i and ali'i nui on a Hawaiian island and were tasked with memorizing and passing on chants called oli. They also made offerings to the akua.

lead_in: This man argued that the growth of bureaucratic, rational management would trap people in an "iron cage" and that modernity is characterized by disenchantment.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this sociologist who argued that the use of worldly success as a sign of being saved helped spur the development of capitalism in The Protestant Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism.

q2.quetsion_text: In this work, Weber outlined three grounds for legitimate authority based on charisma, tradition, and law, and claimed that the state was an institution with a monopoly on the legitimate use of force.
q2.raw_answer: Politics as a Vocation [or Politik als Beruf]

q3.quetsion_text: Weber's anti-positivism led him to embrace this interpretive process of understanding and relating to cultural actions from the actors' own point of view. It's German for "to understand."

lead_in: This opera, inspired by a comic strip written by Rudolf Tesnohlidek, ends with a gamekeeper dropping his gun after catching a frog instead of the title character, a reverse of what happens in the opening scene. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this racy fairy tale opera, whose lusty title character escapes from being tied up to a dog and is eventually shot by the poacher Harasta.
q1.raw_answer: The Cunning Little Vixen [or Prihody Lisky Bystrousky; or Adventures of Vixen Sharp-Ears]

q2.quetsion_text: The Cunning Little Vixen is much lighter than this Czech composer's portrait of jealousy and infanticide, Jenufa.

q3.quetsion_text: The House of Commons is lampooned in this duo's fairy tale opera Iolanthe, in which the Fairy Queen gives Strephon the ability to pass any bill he proposes as MP. They also produced HMS Pinafore.
q3.raw_answer: William Schwenk Gilbert and Arthur Sullivan

lead_in: The artist of this work may have painted himself as Apelles of Kos, while Diogenes of Sinope is sprawled across the steps.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this painting which depicts Zeno of Citium, Socrates and Plato.
q1.raw_answer: The School of Athens [or Scuola di Atene]

q2.quetsion_text: The School of Athens is a painting by this Renaissance artist, who also painted The Parnassus and a portrait of Pope Julius II ("the second").
q2.raw_answer: Raphael [or Raffaello Sanzio da Urbino or Raphael Sanzio da Urbino or Raphael Santi]

q3.quetsion_text: In another Raphael painting, this saint rides a horse over a broken lance while preparing to swing a sword at a dragon.

lead_in: This poem, which relates a legend that first appeared in Clemens Brentano's lay "Zu Bacharach am Rheine", describes a figure who "combs her golden hair" and "sings a song, passing time". For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this 1822 poem in which the "dulcet-voiced power" of the title woman causes the waves to "devour / both boat and man, by and by".

q2.quetsion_text: "The Lorelei" was written by this lyric poet of Atta Troll, whose Buch der Lieder was a popular source for Romantic composers looking to set poems.
q2.raw_answer: Heinrich Heine [or Christian Johann Heinrich Heine]

q3.quetsion_text: Heine mocks the society that spent hundreds of years constructing KÃ¶ln Cathedral, describes being stalked by an axe-carrying "special devil", and visits Frederick Barbarossa in a dream in various parts of this satirical epic.
q3.raw_answer: Germany: A Winter's Tale [or Deutschland. Ein WintermÃ¤rchen; prompt on partial answer]

lead_in: This novel features Luigi and Angelo Capello, two Italian twins who are almost identical.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this novel in which the white Tom Chambers and the 1/32nd black "Chambers" are switched as youths, a deception exposed by the title lawyer, who also uses fingerprints to prove the fake Tom is a murderer.

q2.quetsion_text: Pudd'nhead Wilson is by this author, who also created Tom Sawyer.

q3.quetsion_text: David Wilson gets the nickname "Pudd'nhead" after he makes an ill-advised comment about wishing he owned "half" of what thing, so he could kill his half?

lead_in: Answer the following about matrices, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: A square matrix with ones on the diagonal and zeros elsewhere is this special matrix, which is required to yield the same matrix by which it is multiplied.

q2.quetsion_text: Linearly independent systems of equations can be solved using matrices if the matrix is put in this form, where every leading coefficient is a one and is the only nonzero entry in its column.

q3.quetsion_text: This matrix contains the second partial derivatives of a function and can be used to check if a function has a saddle point at a certain point.

lead_in: This structure is in the shape of an inverted flattened catenary curve. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this stainless steel structure in St. Louis. It is the tallest man-made monument in the Western Hemisphere.

q2.quetsion_text: This Finnish-American architect designed the Gateway Arch. He also designed Dulles International Airport and the Tulip Chair.

q3.quetsion_text: Saarinen studied at this university's architecture school, and later designed the Morse and Ezra Stiles complexes for it, as well as Ingalls Rink. The Woman's Table is a sculpture here designed by its alumna Maya Lin.
q3.raw_answer: Yale University [accept Yale School of Architecture]

lead_in: Name these books that appear in Le Monde's list of 100 Books of the Century,

q1.quetsion_text: The top of the list is this novel which opens with Meursault at his mother's funeral. Meursault's imprisonment during his impending execution for killing an Arab are related in the second part of this book.
q1.raw_answer: The Stranger or The Outsider or L'Etranger

q2.quetsion_text: This book by Andre Malraux, about the communist uprising in Shanghai, appears at number 5. Its characters include Tchen Ta Erh, who tries to kill Chiang Kai Shek and the diplomat Katow.

q3.quetsion_text: At number 47 is this book, about Ludvik Jahn, who is dismissed from the Communist Party after writing "Optimism is the opium of the people" on a postcard and mailing it.

lead_in: This law can be used to show that the electric field within a thin conducting sphere is zero. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this law which states that the flux through a surface surrounding a charge is proportional to the net electric charge enclosed by the surface.

q2.quetsion_text: Gauss' Law can be used to show that the electric field due to this configuration of charges is equal to the area charge density over two epsilon. This is usually calculated by drawing a perpendicular cylinder and noting the flux only goes through the end.

q3.quetsion_text: Gauss' law can be used to find boundary conditions for this inhomogeneous form of Laplace's equation. This equation states that the Laplacian of the potential is equal to negative free charge density over permittivity.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this amendment that granted states greater autonomy in regulating alcohol sales.
q1.raw_answer: Twenty-First Amendment to the United States Constitution (or 21)

q2.quetsion_text: The 21st Amendment was a direct repeal of this amendment, which banned the manufacture, sale, consumption, and distribution of alcohol.
q2.raw_answer: Eighteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution (or 18)

q3.quetsion_text: The enforcement for the 18th Amendment came from an act championed by this Minnesotan and chair of the House Judiciary Committee.

lead_in: This architect developed a scale of proportions based on the height of a man with his arms raised. For  10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this formulator of the aforementioned "modulor" system. He also included the section "Eyes  That Do Not See" in his essay collection Towards a New Architecture and designed the chapel of Notre- Dame du Haut.

q2.quetsion_text: Le Corbusier designed this white, reinforced-concrete building in Poissy, France. It is built on stilts  and has a square floor plan.

q3.quetsion_text: Le Corbusier planned the design of the city Chandigarh in this country. Architectural monuments in  this country include the Brihadeeswarar temple in Thanjavur and the Taj Mahal in Agra.

lead_in: Bishop Warin of Beauvis proposed an oath against attacking churches to Robert the Pious as part of this movement, which was first manifested at councils in Auvergne and Aquitaine.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this tenth- to twelfth-century social movement aimed at protecting property, expanding church power and limiting warfare. The Council of Elne-Toulouges banned contact with excommunicates as part of this movement.
q1.raw_answer: Peace of God movement [or Pax Dei; or Paix de Dieu; accept Truce of God or Treuga Dei]

q2.quetsion_text: The Peace of God was strongly supported by this Benedictine super-monastery that gained power through a system of dependent priories. Peter the Venerable was a leader of this abbey, which promoted namesake anti-simony reforms in the 11th century.
q2.raw_answer: Cluny Abbey [accept Cluniac reforms or Clunian reforms]

q3.quetsion_text: Cluny was located in this region. A duke of this region attempted to promote a crusade that never took place at the 1454 Feast of the Pheasant, and he wore a robe worth three times what he'd paid for the office to the ceremony where he assumed ownership of the Bishopric of Liege.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this type of religious event. Roses dropped out of a cloak during another of these on Tepeyac Hill which included a speech in Nahuatl.
q1.raw_answer: apparitions of the Virgin Mary [or Marian apparitions; or visions of the Virgin Mary; or apparitions of a Lady; accept answers with Mary or "the Theotokos" in place of "Virgin"; prompt on "apparitions", "visions," or "dreams"]

q2.quetsion_text: The Virgin of Guadalupe has been venerated since a 1556 apparition in this country, where families put out yellow marigolds and eat candy skulls for DÃ­a de los Muertos.

q3.quetsion_text: In Mexico, Guatemala, and Spain, this nine-day celebration precedes Christmas. It often involves a parade-like recreation of Mary and Joseph's search for shelter, including knocking on doors within a house.

lead_in: This psychologist described how early language problems predicted the severity of a condition first described by his mentor Leo Kanner.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this psychologist who performed the first random controlled trials in child psychiatry. His trials discovered that tranquilizers were ineffective in treating anxiety disorders, but that stimulants such as Ritalin could treat ADD.

q2.quetsion_text: That aforementioned condition was this one, characterized by repetitive or restrictive actions, such as stereotypy or ritualistic behavior. In the DSM-5, Asperger syndrome was subsumed into the "spectrum disorder" named for this disease.

q3.quetsion_text: Kanner first formulated the bogus "refrigerator mother" theory of autism that was popularized by this UChicago psychologist, who analyzed fairy tales in Freudian terms in The Uses of Enchantment.

lead_in: This state is the largest to have only one seat in the House of Representatives; that position is currently held by Republican Steve Daines.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this western state that usually votes Republican in Presidential elections, but is currently led by Democratic Governor Steve Bullock from Helena.

q2.quetsion_text: Bullock appointed this former lieutenant governor to fill Max Baucus's Senate seat in 2014. He recently dropped a re-election bid when he was found to have plagiarized his master's thesis.

q3.quetsion_text: Bullock's predecessor as Governor was this Democrat, who may be considering a run for President in 2016.

lead_in: Name these celebrities who entertained troops during the Vietnam War, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This ultra-conservative actor and early MPAA president directed The Green Berets to drum up support for the Vietnam War. He visited American troops before the conflict escalated.
q1.raw_answer: John Wayne [or Marion Mitchell Morrison; or Marion Robert Morrison]

q2.quetsion_text: This other, more famous entertainer who went on tour in Vietnam was known for his 57 tours over 50 years for the United Service Organizations. He was unpopular, since he was prowar when anti-war sentiment was high.

q3.quetsion_text: This black entertainer made a 1972 tour to Vietnam with the USO, but he's best known for financing the Civil Rights Movement, having one eye, and converting to Judaism.
q3.raw_answer: Sammy Davis Jr. [or Samuel George Davis, Jr.]

lead_in: Drosophila with this phenotype are unaffected by otherwise-embryonic lethal mutations in the MSL proteins MOF and MLE.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this phenotype possessed by Drosophila that can form an active, dimeric transcription factor because they possess sis-A and sis-B in excess of deadpan. Flies with this phenotype produce the proteins TRA and SXL.

q2.quetsion_text: Drosophila sex determination is regulated by "alternative" forms of this process, which can code for multiple protein products by skipping exons. This post-transcriptional process modifies mRNA via a lariat created by snRNPs (SNURPS).

q3.quetsion_text: The TRA protein accomplishes dosage compensation by binding to dsx and allowing this process to occur at a site following exon 4. This process is initiated by a transferase after CPSF binds to the sequence AAUAAA.
q3.raw_answer: polyadenylation [or adding a poly(A) tail; or adding a sequence of adenine (or adenosine) repeats; accept any equivalents; prompt on "cleavage"; prompt on any partial answer about adenine or adenosine]

lead_in: This novel ends with Lucy selling her farm to Petrus, a conspirator in an attack and rape that left her pregnant. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this novel in which the professor David Lurie is fired after having an affair with his student Melanie Isaacs.

q2.quetsion_text: Disgrace is a novel by this South African author, who also wrote about a hare-lipped gardener who travels to his mother's birthplace in The Life and Times of Michael K.

q3.quetsion_text: In this Coetzee novel, Colonel Joll, sent by the Third Bureau, tortures members of the title group. The Magistrate is tortured by Joll's soldiers when he objects.

lead_in: Marie Dobbs published writing of this kind under the pseudonym "another lady," and of the hundreds of published examples of this kind of writing, the closest to an authorized one is by Anna Lefroy, who inherited the original manuscript.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this kind of fan fiction, which usually explains the meaning of Edward Denham's converation with Clara Brereton and finds a marriage partner for Sidney Parker.

q2.quetsion_text: Sanditon was left unfinished at the death of Jane Austen, much like this 1804 novel in which the title family's daughters are pursued by the Osbornes and Tom Musgrave.

q3.quetsion_text: In Jane Austen's complete novel Northanger Abbey, this protagonist marries Henry Tilney despite the faux pas of accusing his father of murder for no reason.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this problem in machine-learning, the goal of which is to identify the subpopulation to which a given observation belongs. Discriminant analysis is sometimes used for this task.

q2.quetsion_text: Classification with only two groups can take the form of binary regression, and thus can be solved using this generalized linear model, which has binomial errors, and reports predictions in the form of log odds.

q3.quetsion_text: By contrast, the errors in ordinary linear regression models are assumed to follow this distribution. For IID random variables with finite variance and a well-defined mean, the sample mean converges in distribution to this distribution, per the central limit theorem.

lead_in: In 1576, Stephen Bathory became king of this country, which was then part of a commonwealth with  neighboring Lithuania. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this country whose invasion by Nazi troops in 1939 sparked World War II.

q2.quetsion_text: BÃ¡thory was succeeded by a member of the Vasa dynasty with this name. A Holy Roman emperor  with this name from the house of Luxembourg presided over the burning of Jan Hus at the Council of  Constance.
q2.raw_answer: Sigismund [or Sigismund I; or Sigismund III]

q3.quetsion_text: BÃ¡thory lay siege to the city of Pskov in this war, which ended when he forced this man to give up  claims to Livonia. This man had a secret police force called the Oprichnina.

lead_in: The Zoroastrian monster Azi Dahaka was defeated by the god of this phenomenon. For 10 points each:

q2.quetsion_text: In Norse mythology, this trickster god was unable to beat Logi, the personification of fire, in an  eating contest. He was bound with the guts of his son Narfi after tricking Hodr into killing Baldr.

q3.quetsion_text: This Hindu god of fire is often depicted with seven tongues that lick the sacrificial ghee offered to  him. In the Mahabharata, this god burns the Khandava Forest after becoming weak from ingesting too  much ghee.

lead_in: The protagonist of this author's Gogol-inspired short story "A Madman's Diary" sees the phrase "Eat people!" appear in his books, and suspects people of cannibalism.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this author who described a peasant who believes he is superior to everyone and spins defeats as "spiritual victories" in his "The True Story of Ah Q."
q1.raw_answer: Lu Xun [or Lu HsÃ¼n; or Zhou Shuren]

q2.quetsion_text: Lu Xun was an early 20th-century writer from this country. A modern author from this country, Gao Xingjian, was awarded the 2000 Nobel Prize for Literature.

q3.quetsion_text: This 8th-century Chinese poet wrote "I drink alone, for no friend is near" in his poem Drinking Alone By Moonlight.

lead_in: The Tobacco Revolt targeted this dynasty, whose rulers constructed the Sun Throne.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Iranian dynasty, which gave away pretty much everything valuable it had in the D'Arcy concession. The newspaper Qanun ran articles that promoted a constitutional revolution against this dynasty.
q1.raw_answer: Qajar dynasty [or Doodmān e Qājār; accept alternate romanizations: Qachar, Gajar, etc.]

q2.quetsion_text: The Qajar Dynasty was overthrown by Reza Khan, the founder of this other Iranian dynasty. Reza's son, who also belonged to this dynasty, would be overthrown in the 1979 Iranian Revolution.

q3.quetsion_text: Access to this resource was given away by the D'Arcy concession. Mohammed Mossadegh planned to nationalize an Anglo-Persian company that produced this resource and which later became known as BP.
q3.raw_answer: crude oil [or petroleum or equivalents; prompt on "fuel" or "fossil fuel"]

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this woman who marries the protagonist of the novel in which she appears, even though he is in love with her cousin. She is a granddaughter of Mrs. Manson Mingott.

q2.quetsion_text: In The Age of Innocence, May Welland marries Newland Archer despite his love for this woman.

q3.quetsion_text: The Age of Innocence is a novel by this New Yorker, who created the town of Starkfield as the setting for her novel Ethan Frome.

lead_in: The Chorus tells of the making of man and asks, "What storm is this that tightens our sail?" to which Althaea answers, "Love" at the beginning of this verse drama.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this dramatic poem that pits Meleager against Althaea. Its most famous chorus begins: "When the hounds of spring are on winter's traces".

q2.quetsion_text: This sadomasochistic Victorian poet of Atalanta in Calydon also wrote some Poems and Ballads and a collection about political liberty, Songs Before Sunrise.

q3.quetsion_text: This Swinburne poem describes a place "In a coign of the cliff between lowland and highland" that "the years have rifled / Of all but the thorns that are touched not of time".

lead_in: Albert Camus described it as the only philosophical question.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this act of killing oneself. One man studying it noted its increased prevalence among Protestant communities, as well as its decreased prevalence during times of war.

q2.quetsion_text: Suicide was analyzed in a case study by this French sociologist, who helped develop sociology as a field with his The Rules of Sociological Method.

q3.quetsion_text: In The Elementary Forms of the Religious Life, Durkheim described the process by which Native Americans attribute human qualities to these objects. These objects are paired with Taboo in a work by Sigmund Freud.

lead_in: This body of water was formed by an bolide impact at the end of the Eocene.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this large bay found on the coasts of Virginia and Maryland.

q2.quetsion_text: Most of the water found in the Chesapeake is classified as this kind of water, a mixture of salt and freshwater with intermediate salinity.

q3.quetsion_text: The Hampton Roads area is gradually sinking into the Chesapeake due to this process, where land rises due to the disappearance of glaciers, lightening the load on the lithosphere.

lead_in: These gases consist of randomly moving point particles that interact only during elastic collisions, and one mole of them has a volume of 22.41 liters at STP.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify these hypothetical gases described by the law PV equals nRT.

q2.quetsion_text: Dividing the ideal gas constant by Avogadro's number yields a constant named for this scientist. He proved that entropy equals that constant times the log of the number of microstates.

q3.quetsion_text: The ideal gas law can be derived from this theorem, which states that in thermal equilibrium, molecules have the same average energy associated with each degree of freedom.

lead_in: Finish the following quotes by John Donne,

q1.quetsion_text: In one of his Devotions Upon Emergent Occasions, Donne writes "No man is an island, entire of itself, every man is a piece of" one of these things.

q2.quetsion_text: In a poem about this personification, Donne writes that this is "slave to fate, chance, kings, and desperate men, And dost with poison, war and sickness dwell." That poem begins by commanding this to "be not proud."

q3.quetsion_text: In the first of the Holy Sonnets, John Donne asks God "Thou hast made me, and shall thy work [do this]?" Afterwards, the speaker states "Repair me now, for now mine end doth haste."

lead_in: This effect was first observed when changing the lighting levels in a factory boosted production. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this effect which occurs when adjustments in the environment cause workers to change or improve their behaviors, possibly because they are being watched by psychology researchers.

q2.quetsion_text: The Hawthorne effect is important in this field of psychology, which deals with issues at the workplace. Psychologists that work in human resources department typically have experience in this field of psychology.
q2.raw_answer: industrial/organizational psychology [or I/O psychology; or occupational psychology; prompt on work psychology; prompt on partial answer]

q3.quetsion_text: I/O psychologists often have to deal with this phenomenon with employees, which can be mediated through coping mechanisms. If this psychological phenomenon is severe enough, it can manifest with physical symptoms; it is measured on the Holmes and Rahe scale.

lead_in: Answer the following about attempts to sum up all of Jewish law, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This medieval Jewish scholar from Muslim Cordoba distilled out 13 principles of Jewish faith. He also wrote at length on Jewish law in his Mishneh Torah, and wrote a Guide for the Perplexed.

q2.quetsion_text: According to legend, some jerk tested Rabbi Hillel to see if he could recite all of the Torah's laws while performing this other physical task. Hillel simply replied: "What is hateful to you, do not do to any other."
q2.raw_answer: while standing on one foot [or standing on one leg]

q3.quetsion_text: The Talmud itself had to summarize the many rulings from this 71-member council, whose decisions joined the halakha as "oral law". It was chaired in the early 1st century by Caiaphas.

lead_in: In the poem On Nature, one member of this school contrasted "The Way of Opinion" with "The Way of Truth," which asserts that reality is one and unchanging.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this monistic Greek school whose members, such as Parmenides and Melissus of Samos, rejected sense experience and sought to build knowledge on firm premises.

q2.quetsion_text: In his eponymous Platonic dialogue, Parmenides poses this argument against the existence of forms. It claims that the one-over-many argument makes the Form of Largeness itself large, resulting in infinite regress. Its name was given by Aristotle.

q3.quetsion_text: This Cynic is said to have refuted Zeno of Elea's paradoxes against the existence of motion by getting up and walking. His wacky stunts included carrying a lamp in daytime to look for an honest man and living in a clay barrel.

lead_in: In the twelfth century, this form of polyphony was divided into "discant", which was note-against-note counterpoint, and the "purum" form, in which one voice moved freely against the other.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this term also applied to the earliest form of medieval polyphonic music, in which voices sang in parallel fourths and fifths. Musica Enchiriadis is often considered the earliest treatise to define it.

q2.quetsion_text: Organum is particularly associated with Leonin and Perotin, two composers from this modern-day country, whose other medieval composers include Adam de la Halle and Guillaume de Machaut.

q3.quetsion_text: One of the earliest descriptions of organum via oblique motion is in this Italian music theorist's Micrologus. He is credited with the invention of staff notation, solmization syllables, and a namesake mnemonic hand system.
q3.raw_answer: Guido of Arezzo [or Guido Aretinus; or Guido Monaco; or Guido d'Arezzo; or Guy of Arezzo]

lead_in: The first entry in a series depicting this road shows the Nihonbashi, or "Bridge of Japan." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this road, whose numerous stations were depicted in a series by Ando Hiroshige that shows scenes from travelling to the imperial capital.
q1.raw_answer: Tokaido road [or Fifty Three Stations of the Tokaido Road; or Tokaido Gojusan-tsugi]

q2.quetsion_text: This iconic Japanese mountain was shown in a series of thirty-six views of it by Katsushika Hokusai which includes a depiction of a massive wave off Kanagawa.

q3.quetsion_text: Japanese ukiyo-e painting partly inspired this John Whistler painting, which hangs above the fireplace in the Peacock Room in the Freer Gallery at the Smithsonian. It shows a Western woman in a kimono holding a white fan.
q3.raw_answer: Rose and Silver: The Princess from the Land of Porcelain [or La princesse du pays de la porcelaine

lead_in: For liquids, this quantity can be compared to a Lewis-Randall or Henry ideal solution reference state. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this quantity that measures a gas's propensity to escape from a container or expand within one.

q2.quetsion_text: The fugacity of a gas can be calculated by multiplying the fugacity coefficient by this value. In the ideal gas equation, the value of the ideal gas constant is roughly .0821 if this value is measured in atmospheres.

q3.quetsion_text: Fugacity is sometimes calculated with gases approximated by this equation of state, a modification of the ideal gas law that introduces the parameters "a" and "b" to correct for volume and intermolecular attraction.

lead_in: John Stuart Mill's Principles of Political Economy argues that state interventions can be justified on the grounds of this principle.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this ethical principle, which essentially holds that the greatest amount of benefits should be maximized for the greatest number of people if possible.

q2.quetsion_text: This British philosopher is considered the founder of modern utilitarianism, which he discussed in his Introduction to the Principles of Morals and Legislation.

q3.quetsion_text: Bentham described this prison design where a watchman could observe every inmate without the inmates knowing. Michel Foucault discussed it in Discipline and Punish.

q1.quetsion_text: Kabuki plays were originally performed by female casts, but beginning in 1629, all-male casts were used. This is the term for male actors who play female roles in kabuki.

q2.quetsion_text: In this other genre of Japanese theater, pioneered by Kan'ami and his son Zeami, the actors often wear masks. Plays in this genre are separated by farcical interludes called kyogen.

q3.quetsion_text: This pioneer of bunraku theater is known for his "love-suicide" plays and the historical drama The Battles of Coxinga.

lead_in: Answer the following about Thomas Cole's Voyage of Life series, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: One of these beings flies in front of the boat undergoing the title voyage to protect the man in the boat. Fra Angelico's Annunciation depicts another one zooming into the frame.

q2.quetsion_text: How many paintings are there depicting stages on The Voyage of Life? The first one is called Childhood and the last is called Old Age.

q3.quetsion_text: The Voyage of Life series is displayed on four corners of a room in this institution. Its oculus-bearing dome is supported by dark marble columns above a fountain with a statue of Hermes, and its Sculpture Garden was completed in 1999.
q3.raw_answer: National Gallery of Art, Washington D.C.

lead_in: After this war's final battle at Aegospotami, its winners installed the regime of the Thirty Tyrants in the losing city.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this thirty-year-long war fought between Athens and Sparta in the late 5th century BCE.

q2.quetsion_text: This disgraced Athenian general wrote a renowned eight-book History of the Peloponnesian War, which includes Pericles' funeral oration.

q3.quetsion_text: This soldier and historian discussed the Peloponnesian War's aftermath in his Hellenica. He described his expedition back from Persia with the Ten Thousand in his Anabasis.

lead_in: This figure wears the Ring of the Fisherman and a cloak called the mantum and once donned a special tiara.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this leader of the Holy See elected by conclaves of the College of Cardinals. Celestine V and Benedict XVI are the only people to resign from this position, whose current holder is Francis.
q1.raw_answer: the pope [or Bishop of Rome; or il Papa; accept papacy]

q2.quetsion_text: As Bishop of Rome, the pope has an ecclesiastical seat at this oldest major basilica, which is located near a former papal palace that has hosted four ecumenical councils. This basilica allegedly contains Peter and Paul's heads.
q2.raw_answer: Papal (Arch)basilica of St. John Lateran [or (Arci)basilica di San Giovanni in Laterano; or Sacrosancta Papalis Archibasilica Maior Sanctissimi Salvatoris et Sanctorum Iohannis Baptistae et Evangelistae apud Lateranum, omnium Urbis et orbis ecclesiarum Mater et Caput]

q3.quetsion_text: The Lateran Palace contains this wood-and-marble structure, which pilgrims climb on their knees to obtain plenary indulgences. During the Passion, Jesus stood on this structure, which was brought to Rome by St. Helena.
q3.raw_answer: Scala Sancta [accept Holy Stairs or Holy Staircase; accept Scala Pilati or Stairs of Pilate or anything else indicating it's a staircase related to Pontius Pilate]

lead_in: The poet Tyrtaeus celebrated this city's enslavement of the people of Messenia. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this militaristic Greek city state, a rival of Athens. A king of this city, Leonidas, led forces at the Battle of Thermopylae.

q2.quetsion_text: Spartan slaves were known by this name. These people could become semi-free mothakes by undergoing the agoge education system.

lead_in: Note to moderator: do not read anything besides "Pachacuti" if a correct answer is not given to the first part. Pedro Sarmiento de Gamboa says that this man advised his son to not let anyone who raised two eyes against him live and gives his lifetime as an unrealistically long 125 years.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this ruler, who reorganized his empire into the Tawantinsuyu, or "Land of the Four Corners."
q1.raw_answer: Pachacuti Inca Yupanqui [or Pachacutec; or Pachacutiq Inka Yupanki]

q2.quetsion_text: Pachacuti was the greatest ruler of this Andean empire, which was conquered by Francisco Pizarro.

q3.quetsion_text: The Inca employed these runners to deliver messages along their extensive road system. These dudes would stop at stations called tambos for refreshments and could book it from Cusco to Quito in a week.

lead_in: Langton's ant and termite are two rule-based constructs that are equivalent to these constructs. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this construct that consists of a tape that contains symbols, which can be read or written by a head. A state register stores the state of the computation and a transition function describes what action to take.

q2.quetsion_text: These limited-memory constructs also have a transition function describing their transitions. Their deterministic and nondeterministic types are divided based on whether an input can result in multiple possible transitions.
q2.raw_answer: FSMs [or finite-state machines; or deterministic/nondeterministic finite-state automata; or even finite automata; or finite automatons; or FSAs; or DFA; or NFA]

q3.quetsion_text: This kind of machine is different from an ordinary automaton because it has two tapes for input and output. It accepts a string from language, and outputs a string in another,

lead_in: Bonus: Name the following people who have graduated last in their class at West Point, for ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Sitting Bull wiped out the troops of this man at the Battle of Little Bighorn, which is often known as this man’s “Last Stand.”

q2.quetsion_text: This Confederate general names an ill-fated charge at the end of the Battle of Gettysburg, in which most of his division was wiped out. Surprisingly, his cousin Harry Heth also graduated last in his class at West Point.

q3.quetsion_text: One man with this last name graduated last in the West Point Class of 1845. Another person with this last name organized the Constitutional Union party and proposed a last-ditch compromise between slave and free states.
q3.raw_answer: Crittenden [accept William Logan Crittenden or John Jordan Crittenden] <BZ>

lead_in: Two men climb trees to get a better view in this building's Christ Entering Jerusalem. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Paduan building that contains a famous 1305 fresco of The Lamentation with angels flying around wildly.
q1.raw_answer: Arena Chapel [or Scrovegni Chapel; or Cappella degli Scrovegni]

q2.quetsion_text: The Arena Chapel frescoes were painted by this Florentine, who, alongside his teacher Cimabue, is counted among the first artists of the Renaissance.

q3.quetsion_text: Vasari related that, later in his life, Giotto demonstrated his skill to the Pope by performing this action with red paint.
q3.raw_answer: drawing a perfect circle [prompt on drawing a circle]

lead_in: People lean over balconies with green balustrades to peer into a courtyard in one of several paintings of a Jewish wedding in this city.

q1.quetsion_text: The Assawa brotherhood throng the street, as a hooded figure rides in beneath a green banner in a painting titled for The Fanatics of "this city".

q2.quetsion_text: The artist of those works, Eugene Delacroix, also painted the hand of a dead body poking out from under some rubble in a painting of an allegorical figure of Greece at this geographical location.

q3.quetsion_text: Delacroix also painted this Assyrian king looking remarkably bored, while reclining on his enormous bed, watching his horses and concubines being prepared for slaughter.

lead_in: A ratio test based on values of this kind of function for nested models is the subject of Wilks' Theorem.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this kind of function which, for a model and a set of parameter values, evaluates the probability of the observed data given those parameter values.

q2.quetsion_text: Wilks' theorem demonstrates that the negative log-likelihood ratio asymptotically approaches this distribution. This distribution, whose only parameter is degrees of freedom, is often used in goodness-of-fit tests.

q3.quetsion_text: This measure of model fit is equivalent to two times the number of parameters minus two times log maximum likelihood. It differs from a similar Bayesian measure by penalizing less for extra parameters.

lead_in: Bonus: This event was led in part by the Armed Forces Movement. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this peaceful event begun on the 25th of April, which resulted in the brief presidency of Antonio de Spinola and the renaming of the Salazar Bridge.

q2.quetsion_text: The Carnation Revolution began in Lisbon and ended the Estado Novo of this Iberian country, which had long been ruled by Antonio Salazar.
q2.raw_answer: Portugal [accept Portuguese Republic or República Portuguesa]

q3.quetsion_text: Another Estado Novo was established by Getulio Vargas in this South American country. Vargas helped industrialize this country during his presidency.
q3.raw_answer: Federal Republic of Brazil [or República Federativa do Brasil] <BZ>

lead_in: This man protested the Stamp Act's "chains of slavery" ironically by having his own slaves walk around with protest banners.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Virginia senator whose namesake resolution at the Second Continental Congress led to the Declaration of Independence a month later. One of his relatives would later eulogize George Washington as "first in war, first in peace, and first in the hearts of his countrymen."
q1.raw_answer: Richard Henry Lee [do not accept "Light-Horse" Harry Lee]

q2.quetsion_text: Richard Henry Lee's relative, the aforementioned "Light-Horse" Harry, also joined George Washington in quelling this 1794 Pennsylvania rebellion. It was sparked by an excise tax on a certain beverage.

q3.quetsion_text: "Light-Horse" Harry Lee was presumably not present at a 1783 dinner at this New York location, where the victorious General Washington enjoyed a "turtle feast" and emotionally bid goodbye to his officers after the Revolutionary War.

q1.raw_answer: Middlemarch: A Study of Provincial Life

q2.quetsion_text: This Victorian-era author wrote Middlemarch. She also wrote about how the orphan Eppie alters the life of the title “Weaver of Raveloe” in Silas Marner.

q3.quetsion_text: In this first novel of George Eliot, Arthur Donnithorne saves Hetty Sorel from being executed, and the title character decides to marry the Methodist preacher Dinah Morris.

q3.quetsion_text: This other British composer created the opera King Priam for the Coventry festival. He also wrote an oratorio inspired by Kristallnacht.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this one-eyed god, the supreme god of the Norse pantheon.

q3.quetsion_text: Kvasir is born during a truce after the Aesir-Vanir war, when the Aesir and Vanir all donate some of this substance and mix it together.

lead_in: Name some important musical contributions of the perpetually underrated Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach.

q1.quetsion_text: Bach played a major role in developing this form. Though many of his were monothematic, most pieces in this three-part form introduce one theme in the tonic and another in the dominant during the initial exposition section.

lead_in: A pink ribbon falls from the sky after the title character of this work screams his wife's name.

lead_in: This king regained the Isle of Man and the Hebrides from Norway after winning the Battle of Largs. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this king who died in 1286 when he rode his horse off a cliff while traveling at night for the birthday of his second wife, Yolande de Dreux. His only surviving heir was Margaret, Maid of Norway.
q1.raw_answer: Alexander III [or Alexander III of Scotland; prompt on "Alexander"]

q2.quetsion_text: Margaret's death in 1290 plunged this kingdom into an interregnum. Alexander III's death ended this kingdom's ruling House of Dunkeld that included rulers such as Duncan, Malcolm III, and Macbeth.

q3.quetsion_text: At the 1290 Great Cause, Edward I passed over Robert Bruce to give Scotland to this ruler known as Toom Tabard after his loss at Dunbar. His son Edward was briefly restored after the battle of Halidon Hill.

q1.quetsion_text: Name these two landmasses between which an isthmus formed roughly 5 million years ago. One of them was colonized by glyptodonts and giant ground sloths, while the other was colonized by saber-toothed cats and bears.
q1.raw_answer: North America and South America [both answers required; accept in either order; prompt on "the Americas"]

q2.quetsion_text: Some of these flightless birds also crossed over into North America. Until they went extinct, they were probably the largest apex predators in South America, and they may have killed their prey by grasping them with their enormous jaws and repeatedly bashing the prey against the ground.

q3.quetsion_text: North America was also colonized by Eurasian species such as bison, mammoths and humans during the Pleistocene. Their main migration route was across this now-submerged landmass between the two continents.

lead_in: Korea's refusal to acknowledge this emperor led to the Seikanron debate over invasion. For 10 points  each:

lead_in: This terrain can create geomorphic hazards and can present as hummocky. For 10 points each:

lead_in: The fundamental theorem of algebra states that all polynomials have at least one root in this field. For 10  points each:

q3.quetsion_text: This man's namesake rule of signs can tell you how many of the roots of a polynomial are positive  and how many are negative. He also developed the coordinate plane.

lead_in: Name some important advances in metallurgy

q1.quetsion_text: The Thomas-Gilchrist converter improved on this process by using a basic lining instead of an acidic one. In this process, air is blown through pig iron to remove impurities and create steel.

q2.quetsion_text: The patio process used mule-powered devices called arrastras to process ores of this metal by forming a mercury amalgamation. The Washoe process was an improvement on pan amalgamation for recovering this element.

lead_in: This book's fifth chapter tells the story of Ananias and Sapphira. For 10 points each:

lead_in: This philosopher's notion of a telos, or final cause, was later revised by Christian thinkers to mean the God-given purpose of each created object.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this student of Plato and teacher of Alexander the Great. His lectures from the Lyceum became such writings as Poetics, Rhetoric, and Nicomachean Ethics.

lead_in: The program which led to the existence of this database was authorized by an order from Roger Vinson.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this database, whose records are supposedly kept for five years. A review group convened by President Obama recommended that it be transferred to a private third-party, with access granted only when a Section 215 order is obtained.

q2.quetsion_text: Slides about this program, which Edward Snowden revealed, advertise its ability to collect emails, chat messages, and VoIP data from the servers of "providers" like Google and Facebook, prompting denials from these companies that they created back doors for the NSA.

q3.quetsion_text: The NSA cooperates with its counterparts in Australia, Canada, New Zealand, and Britain, which together comprise this intelligence-sharing group. This group operated the ECHELON system, and its members are party to the UKUSA Agreement.

lead_in: Bonus: One of these properties, boiling point elevation, can be calculated as i times “K sub b” times m. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify these properties of solutions that only depend on the concentration of the solute.

q3.quetsion_text: Another colligative property related to boiling point elevation concerns the reduction of this point where a liquid changes to a solid. Salting roads in winter takes advantage of the decrease of this point.

lead_in: This thing is central to the Indian yajna ritual and the practice of sati, by which Indian wives killed themselves after their husbands' deaths. For 10 points each:

q3.raw_answer: Church of the Holy Sepulchre [or Basilica of the Holy Sepulchre; or Church of the Resurrection; or Tomb of Jesus Christ; or Tomb of Jesus Christ; prompt on "Jerusalem", "Old City", or "Golgotha"]

lead_in: Bonus: This quantity rises due to the law of diminishing returns. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this quantity whose curve intersects with the average total cost curve at its lowest point. Profit-maximizing firms seek to produce at the point where the curve of this quantity intersects with the marginal revenue curve.
q1.raw_answer: marginal cost [or MC; prompt on “cost”; do not accept or prompt on “opportunity cost”]

q2.quetsion_text: While these firms produce where marginal revenue equals marginal cost, they increase the price to a point on the demand curve. These firms are the sole supplier of a good, and John D. Rockefeller’s Standard Oil was one of them.

q3.quetsion_text: In these markets, the marginal cost curve, average total cost curve, and marginal revenue curve all intersect at one point in long-term equilibrium. These markets are characterized by many suppliers of undifferentiated goods.

lead_in: Answer the following about American Jewish authors,

lead_in: The abundance of these highly plastic structures can be increased by fragile X syndrome, which causes a deficiency of FMRP, the protein that regulates their development from filopodia.

q2.quetsion_text: Sodium enters dendritic spines that receive these post-synaptic potentials. Neurotransmitters like glutamate that increase the likelihood of generating an action potential are described by this adjective, contrasted with inhibitory.

q3.quetsion_text: Glutamate's binding to the heterodimeric G protein-coupled receptor T1R1/T1R3 initiates the gustatory signal transduction pathway of this basic taste. This taste is potentiated by the ribonucleotides IMP and GMP.

lead_in: Discourse about whether and how the conduct of this thing can be "just" originated with Saint Augustine. For 10 points each:

lead_in: One country's failed attempt to act as a mediator in this was the Buol Note. For 10 points each:

lead_in: Bonus: The plaintiffs in this case were accused of selling uninspected chickens. For ten points each:

lead_in: Answer the following about round-robin quizbowl tournaments,

q1.quetsion_text: Round-robin quizbowl tournaments can be mathematically represented as the complete directed variety of these entities, consisting of vertices and several edges connecting them.

q1.quetsion_text: p53 can arrest the cell cycle in this phase, which occurs immediately before the S phase of interphase. During this part of the cell cycle, the cell can choose to enter a quiescent state or go on to divide.

lead_in: Name some biases,

q1.quetsion_text: Any sort of sample picked with the possibility of distorting the results through improper sampling can have this kind of statistical bias.

lead_in: These poems' author said he composed them during a "hurricane of the spirit," during which time he also wrote Sonnets to Orpheus.

lead_in: This protein's subunits are produced in an imbalanced fashion in beta-thalassemia, and in acidic environments its binding curve moves in the Bohr effect. For 10 points each:

lead_in: This person is the subject of an argument in which the author assumes that he is not gouging the owners and that contracts last for one year. For 10 points each:

lead_in: Bonus: Two candles, a mirror, and one of these objects lie on the mantlepiece in Magritte’s Time Transfixed. For ten points each:

q3.quetsion_text: Before writing for L’age d’Or, Dali collaborated with Luis Buñuel to write this short film, which begins with an eyeball being slashed by a razor.

lead_in: Bonus: The Tolman-Oppenheimer-Volkoff limit is the minimal mass required to overcome electron and neutron degeneracy pressures to form these bodies. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify these astronomical bodies that contain a gravitational singularity formed after the collapse of massive stars, from which not even light can escape.

q2.quetsion_text: This surface around a black hole marks “the point of no return” at which the gravitational pull is so strong that not even light can escape from beyond this boundary.

lead_in: The 2014 epidemic of this disease has led to the institution of a cordon sanitaire in August leading to a quarantine of West Point, Monrovia. For 10 points each:

lead_in: This question follows "Who had a beauty too much more than human?," "Who ordered that Buridan be thrown in a sack into the Seine," and "Where are they, oh sovereign Virgin" in the first three stanzas of its poem.

lead_in: He believed that criminality manifests itself in physical characteristics, which are genetically reproduced, a concept known as "criminal atavism."

q3.quetsion_text: This French criminologist used anthropometric methods to classify criminals, keeping namesake data cards recording various measurements, so criminals could always be positively identified. The incompetent handwriting analysis he provided as an expert witness was partially responsible for the conviction of Alfred Dreyfus.

lead_in: A clerk in this play earns the nickname "Twenty-Two Calamities" because of his clumsiness. For 10 points each:

lead_in: This linguist divided language into two components, langue, referring to the system of language rules, and parole, referring to the instances of their use. For 10 points each:

lead_in: Answer the following about black historians, for 10 points each.

lead_in: Milt Jackson played this instrument in the Modern Jazz Quartet.

lead_in: This psychologist linked gender nonconformity among young children with homosexuality in adulthood with his "exotic becomes erotic" theory. For 10 points each:

lead_in: Answer the following about writing methods in Java, for 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Methods in Java are defined inside one of these fundamental units of object-oriented programming. They have constructors, and objects are instances of them.

q2.quetsion_text: At least one class must have a "main" method, which is usually public, void, and has this property. This property means that a method can be executed without an object of the class having first been instantiated.

q3.quetsion_text: Methods in subclasses can overwrite same-named methods in parent classes. To access the parent class's method in Java, you can use this keyword before the method's name.

lead_in: The ninth section of this poem is filled with exclamations, such as "Throb, baffled and curious brain! Throw out questions and answers!" For 10 points each:

lead_in: After its death, the last of these creatures was placed in a large block of ice and shipped to DC to be put on display in the Smithsonian.

lead_in: EdlÃ©n calculated the density factor, which he then used to calculate this quantity for air, and Cauchy's equation gives it as a power series in the wavelength with empirically calculated coefficients.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this quantity defined as the ratio of the speed of light in a vacuum to the speed of light in a material.

q3.quetsion_text: Materials can have an index of refraction which is defined as less than one, but to avoid violating causality, that just means that this quantity is greater in the material than in a vacuum.

lead_in: Answer the following about exciting feuds in the history of science, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: Newton and Leibniz feuded over who actually invented this mathematical discipline. Newton's method of fluxions is equivalent to this field's operation of differentiation.

q2.quetsion_text: Idiotic French revolutionary Jean-Paul Marat advanced a number of bogus theories refuted by this scientist, who figured out oxygen aids in combustion. The price of success? His head, in 1794.

q3.quetsion_text: This Lithuanian-German mathematician names the four-dimensional setting of special relativity. This man's spacetime model includes the PoincarÃ© group and places a double light-cone at the center of each event.

q2.quetsion_text: The Lords of the Isles were from this clan. The first Prime Minister of Canada post-Confederation and the first Labour Prime Minister of the UK were also presumably descended from this clan and its vassals.

This king is depicted in Hugo van der Goes' Trinity Altarpiece.

lead_in: This character can only be killed by finding his soul, which is kept in a needle, in an egg, in a duck, in a hare, in a buried chest, on the island of Buyan.

lead_in: Answer the following about reciprocal lattices.

q1.quetsion_text: Reciprocal lattices are representations of the crystal in this space, which is conjugate to the position. This variable and position obey the Heisenberg uncertainty principle

q3.quetsion_text: By considering the incident wavevector in a reciprocal lattice, it is possible to derive this construct which is used to figure out the possible scattering wave-vectors in reciprocal space. q3.quetsion_text: In the group of additive integers, this integer is the identity, because it plus any number, x, equals x.  This integer is divisible by all prime numbers.

lead_in: This condition often occurs due to head trauma or brain damage, and was famously observed in a patient named Henry Molaison.

q2.quetsion_text: The asthenosphere comprises the uppermost region of this other layer of the Earth. It constitutes 84% of Earth’s volume and surrounds the core.

lead_in: Gibbs sampling is one of these algorithms that uses Markov chains to get a series of observations from a specified multivariate probability distribution.

lead_in: Smoluchowski's equation for calculating the zeta potential is only valid when this value is much smaller than particle size.

lead_in: This algorithm is used in the quickselect algorithm. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this constant that is the ratio of a circle’s circumference to its diameter, equal to approximately 3.14.

q3.quetsion_text: Proving that pi was transcendental also proved the impossibility of squaring the circle using only these two instruments employed in geometric constructions. Give both.
q3.raw_answer: compass and straightedge [accept in either order; accept ruler in place of “straightedge”] <EC>

lead_in: This general lost the Battle of Lesnaya while attempting to bring tons of supplies to aid his superior.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this kind of market that can be created by the government through the granting of patents and copyrights. Common geographic ones include public utilities.

q2.quetsion_text: Because the firm in a monopoly supplies fewer goods than would create equilibrium, this reduction of economic efficiency occurs as buyers who would pay more than the equilibrium price are shut out of the market.
q2.raw_answer: deadweight loss (accept excess burden or allocation inefficiency)

q3.quetsion_text: Deadweight loss occurs because a monopolist, like any capitalist in a rational choice system, seeks to maximize this quantity. As a market approaches perfect competition, this value for each seller approaches zero.

lead_in: Fifteen percent of this city was devoted to a large district of shipyards and armories called the Arsenal

lead_in: According to Stesichorus, a shepherd of this name informed Geryon of the theft of his cattle.

lead_in: A ruler of this dynasty led a campaign against the Ottoman Murad II before being killed at the Battle of Varna.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this dynasty that briefly ruled Bohemia and Hungary during the reigns of Vladislaus II and Louis II. The Landshut Wedding commemorates the marriage of a woman from this dynasty to George of Bavaria.
q1.raw_answer: Jagiellonian dynasty [accept anything involving Jagielo or Jogaila]

q2.raw_answer: Poland and Lithuania [accept Polska, Polonia, and other names for Poland; accept Lietuva, Litwa, and other names for Lithuania]

q3.quetsion_text: In this series of 1385 prenuptial agreements, Jogaila, Grand Duke of Lithuania, converted to Christianity and was betrothed to the underage queen regnant Jadwiga of Poland.

lead_in: During this time period, all blood ties will be ignored: brothers will kill brothers and sleep with their sisters.

lead_in: The bassoons and violas introduce the funeral march-like theme that opens this piece. For 10 points each:

lead_in: These mathematical objects are sets with an associated binary operation satisfying four axioms.

q1.quetsion_text: Name these objects that must satisfy the conditions of closure and associativity and have an identity and inverses for each element.

q2.quetsion_text: A group isomorphism is a bijective one of these. These maps are structure-preserving, meaning that for one of these called F, F(xy) = F(x) F(y).

q3.quetsion_text: Up to isomorphism, there are only two groups of order 4. One is the cyclic group, and the other is this. This group is the smallest non-cyclic group, and it is isomorphic to the dihedral group of order 4.
q3.raw_answer: Klein group [accept Klein four-group or Vierergruppe or V four or Z two cross Z two]

lead_in: This work begins with the funeral of the title Southern spinster and includes scenes that describe how she fell in love with a Northern laborer, Homer Barron.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this short story that ends with some townspeople opening a room in the title woman's house to reveal her bed, which contains the decomposed body of her former lover and a single strand of gray hair on its pillow.

q2.quetsion_text: This Southern author penned stories that often centered around the Compson family in Yoknawpatawpha County. In addition to writing "A Rose for Emily," he authored As I Lay Dying and Light in August.

q3.quetsion_text: This novel by Faulkner focuses on four members of the Compson family, including the mentally handicapped Benjy. This novel depicts Quentin Compson's suicide after he is separated from his sister Caddy.

lead_in: The tone row of this composer's Concerto for Nine Instruments was derived by taking a retrograde inversion, retrograde, and inversion of an initial trichord.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Austrian composer known for such concise works as his Six Bagatelles for string quartet, which together last less than three minutes. His first cataloged work was a Passacaglia for orchestra based on a pizzicato theme.

q2.quetsion_text: Webern was a student of this inventor of twelve-tone serialism and leader of the Second Viennese School. He included a passacaglia about giant moths, "Nacht," in his early piece Pierrot Lunaire.

q3.quetsion_text: This technique, in which a melodic line is passed between instruments, was first coined in Schoenberg's Harmonielehre. Webern used it most notably in his arrangement of J. S. Bach's six-part ricercare from A Musical Offering.

lead_in: This country has faced civic unrest in eastern cities like Donetsk and Luhansk. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this former Soviet Republic. Its Crimean peninsula was annexed by Vladimir Putin in 2014.

q2.quetsion_text: This owner of the Roshen candy company succeeded Viktor Yanukovych and Oleksandr Turchynov  as President of Ukraine in May 2014.

q3.raw_answer: European Commission [or EC; don't accept "European Council"]

lead_in: The Republic of the Marshall Islands and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands were part of this organization's Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this supranational organization, whose Trusteeship Council arranged for countries to oversee the decolonization of such dependent territories. It is the successor to the League of Nations.

q2.quetsion_text: Italy was given control over this territory in East Africa in 1949, having colonized it before World War II. It joined with the British-held territory of the same name to the north and is now an anarchic country on the Horn of Africa.
q2.raw_answer: Trust Territory of Somaliland [or Trust Territory of Somalia; or Amministrazione Fiduciaria della Somalia; or Italian Somaliland; or Italian Somalia; or Somalia italiana; or Dhulka Talyaaniga ee Soomaliya; or Al-Sumal Al-Italiy; do not accept "British Somaliland" or "Dhulka Biritishka ee Soomaaliya" or "Al-Sumal AlBritaniy"]

q3.quetsion_text: South Africa objected to the UN Trust Territory status of this modern country, then known as South-West Africa. It gained independence from South Africa in 1990, after a twenty-year guerilla war.
q3.raw_answer: Republic of Namibia [or Republiek van NamibiÃ«; or Republik Namibia]

lead_in: Identify some things about the NFPA safety diamond, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: The red part of the diamond indicates the danger of ignition while heating, which is measured by this value. Another way of defining this value is the lowest temperature at which a chemical may catch fire.

q2.quetsion_text: The section with this color indicates the reactivity of the compound, or how likely it will detonate when exposed to pressure, or sometimes, water.

q3.quetsion_text: This very common chemical quickly reacts with moisture on the skin and in the body to form an extremely strong base, giving it a 3 in the blue health hazard section. Stimulated emission of this compound was the basis for the first maser.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Punjabi monotheistic religion. It reveres a chain of gurus starting with Nanak and ending with its holy book, the Guru Granth Sahib.
q1.raw_answer: Sikhism [or Sikh faith; or Sikhi; or Sikhs]

q2.quetsion_text: Each gurdwara, or Sikh temple, has a communal area of this type called a langar which is open to all people, regardless of religion. A Chinese god of this area reports to the Jade Emperor one each family each year.
q2.raw_answer: kitchen [or canteen; or pantry; or dining hall; accept any answer indicating a room whose express purpose is to make, serve, eat, or store food]

q3.quetsion_text: This Sanskrit word is used by Sikhs and Hindus alike to refer to the realm of illusion and temptations with no basis in reality.

lead_in: This empire's classical mosque type consists of a central dome with subsidiary half-domes and tall, skinny minarets with conical roofs.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this empire, whose oldest major architectural landmark is the Haci Ozbek Mosque in Iznik, Turkey.

q2.quetsion_text: This Ottoman architect used Iznik tiles extensively in the lower walls of the Rustem Pasha Mosque. The Mihrab of his Selimiye Mosque in Erdine is set in a apse-like chamber off the main hall.
q2.raw_answer: Mimar Sinan [or Koca Mi'mar Sinan Aga]

q3.quetsion_text: This early Ottoman mosque in the Seljuk style follows the hypostyle hall plan but is roofed by twenty full domes supported by square piers. Its piers are notably covered with 192 calligraphy inscriptions.
q3.raw_answer: Bursa Grand Mosque [or Bursa Ulu Camii; prompt for city if given just "Ulu Camii"]

lead_in: This novel's narration alternates between first-person "I," second-person "you," and thirdperson "he." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this 1962 novel whose title character is banished from Coyuca for killing his uncle Pedro. Then, he kills Gonzalo, the brother of his future wife Catalina, to inherit land from his father-in-law Don Gamaliel.
