q3.quetsion_text: This phrase was used to characterize Pablo Escobar's dealings with Colombian government officials. Its figurative meaning is, essentially, "accept a bribe or face assassination."

lead_in: Bonus: The speaker of this poem remarks, “He is all pine and I am apple orchard.” For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this blank verse poem in the collection, North of Boston, which makes the statement that "Good fences make good neighbors" in regards to a structure that separates two properties.

q2.quetsion_text: “Mending Wall” is a work of this American poet. The speaker of another of his works notices that the road “less traveled by” has “made all the difference” in the poem, “The Road Not Taken.”

q3.quetsion_text: This poem of Robert Frost describes how a boy has been bending trees “left and right,” when in fact, “Ice storms do that.” In the end, the speaker remarks, “One could do worse than be a swinger of” the title trees.

lead_in: The scholar Felix Philipp Ingold is among the few who still cling to the theory that this novel was plagiarized from the work of Fyodor Krukov or others. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this novel in which Grigori Melikhov falls in love with Aksinia Astakhova, the most famous work by the author of Virgin Soil Upturned.
q1.raw_answer: And Quiet Flows the Don [or Quietly Flows the Don; or Tikhiy Don; or The Quiet Don]

q2.quetsion_text: Mikhail Sholokhov's And Quiet Flows the Don is a landmark of this official Soviet literary genre, propounded by culture minister Andrei Zhdanov (ZUH-dah-nov). The first major work in this style was another author's 1906 novel Mother.

q3.quetsion_text: Mother was written by this author, the namesake of a Moscow amusement park, whose more famous works include the short story "Twenty-Six Men and a Girl" and the play The Lower Depths.

lead_in: The incompleteness of this understanding can result in an a-not-b error. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this concept, the continued existence of items that can no longer be seen or otherwise observed. The lack of it may be why some babies are startled by the game of peek-a-boo.

q2.quetsion_text: This psychologist first studied object permanence in infants, and believed it originated in the sensorimotor stage of his theory of cognitive development.

q3.quetsion_text: The first stage of object permanence is named for the schema of these involuntary reactions. They include sucking and grasping, and Piaget suggested that they facilitate sensorimotor development.

lead_in: A chess piece museum stands underneath one of these structures, whose walls are angled at 54.7 degrees. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify these dwellings designed by Piet Blom, which rest on top of hexagonal pillars. There are groups of them in both Helmond and Rotterdam.

q2.quetsion_text: Another structuralist dwelling is Habitat 67, designed by Moshe Safdie in this nation. This nation's other architectural wonders include the CN Tower.

q3.quetsion_text: This other architect used structuralist principles to design a building that contains the only Michelangelo painting in the Americas. That building by this architect is the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth.

lead_in: The pregnancy of Ozbeg Khan's wife afforded this man an opportunity to visit Constantinople, after he had earlier encountered pearl divers near the Strait of Hormuz.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this man who left Tangier in the 1320s to go on a grand tour of the Dar-e-Islam, passing through many places in the Islamic world.
q1.raw_answer: ibn Battuta [or Abu Abdallah Muhammad bin Abdallah al-Lawati al-Tanji bin Battuta]

q2.quetsion_text: Ibn Battuta also visited this empire, whose King Mansa Musa made a lavish pilgrimage to Mecca in 1324. This empire had major urban centers at Djenne and Timbuktu.

q3.quetsion_text: On a pilgrimage to Mecca, Mansa Musa doled out large amounts of this metal, causing a precipitous drop in its price. It was mined in large quantities at Witwatersrand in South Africa.

lead_in: This man's theory of the cosmos includes an "overflow" from the Creator, and he wrote that human-like descriptions of God in the Bible are a non-literal aid to help ordinary people understand. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Cordoba-born philosopher who wrote the Mishneh Torah and thirteen principles of the Jewish faith while bouncing about the medieval Islamic world.
q1.raw_answer: Moses Maimonides [or Rabi Moshe ben Maimon; or Rambam]

q2.quetsion_text: Maimonides read some work by this fellow Cordoban, a Muslim Aristotelian whose commentaries on Aristotle challenged the Neoplatonic reading. This man's Decisive Treatise attacked the earlier al-Ghazali.
q2.raw_answer: Averroes [or ibn Rushd; or 'Abu l-Walid Muhammad bun 'Ahmad bin Rusd]

q3.quetsion_text: According to Guide for the Perplexed, God is best described in this way, so as to avoid unintended blasphemy or placing restrictions on His unlimited nature.
q3.raw_answer: using negative attributes [or negatively; or negative theology; or apophatic theology; or the via negativa; accept answers indicating "describing God in terms of what God is not"]

lead_in: Bonus: An example of this interaction is a hawk building a nest on a saguaro cactus. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these interactions between two different species, which benefit one but do not harm or hurt the other.
q1.raw_answer: commensalism [accept word forms; prompt on an answer of “symbiosis”, but do not otherwise reveal it since it is the answer to the next part]

q2.quetsion_text: Commensalism, like mutualism and parasitism, is one form of these general interactions between two species that benefits at least one of those involved.

q3.quetsion_text: One example of commensalism is the growth of these types of plants on the branches of taller trees. They do not harm the tree unless their weight breaks its branches, and benefit from the increased access to water and light.

lead_in: Simon Baron-Cohen claimed that people with this condition lacked a "theory of mind" based on his 1985 study.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this neurological condition. The "broken mirrors" hypothesis posits people develop it when mirror neurons fail before or during infancy.

q2.quetsion_text: Baron-Cohen used this experiment to test for a theory of mind, in which one of the namesake dolls places a marble in a basket and the other moves it to a box when the first isn't looking. Most autistic children said the first doll would look for the marble in the box rather than the basket.

q3.quetsion_text: One proposed cause for the rise in the prevalence of autism-spectrum disorders is an increase in the efficiency of this process in the marriage market, because spouses who are outliers in their genetic endowment for mathematical reasoning are more likely to marry one another.
q3.raw_answer: assortative matching or mating [accept word forms]

lead_in: Bonus: Members of this denomination do not recognize or salute flags or other symbols. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Christian denomination whose members refuse blood transfusions and engage in door-to-door proselytization.

q2.quetsion_text: Jehovah’s Witnesses practice a form of excommunication known by this name, which involves expelling and shunning the affected person.

q3.quetsion_text: According to Jehovah’s Witnesses, Jehovah is not divided into this construct, which is also denied by Unitarians and Arians.

q1.quetsion_text: A gigantic helmet falls from the sky and crushes Conrad, son of the villainous Manfred, at the beginning of The Castle of Otranto, a pioneering Gothic novel by this son of the first Prime Minister of Great Britain.
q1.raw_answer: Horace Walpole [or Horatio Walpole, 4th Earl of Orford]

q2.quetsion_text: A giant pig named "The Empress of Blandings" lives with her owner Lord Emsworth at Blandings Castle, the setting of many stories by this English creator of Psmith and the Drones Club.

q3.quetsion_text: The Castle of Indolence is the final completed poem by this Scotsman, whose more famous works include the lyrics to "Rule, Britannia!" and the poem cycle The Seasons.

lead_in: David May collaborated with this man to create the occam programming language, and this scientist talked about his Elliott ALGOL compiler in his Turing lecture.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this computer scientist. His namesake logic is used to define the correctness of a program, and he also invented Quicksort.
q1.raw_answer: C. A. R. Hoare [or Tony Hoare or Sir Charles Antony Richard Hoare]

q2.quetsion_text: Although randomizing the input can make Quicksort run in expected Big O of n log n time, its worst case is Big O of this quantity, also the worst case runtime for Selection Sort and Bubble Sort.
q2.raw_answer: O(n^2) [or Big O of n squared]

q3.quetsion_text: Novosobirsk published a paper that combined Radix Sort and Quicksort on one of these machines used for parallel computing. Machines built on this paradigm have many serial processes all accessing a shared memory, and algorithms typically build on pointer jumping and can be put into categories like exclusive read exclusive write.

lead_in: This composer is often considered the pivotal figure in the transition from the Renaissance to the Baroque.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Italian composer, whose 1607 opera L'Orfeo is the earliest in the standard repertoire. Only a "Lamento" survives from his second opera, Arianna.

q2.quetsion_text: Though Monteverdi's Orfeo is sometimes erroneously called the first opera, this mythological music drama written for the 1598 Florentine Carnival by librettist Ottavio Rinuccini and composer Jacopo Peri came earlier.

q3.quetsion_text: Jacopo Peri popularized this form of speech-like singing, which commonly precedes arias in later styles of opera. It is divided into a "secco" or "accompagnato" styles, based on whether a continuo or a whole orchestra accompanies it.

lead_in: This poem admits "a new mistress now I chase" and promises that the speaker will "with a stronger faith embrace" that allegorical new lover.

lead_in: This was the capital of the British Raj upon independence in 1947. For 10 points each:

lead_in: Answer some questions about a perennial thorn in the side of Rome, the king Jugurtha. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Jugurtha was a ruler of this North African region, which was divided for a long time between the Massyli and Masaesyli until its unification under the king Syphax. This region's traditional capital was Cirta.

q2.quetsion_text: Jugurtha was a mercenary commander during the 133 BC siege of this Celtiberian oppidum. Rather than surrender to Scipio Aemilianus, the majority of this settlement's inhabitants committed suicide after 13 months of siege.

q3.quetsion_text: Jugurtha was brought to Rome in chains for one of these military ceremonies performed for Gaius Marius. These laudatory events typically involved a victorious general receiving a crown of laurels.

lead_in: Identify the following techniques of cinematography, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This type of shot involves framing the subject tightly in a way that often ignores surroundings. At the end of Sunset Boulevard, Norma Desmond declares that she is ready for this kind of shot.

q2.quetsion_text: In this kind of shot, the camera is mounted on a moving platform on rails to keep a moving subject in the frame. In Goodfellas, there is a very long one of these shots through the Copacabana nightclub.

q3.quetsion_text: In this type of shot, the frame appears tilted. The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari was the first film to use this kind of shot, which perhaps explains one of its alternate names.
q3.raw_answer: Dutch angle [or German angle; or Dutch tilt; or canted angle; or oblique angle]

lead_in: In his Danger Music for Dick Higgins, this artist instructed the performer to crawl into the womb of a living whale, and in another of his works, a seated Buddha statue faces its own image on closed-circuit television.

lead_in: In times of trouble, the Roman Republic would appoint someone to fill this role. For 10 points each:

lead_in: It is equal to two times the principal quantum number times energy squared all over m c squared. For 10 points each:

lead_in: French art was quite contentious in the first half of the nineteenth century. For 10 points each:

q3.quetsion_text: This Frenchman, who coined the term "modernity" in the essay "Painter of Modern Life," was one of Delacroix's staunchest advocates. Walter Benjamin developed several of this man's other ideas, including that of the "flÃ¢neur."

lead_in: The formal definition of this concept in frequentist statistics is that the expectation of an estimator is not equal to the population moment.

q1.quetsion_text: What is this statistical concept, which may arise when a sample is not drawn randomly from the population?
q1.raw_answer: bias [accept word forms and more specific answers: "sampling bias," for example]

q2.quetsion_text: This type of bias arises because the data are generated by agents who make decisions. For instance, the observed wage distribution does not include the "latent" wages of those outside the labor force, so the data is not a random sample.

q3.quetsion_text: Selection bias is a major issue in estimates of this data object, the parameter of interest in most applications of the "Mincer equation." This data object can potentially be compared to the market interest rate to test for over- or- under-investment in human capital.

lead_in: Three men examine this sculpture by candlelight in a 1765 painting by Joseph Wright of Derby.

q2.quetsion_text: Joseph Wright of Derby is perhaps best known for his painting of an experiment on one of these animals in an air pump. Rembrandt's Rape of Ganymede features a specific kind of this animal.

lead_in: For 10 points each, answer these questions about power laws:

q1.quetsion_text: Power laws are unique in that they are scale-invariant, which means that they appear as this kind of curve on a log-log plot.

q3.raw_answer: negative one [accept minus one; do not accept "one"]

lead_in: The formation of these weather systems is heavily influenced by the Madden-Julian oscillation. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these weather systems singularly associated with lightning and cumulonimbus clouds.
q1.raw_answer: thunderstorms [or electrical storm; or thundershower; prompt on storms]

q2.quetsion_text: This thunderstorm formation generally forms along a cold front because the cold front lifts air ahead of it, which rises unaided to the point where condensation occurs. These mesoscale formations can produce downdrafts more than 4 kilometers in extent.

q3.quetsion_text: Squall lines can also form along this type of boundary, which separates air masses with a significant difference in moisture. A sharp change in dew point temperature occurs across it, and one example occurs just east of the Rockies.

lead_in: This scientist coined the term "ghost of competition past" to describe interspecific competition as an evolutionary force that can segregate species even if they do not currently occur sympatrically.

He codified Grime's intermediate disturbance hypothesis and, like Janzen, predicted that most seedlings would die off in the dense areas near their parent trees in tropical forests.

q2.quetsion_text: Connell's barnacle experiments modeled the formation of these ecological roles, which may be "fundamental" or "realized." Hutchinson described these roles, which do not overlap according to Gause's law of competitive exclusion.

q3.quetsion_text: Niche partitioning is often studied using the Caribbean Anolis genus of these animals. The Sceloporus genus of these animals exists in alternative color morphs that illustrate frequency-dependent selection.

lead_in: Bonus: This god established the Pythian Games after killing a gigantic snake. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this son of Leto and Zeus, who was the Greek god of light, music, and medicine.

q2.quetsion_text: This son of Apollo worked as a renowned healer until Zeus struck him with a thunderbolt for resurrecting Theseus’s son Hippolytus. In revenge, Apollo slew the Cyclopes who made the thunderbolts that killed this man.

q3.quetsion_text: Asclepius attained the power of resurrection after this goddess gave him a vial of Gorgon blood. This daughter of Metis cast the deciding vote in a trial that acquitted Orestes of matricide.

lead_in: The tables are turned in this story when Ebenezer Dorset demands 250 dollars.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this short story in which Sam and Bill's attempt to extort money from a concerned father in Summit, Alabama goes awry.

q2.quetsion_text: This author of the collections Sixes and Sevens and The Four Million wrote "The Ransom of Red Chief."

q3.quetsion_text: While living in Austin, Texas, O. Henry coined the insane nickname for this person, real identity still unknown, who was America's first celebrity serial killer.

lead_in: For turbulent flow, this value equals the size of the largest eddies in the system.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this quantity, the distance over which an entity can be influenced by a disturbance.

q2.quetsion_text: Since the transformation using this group always multiplies the correlation length by some factor, this group can be used to show that the correlation length tends to infinity at a critical point.

q3.quetsion_text: The correlation length appears as a critical exponent in this model of ferromagnetism, whose two-dimensional version was described by Lars Onsager.

lead_in: According to legend, soldiers who jumped into the sea during this battle turned into Heike crabs. For 10  points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this battle at which the boy emperor Antoku was killed. The Minamoto clan's victory at this  battle effectively ended their conflict with the Tairas, the Genpei War.

q2.quetsion_text: The Genpei War marked the beginning of the Kamakura era and the end of this period, which was  dominated by the Fujiwara clan. Lady Murasaki wrote The Tale of Genji during this era.

q3.quetsion_text: After moving his capital to Kamakura, Minamoto no Yoritomo took this title, making him the military  ruler of Japan. The daimyos were feudal lords subservient to holders of this title, which was later taken  by Tokugawa Ieyasu.

lead_in: A spin-off of this AMC TV series, Better Call Saul, is set to be produced. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this TV show that documents the escapades of terminal cancer patient Walter White as he struggles to provide for his family through the dealing of methamphetamine.

q2.quetsion_text: Using his knowledge of chemistry, Walter is able to produce a 99.1% pure form of methamphetamine that is this color because of his usage of methylamine instead of pseudoephedrine.

q3.quetsion_text: In Season 5 of Breaking Bad, Walter meets Lydia, a top executive at Madrigal Electromotive, who offers to help him distribute his blue sky to this central European country.

lead_in: The Burrows-Wheeler transform assists in this process by finding runs of similar characters and encoding them more succinctly.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this type of algorithm which can be used to reduce file size.  Zipping a file is an example of performing this action.

q2.quetsion_text: In this type of compression, no important information is removed, allowing the original data to be uncompressed at the same fidelity.  PNG files generally use this type of compression, but JPEGs do not.

q3.quetsion_text: This method for lossless data compression builds a table of the frequency of each character and then uses a greedy algorithm to generate a namesake prefix-free code, with the most common characters having the shortest code.

lead_in: One version is currently digitizing the New York Times archive and Google Books. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these challenge tests often consisting of a distorted image for the user to solve. They are intended to be OCR-resistant and determine whether or not a user is human
q1.raw_answer: [accept reCAPTCHA; accept but otherwise don't reveal Completely Automated Public Turing tests to tell Computers and Humans Apart]

q2.quetsion_text: CAPTCHA is a specific type of this test, which challenges a machine's ability to emulate human intelligence. It originally took the form of a conversation with a human judge.

q3.quetsion_text: This programmer argued that computers like Babbage's Analytical Engine can never pass the Turing test or have minds, because computers are incapable of exceeding the originality of their programmers.
q3.raw_answer: Ada Lovelace [or Augusta Ada Byron; or Augusta Ada King]

lead_in: Answer some question about everyone's favorite giant hundred-headed snake, Shesha, for 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Shesha is the mount of this member of the Hindu Trimurti, the preserver of said group. This god has several avatars, including Krishna and Rama.

q2.quetsion_text: Among the incarnations of Sesha are this loyal brother of Rama, who leaves his wife Urmila to join his brother in exile. Among his exploits are cutting off the demon Surpanakha's nose.

q3.quetsion_text: Another avatar of Shesha was this brother and companion of Krishna, who unlike Krishna was born fair. He also taught the Pandava Bhima how to fight with a mace.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this landmark case decided in 1772 by Lord Mansfield.

q2.quetsion_text: The ruling in the Somerset Case was a victory for this movement in Britain, which sought to end the 'nefarious trade.' This movement fully succeeded in Britain in 1833 with the passage of the Emancipation Act.
q2.raw_answer: abolitionism [accept equivalent answers about ending slavery]

q3.quetsion_text: This Member of Parliament wrote A Letter on the Abolition of the Slave Trade before the passage of the Slave Trade Act of 1807, but died before he could see his efforts fully rewarded by the Slavery Abolition Act in 1833.

lead_in: Bonus: The brothers Alfred and William oversaw their design and construction. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Give the name of these planned suburban communities, many of which were built in the 1940’s and 50’s. The homogeneity of these communities were symbolic of post-World War II mass-produced suburbs.
q1.raw_answer: Levittowns [accept William Levitt, Alfred Levitt, or Levitt & Sons]

q2.quetsion_text: The expansion of suburbs spurred a “flight” of these people from the cities that left a large number of African-Americans stranded in urban areas. Levittowns drew controversy for only leasing to people of this race.

q3.quetsion_text: The first Levittown was constructed in Nassau County in this state. Other suburban communities in this state include Great Neck, Piermont, and Bronxville.

lead_in: The Ket people historically lived in the basin of this river, which terminates in a namesake gulf in the Kara Sea.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Siberian river, which is the largest of the three that flows into the Arctic Ocean and is thus way cooler than the Ob and Lena rivers.

q2.quetsion_text: In 2009, one of the biggest dam disasters in Russian history occurred on the Yenisei at this dam, the largest power plant in Russia, killing 75 people when the engine and turbine rooms were flooded after a turbine detached from its bearings and flew 50 feet in the air.
q2.raw_answer: SayanoÂ–Shushenskaya Dam [or the Sayano-Shushenskaya Gidroelektrostantsiya; or the OJSC P. S. Neporozhny Sayano-Shushenskaya HPP]

q3.quetsion_text: The majority of the energy from the Sayano-Shushenskaya Dam was used by an industry that smelts this metal. This metal is smelted by employing the Hall-Heroult process on its oxide.

lead_in: SansÃ³n Carrasco challenges this character in disguises as the Knight of Mirrors and later as the Knight of the White Moon. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this so-called "Knight of the Sorrowful Face," a delusional middle-aged man who rides around Spain with Sancho in a novel by Cervantes.
q1.raw_answer: Don Quixote de La Mancha [or Alonso Quijano the Good]

q2.quetsion_text: In this building from Part I of Don Quixote, Dorotea, Don Fernando, Lucinda, and Cardenio resolve their love rectangle. The hunchback Maritornes lives in this place, where Sancho was tossed up and down in a blanket.
q2.raw_answer: the inn which Don Quixote believes to be a castle

q3.quetsion_text: In Part II, Quixote meets this wealthy duo, who have read the first part of the novel and use their knowledge to play increasingly-malicious tricks, such as having Sancho lash himself three thousand times.

lead_in: Answer the following about unusual animal defense mechanisms, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: When threatened by predators, some members of this class of echinoderms can eviscerate themselves by ejecting sticky tubules through their anus.

q2.quetsion_text: As a last resort, the Texas horned lizard uses its eyes to spray predators with a stream of this substance.

q3.quetsion_text: In a process known as caudal autotomy, some geckos are able to leave behind this body part when it is grabbed by predators. In that process, caudal muscles break apart vertebrae in order to sever this body part.

lead_in: This political issue also called the English Question is named for the constituency of the MP who first brought it up. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this political debate on whether MPs at Westminster representing constituents from regions with devolved parliaments should vote on laws that solely concern England.
q1.raw_answer: the West Lothian question [prompt on "English votes for English laws"]

q2.quetsion_text: David Cameron pledged to solve the West Lothian question in a speech that promised more devolution to this constituent country of the United Kingdom that had a failed independence referendum in September 2014.

q3.quetsion_text: This party's leader Nigel Farage called on Scottish MPs to recuse from voting on English affairs until a constitutional convention. This far-right party broke into Westminster with Douglas Carswell's by-election win.
q3.raw_answer: UKIP [pronounced YOU-kip out loud, or read normally as an acronym; or UK Independence Party; or United Kingdom Independence Party]

lead_in: One character in this story is revealed not to be a god when a bite draws his blood. For 10 points each:

lead_in: This method was developed after a psychologist noticed the high correlation in test scores for apparently unrelated topics among schoolchildren.

q2.quetsion_text: Charles Spearman explained the testing correlation with the "g factor," which is a general measure of this quality. Tests created to measure this include the WAIS and Stanford-Binet.

q3.quetsion_text: Raymond Cattell used factor analysis to identify these two components of general intelligence. One accounts for the ability to recognize patterns in new situations and the other describes the ability to use previously learned facts.

q1.raw_answer: Tiberius Claudius Nero [or Tiberius Julius Caesar]

q3.quetsion_text: Methylation also occurs directly on nucleotides; for example, at these sites, where a namesake pyrimidine is methylated at the 5 carbon when it lies next to a namesake purine. They are especially common in promoters.
q3.raw_answer: CpG islands [or CpG sites; or CG sites; or CGI; or cytosine and guanine instead of C and G]

lead_in: These drawings represent shared electrons involved in bonds as line segments.

lead_in: The "grim trigger" strategy for this situation calls for cooperation until the other player defects for the first time, after which the first player defects for every other iteration. For 10 points each:

q2.quetsion_text: John von Neumann and Oskar Morgenstern founded this field with an influential 1944 book. The prisoner's dilemma is a classic scenario in this field that models decision making in competitive activities.

q3.quetsion_text: Anatol Rapoport came up with this winning strategy for iterated versions of prisoner's dilemma. It calls for doing exactly what the other side did in the previous iteration.

lead_in: This state is the home base of the ski-mask wearing insurgent Subcomandante Marcos. For 10 points each:

lead_in: In a poem, one of these animals "came to my water-trough / On a hot, hot day." For 10 points each:

lead_in: The Becker type of this disease is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern while the Duchenne type is most common. For 10 points each:

lead_in: This essay compares historical materialism's use of theology to the chess-playing Mechanical Turk.

q2.quetsion_text: "On the Concept of History" is found in Walter Benjamin's Illuminations, which also contains this essay. It describes the shriveling of the title objects' auras and argues that film is characterized by an estrangement in which the aura is replaced by the actors' personality.

lead_in: Histological divisions of this part of the brain are labeled CA1, CA2, CA3, and CA4. For 10 points each:

lead_in: One result of this theorem is that the number of n-color rotationally distinct colorings of a p-faced platonic solid is a polynomial in n of degree p.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this combinatorial identity, which says the total number of results is equal to the average number of fixed points under the action of a certain group. It was originally proven by Frobenius.

q2.quetsion_text: Burnside's lemma gives the number of these entities, the set of elements to which an element can be moved to by group actions. This thing is paired with stabilizers in the name of a theorem that can be used to derive Burnside's lemma.

q3.quetsion_text: Using Burnside's lemma is overkill when the group in question consists of these actions, which simply re-order n elements in some fashion. For those n elements, there are n-factorial of them.

lead_in: Answer some questions about Lagrangian mechanics, for 10 points each:

lead_in: Answer some questions about legal challenges to the Affordable Care Act

q1.quetsion_text: The case NFIB v. Sebelius dealt primarily with this provision of the Affordable Care Act. The Court held that this provision of the law was a constitutional exercise of Congress's power to tax, but not of its power to regulate commerce.

Prompt if the word "individual" or equivalents like "people" is not included, and do not accept "employer mandate" or anything about businesses. This tournament opposes the concept of corporate personhood.]

q2.quetsion_text: This leader of the Myrmidons kills the Trojan champion Hector, but later dies when an arrow hits him in the heel.

q3.quetsion_text: Achilles is killed by this Trojan prince, whose abduction of Helen from the court of Menelaus kicked off the Trojan War. He also presents Aphrodite with a certain golden apple.

lead_in: This philosopher coined the term "intentional stance" for the attitude we take toward entities we perceive to have beliefs and desires.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this American philosopher who attacked the unitary Cartesian theatre and proposed the alternative Multiple Drafts model in Consciousness Explained.

q2.quetsion_text: Dennett describes John Searle's Chinese Room thought experiment as one of these scenarios framed to elicit an instinctual, though often false, answer. The title of a 2013 book by Dennett mentions them among "other tools for thinking."

q3.quetsion_text: Dennett takes a strongly adaptationist position in a book about this scientist's "dangerous idea," which attacks the pluralism of Steven Jay Gould. Dennett claims that this man's theories explain the appearance of design in biology.

lead_in: Charles Young was a decorated member of this group, which built the first trail to the summit of Mount Whitney. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Give this unofficial nickname of members of the U.S. 10th Cavalry regiment, which was later extended to members of all black regiments that fought against American Indians.

q2.quetsion_text: In this 1906 incident, a regiment of buffalo soldiers stationed in a Texas town were accused of killing a white bartender, leading them to be dishonorably discharged en masse under the orders of Theodore Roosevelt.

q3.quetsion_text: Due to his friendliness with members of the 10th Cavalry Regiment, this commander of a Punitive Expedition against Pancho Villa received the pejorative nickname "Black Jack."

lead_in: This river forms the border between South Africa and Zimbabwe, part of the border between South Africa and Botswana. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this river that shares its name with the northernmost province of South Africa.

q2.quetsion_text: The mouth of the Limpopo River lies near the town of Xai-Xai, which is located in this nation. This Portuguese-speaking nation is the namesake of a channel between it and Madagascar, and its capital is Maputo.

q3.quetsion_text: Two of the major geographical regions of South Africa are the "High" and "Low" ones of this type of grassland. Its name is an Afrikaans word that loosely translates as "field."

lead_in: This constellation's star Betelgeuse makes up part of the Winter Triangle. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this constellation, whose three stars Alnitak, Alnilam, and Mintaka form a namesake "belt." Its brightest star is Rigel.

q2.quetsion_text: This astronomer's namesake "Loop" is found within Orion. He also names a star which is the closest to Earth after the three in Alpha Centauri.

q3.quetsion_text: Also found within Orion is this dark nebula, sometimes called Barnard 33. It resembles part of a certain animal's body.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this alliance between a Christian country and Muslim empire, both of which worked together to capture Nice in 1543 because of their mutual dislike of the Hapsburgs.
q1.raw_answer: French-Ottoman alliance [accept in any order and other equivalent answers such as Franco-Turkish alliance or alliance between France and the Ottoman empire]

q2.quetsion_text: An impetus behind the alliance was the power gained by this Habsburg ruler, who took the Spanish throne in 1516 and became Holy Roman Emperor three years later.
q2.raw_answer: Charles V of the Holy Roman Empire [or Charles I of Spain; prompt on "Charles"]

q3.quetsion_text: In 1553, French and Ottoman forces collaborated to capture this island. Much later, France paid Genoa in the 1768 Treaty of Versailles to buy this island, which had an independence movement led by Pascal Paoli.

lead_in: This series concludes in 1968, where the Charles Manson analogue Murtlock recruits several descendants of the central family to his cult.

q1.raw_answer: A Dance to the Music of Time

q2.quetsion_text: Another British novel series is Lawrence Durrell's "Quartet" set in this cosmopolitan city, where Constantine Cafauvy also lived.

q3.quetsion_text: This other British novel series is about a character who saves the life of Second Lieutenant Aranjuez and refuses to let O Nine Morgan leave the army because he knows his wife is cheating on him with a murderous boxer.

lead_in: Bonus: One way of achieving this state is through the four yogas. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this state of liberation in Hinduism, in which one breaks from from samsara, or the cycle of rebirth.

q2.quetsion_text: This entity, which can be described as a soul, must acquire gnana in order to attain moksha. This essence of the true self is often considered the same as Brahman.

q3.quetsion_text: This Hindu principle that causes the cycle of samsara states that one’s actions may influence one’s fate. According to this principle, good behavior leads to good consequences and bad actions are punished.

lead_in: Bonus: This television series is based on the works of forensic anthropologist Kathy Reichs. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this TV series starring Emily Deschanel as Dr. Temperance Brennan, a forensic anthropologist at the Jeffersonian who solves murder cases by studying the title remains.

q2.quetsion_text: Bones is broadcasted on this television network that also has shows such as New Girl, Sleepy Hollow, Family Guy, and Glee.

q3.quetsion_text: This Special Agent, Dr. Brennan’s partner, works for the FBI and does not favor the scientific procedures of “squints.” He has a daughter named Christine with Dr. Brennan, and marries her in Season 9 after the death of Pelant.
q3.raw_answer: Seeley Joseph Booth [accept either part; but do NOT accept “Jared Booth”] <EC>

lead_in: Answer some questions about musical films. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this film about a silent film star who is forced to publicly enter a relationship with his co-star, Lina Lamont. That star, Don Lockwood tries to create a hit to compete with the Jazz Singer called the Dancing Cavalier.

q2.quetsion_text: Singing in the Rain was directed by this man, who also choreographed the musical film An American in Paris. He's credited with making ballet dance mainstream.

q3.quetsion_text: This Jean-Luc Godard musical-comedy centers on an Anna-Karina-played woman who wants to get pregnant despite her husband's reservations. This film features a scene of said couple having an argument only using book titles.
q3.raw_answer: Une femme est une femme [or A Woman is a Woman Â– the underlined "A" is not a mistake]

lead_in: Answer some questions about sequential logic circuit parts, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This logic gate produces a "1" if either of its inputs is a "1", unlike the AND where only both inputs being "1" outputs a "1". Its inverted form thus gives an output of "1" only when both inputs are "0".

q2.quetsion_text: The "set-reset" variety of these circuits are easily constructed from two cross-coupled NOR gates or NAND gates. These circuits are prominent examples of bistable multivibrators and are the building blocks of sequential logic.

q3.quetsion_text: The SR NOR latch is active in this state, in which case a voltage of like 3.3 Â– 5 volts corresponds to "1", while the SR NAND latch is active in this other state, in which case tying it to ground corresponds to "1". Name either state.
q3.raw_answer: high-output state or low-output state [accept either underlined portion]

lead_in: Bonus: This poem’s speaker has “bathed in the Euphrates when dawns were young.” For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this poem whose speaker’s “soul has grown deep” like the title entities and has “looked upon the Nile and raised the pyramids above it.”

q2.quetsion_text: This Harlem Renaissance poet wrote “The Negro Speaks of Rivers” and “Theme for English B.”, and asked “what happens to a dream deferred” in another poem.

q3.quetsion_text: This poem by Hughes begins with “Droning a drowsy syncopated tune” and later describes an individual who “slept like a rock or a man that’s dead.”

lead_in: This poem describes bards singing "Of Turneys and of Trophies hung; Of Forests, and inchatments drear".

q1.quetsion_text: Name this poem by John Milton that declares "Hail divinest Melancholy". It is paired with a pastoral poem depicting joyousness.

q2.quetsion_text: This Romantic poet opened his "Ode on Melancholy" with the lines "No, no! go not to Lethe, neither twist / Wolf's-bane, tight-rooted, for its poisonous wine". He also wrote an "Ode to a Nightingale".

q3.quetsion_text: The speaker of this poem sees "through [her] tears / The sweet, sad years, the melancholy years". This poem ends with the speaker being held by the hair by a figure who reveals himself to be "Not Death, but Love".

lead_in: The ritualistic performance of this action is known as salat and is required as one of the Five Pillars of Islam.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this action, which devout Muslims perform five times per day while facing Mecca.

q2.quetsion_text: This is the Arabic term for the direction that one must face while performing ritualistic prayer or salat.

q3.quetsion_text: While most instances of salat are done in private, Muslims frequently hold congregational prayers known as jumu'ah at noon on this day of the week.

lead_in: Ketose monosaccharides test positive when exposed to this chemical because the ketose form is turned into an aldehyde by the basic conditions.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this chemical made up of cupric sulfate and sodium tartarate that can be used to distinguish aldehydes from ketones.

q2.raw_answer: brick red [accept other dark shades of red]

q3.quetsion_text: Another test for detecting aldehydes is through the use of Tollens' reagent, in which aldehydes form a mirror of this colour.

lead_in: Reactions are exergonic and spontaneous if the change in this quantity is negative. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this quantity whose change be found by subtracting the product of temperature and the  change in entropy from the change in heat.
q1.raw_answer: Gibbs free energy [prompt on "free energy" or "energy" or "G"]

q2.quetsion_text: In an electrochemical cell, the change in Gibbs free energy can be calculated by multiplying the  inverse of the Faraday constant, the number of moles of electrons, and this other quantity for the cell.
q2.raw_answer: standard cell potential [or EÂ° cell ("E-nought-cell"); prompt on "electrode potential" or  "reduction potential"; prompt on "E cell"]

q3.quetsion_text: Standard electrode potentials are measured relative to that of the standard hydrogen electrode,  which uses this metal as an electrode due to its inertness. This metal is also used in catalytic converters.

lead_in: This band exhibited a more aggressive metal sound in their recent album Kveikur. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this post-rock band led by Jonsi, who plays bowed guitar and sings ethereal vocals in Vonlenska. Their albums include Agaetis byrjun ("OW-guy-tis bee-ARR-yun"), TakkÂ…, and Valtari.

lead_in: This region contains the Maasai Mara, a hunting grounds named for the Maasai people, and a Great Wildebeest Migration occurs here yearly. For 10 points:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this grassland plain and common safari destination, now protected largely as a namesake national park in Tanzania.
q1.raw_answer: Serengeti plain [or Serengeti ecosystem; or Serengeti National Park]

q2.quetsion_text: The very wide branches of this tree can be seen throughout the African continent, including sporadically on the Serengeti. According to legend, the hyena planted this tree upside-down.

lead_in: Bonus: It talks of a woman who has “The smiles that win” and “the tints that glow.” For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this poem, whose title action is performed “like the night/ Of cloudless climes and starry skies” by a woman whose “love is innocent.”

lead_in: A famous section of this work contrasts mere "fancy" with "imagination", which the author claims has an "esemplastic", or unifying, power. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this autobiographical prose work that, among other things, coins the term "suspension of disbelief" and extends the philosophy of poetry first put forth by its author's counterpart in Lyrical Ballads.

lead_in: Cesaro summation and Abel summation are methods for assigning values to series even if they have this property.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this term for a series which, when taken as a sequence of partial sums, does not converge to a finite limit.

q2.quetsion_text: The proof of the no-ghost theorem in bosonic string theory involves summing over infinite oscillator modes. In the proof, according to the method of Ramanujan summation, what is the value of 1 + 2 + 3 + 4 + Â… etc.?
q2.raw_answer: Â–1/12 [or negative one twelfth; or obvious equivalents]

q3.quetsion_text: The infinite sum 1 + 2 + 3 + Â… etc. can be regularized by viewing it as the analytic continuation of this function to Â–1. This function is defined as the sum over positive integers n of 1 over n to the power s.
q3.raw_answer: Euler-Riemann zeta function [prompt on zeta function]

lead_in: Heracles once threatened to shoot this god because it was too hot. For 10 points:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this son of the Titan Hyperion, who drove the Sun across the sky each day.

q2.quetsion_text: Helios's own son Phaeton persuaded his father to let him use one of these objects, but Phaeton failed to control the horses that pulled it and had to be killed by Zeus before he did too much damage.

q1.quetsion_text: Fullerenes are the third allotrope of this element, whose other allotropes are diamond and graphite.

q1.raw_answer: fMRI [or functional magnetic resonance imaging; or functional MRI]

lead_in: Answer the following about approximating pendulum motion,

q1.quetsion_text: To reduce pendulums to simple harmonic oscillators, one can use the small angle approximation, which states that for small values, sine of theta equals this quantity.

q2.quetsion_text: One way of estimating the elliptic integral to get an exact solution involves this function of two inputs. To evaluate it, one repeatedly takes the average of the two inputs and the square root of their products until it converges.

q3.quetsion_text: The Kidd-Fogg approximation multiplies the expected period by one over the square root of this trig function. This function of theta can itself be approximated by one minus one-fourth times theta-squared, for small theta.

q1.quetsion_text: Neutral theory assumes that trophically similar species do not differ in this entity, the set of environmental conditions under which the species can persist. G. Evelyn Hutchinson defined this entity as an n-dimensional hypervolume, and distinguished its realized and fundamental kinds.

q1.quetsion_text: This data structure is traditionally implemented by indexing a numerical offset into a contiguous block of memory. Its "associative" type is a collection of key-value pairs and is often called a "map" or a "symbol table."

q2.quetsion_text: This kind of relation is often used to implement an associative array. It maps its input to an integer in constant time so that the underlying array can be accessed quickly; usually its output is fed into a modulo function whose other input is the size of the array.

q3.quetsion_text: This other data structure is a bit array, with a given number of independent hash functions, each of which map an element to an array index. It is used to test if an element is present in a set, reporting false positives but not false negatives.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Though famous performers on this instrument often play similar instruments such as the flugelhorn [FLOO-gul-horn], cornet, and horn, this was the primary instrument of Woody Shaw, Miles Davis, and Wynton Marsalis.

q2.quetsion_text: This was the primary instrument played by McCoy Tyner, Thelonius Monk, and Art Tatum.

q3.quetsion_text: This was the primary instrument played by Kid Ory, Glenn Miller, and Curtis Fuller.

lead_in: The statue Alba by George Kolbe is found in this structure, whose main building sits atop a travertine plinth opposite a pool. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this building designed for the 1929 International Exposition, which was held in the capital of Catalonia.

q2.quetsion_text: The Barcelona Pavilion was constructed by this German-American International Stylearchitect, who designed the Farnsworth House, collaborated with Philip Johnson on the Seagram Building, and used the phrase "less is more."

q3.quetsion_text: Mies's Barcelona Pavilion was recognized as a significant International Style building in the 1932 MoMA exhibition, which conferred similar honors upon the Lovell House designed by this Austrian-American architect of many prominent modernist buildings in Southern California.

lead_in: Answer the following about models in the social sciences which can be diagrammed as triangles or pyramids, of which, sadly, none are Sternberg's triangle of love, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This humanistic psychologist put the "deficiency needs" of physiological satisfaction, safety, belonging, and esteem below self-actualization in his silly-ass hierarchy of needs.

q2.quetsion_text: Robert Gordon developed a New Keynesian "triangle" model of this phenomenon that incorporates a "built-in" component. People seeking a less volatile estimate of this phenomenon often use data on its "core" variety.

q3.quetsion_text: Though sometimes depicted as a Trivial Pursuit piece-like pie, this schema for classifying skills important to learning is often shown as a pyramid with "creating" or "evaluating" at the top.

lead_in: Name the following beings encountered by Samuel Taylor Coleridge's Ancient Mariner, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This creature is shot by the mariner with a crossbow, and hangs around his neck as his misfortunes and eerie encounters pile up.

q2.quetsion_text: The mariner watches this womanly figure gloats after winning a dice game against the haggard male figure of Death.

q3.quetsion_text: The albatross falls off the mariner's neck after he blesses these two creatures "unawares" at the end of Part IV. These creatures "moved in tracks of shining white" and had "rich attire" of "blue, glossy green, and velvet black."

lead_in: This artist filmed himself dancing to "Gangnam Style" in handcuffs and co-curated the "Fuck Off" exhibition in 2000 with Feng Boyi.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this Chinese dissident artist of Han Dynasty Urn with Coca-Cola Logo, who designed the "Bird's Nest" stadium for the 2008 Olympics.

q2.quetsion_text: In 2010, Ai filled the floor of the Tate Modern's Turbine Hall with millions of porcelain replicas of the seeds of this flower. Vincent van Gogh created a series of paintings of these flowers for the Yellow House in Arles.

q3.quetsion_text: Ai collaborated on the Beijing National Stadium with this Swiss architectural firm, whose two senior partners made their names by converting the Bankside Power Station into the Tate Modern.
q3.raw_answer: Herzog & de Meuron Basel Ltd. [or Herzog & de Meuron Architekten; or Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron]

lead_in: Henry Lawson and "Banjo" Paterson feuded over the role of romanticizing its countryside in the socalled "Bulletin" Debate.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this country that is the setting for a trilogy about Richard Mahony. Jean Paget emigrates to this country in A Town Like Alice

q2.quetsion_text: This modern Australian author of The True History of the Kelly Gang wrote of a bet to transport a glass church in Oscar and Lucinda.

q3.quetsion_text: David Malouf was nominated for a Booker prize for this novel about Gemmy Fairley, who is taken in by Aborigines after landing ashore on Australia, but who tries to re-integrate with the European settlers once they arrive.

lead_in: Answer these questions about the maritime provinces, for 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: This province includes the traditionally-Scottish-inhabited Cape Breton Island, although its capital, Halifax, is on the mainland. French settlers from Acadia were deported from this place and it was renamed by the Brits in 1755.

q2.quetsion_text: Nova Scotia is bordered to the west by this body of water, which has access to the Irving oil refinery and is located on a rift valley. St John's lies on it, and it separates most of New Brunswick from Nova Scotia.
q2.raw_answer: Bay of Fundy [prompt on Gulf of Maine]

q3.quetsion_text: The Bay of Fundy was originally named "French Bay" by this French explorer, who also names a large lake in upstate New York

lead_in: Bonus: One square in this neighborhood features an equestrian statue of Andrew Jackson. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this neighborhood lying along the Mississippi, where attractions such as Jean Lafitte’s Blacksmith Shop lie along Bourbon Street.
q1.raw_answer: French Quarter [or Vieux Carré; prompt on “the Quarter”]

q2.quetsion_text: The French Quarter is located in this city that was devastated by Hurricane Katrina and has a notable Mardi Gras celebration.

q3.quetsion_text: The French Quarter used to border the historic neighborhood of Storyville, which until its closure in 1917 was a legalized one of these prostitution-heavy districts. Modern examples include De Wallen in Amsterdam and Soi Cowboy in Bangkok.

lead_in: Answer these questions about totems called Tjurungu ("chuh-ROON-guh"), for 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Tjurunga are spiritual totems of indigenous people from this country. Those people are collectively known as "Aborigines."

q2.quetsion_text: The Tjurunga cannot be approached by people who have not undergone this rite. Women, foreigners, and children who have not come of age cannot undergo this.
q2.raw_answer: initiation rite [accept equivalents like initiation into the clan]

q3.quetsion_text: This ritual, performed on male Jewish babies, is an example of an initiation rite.
q3.raw_answer: circumcision [or brit milah; or bris; prompt on first mitzvah]

lead_in: Bonus: The American filibuster William Walker became president of this country in 1856 but was ousted a year later. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this country now ruled by Daniel Ortega from Managua.

q2.quetsion_text: Daniel Ortega first came to power in the wake of the Nicaraguan Revolution as the leader of this party, which was opposed by the Contras.
q2.raw_answer: Sandinistas [Sandinista National Liberation Front; or Frente Sandinista de Liberación Nacional; or FSLN]

q3.quetsion_text: This family held control over Nicaragua for several decades of the 20th century before being overthrown in the Nicaraguan Revolution. Of the three members of this family who became president, two were named Anastasio.

lead_in: Answer the following about Enrico Dandolo, a power broker of medieval European politics,

q1.quetsion_text: Dandolo held this elected leadership title with an Old Italian name. Genoa was ruled by one of these people, and in Dandolo's city they ruled from a palace near Saint Mark's Square.

q2.quetsion_text: As doge, Dandolo presided over this Italian city-state whose layout has been organized around canals for centuries.
q2.raw_answer: Serene Republic of Venice [or Serenissima Republica di Venezia]

q3.quetsion_text: Dandolo helped finance this anti-Muslim campaign, despite being over eighty years old and blind when it started. In 1204, its participants went astray and sacked Constantinople

lead_in: Identify the following about some parts of a computer,

q1.quetsion_text: This important part of a computer typically contains an arithmetic logic unit. The speed at which these entities operate can be increased by overclocking.
q1.raw_answer: CPUs [or central processing unit; prompt on "processor" or "microprocessor"]

q2.quetsion_text: This extremely popular processor for lower-end devices like phones and tablets is licensed by a namesake British company. The v8-A version of this processor added 64-bit support, and this type of processor is typically cheaper to produce than an x86 processor.

q3.quetsion_text: Rather than interact with hardware directly, programs will go through this layer of software, broken down into components like the kernel. Examples of this type of software include Unix and Linux.

lead_in: In the 18th century, Austria was not exactly friendly to the idea of a female ruler. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Austrian ruler whose father Charles VI attempted to facilitate her ascension to the throne with the passage of the Pragmatic Sanction of 1713.

q2.quetsion_text: The Pragmatic Sanction failed to quell the desires of other European nations for Austrian land. Prussia's invasion of Silesia prompted this conflict over the Austrian crown which was ended by the Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle.

q3.quetsion_text: Dispute over Maria Theresa's succession centered on this ancient Frankish law which prohibited agnatic succession and more specifically females from inheriting ancestral land.

lead_in: The strength of fibroin, a major component of silk, results from the crystallization of many of these structures.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this protein structure held together by hydrogen bonds that may be classified as either parallel or antiparallel depending on the orientation of the C-terminus.

q2.quetsion_text: Along with alpha helices, beta-pleated sheets make up this level of protein structure, which involves the local geometrical structure of amino acid sequences.

q3.quetsion_text: The two most common types of alpha helices have three residues per turn and this other non-integer number of residues per turn.
q3.raw_answer: 3.6 [or three point six, accept numbers between 3.55 and 3.65]

lead_in: A couple of living composers of this ethnicity got thrown in concentration camps after their music was labelled Entartete Musik, including Viktor Ullmann and Erwin Schulhoff. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this ethnicity whose music was labelled "degenerate" by the Nazis. It included Felix Mendelssohn.

q2.quetsion_text: This titan among classical labels has been releasing albums in its Entartete Musik series for about twenty years, to bring back forgotten works of "degenerate" composers. This British label got huge after developing full frequency range recording and is instantly recognizable by their two-tone blue and red logo.

q3.quetsion_text: This degenerate composer came to the United States just before the Anschluss and revolutionized film scores. His violin concerto was the first classical work he wrote after vowing to only compose film music until Hitler was defeated

lead_in: Bonus: Answer the following about leaves, for ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: The surface of leaves contain these microscopic pores which open to allow carbon dioxide in and close to prevent water loss. They are surrounded by two guard cells.

q2.quetsion_text: Leaves are green because of this pigment, which absorbs solar energy to trigger the start of photosynthesis.

q3.quetsion_text: Most of the photosynthesis occurs in this leaf tissue, which is situated below the cuticle and epidermis. This tissue is divided into a palisade layer and a spongy layer.

lead_in: This painting took forever to complete because its artist insisted on only working during two or three specific minutes of twilight every day, taking breaks from his tennis games with Edmund Gosse to do so.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this 1886 painting in which Frederick Barnard's two daughters hang softly-glowing Chinese lanterns in a garden.

q2.quetsion_text: Carnation, Lily, Lily, Rose was painted by this American artist of El Jaleo who scandalized the 1884 Paris Salon with his Portrait of Madame X.

q3.quetsion_text: This subject of a trio of Sargent portraits deemed the most famous of them "damn queer". In that painting, the extremely lean form of this author wanders towards the left with his hand to his mouth, while his wife blends in with an armchair on its right edge.

lead_in: Peyer's patches are lumps of immune tissue found in this organ.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this segment of the digestive system that connects the large intestine and the stomach. It receives bile from the sphincter of Oddi.

q2.quetsion_text: This middle segment of the small intestine begins at the ligament of Treitz. It comes after the duodenum and before the ileum.

q3.quetsion_text: The I-cells of the duodenum secrete this hormone in response to chyme, which triggers the release of pancreatic enzymes into the small intestine and the release of bile from the gallbladder.

lead_in: In a novel by Cesar Aira, a member of this profession wears a black veil during an Indian raid after becoming disfigured in a lightning strike. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this profession of a man who stabs Maria Iribarne to death in Ernesto Sabato's The Tunnel.

q2.quetsion_text: This other Latin American author wrote about the painter Paul Gauguin in The Way to Paradise. He also satirized Peruvian politics in Conversation in the Cathedral and wrote Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter.

q3.quetsion_text: This writer featured the romance between a sculptor and an art critic in The Buenos Aires Affair but is better known for a novel in which Molina retells movies like Cat People to his cellmate.

lead_in: Identify some characters from The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This slave keeps Huck company as they travel down the Mississippi River, after he escapes his owner, Miss Watson.

q2.quetsion_text: Two answers required. One member of this pair of con-artists claims to be rightful heir to  "bilgewater," and the other a long-lost son of Louis XVI. Soon after this pair appears, they pretend to be Peter Wilks' brothers.
q2.raw_answer: The Duke and the Dauphin [order does not matter; do not prompt on partial answer]

q3.quetsion_text: After an accident with a steamboat, Huck is taken in by this family, becoming a first-hand witness of their murderous feud with the Shepherdsons.

lead_in: This politician criticized the tactics of the National Union of Mineworkers in their 1984-85 strike, but agreed with their general objectives, which he called the "case for coal."

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Welsh politician who served as head of Labour from 1983 to 1992, making him the longest-serving opposition leader ever. He also served as Vice President of the European Commission.

q2.quetsion_text: This U.S. politician was discovered to have plagiarized Kinnock's speeches, which ended his 1988 run for President. He presided over the Robert Bork nomination hearings as head of the Senate Judiciary Committee.

q3.quetsion_text: The Sun, a tabloid that's part of this man's media empire, ran a 1992 headline denouncing Kinnock on the eve of the elections. His companies have been investigated in Britain recently for a phone hacking scandal.

lead_in: This event was led by Arthur "Slim" Evans and was stopped in Regina.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this event that took place in Depression-era Canada. It was organized by the Relief Camp Workers Union.
q1.raw_answer: On-To-Ottawa Trek [accept On-To-Ottawa March; accept other equivalents for march or trek]

q2.quetsion_text: This "elite" Canadian police force stopped the On-To-Ottawa Trek. This unit wears funny hats and killed a bunch of people during a coal strike in Estevan, Saskatchewan.
q2.raw_answer: Royal Canadian Mounted Police [accept RCMP; accept Mounties]

q3.quetsion_text: The On-To-Ottawa Trek targeted this Canadian prime minister. This guy's nickname was "Iron-Heel," cars that had horses attached to them for lack of gasoline were known as his "buggies" and he was obviously swept out of office by Mackenzie King's Liberals in 1935.
q3.raw_answer: Richard Bedford Bennett [accept First Viscount Bennett]

lead_in: This object contained an inscription establishing the authority of Ptolemy V. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this object crucial to the decoding of Egyptian hieroglyphs. It was translated by Jean Francois Champollion.

q2.quetsion_text: The Rosetta Stone has three languages: Egyptian hieroglyphs, Demotic, and this language, which had Attic, Ionic, and Homeric dialects.
q2.raw_answer: Ancient Greek [accept Koine Greek; prompt on Greek]

q3.quetsion_text: Thomas Young used this oval-shaped symbol to find the name Ptolemy in hieroglyphic form. They enclosed royal names for protection, guarding them from evil spirits.

lead_in: The speaker of this poem declares: "My foothold is tenon'd and mortis'd in granite / I laugh at what you call dissolution / And I know the amplitude of time".

q1.quetsion_text: Name this long poem, whose speaker declares: "I too am not a bit tamed, I too am untranslatable / I sound my barbaric yawp over the roofs of the world".

q2.quetsion_text: In Whitman's "Song of Myself", a child asks "What is this substance"? This substance titles a Carl Sandburg poem that begins: "Pile the bodies high at Austerlitz and Waterloo".

q3.quetsion_text: This Berkeley professor and former U.S. Poet Laureate co-wrote a lexicon of Whitman's diction in "Song of Myself" with Paul Ebenkamp. He is the leading English translator of Czeslaw Milosz's poetry, and his own poetry is known for its ecological themes.

lead_in: Nusslein-Volhard and Wieschaus employed this technique in order to demonstrate that bicoid is expressed in the anterior portion of the Drosophila embryo.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this technique, whose chromogenic form was developed to study breast cancer oncogenes. This procedure uses oligonucleotide, DNA or cRNA probes to detect and localize sequences to tissue.
q1.raw_answer: chromogenic in situ hybridization [or CISH; prompt on partial answer; antiprompt on "FISH" or "fluorescence (or fluorescent) in situ hybridization"]

q2.quetsion_text: A common in situ hybridization immunolabel is digoxigenin, a steroid hapten derived from this organism. Fab treats a toxin from this organism that inhibits Na+/K+ ATPase, increasing intracellular calcium
q2.raw_answer: Digitalis [or foxgloves; accept specific species such as D. purpurea]

q3.quetsion_text: An alternative to digoxigenin is labeling with radioactive examples of these things. The MeselsonStahl experiment employed two nitrogen ones, while the C3 and C4 pathways metabolize carbon ones in different ratios.

lead_in: This character claims that the "highest female grace is silence" while Lady Would-Be speaks to him.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this wealthy Venetian who pretends to be mortally ill with the help of his servant Mosca.

q2.quetsion_text: Volpone was created by this Elizabethan playwright also known for The Alchemist and Bartholomew Fair.

q3.quetsion_text: Volpone is also served by a dwarf, a eunuch, and a person of this type. This person is said to be a reincarnation of Pythagoras and a mule, among other things.

lead_in: This politician was the youngest MP during the Narvik debate and was called an "utterly contemptible little shit" by the government whip for voting against Chamberlain. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this politician who spent the last forty years of his life cleaning toilets for the Toynbee Hall charity in London's East End. Stephen Ward was arguably convicted as a scapegoat for this politician.

q2.quetsion_text: The Profumo affair plus a misdiagnosis of cancer prompted this British Prime Minister to resign in October 1963 in favour of Alec Douglas-Home, who promptly lost the 1964 election to Harold Wilson.
q2.raw_answer: Maurice Harold MacMillan, 1st Earl of Stockton

q3.quetsion_text: Profumo and MacMillan were both members of this British political party that also included Bonar Law, Disraeli, Churchill, and Thatcher. It has historically opposed the Liberal and Labour Parties.
q3.raw_answer: Conservative and Unionist Party [or Tory Party; or Tories]

lead_in: If this is your first quizbowl tournament ever, you will soon learn that this painting features a billboard advertising Phillies cigars for five cents.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this painting of a nighttime scene with four people sitting in a cafÃ©.

q2.quetsion_text: Nighthawks is a painting by this artist, who also painted Chop Suey and Early Sunday Morning.

q3.quetsion_text: This other Hopper painting shows a lone man working on a fuel pump near a desolate road; above him and to his right is a sign advertising Mobil.

lead_in: The Bloom filter can check the correctness of one of these and yields a result of either "definitely not in the set" or "possibly in the set". For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these mappings of variable-length data to fixed-length data, used to encrypt passwords. They can be stored in namesake tables.

q2.quetsion_text: Hashing collisions, when multiple inputs yield the same hash value, results from this mathematical principle. If you have more birds than boxes, this tells you that some birds are going to be crammed into the same box.

q3.quetsion_text: One hash collision exploit takes advantage of the high likelihood of many users to have the same one of these things. There is over a 50 percent chance that two among 23 people will share one due to the pigeonhole principle.
q3.raw_answer: birthday [accept birthday problem; accept birthday paradox

lead_in: Many composers were inspired to write their music by our avian friends. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: The pentatonic scale features prominently in the solo violin part in this Ralph Vaughan Williams work, whose extensive cadenzas represent a certain bird.

q2.quetsion_text: A flute trill represents the call of a nightingale in this Beethoven symphony, which also features an oboe call representing a quail in its second movement "By the brook."
q2.raw_answer: Pastoral Symphony [accept Symphony No. 6 and equivalents]

q3.quetsion_text: Beethoven's Pastoral Symphony also uses this instrument to represent the two-note call of a cuckoo. It is a single reed woodwind instrument.

lead_in: Identify the following about an incident in the life of the Sumerian sage Adapa, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: Adapa got himself in trouble with Anu for breaking the wing of a god of these things. In Greek  mythology, the West one of these things is personified by Zephyrus, and they are governed by Aeolus.
q1.raw_answer: wind god [or South wind; or anemoi]

q2.quetsion_text: Ea told his son Adapa to never eat the food of the gods and gave him advice on how to pass this  guard of the heavenly gates. This husband of Ishtar was forced to remain in the underworld for six  months each year.

q3.quetsion_text: Adapa unfortunately followed Ea's advice and refused Anu's offer of food and drink, which would  have done this to him. Athena refused to perform this action on Tydeus after the latter ate the brains of  Melanippus.
q3.raw_answer: making him immortal [or logical equivalents; accept making him into a god or equivalents]

lead_in: This test sorts people into categories such as thinking or feeling. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this personality indicator test, whose uses in society are advocated by the Center for Application of Psychological Type.

q2.quetsion_text: The Myers-Briggs test is based on the theories of this psychiatrist, the founder of analytical psychology, who also proposed such ideas as "archetypes" and the "collective unconscious."

q3.quetsion_text: Jung proposed this concept, in which events that appear to be causally unrelated are observed to act together in a meaningful manner. An example is hearing about a golden scarab and then immediately spotting an insect that resembles the scarab.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this German artist of Landscape with a Footbridge, whose most famous work was commissioned by Duke William IV.

q2.quetsion_text: Duke William IV commissioned The Battle of Issus, which depicts this leader defeating the Persians led by Darius III.
q2.raw_answer: Alexander the Great [or Alexander III of Macedon]

q3.quetsion_text: Altdorfer also made a version of this scene, which is depicted on the central panel of the MÃ©rode Altarpiece. Other famous versions of this scene include one by Fra Angelico and the Cestello one by Botticelli.
q3.raw_answer: Annunciation to the Blessed Virgin Mary

lead_in: The formulator of this thought experiment used the claim that syntax itself is not sufficient for semantics to conclude that "programs are neither constitutive of nor sufficient for minds". For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this thought experiment in which a man using a manual for manipulating a set of symbols can conduct a conversation despite not understanding any of its meaning. It was proposed by John Searle.

q2.quetsion_text: Searle defined the idea that a computer could be programmed to meaningfully understand dialog as the "strong" form of this concept, which can be described as the ability of machines to think.

q3.quetsion_text: Searle's argument claims that a machine like the Chinese room could pass this test that compares computer and human responses in a conversation. It is named for the British computer scientist who described it.

lead_in: This piece opens with solo flute playing BÂ–G sharpÂ–F sharpÂ–EÂ–F sharpÂ–G sharp, a motif immediately quoted by the oboe.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this first of four movements in the suite it appears, meant to depict the rising sun of a Moroccan desert.

q2.quetsion_text: "Morning Mood" begins this suite, incidental music for a play by Henrik Ibsen. Its title character escapes the Hall of the Mountain King in a movement that opens with the low strings playing pizzicato.

q3.quetsion_text: This Norwegian composer of Peer Gynt transcribed his Holberg Suite for string orchestra. "Arietta," "To Spring," and "Wedding Day at Troldhaugen" are among his sixty-six Lyric Pieces.

lead_in: This holiday begins on the 15th of Nisan, and preparation the night before involves the sacrifice of a goat. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this religious holiday that commemorates the liberation of the Israelites from slavery in Egypt.

q2.quetsion_text: Passover includes this feast in which four cups of wine and plenty of matzah are consumed.

q3.quetsion_text: Because the Israelites were in such a hurry to leave after being freed by the Pharaoh, they left before even their bread could leaven. Leavened foods are thus referred to by this Hebrew term, and are forbidden on Passover.

lead_in: This man founded the colony of Providence Plantations in 1636.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this proponent of religious tolerance and church-state separation, who was exiled from Salem for opposing the king's Massachusetts charter.

q2.quetsion_text: Williams' book A Key into the Language of America is based on material he gathered doing missionary work with this tribe, who sold him the land for Providence.

q3.quetsion_text: Williams' Bloody Tenent of Persecution is an attack on this Boston clergyman and leading theologian, who attempted to impose religious uniformity in Massachusetts Bay. This man supported orthodox Puritanism in the Antinomian Controversy.

lead_in: In phosphorus, these entities include red, black, and highly flammable white forms.

q1.quetsion_text: Give this term for different structural forms that an element can take. Those of oxygen include diatomic oxygen and ozone.

q2.quetsion_text: This soft allotrope of carbon consists of layered sheets of carbon arranged in a honeycomb lattice. It is used to make pencil lead.

q3.quetsion_text: Allotropy is related to this term, the general ability for a solid material to assume multiple alternate forms or crystal structures.

lead_in: Answer some questions about Young's double-slit experiment,

q1.quetsion_text: Young's double-slit experiment showed that these particles have wave properties, since they form an interference pattern of alternating fringes on the film.

q2.quetsion_text: In the far field, the angular spacing of the fringes is approximately equal to the wavelength of the light divided by this other quantity.
q2.raw_answer: the distance between the slits [accept reasonable equivalents]

q3.quetsion_text: In this modification of the double-slit experiment, the slit through which each photon passes is recorded, which destroys the interference pattern. Then, when the path information is destroyed, the interference pattern returns.

lead_in: This behavior is reliant on the PGM1 gene in Arabidopsis, and it is mediated by starch accumulation in plastids. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this behavior exhibited by plant roots, in which they instinctively grow downward.

q2.quetsion_text: Root growth occurs in the apical part of this tissue, which contains the quiescent center. The intercalary type of this tissue only exists in monocots, and in general this type of tissue contains undifferentiated tissue that can divide.

q3.quetsion_text: One method of studying gravitropism is to impregnate one of these objects containing calcium and attaching it to the side of a root. Auxins were originally discovered when they leached into these objects.

lead_in: The title figure of this painting is depicted bent over, with his eyes wide open in the moment of realization.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this painting where the title figure sticks his dirty right index finger into the open wound of another figure.
q1.raw_answer: The Incredulity of St. Thomas [or Doubting Thomas or anything mentioning Thomas and some uncertainty]

q2.quetsion_text: The Incredulity of Thomas was painted by this Baroque Italian artist whose other religious scenes include the Supper at Emmaus where a disciple holds out his arms, and The Calling of St. Matthew.

q3.quetsion_text: The balding antagonist of this other religious scene by Caravaggio interlaces his fingers with the title figure and brings his mouth extremely close to the title figure's face. A solider in black armor with his back to the viewer mostly obscures a man holding up a lantern on the right of this canvas.
q3.raw_answer: The Betrayal of Christ [or The Taking of Christ or Cattura di Cristo]

lead_in: Answer some questions about women who have their own Old Testament books, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This woman married the Persian king in order to stop a plot to kill the Jews. Her namesake book forms the basis for the holiday Purim.

q2.quetsion_text: This woman set the precedent for conversion and familial piety in her namesake book by telling her mother-in-law that "your people shall be my people, and your God shall be my God".

q3.quetsion_text: Ruth was formerly a resident of this land before marrying Boaz. Namesake residents of this region east of the Dead Sea and south of Ammon were rivals with the Israelites.

lead_in: In 2002, NYU became the first private university to recognize a labor union representing these type of people.

lead_in: This text was compiled in the Gurmukhi script by Guru Arjan. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this book that is divided into numerous shabad, the first of which is a "chief verse" called the Mul Mantar. This text is regarded as the current and eternal Guru, after the ten human Gurus that preceded it.
