lead_in: Satisfy Patrick Liao's royalist obsessions by answering the following about the Order of the Garter,

q1.quetsion_text: This New Zealander was made a member of the order in 1995, 42 years after he and Sherpa Tenzing Norgay became the first climbers to reach the summit of Mount Everest.

q2.quetsion_text: The Order's motto is this six-word Anglo-Norman French phrase, which translates as "Shame be to him who thinks evil of it."

q3.quetsion_text: The Order's investiture ceremony takes place at Windsor Castle on the Monday of the week dedicated to the "Royal" series of thoroughbred races at this racecourse, which is located in a namesake village in Berkshire.

lead_in: The Guangdong Coalition was formed to fight this man's Xiliang Army. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this man who deposed Emperor Shao for Emperor Lian and moved the capital from Luoyang to Chang'an. He was killed after Wang Yun ostracized him from his adopted son, Lu Bu.
q1.raw_answer: Dong Zhuo [or Dong Zhongying; or Dong Zei]

q2.quetsion_text: Dong Zhuo came to power after being asked by Yuan Shao and He Jin to fight the Ten Attendants, a group of these powerful court officials. Sima Qian and Zheng He were both forcibly turned into this type of official.
q2.raw_answer: eunuchs [or huan guan; prompt on answers mentioning "castration" and equivalents; prompt on "chang shi"]

q3.quetsion_text: Dong Zhuo's tyranny led to the decline of this dynasty and the advent of the Three Kingdoms, when it was controlled by the state of Cao Wei. This dynasty shares its name with China's largest ethnic group.
q3.raw_answer: Han dynasty [or Han Chao; or Da Han]

lead_in: This term comes from Tungusic languages, and Mircea Eliade wrote a book about this belief system as  an "archaic technique of ecstasy." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Give this term referring to the use of trances or other methods to communicate with spirits for  purposes like healing. Its practitioners include curanderos in Latin America and noaidi among the Sami.
q1.raw_answer: shamanism [prompt on "medicine men" or similar answers]

q2.quetsion_text: The religion of these peoples includes shamans called angakkuq. Their mythology includes creatures  like the qalupalik that steal away bad children, as well as gods like Anguta and Sedna.

q3.quetsion_text: This people's religion includes black, white, and yellow forms of shamanism that are defined based  on their incorporation of Buddhist practices. They also worship numerous gods called tengri.

lead_in: The Big Bend National Park is named for the arc that this river cuts during its journey into the Gulf of Mexico.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this river that defines the border between Texas and four Mexican states.
q1.raw_answer: the Rio Grande [or the RÃ­o Bravo del Norte]

q2.quetsion_text: A series of killings termed feminicidio have taken place in this city on the Rio Grande, which is home to hundreds of maquiladoras. The Bridge of the Americas connects it to El Paso.
q2.raw_answer: Ciudad Juarez [or Paso del Norte; or Juarez City; prompt on "Juarez"]

q3.quetsion_text: This city near the mouth of the Rio Grande lies across it from the Mexican city of Matamoros. In 1906, 167 African-American soldiers stationed near this city were dishonorably discharged after they were falsely accused of a pair of shootings.

lead_in: Jonathan Larson's Rent won this prize in 1996.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this annual prize that has been won thrice by Edward Albee. It is frequently given to musicals and operas, but more commonly to plays, such as Long Day's Journey into Night.

q2.quetsion_text: Tracy Letts won a Pulitzer for this play about the Weston Family in Oklahoma; the disappearance of Beverly Weston catalyzes much of this play's action.

q3.quetsion_text: In this William Inge play, Hal accompanies Millie to the title event on Labor Day, though he is much more attracted to Madge.

lead_in: A loss for troops under the Duc de Villeroi and Maximilian Emmanuel II of Bavaria, this battle was fought between Taviers and the Belgian town for which it is named.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this battle, after which most of Belgium fell under the control of the Grand Alliance.

q2.quetsion_text: The Battle of Ramillies was won by this English general. Blenheim Palace was built to honor one of this man's victories that he won while commanding forces alongside Eugene of Savoy.
q2.raw_answer: John Churchill, 1st Duke of Marlborough [accept either underlined part]

q3.quetsion_text: Blenheim and Ramillies were both battles during this conflict, which was fought over Louis XIV's attempt to put his grandson on the throne of a southern neighbor.

lead_in: This person sits high atop a chariot in the final painting of a series in the Ducal Palace of Mantua. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this military leader whose standard bearers, vase bearers, captives, and musicians also figure into that Mantegna series about his Triumphs.

q2.quetsion_text: This other painter created a head of Julius Caesar as a study for a Tribute to the Roman. This "faultless painter," whose name means "son of a tailor," depicted the Madonna and child standing atop a pedestal decorated with harpies.

q3.quetsion_text: In 1524, Del Sarto fled Florence and took refuge from the plague in a Camaldolese convent. He thanked the church by painting them one of these scenes of Mary cradling the dead Jesus.

lead_in: After seeing his Russian captors use the schoty version of this device, Jean-Victor Poncelet reintroduced it to Western Europe. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this device that gave its name to a namesake group that opposed the efforts of algorists. The Russian schoty used horizontal wires, but East Asian versions like the Chinese suanpan used vertical ones.
q1.raw_answer: abacus [or counting frame; prompt on foreign language equivalents such as "schoty" or "suanpan" or "soroban" or "jupan" or "supan" or "jusan" or "nepohualtzintzin"]

q2.quetsion_text: The abacists spread of these mathematical symbols to Europe. Leonardo Fibonacci argued that they were better for commerce and calculations than Roman numerals in his Liber Abaci.

q3.quetsion_text: Algorists derived their methods from this Abbasid mathematician, who edited Ptolemy's Geography and wrote The Compendious Book on Calculation by Completion and Balancing.
q3.raw_answer: Abu Abdallah Muhammad ibn Musa al-Khwarizmi [or Algoritmi; or Algaurizin; do not accept answers with "Jafar"]

lead_in: Answer the following about the prophecies of Calchas ("KAHL-kahs"), for 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Calchas told this commander of Greek forces to sacrifice his daughter Iphigenia before setting sail for Troy. After the war, he was murdered by his wife Clytemnestra.

q2.quetsion_text: Calchas recommended interrogating Helenus, who revealed that the Achaeans would need the bones of this figure to take Troy. He was given an ivory shoulder blade after his father Tantalus cut him up for the gods.

lead_in: A Tartar prince who is given an enormous sturgeon, and two lovers who perish by murder and fire are the subject of this author's short story collection that eschews character names, Almost No Memory.

lead_in: The first component of this two-part work is a refutation of John Filmer's Patriarcha and the divine right of kings.

lead_in: In March 2014, three members of Congress wrote a letter to this company asking why one of its best selling drugs costs so much.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this biotech company which produces Sovaldi, a drug whose full treatment costs around eighty thousand dollars.

lead_in: Including foams and aerosols, they are classified based on the phases of the dispersed phase and continuous medium. For 10 points each:

lead_in: The Orange Alternative, a protest movement associated with this group, engaged in antics such as  singing odes to Stalin in front of a chimpanzee cage. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this trade union begun in 1980 at the Lenin Shipyards by electrician Lech Walesa.

lead_in: This man's curly hair is rendered with a hard pencil, while the distinction in material between his jacket and his shirt collar owes to the different hardness of the pencil used.

q1.quetsion_text: Bribes can prevent politicians from dealing with these problems. Remedying these problems efficiently involves bringing marginal social costs in line with marginal private costs.

q1.quetsion_text: In this type of microscopy, an image with a topological, 3-dimensional quality is generated. This form of electron microscopy uses backscattered electrons, unlike transmission EM.

lead_in: This country is home to Mount Kinabalu. For 10 points each:

q3.quetsion_text: A namesake strait separates this Malaysian state from Singapore. The southernmost state of the peninsular portion of Malaysia, it corresponds to a former sultanate of the same name.

lead_in: You should avoid feeding your 10 month-old brother honey since it may contain the toxin responsible for this disease.

q2.quetsion_text: The botulinum toxin is produced by organisms belonging to this genus of anaerobic, gram-positive bacteria, which also includes the causative agent of tetanus.

q3.quetsion_text: The mechanism of action of both botulinum and tetanus toxins involves the inactivation of synaptobrevin, one type of these proteins, to prevent neurotransmitter release. This family of proteins mediates vesicle fusion with the plasma membrane.

q3.quetsion_text: Warm air rises from the doldrums and falls at the horse latitudes to create the subtropical type of these air currents. They flow from west to east and dramatically influence flight times.

q3.quetsion_text: This Russian general failed to reach Ulm in time to help the Austrian forces. He fought against Napoleon at Austerlitz and again during the French invasion of Russia.

lead_in: Answer these questions about the ways in which Vikings governed their territory after settling down from raiding, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This Icelandic deliberative body, the world's oldest still-extant parliament, was established by Norse settlers in the 900s CE to resolve disputes.

lead_in: Bruno Bauer accused this man's dialectic of being drawn from Friedrich Schleiermacher, not Hegel, leading this philosopher to establish a difference between Right Hegelians and Left Hegelians.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this German materialist theologian who interpreted New Testament stories as mythical in The Life of Jesus. His On Christian Doctrine interpreted Christianity as deteriorating.

lead_in: Works in this branch of philosophy include Immanuel Kant's Critique of Judgment, which spends its second half discussing the teleology of beautiful objects.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this branch of philosophy concerned with art and beauty.

q2.quetsion_text: In the 18th century, the aesthetic "quarrel" named for these two groups was the subject of much debate in the French Academy. The quarrel basically asks whether antiquated or progressive notions of beauty are more correct.
q2.raw_answer: Quarrel between the Ancients and Moderns [need both underlined components; accept Querelle des Anciens et des Modernes]

q3.quetsion_text: Immanuel Kant also wrote a work that distinguishes the enjoyment derived from beauty with the enjoyment derived from this other feeling, which is a mixture of awe and horror. Looking at a waterfall, or the night sky induces this feeling, according to Kant.

lead_in: Eight rooms in this man's Hanover apartment were used to create a mixed media work dedicated to the memory of the city of Molde.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this artist fond of creating works of art in "new forms", including the aforementioned Merzbau .

lead_in: This essay opens with a brief overview of the approach to science taken by such figures as Bacon, Kepler, and Darwin.

q3.quetsion_text: The physicist Kerner is a defector and double agent in this Tom Stoppard play in which the title spymaster must figure out if Ridley is a traitor.

lead_in: Wildfires, landslides, and other types of massive environmental damage often lead to these ecological phenomena. For 10 points each:

lead_in: He drew on Arthur Schoenberg's pan-atonality to distinguish melodic and symphonic composition. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Russian-born Expressionist artist of The Blue Rider who painted numerous abstract Compositions and Improvisations.

q3.quetsion_text: Kandinsky fled to France after the Nazis closed Bauhaus and classified his work as this type. This type of art was destroyed after a contemptuous 1937 exhibition by Nazi Germany.

q3.quetsion_text: Yang-Mills theory can be quantized using this physicist's path integral formulation of quantum mechanics. He also proposed the parton model.

lead_in: Bonus: Answer some questions about Venetian artists, for ten points each:

lead_in: Because her husband was blind, this queen blindfolded herself as well. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this queen, who gave birth to a lump of flesh, the hundred pieces of which developed into the hundred Kaurava brothers.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this drama in which Don Rodrigue and Chimene are members of quarrelling families. Rodrigue avenges his father Diegue by killing Gormas, but spares Chimene's champion. They ultimately marry and Rodrigue sets off to become the titular character.

q3.quetsion_text: Pierre Corneille's Le Cid was criticized for not following this convention, which states that plays should have one main action, should be set in a single place, and should take place over the course of less than a day. They are sometimes named for Aristotle, who outlined them in Poetics.

lead_in: Bonus: The isogonal conjugate of this point is the circumcenter. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this point that is the intersection of the three altitudes in a triangle. It is found inside the triangle if and only if the triangle is acute.

q2.quetsion_text: The orthocenter, circumcenter, and centroid all lie on this line that also passes through the center of the nine point circle. Points on the line may be parameterized as the cyclic sum “cos[A] plus t times cos[B] times cos[C].”

q3.quetsion_text: The Euler line cannot be found for this type of triangle because its orthocenter, circumcenter, and centroid all lie at the same point. This type of triangle has three equal sides.

lead_in: This mathematician humiliated Adriaan van Roomen in a math contest so much that van Roomen rode to this man's home to beg him to become his teacher. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this 16th century mathematician and French minister. This developer of new algebra was the first to represent known and unknown quantities in equations with letters. He was also an adept codebreaker.
q1.raw_answer: Franciscus Vieta [or FranÃ§ois ViÃ¨te; or Fransisci Vietae]

q2.quetsion_text: Vieta broke a difficult cipher of this Spanish king, who then complained of French black magic to Pope Sixtus V, who designated one of the disastrous expeditions of this five times bankrupt king a crusade.

q3.quetsion_text: During the French Wars of Religion, Philip II tried to use the Catholic League install one of his daughters over this Huguenot king of Navarre, who eventually converted and issued the Edict of Nantes.

lead_in: Name the following Jewish holidays.

q1.raw_answer: Hanukkah [or Chanukah; or Festival of Lights; or Feast of Dedication]

q2.quetsion_text: This holiday is celebrated on the fourteenth day of Adar and commemorates an event in which Esther and Mordecai foiled Haman's plot to kill the Jews.

q3.quetsion_text: This seven-day holiday starts five days after Yom Kippur and concludes with the Hoshana Rabbah. Jews celebrate the huts inhabited by the Israelites during the Exodus by spending time in wooden booths.
q3.raw_answer: Sukkot [or Sukkos; or Feast of Tabernacles]

lead_in: The last tempter in this work urges the main character to become a martyr and affect change through his fame, after which the protagonist preaches to the congregation on Christmas morning.

lead_in: This composer announced that his "Russian" string quartets, Opus 33, were written in a "new and  completely special way." For 10 points each:

lead_in: A fade-out effect in this movement was achieved by placing several performers in an adjoining room, the door to which was carefully closed during the last bar. For 10 points each:

lead_in: This pope initiated the "Babylonian Captivity" by moving the papal curia from Rome to Avignon. For 10 points each:

lead_in: This man's work allowed him to divide the Chinese world into nine provinces. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this man, who devised a system of controls that allowed Chinese agriculture to flourish. He left home to control the waters four days into his marriage and labored for thirteen years without returning home.
q1.raw_answer: Da Yu [or Yu the Great; or obvious equivalents mentioning Yu]

q2.quetsion_text: Unlike his father, Da Yu was able to control this event that lasted two generations by dredging the Yellow River riverbeds, and enlisted the help of mythical creatures such as mud-dragging tortoises and channel-digging dragons.

q3.quetsion_text: Da Yu established this dynasty, initially set up under the Abdication system, after he received the throne from the last of the Five Emperors. The concrete existence of this dynasty has yet to be proven by archaeological data.

lead_in: Bonus: Leon Foucault used one of these devices to demonstrate the rotation of the earth. For ten points each,

q1.quetsion_text: Name these objects consisting of a bob attached to a pivot that can swing freely under the influence of gravity.

lead_in: Evaluating the Riemann Zeta function at 4 yields this value raised to the fourth power divided by 90.

q2.quetsion_text: Pi is not algebraic, so it is one of these numbers, which means it is not the root of any polynomial with rational coefficients.

lead_in: This author recounts how Croesus was warned "If you attack you will destroy a great empire."

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Greek Historian and so-called "Father of History," whose 10-volume The Histories is the primary source of information on the Persian Wars.

lead_in: A poem in this collection by Ariwara no Narihira is noted for its use of the pillow word "chihayaburu" to connote ephemerality.

lead_in: Identify the following about the various times Ares got humiliated, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: Ares left Troy and went back to Olympus to whine to Zeus after he got stabbed in the stomach by  this Greek soldier. This man also crushed the hip of Aeneas and wounded the hand of Aphrodite.

q2.quetsion_text: These two giants, the sons of Iphimedia and Poseidon, trapped Ares in a bronze jar for thirteen  months. They also planned to reach Olympus by piling Mount Helion on top of Mount Ossa, but died  before that happened.

q3.quetsion_text: This lame god trapped Ares in bed with his wife Aphrodite, after which all the gods laughed at  them. This god was thrown out of Olympus by Hera because she found him too ugly.

lead_in: Answer the following about sculptors who created more abstract works,

q1.quetsion_text: This sculptor created a work showing two block-like people embracing in The Kiss, and he also created a series of works emphasizing the motion of the title avian in Bird in Space.

q2.quetsion_text: This sculptor's somewhat abstract representations of human figures include Two Large Forms and Draped Seated Woman.

q3.quetsion_text: Umberto Boccioni was a member of this art movement, which was exemplified by his works like Spiral Expansion of Muscles in Action. Filippo Marinetti wrote this movement's manifesto.

lead_in: This process uses an iridium catalyst to decrease side products secondary to the water gas shift reaction. For 10 points each:

q2.quetsion_text: Along with the Monsanto process, the Cativa process produces this compound. This compound has a "trifluoro" derivative that is used as an ion-pairing agent in HPLC.

q3.quetsion_text: The Monsanto process uses a catalyst made up of this transition metal. This metal is found attached to three arylphosphine ligands in Wilkinson's catalyst, and it is combined with platinum to catalyze the production of nitric acid in the Ostwald process.

lead_in: Answer the following about mythological thunder,

q1.quetsion_text: This Norse god's name is etymologically related to older terms for thunder. More excitingly, he wields the hammer Mjollnir and will kill the Midgard Serpent at RagnarÃ¶k but die after taking nine steps.

lead_in: This painting was published with an essay by Carlos Bulosan, which stated, "The America we hope to see is not merely a physical but also a spiritual and intellectual world."

q1.raw_answer: Freedom from Want [prompt on Four Freedoms]

q2.quetsion_text: Freedom from Want was part of the Four Freedoms series painted by this man, a frequent contributor to the Saturday Evening Post magazine.

q3.quetsion_text: In 1967, Rockwell painted a room in a Russian example of these institutions. In his painting The Problem We All Live With, the black girl Ruby Bridges is walking to one of these places.

lead_in: Bonus: A period of the same name in China ended with the establishment of the Qin Dynasty. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this time of unrest in Japanese history that began with the Onin War. It resulted in the destruction of Kyoto, the capital of the ruling Ashikaga Shogunate.

q2.quetsion_text: The Warring States Period ended with the rise of this last Japanese shogunate, which moved the capital to Edo and eventually gave way to the Meiji Restoration.

lead_in: One particularly amusing way to use this result is to measure a dead body's temperature, then do so again a few hours later, in order to figure out how long it's been dead.

lead_in: The Hawar Islands are one group of disputed islands in this body of water.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this body of water that is connected by the Strait of Hormuz to the Gulf of Oman and is located to the southwest of Iran.

q2.quetsion_text: This small island nation in the Persian Gulf with capital Manama claims the Hawar Islands, although the islands are closer to Qatar. This nation is ruled by the House of Khalifa.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Harvard philosopher. In "The Meaning of 'Meaning'," this man posited a world where all water is replaced by the chemical XYZ, called Twin Earth.

q3.quetsion_text: This German thinker tried to turn math into logic in his Foundations of Arithmetic. He examined the sentence 'Hesperus is Phosphorus,' in which both names refer to Venus, in "Sense and Reference."

lead_in: This ruler's "hell" was a torture chamber that was designed to look like a beautiful palace from the outside. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Mauryan emperor who converted to Buddhism after witnessing the bloody Kalinga war.

q2.quetsion_text: Ashoka's son Mahinda became a monk and brought Buddhism to this island. This island was dubbed "Ceylon" by the English and has more recently been home to the Tamil Tigers terrorist group.

q3.quetsion_text: This other Indian empire imitated Ashoka's sandstone pillars by constructing the iron pillar of Delhi. Kalidasa lived during this empire, which was eventually overrun by White Huns.

lead_in: This man said that the glory of his state was made by the bravery of the war dead.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Athenian statesman who led the city-state during the Peloponnesian War, during which he delivered a difficult-to-translate funeral oration and died of plague.

q2.quetsion_text: Pericles' funeral oration was recorded by this man in his History of the Peloponnesian War, although that text may have been a combination of two orations, one delivered earlier during the Samian War.

q3.quetsion_text: Thucydides also chronicled a dialogue between envoys of Athens and this city-state, in which Athens demands that this city join the Delian League, saying, "The strong do as they can and the weak suffer what they must."

lead_in: These artworks usually depict a circle within a square with four "gates." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these artworks of Hinduism and Buddhism. As a form of meditation, Tibetan Buddhist monks create these out of sand over the course of many days or weeks, and then destroy them as soon as they are finished.

q2.quetsion_text: This good luck symbol often shows up in Hindu and Buddhist art. Unfortunately, this symbol is more recognizable in reverse from its appearances as an emblem of Nazi Germany.

q3.quetsion_text: This Indonesian island is the site of the enormous Hindu and Buddhist temples Prambanan and Borobudur, both of which are over a thousand years old.

lead_in: Identify the following data structures from computer science,

q1.quetsion_text: This data structure is commonly used as a data buffer because the oldest entry is removed from it first. In other words, it is first-in first-out.

q2.quetsion_text: This self-balancing binary search tree is often compared to the AVL tree, but has a faster real-time bounded worst case performance for insertion and deletion. It's unique for including a color attribute for leafs.

q3.quetsion_text: These bitmaps give a probabilistic representation of a set that supports membership queries. They do not allow false negatives, but false positives can occur if the hash function it uses is not well-spread.

lead_in: In March 2010, this group collected ten milliliters of blood from volunteers and symbolically poured it out at the Government House. For 10 points each:
