lead_in: A superscript h can be used in International Phonetic Alphabet to denote these consonants.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify these consonants, whose utterance is accompanied by a burst of air, such as in pill but not in bill.

q2.quetsion_text: This law states that for some languages derived from Proto-Indo-European, like Sanskrit, when two syllables both had aspirated consonants, only the second one remained aspirated.

q3.quetsion_text: Grassmann's Law also applies to this language, whose Koine form was used in the Hellenistic Era to write books like the Septuagint.

lead_in: Well-run quizbowl tournaments use buzzers. This is a well-run quizbowl tournament, therefore it must have used buzzers.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this argument form which can also be stated as "If P implies Q and P is true, then Q must be true". It has a Latin name.

q2.quetsion_text: Modus ponens forms a basis for this type of logic which uses variables as quantifiers, such as "almost all" or "at least one".
q2.raw_answer: first-order logic [or predicate logic; accept the word "calculus" in place of logic; prompt on "quantification theory"]

q3.quetsion_text: The process of removing quantifiers from a statement is named for this Norwegian, who also names a theorem with Lowenheim which states that you can always produce a countable model from a countable first-order theory.

lead_in: Bonus: Bartolomeu Dias rounded the Cape of Good Hope nine years before his first voyage. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this Portuguese explorer who became the first European to reach India by sea, stopping in east African cities like Malindi and Mombasa along the way.

q2.quetsion_text: Almost a century before da Gama’s journey, this Ming dynasty eunuch led several expeditions to east Africa. The giraffe that he brought back to China from Malindi was widely regarded as a mythical creature called qilin.

q3.quetsion_text: Malindi and Mombasa were a part of this historic region of east Africa, which was inhabited by its namesake Bantu ethnic group and saw a mix of Arab and African cultures.

lead_in: This concept argues that individual self-interest in the economy benefits society overall. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this metaphor used by a Scottish economist to describe the self-regulation of a free market.

q2.quetsion_text: This economist posited the idea of the "invisible hand" in his works The Theory of Moral Sentiments and The Wealth of Nations.

q3.quetsion_text: One critic of the "invisible hand" is this economist, who examined America's inequity in The Price of Inequality, and attacked the global economy in Globalization and Its Discontents.

lead_in: This building is explicitly noted to be hemmed in by "desolate marshes and treacherous swamps," creating a set list of potential murderers.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this country estate served by the maid Mrs. Drudge, where Major Magnus and others try to find out who caused a corpse to appear on the floor.

q2.quetsion_text: Muldoon Manor is the setting for the play-within-the-play in this Tom Stoppard comedy, in which Birdboot and Moon become involved in the mystery farce they are reviewing.

q3.quetsion_text: Muldoon Manor is a parody of Monkswell Manor, the location of this archetypal British stage mystery, which hit its 25,000th performance in 2012.

lead_in: Two kings of West Francia belonged to the Robertian branch of the family that produced this dynasty. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this dynasty whose direct line was ended with the death of Philip the Fair. Less famous cadet branches of this house include the House of Artois.
q1.raw_answer: Direct Capetian Dynasty [or House of Capet; or the Capets; or Les CapÃ©tiens; or la Maison capÃ©tien; prompt on the "House of France" or "la maison de France"]

q2.quetsion_text: This first king of West Francia from the House of Capet was the older brother of Robert I. He succeeded his inept predecessor Charles the Fat.
q2.raw_answer: Odo of France [or Eudes of France]

q3.quetsion_text: Odo established the Capetian dynasty as counts of this city, which he had earlier defended from Viking raiders under Rollo. With the exception of Vichy, it's been the capital ever since.

lead_in: Many species which give a negative result for this test have endotoxins in their cell membranes. For 10  points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this stain test which classifies bacteria by how well they retain the dye crystal violet.

q2.quetsion_text: When performing a Gram stain, a solution containing this element is added to the cells after  applying crystal violet dye. This element helps a bacterial cell retain the crystal violet dye by binding to  it.

q3.quetsion_text: Gram-negative bacteria have a thin cell wall composed of this protein-carbohydrate polymer, while  it is thicker in Gram-positive bacteria. Beta-lactam antibiotics like penicillin work by inhibiting the  synthesis of this polymer.

lead_in: Answer the following about British labour politician Ernest Bevin,

q1.quetsion_text: The "Bevin Boys" were men drafted to serve in this industry during World War II. A later strike in this industry was led by Arthur Scargill of the NUM and opposed by Margaret Thatcher.

q2.quetsion_text: This politician tried to replace Clement Atlee with Bevin, but he is better known for promising Gandhi that India would be given Dominion Status after the war while leading his namesake 1942 mission.

q3.quetsion_text: Ernest Bevin shouldn't be confused with Aneurin Bevan, a Minister of Health who oversaw the implementation of this document. This document proposed the creation of social welfare to address the "Five Giant Evils."
q3.raw_answer: Beveridge Report [or Report on Social Insurance and Allied Services]

lead_in: The isothermal titration variety of these devices is used to analyze ligand binding, while its differential scanning type gives a heat flux vs temperature curve. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these devices which measure the heat change of a reaction. A simple example can be made from a coffee cup.

q2.quetsion_text: ITC can be used to show whether ligand binding follows this model. In this kind of binding, which is common between an enzyme and a substrate and opposes the lock-and-key model, the binding site changes confirmation slightly to accommodate the ligand.

q3.quetsion_text: Another technique for understanding protein-protein binding measures the conformational change of proteins attached to the surface of a waveguide by using the evanescent wave of a laser.
q3.raw_answer: dual polarization interferometry [or DPI; prompt on partial answers]

lead_in: After the creation of this company, citizens donated items such as pigs and jewelry to help pay off foreign debts. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Mexican company created via the nationalization of foreign companies under LÃ¡zaro CÃ¡rdenas. Its founding in 1938 is commemorated by a national holiday.

q2.quetsion_text: Another Mexican national holiday celebrates the birth of this Zapotec-born politician, who led liberal forces in the Reform War and ordered the execution of Maximilian I.

q3.quetsion_text: This country nationalized its oil industry after its 1979 Islamic revolution created a theocracy ruled by Ayatollah Khomeini from Tehran.
q3.raw_answer: Iran [or Islamic Republic of Iran; or Jomhuriye Islamiye Iran]

lead_in: Identify the following about ships in Ancient Greece,

q1.quetsion_text: The name of these quick ships comes from the fact that they were powered by three levels of oarsmen, who generally tried to ram other ships with these ships' bronze rams.

q2.quetsion_text: Both the trireme and the bireme were improvements on this older Greek warship and merchant vessel. Its name comes from the fifty oarsmen who manned it from a single level.

q3.quetsion_text: The Romans started using ships called liburians during these conflicts with the namesake Balkan pirates. The namesake people in these conflicts were the western neighbors of the Thracians, and Queen Teuta led them during the first of these wars.

lead_in: Bonus: Identify some classes of religious leaders in Islam, for ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: This title is given to rulers of ummah, or Islamic communities, and means “successor” or “representative.” The four rightly-guided ones of these people were Abu Bakr, Umar, Uthman, and Ali.

q2.quetsion_text: Sunni Muslims give this title to worship leaders of mosques. Twelver Muslims believe there were twelve of these people, the last of whom is a messianic figure known as the Mahdi.

q3.quetsion_text: This title is given to Sunni Muslim scholars who are experts in Islamic law and have the ability to issue fatwas. A “grand” version of this title is given to the highest ranking one of these people in a country.

lead_in: The protagonist of this work often recalls the songs and stories of a fellow slave named Macandal and travels to Cuba with Lenormand de Mezy.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this novel by Alejo Carpentier that follows the slave Ti-NoÃ«l's life during the Haitian Revolution.
q1.raw_answer: The Kingdom of This World [or El reino de este mundo]

q2.quetsion_text: In the prologue to The Kingdom of this World, Carpentier claimed that the existence of this style in Latin American fiction is natural, unlike surrealism in European literature. This style places fantastical events in mundane settings, and is exemplified by works like One Hundred Years of Solitude.
q2.raw_answer: magical realism [or marvelous realism or lo real maravilloso or realismo mÃ¡gico]

q3.quetsion_text: This Chilean author claimed that "magical realism reduces a much too complex situation and just makes it cute" in "Magical Neoliberalism." He co-edited the anthology McOndo with Sergio GÃ³mez.

lead_in: For 10 points each, name the following about the study of suicide.

q1.quetsion_text: The first sociological study of suicide was conducted by this French author of Rules of the Sociological Method. He studied differences in suicide rates between Catholic and Protestant communities.

q2.quetsion_text: This anxiety disorder is often comorbid with suicidality. Its symptoms include flashbacks, irritability, and hypervigilance. It occurs frequently among military personnel.

q3.quetsion_text: In this test, those at high risk for suicide exhibit delayed reaction time in naming the color of suicide-related words. Its classical formulation presents a conflict between word meaning and font color.

lead_in: The woodpecker and the wolf were sacred to this god, who received the sacrifices of the October Horse and the suovetaurilia.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this Roman god who fathered Romulus and Remus with Rhea Silvia. This war god was substantially more well-liked than his earlier Greek counterpart Ares had been in his time.

q2.quetsion_text: These "leaping priests" of Mars guarded the twelve sacred ancilia and performed a procession around the city every March.

q3.quetsion_text: The original ancile fell from the sky during the reign of this semi-legendary second King of Rome, who was advised by the nymph Egeria.

lead_in: Dan learned a lot about a specific Jewish holiday starring the great Israeli actor Shuli Rand. Name some stuff about what he learned.

q1.quetsion_text: In the film, Moshe Bellanga searches for a perfect type of this fruit from a citron tree. It makes up the Four Species with the lulav, hadass and aravah.

q2.quetsion_text: The Four Species are used to bless the booths during this holiday, which is coincidentally also known as the Festival of Booths. It is celebrated on the fifteenth day of Tishrei.
q2.raw_answer: Sukkot [accept Sukkoth; accept Sukkos; accept Feast of Tabernacles]

q3.quetsion_text: This film was named after this prayer that welcomes guests like Abraham and Moses to the booth.

lead_in: Like PI3-kinase, this class of kinases is inhibited by Perifosine. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this family of serine-threonine protein kinases, also known as protein kinase B. Its second member, which is cytosolic, is found in the insulin signalling pathway, where it indirectly activates mTOR

q2.quetsion_text: Insulin is released from the islet cells of this organ, which contains both endocrine and exocrine sections.

q3.quetsion_text: In the Islets of Langerhans' cells, ATP-gated channels of this ion are inhibited by sulfonylureas. Mutations in channels that conduct this ion can cause the "shaker" phenotype.

lead_in: This man's most famous work is divided into two major sections called "Pars Speculativa" and "Pars Activa," the latter of which describes the mathematical relationships behind musical intervals.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this Austrian baroque composer and music theorist who wrote the book Gradus ad Parnassum , as well as operas like the Colossal Baroque work Costanza e Fortezza.

q2.quetsion_text: Fux coined this term for strict contrapuntal exercises of five increasing degrees of complexity. The first one sets one note against each note in the cantus firmus, while higher ones allowed shorter notes and suspensions.

q3.quetsion_text: Gradus ad Parnassum codified the contrapuntal style of this Italian composer of the free-composed Missa Papae Marcellis, which supposedly convinced the Council of Trent not to ban polyphonic music.

lead_in: The heat capacity of a substance can be defined as the change in this quantity divided by the accompanying change in temperature.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this measure of the total energy of a system, calculated by summing the internal energy and the pressure on the system multiplied by its volume.

q2.quetsion_text: This quantity, the standard enthalpy of formation for an ionic compound, is found using the Born-Haber cycle, which calculates the enthalpy change caused by the combination of two elements into an ionic solid.

q3.quetsion_text: This quantity is the amount of energy required to remove one electron from an atom. The first type of this quantity increases as one moves to the right of a period because of increasing effective nuclear charge.

lead_in: The Gospel of Nicodemus says this man's name is "Dismas."

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this man who is not given a formal name in the New Testament. He asks his companion "have you no fear of God?" and then asks Jesus to remember him. Christ tells this person "I say to you today you will be with me in paradise."
q1.raw_answer: the penitent thief on the cross [or criminal or other descriptions]

q2.quetsion_text: The only mention of the thief's penitence comes in this synoptic Gospel, which is also the only place the stories of the Prodigal Son and the Good Samaritan appear.

q3.quetsion_text: Jesus tells this person at his crucifixion "Here is your mother." This person asks Jesus who will betray him and is mentioned by Peter at the end of the Gospel of John. This unnamed person is traditionally thought to be the author John himself.
q3.raw_answer: disciple whom Jesus loved [or close equivalents]

lead_in: The title character of this poem barely escapes over the River Doon as his pursuers, who he'd angered by shouting "Weel done, cutty-sark!", pull off his horse Meg's tail. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this poem about a man who gets drunk and interrupts a witches' sabbath at Alloway kirk. It also lends its name to a type of round cap.

q2.quetsion_text: "Tam o' Shanter" was written by this poet of "A Red, Red Rose" and "Auld Lang Syne", the national poet of Scotland.
q2.raw_answer: Robert Burns [or Rabbie Burns; or Robden of Solway Firth]

q3.quetsion_text: Burns laments "Oh, would some Power the giftie gie us, to see ourselves as others see us" in this poem, which describes a "crowlin ferlie" the speaker sees in a lady's bonnet.
q3.raw_answer: "To a Louse" [do not accept "To a Mouse"]

lead_in: Bonus: One of its characters prepares to die when he finds his servant has no more pain-killer. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this play in which Hamm is unable to stand and his servant Clov is unable to sit. Two characters in this work, Nagg and Nell, live in dustbins since they have no legs.

q2.quetsion_text: The author of Endgame also wrote this play, in which Lucky and Pozzo join a pair of vagrant men, Vladimir and Estragon, who expect the arrival of the title person.
q2.raw_answer: Waiting for Godot [or En attendant Godot]

q3.quetsion_text: This Irish author wrote the plays Endgame and Waiting for Godot.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this Cabinet post held by Earl Butz, which had earlier been held separately by father and son Henry C. and Henry A. Wallace.

q2.quetsion_text: Another Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson, served as the thirteenth president of this religious group, some of whose members carried out the Mountain Meadows Massacre after moving to the Utah Territory.
q2.raw_answer: Mormon Church [or LDS Church; or Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]

q3.quetsion_text: The USDA was elevated to a Cabinet-level department by this president, who vetoed the Texas Seed Bill and was attacked for having an illegitimate child with Maria Halpin.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this measure of the hydrophobicity of a surface. It's high for substances exhibiting the lotus effect.

q2.quetsion_text: When they encounter a hydrophobic surface, water molecules show this phenomenon, in which they stick to each other, not to the other molecules. Mercury strongly exhibits this property, which is why mercury thermometers have convex menisci.

q3.quetsion_text: Another measure of hydrophobicity is the partition coefficient or log P. That quantity is usually measured as the logarithm of the ratio of the concentration of the solute in water to its concentration in this alcohol.
q3.raw_answer: octanol [or 1-octanol; or octan-1-ol; or octyl alcohol]

lead_in: The original scoring of this piece called for a whopping 24 oboes.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this orchestral work that was commissioned for a celebration of the end of the War of the Austrian Succession. Its third movement is a Largo alla siciliana that, suitably for the occasion, is titled "La Paix".

q2.quetsion_text: The Music for the Royal Fireworks is by this German-English Baroque composer of the Water Music and Messiah.
q2.raw_answer: George Frideric Handel [or Georg Friederich HÃ¤ndel]

q3.quetsion_text: The opening sinfonia of Handel's Messiah is followed by two tenor arias, "Comfort Ye My People" and this aria, which uses text painting to illustrate a hill being made low and the crooked being made straight.

lead_in: This entity is depicted wielding both a sword and a papal staff with a body made of people. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this symbol of the Commonwealth, headed by a Sovereign with civil and ecclesiastical power. It represents a covenant where people cede their natural rights for a state of peace.

q2.quetsion_text: The Leviathan is a political structure imagined by this English philosopher, who warned that the alternative is a state of nature where life is "solitary, poor, nasty, brutish, and short".

q3.quetsion_text: According to Hobbes, people are primarily driven by the pursuit of this concept. The state of nature is anarchic because people are preoccupied with this, which is more certain in a state of peace.

lead_in: The third example of a type of work in this collection takes the subject for its second movement fugue from the chorale Komm, Heiliger Geist. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this set of six works for solo violin by J.S. Bach.
q1.raw_answer: J.S. Bach's Sonatas and Partitas for solo violin [or J.S. Bach's Six Violin Sonatas and Partitas; or Sei Solo Â– a violino senza Basso accompagnato]

q2.quetsion_text: The probable inspiration for Bach's Sonatas and Partitas is Johann Paul von Westhoff's six partitas for solo violin, which make extensive use of this technique in which two notes are played simultaneously, using two strings.

q3.quetsion_text: As this is the number of strings on a violin, it's also the maximum number of notes that can be played on different strings simultaneously, though it's ridiculously hard to do so. Common time has this many quarter-notes per measure.

lead_in: This man used Greenlander Norse and Easter Islanders as examples of societies whose collapse was brought on by ecological destruction.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this author of Collapse who also claimed ecology and geography were the primary factors for the success of Europe compared to the Americas in Guns, Germs, and Steel.

q2.quetsion_text: Diamond's emphasis on geography was criticized in Why Nations Fail, a book by this man and James Robinson. This man argued political institutions established while a country was a colony were largely responsible for current development in "Colonial Origins of Comparative Development."

q3.quetsion_text: To overcome omitted variable bias, Acemoglu used European settler mortality as this type of variable. This variable is correlated only with the independent variable and is the regressor in the first stage of twostage least-squares regression.

lead_in: An early instance of these items were worn by the Cornuti, but they may have entered popular culture by way of Carl Doepler's costumes for the first Bayreuth Festival. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify these pieces of protective gear which were, contrary to popular belief, more commonly worn by samurai than by Vikings.
q1.raw_answer: horned helmets [or helmets with horns on them; or horned headgear]

q2.quetsion_text: An unhorned Viking helmet was unearthed from the undisturbed seventh century ship burial at this English archaeological site.

q3.quetsion_text: The aforementioned "Cornuti" were Germanic soldiers working for this Roman Emperor, who used them against Maxentius at the Siege of Verona and Battle of Milvian Bridge.
q3.raw_answer: Constantine the Great [or Constantine I; or Saint Constantine]

lead_in: This poem frequently makes references to Confucian political philosophy. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this long poem, whose sections include "Rock-Drill" and "Pisan," and which famously denounces usura.

q2.quetsion_text: The Cantos is by this American poet of the collection Ripostes. He wrote about a poet whose "true Penelope was Flaubert" in "Hugh Selwyn Mauberley."

q3.quetsion_text: Many of Pound's poems are extremely brief, like his two-line poem "In a Station of the Metro." Name the two adjectives which appear in the second line of the poem.

lead_in: A standard electrode potential is written as a reaction of this type, which takes place at the cathode of a voltaic cell.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this component of a redox reaction in which a species gains electrons.

q2.quetsion_text: The component reactions of a redox reaction are called this, which also denotes a method used to balance redox reactions, contrasted with using oxidation numbers.

q3.quetsion_text: A standard electrode potential of zero is defined as the potential of the half reaction that produces this gaseous molecule.

lead_in: This character lent his name to a satirical magazine which survived from the Second Reich through two decades of West Germany. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this boy who wanders through the horrors of the Thirty Years War and becomes a hermit, the title hero of a 17th-century novel by Jacobus von Grimmelshausen.

q2.quetsion_text: Simplicissimus is a German example of this genre, in which a roguish protagonist wanders widely and has comic adventures. Its Spanish exemplars include Lazarillo de Tormes.

q3.quetsion_text: This more recent author dealt with the Thirty Years War in The Meeting at Telgte. He revealed his teenage experiences in the SS in his memoir Peeling the Onion.

lead_in: Answer the following about public housing projects in the United States,

q1.quetsion_text: The Minoru Yamasaki-designed Pruitt-Igoe project in this city became a symbol of poor public planning policies. This city is also home to the Eero Saarinen-designed Gateway Arch.

q2.quetsion_text: Hip hop DJ Afrika Bambaataa grew up in the River Houses project in this New York City borough, which is also home to Yankee Stadium.

q3.quetsion_text: This Northern California city is home to the Acorn and Cypress Village projects, close to where Huey Newton was killed in 1989. This city's International Boulevard is near Lake Merritt.

lead_in: This man spends seven years on the island of Calypso and one on the island of Circe.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Greek hero whose ten-year trip back from the Trojan War to reclaim his kingdom, Ithaca, and his wife Penelope make up the plot of his namesake Homeric epic.

q2.quetsion_text: The first four books of the Odyssey focus largely on this son of Odysseus, who visits Nestor, Menelaus, and other characters while searching for news of his father.

q3.quetsion_text: One of the tactics Penelope uses to delay her many suitors is to weave by day, and un-weave by night, a burial shroud for this elderly father of Odysseus.

lead_in: Identify the following about machine learning,

q1.quetsion_text: Machine learning is a sub-field of this computer science discipline. A machine implementing the "strong" form of this discipline could perform any task that the human brain can.

q2.quetsion_text: The "decision" type of these data structures are used in some modeling problems in machine learning.  The red-black type of these data structures can be searched in Big O of log n time.

q3.quetsion_text: One practical example of machine learning is to use a naÃ¯ve algorithm named for this statistician to perform spam filtering. This man's namesake theorem provides a definition for conditional probability.

lead_in: This character points out that there is no mention of Jesus ever laughing, and that laughter's rationality is not proof of its licitness, as speech, which is also rational, may be used to blaspheme.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this character who sets a trap in the finis Africae, and who dies after starting a fire and eating the pages of a certain book.

q2.quetsion_text: Jorge of Burgos appears in this Umberto Eco novel narrated by Adso of Melk, which tells of his and William of Baskerville's time in a murderous abbey.
q2.raw_answer: The Name of the Rose [accept Il nome della rosa]

q3.quetsion_text: This other work of Italian historical fiction is partly set in plague-ridden Milan. In this novel, Fra Cristoforo works to aid Renzo and Lucia after thugs sent by Don Rodrigo to threaten Don Abbondio foil their plans.

lead_in: Vance Randolph studied the folklore of this region. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this region near the Ouachita Mountains, which takes up much of Missouri and northern Arkansas.
q1.raw_answer: the Ozarks [accept the Ozark Mountains or the Ozark Plateau]

q2.quetsion_text: The Ozarks also spill into the northeastern region of this state, whose second-largest city is Tulsa.

q3.quetsion_text: Paul Henning was inspired to create The Beverly Hillbillies by a camping trip near this Missouri city in the Ozarks. A tourist center, it is known for its live music venues.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: The first movement of the quartet was composed by this member of The Five, who also composed the Russian Easter Festival Overture and "The Flight of the Bumblebee."

q2.quetsion_text: The second movement was written by this composer, whose tone poems include The Enchanted Lake, Kikimora and Baba Yaga. Before hiring Stravinsky, Diaghilev asked this composer to score The Firebird.

q3.quetsion_text: The third movement was by this composer, who is known for the third-movement nocturne from his second string quartet, as well as the "Polovtsian Dances."

lead_in: This ruler limited the rents paid by Christian serfs known as rayas as part of his Kanun law reforms. For 10  points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Ottoman sultan known as "the Magnificent" who defeated the Hungarians at Mohacs but  turned back at the 1529 siege of Vienna.
q1.raw_answer: Suleiman the Magnificent [or Suleiman I; or Suleiman Kanuni]

q2.quetsion_text: This admiral of Suleiman's navy won the Battle of Preveza against the Genoese navy and declared  himself Sultan of Algiers after capturing the city with his brother Oruc.
q2.raw_answer: Hayreddin Barbarossa [or Barbarossa Hayreddin Pasha; or Khayr ad-din]

q3.quetsion_text: One of Suleiman's many architectural projects was the construction of a gate named for this city in  Jerusalem. This city's namesake style of steel was characterized by a wave pattern.

lead_in: Flows of this type have high momentum diffusion and low momentum convection, and reactors that use this type of flow are commonly used to study multi-step reaction mechanisms. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this type of flow which occurs at low Reynolds numbers, as opposed to turbulent flow.

q2.quetsion_text: When the Reynolds number is less than one, a type of flow named for this man occurs. A formula derived by him states that the force of drag on a small sphere is equal to six pi times viscosity times radius times velocity.

q3.quetsion_text: This physicist names vortex streets that appear for Reynolds numbers between like 40 and 400 when a cylinder is in a flow; the vortices appear and shed alternately from each side of the cylinder.

lead_in: Answer the following about wide-open expanses in ancient Egyptian mythology, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This evil god with tall flat-topped ears and a thin snout ruled the "Red Land," a.k.a. the vast desert anywhere not along the Nile. He ripped his brother Osiris into pieces.
q1.raw_answer: Set [or Seth; or Seteh; prompt on "Typhon" if there are any ancient Greeks playing this set]

q2.quetsion_text: This lush paradise is the destination of people whose hearts weigh less than the feather of Ma'at after death. In English-language sources, it is usually identified by the plant life that grows there.
q2.raw_answer: Field of Reeds [or Aaru; prompt on "Next World;" prompt on "Du'at"]

q3.quetsion_text: In the Ogdoad cosmology, this husband of Naunet represents the endless cosmic waters or cosmic abyss, from which the first landmass emerged.
q3.raw_answer: Nun [or Nu; do NOT accept "Nut;" if necessary, ask teams to spell their answer]

lead_in: Answer the following about ways government can take property from private citizens in the United States without trial, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This process of buying back private land is constitutionally limited to "public use" for which the owner is given "just compensation" by the Takings Clause in the Fifth Amendment.

q2.quetsion_text: Law enforcement officials can use this procedure during a roadside stop to seize suspicious cash in a vehicle without an indictment. A series of 2014 articles by the Washington Post criticized its overuse on state highways.
q2.raw_answer: civil asset forfeiture [or civil forfeiture; or Equitable Sharing program]

q3.quetsion_text: SWAT teams can get warrants for these raids, which do not require announcing one's presence before entering, if they believe evidence would be destroyed due to their announcement. Cato Institute fellow Radley Balko drew attention to them in the mid-2000s.
q3.raw_answer: no-knock police raids [or no-knock warrants; prompt on "SWAT team raids," "drug raids," etc.]

lead_in: These ligands induce dimerization of their receptors via serine/threonine kinase activity, causing the recruitment of Smad proteins.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this superfamily of dimeric proteins which include its namesake alongside the activins and BMPs. They serve roles in both developmental pattern formation and tissue repair.
q1.raw_answer: transforming growth factor beta superfamily [or TGF-Beta]

q2.quetsion_text: The Smad family is named for the Sma protein, first identified in C. elegans, and the Mad protein, which was first identified in this other model organism with a lifespan of 30 days used by Thomas Hunt Morgan for genetic analysis.

q3.quetsion_text: During development, some members of the TGF-beta superfamily serve this role. These are diffusable proteins that determine tissue development and polarity by forming a concentration gradient.

lead_in: Bonus: Thymol blue turns this color when placed in an acid, and adding dinitrogen tetroxide to nitric acid also produces this color. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this color produced in the flame test for lithium.

q2.quetsion_text: This element has a red allotrope that is found in matches, and this nonmetal, symbolized P, is also present in fertilizer.

q3.quetsion_text: Phosphorus-31, which has a spin of one-half, is employed in this analytical technique where atomic nuclei absorb and re-emit radiation, and which can be used to selectively identify chemical compounds.

lead_in: The opening fanfare to this piece was used as the theme for 2001: A Space Odyssey.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this tone poem that features sections such as "Sunrise," "Of Science and Learning," and "Song of the Night Wanderer," inspired by a Friedrich Nietzsche essay.
q1.raw_answer: Also sprach Zarathustra [or Thus Spoke Zarathustra; or Thus Spake Zarathustra]

q2.quetsion_text: This composer of Also sprach Zarathustra also wrote a tone poem depicting a sick artist, Death and Transfiguration. He included two themes played by the horn and D clarinet in Till Eulenspiegel's Merry Pranks.

q3.quetsion_text: Richard Strauss also composed this opera in which Octavian falls in love with Sophie after he is chosen by Baron Ochs as the title figure to deliver a silver engagement flower to Sophie.
q3.raw_answer: Der Rosenkavalier [or The Knight of the Rose]

lead_in: An ivu is a sudden wind-driven rush of a large amount of this material onto a lakeshore, which is also called a "shove" of this material.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this material that makes up frazil, a needle-like substance found in cold, turbulent waters.

q2.quetsion_text: These chunks of ice are bounced around a cloud by updrafts and downdrafts, and grow as raindrops freeze upon collision. The largest one ever measured was one point six seven pounds and was a foot and a half wide.

q3.quetsion_text: In rough oceans, frazil ice crystals accumulate into these objects named for their resemblance to a food. These objects have upturned edges from bumping into each other a lot, and can later cement together to form sheet ice.

lead_in: This man first proposed the concept of a "natural rate of interest" that would equalize saving and investment at full employment.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this economist, whose work on the linkage between the real and financial sector presaged Keynesian macroeconomics.

q2.quetsion_text: Wicksell was an influential figure from this school of economics, which also included the namesakes of the Heckscher-Ohlin model and Mancur Olson, who published a 1937 books that is by turns admiring of Keynes and resentful of the lack of attention to this school's earlier influential research.
q2.raw_answer: Stockholm School of Economics [or Swedish School of Economics]

q3.quetsion_text: Stockholm School economist Erik Lindahl proposed a way to pay for these goods that requires knowledge of individuals' marginal benefits. The Groves-Clark mechanism provides a way for funding them that is strategy-proof but not Pareto optimal.

lead_in: Name some things about famous mythological jewelry.

q1.quetsion_text: Freya slept with four dwarves to acquire this necklace, which in one story was stolen by Loki in the form of a seal and then retrieved by Heimdall in the same form.

q2.quetsion_text: This Japanese sea god, who could either take the form of a dragon or a human, used a pair of jewels to control the tides. His daughter Otohime married the hunter Hoori.
q2.raw_answer: Ryujin [or Ryojin; or Owatatsumi; do not accept "Raijin"]

q3.quetsion_text: This Greek smith god made a cursed necklace as a spiteful wedding gift for Harmonia, who was the daughter of this god's wife Aphrodite from her affair with Ares.

lead_in: The title character of this novel is described as "handsome, clever, and rich Â… [and having] lived nearly twenty-one years in the world with little to distress or vex her."

q1.quetsion_text: Name this novel, whose title character tries to set up Philip Elton with her friend Harriet Smith, chasing off Harriet's more appropriate suitor Robert Martin in the process.

q2.quetsion_text: This author of Emma wrote about the Dashwood sisters in Sense and Sensibility. Her manner of death is disputed, but some scholars think she died by drinking unpasteurized milk that gave her consumption.

q3.quetsion_text: Scholars believe that this unfinished novel by Jane Austen is an early version of Emma. It focuses on the title sisters and features the following potential suitors: the "fine, but cold" Lord Osborne, the "gentlemanly clergyman" Mr. Howard, and the "cruel and hardened flirt" Tom Musgrave.

lead_in: Li'an is a form of this practice where a male invokes the wrath of God on himself if it turns out he's lying. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this practice, the khula form of which can be initiated by a Muslim woman if she can prove her husband hasn't had sex with her for two months.

q2.quetsion_text: If a Muslim man says this word, which means "I divorce you", aloud three times to his wife then he is allowed to divorce her. Scholars debate whether this word can be said all three times in one sitting.

q3.quetsion_text: This controversial Shi'a marital practice allows temporary marriage that can be annulled after a predetermined period of time. Sunnis often accuse Shi'as of using this practice as a cover to legitimize premarital sex.

lead_in: After bad weather caused significant delays, this action's original codename of Operation Rutter was later changed to Operation Jubilee. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this action which captured a heavily fortified French port city, but at the high cost of many Canadian soldiers killed. Many lessons learned here would be later put to use during the Normandy landings.

q2.quetsion_text: The Dieppe Raid occurred in this year, which also saw the Wannsee conference in Germany and the Torch Landings in Africa. In the Pacific, the previous year's disaster at Pearl Harbor was followed up with the total American victory at Midway in this year.

q3.quetsion_text: After Dieppe, these special tanks were designed by Royal Engineers for the Normandy landings. Variants of these tanks included the Crab, which used metal flails to clear mines in front, and the Crocodile, which carried a long range flamethrower.

lead_in: Bonus: One of his characters, Halvard Solness, dies after he attaches a garland to a tower. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Norwegian playwright of The Master Builder and a work in which the wife of Jurgen Tesman commits suicide, Hedda Gabler.

q2.quetsion_text: Henrik Ibsen also wrote this play, in which Krogstad writes a letter about the forgery of a character who, in the end, slams the door and leaves her wedding ring behind, ending Torvald’s marriage to Nora Helmer.

q3.quetsion_text: This other Ibsen play opens with a dinner party hosted by Hakon Werle, whose son Gregors gradually discovers truths in the Ekdal family. It ends with Hedvig using the pistol to shoot himself rather the title animal.

lead_in: Cross-dressing in mythology is quite popular! For 10 points each, name some figures who did so.

q1.quetsion_text: This Norse god of thunder reluctantly dressed up as Freyja to marry the giant Thrym, who stole this god's hammer Mjolnir.

q2.quetsion_text: Cursed with impotence during the Pandavas' exile, this Hindu hero from the Mahabharata crossdressed as Brihannala to teach music and dance. When the curse was lifted, he took up his bow to fight the Kauravas.

q3.quetsion_text: Thetis dressed this Greek hero as a girl and hid him on Skyros to shield him from joining the Trojan War. Odysseus recognized him as a boy after he took up a spear.

lead_in: Bonus: Examples of these include src [“sarc”] and Ras, which mediate cell receptor signaling. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Give this term for genes whose mutation may result in cancer.

q2.quetsion_text: A tumor considered cancerous is given this term, contrasted with benign. Cells from this type of tumor often metastasize and spread to other parts of the body.

q3.quetsion_text: Mutations in the gene that codes for this tumor-suppressor protein, called the “guardian angel of the human genome”, can cause it to become an oncogene due to its importance in cell maintenance and repair.

lead_in: In this novella, the title character murders some peasants and buries them in a graveyard so that a doctor will be able to hunt for will-o-the-wisps there.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this novella in which the Bad 'Un returns from the Turkish wars and terrorizes his village but it is ultimately reunited with the Good 'Un.
q1.raw_answer: The Cloven Viscount [or Il visconte dimezzato]

q2.quetsion_text: The Cloven Viscount was included in Our Ancestors, a novella collection by this Italian author who also wrote If on a winter's night a traveler.

q3.quetsion_text: Calvino's Baron in the Trees opens with the title character refusing to eat a dish of this food, prepared by his sister who also enjoys feeding the family things like "hares' ears set on a collar of fur."

lead_in: Answer these questions about philosophers who cared about law, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This Englishman distinguished the "right of nature," by which each man can do whatever, from the "law of nature," which implies that men ought to endeavor peace and use self-defense, in his Leviathan.

q2.quetsion_text: This Dutch jurist was attacked at the start of Rousseau's The Social Contract. He inspired the field of international law with his On the Law of War and Peace and Mare Liberum.

q3.quetsion_text: More recently, this legal philosophy was espoused at Oxford by H.L.A. Hart. Less harsh than imperativalism, it holds that law exists as a matter of social fact irrespective of its morality or merit.

lead_in: The Third Party System ended with the Panic of 1893 in this president's second term.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this president whose two nonconsecutive terms were divided by the presidency of Benjamin Harrison.

q2.quetsion_text: Cleveland won his first presidency in 1884 after these amusingly named anti-corruption Republicans rejected James G. Blaine in favor of him; they did so despite Blaine's support of the reformist Half-Breeds against the Stalwarts.

q3.quetsion_text: Blaine's presidential hopes were harmed by the public reveal of these documents, which seemed to show Blaine selling favors to businesses. One of these documents notoriously ended with the phrase "Kind regards to Mrs. Fisher--burn this letter."

lead_in: Answer some questions about a state of matter, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This equation models the behavior of particles that theoretically have no molecular volume and undergo perfectly elastic collisions, and states that P V equals n R T.

q2.quetsion_text: This equation expresses P V hat over R T as a series expansion and takes into account the Pitzer eccentricity factor and reduced temperature. Its second order truncation is the Van der Waals equation.
q2.raw_answer: virial equation of state [or Kamerlingh-Onnes equation]

q3.quetsion_text: This equation of state used in fluid dynamics contains eight experimentally determined coefficients and was created as an expansion and rearrangement of the Beattie-Bridgeman equation of state.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Swiss developmental psychologist whose system used four discrete stages of development in children.

q2.quetsion_text: During this first of Piaget's [pee-ah-jays] stages of development, which lasts from birth until around two years, a child learns object permanence while maintaining an egocentric view of its environment.

q3.quetsion_text: Piaget's theories have been used in this field, abbreviated A.I., which has the goal of designing machines that can reason, learn, and use human languages.

lead_in: One character in this work assures Jig that the "operation" will be "simple" and "natural."

q1.quetsion_text: Name this short story, in which a couple talks cryptically about getting an abortion in Madrid. Its title comes from a comment the girl makes on the scenery.

q2.quetsion_text: This author of The Sun Also Rises and "The Short Happy Life of Francis Macomber" wrote "Hills Like White Elephants."

q3.quetsion_text: In a Hemingway story named for the "snows of" this mountain, Harry reflects on his life as he is dying of gangrene. He dreams of a rescue plane taking him up this mountain.

lead_in: This molecule's concentration in the atmosphere has increased concomitant with the increase in carbon dioxide, as warmer air is able to hold more of it. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this most abundant greenhouse gas in the atmosphere and dominant contributor to the greenhouse effect.

q2.quetsion_text: The greenhouse effect is the absorption and re-emission of this type of radiation, which is just longer in wavelength than visible light.

q3.quetsion_text: Carbon dioxide has three vibration modes, of which symmetric stretching is IR inactive and asymmetric stretching is IR active. What third vibration mode, which is degenerate, is also IR active because it causes a change in dipole moment?
q3.raw_answer: bending vibration [prompt on change in bond angle]

lead_in: This book divides identity into two parts: the "I" dealing with the reaction to others and the "Me" concerned with the attitudes of others. For 10 points each;

q1.quetsion_text: Name this posthumously published sociological book by George Herbert Mead that argues that the individual is a product of socially significant gestures.

q2.quetsion_text: Mind, Self, and Society is one of the foundational texts of this school of sociology whose leaders include Herbert Blumer and Erving Goffman.

q3.quetsion_text: Mead wrote a book about the "philosophy of the act," setting forth the four stages of impulse, perception, manipulation, and consummation. This author's nonfiction Shadow and Act discusses racial and literary issues; he also wrote about Ras the Destroyer.

lead_in: This painter showed three witches hovering over a writhing nude figure in Witches' Sabbath. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this court painter to Charles IV, who painted scenes of madness and fantasy like Saturn Devouring His Sons in his Black Paintings series. He also showed an execution in The Third of May, 1808.

q2.quetsion_text: This Goya painting depicts a young woman unabashedly gazing directly at the viewer. It was originally positioned behind its less obscene companion painting, so that a pulley could be used to reveal this painting from behind.
q2.raw_answer: The Nude Maja [or La maja desnuda]

q3.quetsion_text: Goya gave this name to prints 65 to 82 of his The Disasters of War Series, which show allegorical scenes of Spanish politics following the devastation of the Napoleonic Wars.
q3.raw_answer: emphatic caprices [or caprichos enfaticos; prompt on "caprichos" or "caprices"]

lead_in: Many staples of this ballet company's repertoire had their mime sequences cut and happy endings attached by the on-and-off director Konstantin Sergeyev. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this ballet company, long served by the ballet master Marius Petipa, that today is still internationally known by the name of an assassinated Bolshevik.
q1.raw_answer: Kirov Ballet [or Mariinsky Ballet; or Imperial Russian Ballet]

q2.quetsion_text: In Sergeyev's 1950 revision of this ballet, the sorceror von Rothbart dies a painful death, allowing Siegfried to be together with the no-longer-avian Odette on Earth.

q3.quetsion_text: The Kirov ballet lost two of its greatest stars, Rudolf Nureyev in 1961 and Mikhail Baryshnikov in 1974, when they performed this action.
q3.raw_answer: defecting to the West [or equivalent answers such as leaving the Soviet Union; or moving to France and moving to Canada]

lead_in: This country's poet Sa'di wrote collected stories on subjects like "The Manners of Kings" in his book  Gulistan, and Edward FitzGerald collected hundreds of quatrains or rubaiyat by another poet from here.  For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name either the ancient nation or its modern equivalent whose writers included Hafez, Omar  Khayyam, and Ferdowsi.

q2.quetsion_text: Ferdowsi wrote this national epic of Iran, a "book of kings" that records the lives of rulers from  ancient times through the Sassanid Empire.

q3.quetsion_text: This hero in the Shahnameh is killed when his jealous brother Shaghad drops him and his horse  Rakhsh into a pit of swords. He unknowingly kills his son Sohrab when the two meet in a battle.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this West African ethnicity whose pre-Christian religion included a divination ritual using palm nuts and the drum-accompanied "mounting" ritual, in which spirits called orishas could possess a person.

q2.quetsion_text: On this island, slaves of Yoruba descent blended their beliefs with Spanish Catholicism to create SanterÃ­a.

q3.quetsion_text: In Cuba, this female saint and martyr is syncretized with ChangÃ³, the male fire and lightning orisha. This patron saint of artillery has a feast on December 4. Her father was struck by lightning for beheading her.

lead_in: This concept was first introduced in its creator's book Theory of Moral Sentiments.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this metaphor that captures the idea that the self-interested nature of the market seamlessly promotes the interest of the nation at large.

q2.quetsion_text: The invisible hand metaphor was created by this Scottish thinker, who laid the foundation for capitalism and the field of economics in his masterpiece The Wealth of Nations.

q3.quetsion_text: Adam Smith promoted the free market in opposition to this economic system. He coined this system's English name and believed that it gave too much power to the royal state.

lead_in: This economist pointed out that it's very hard for planners to rationally distribute resources without a price mechanism to guide their decisions in "Economic Calculation and the Socialist Commonwealth."

q1.quetsion_text: Name this economist, who argued for laissez-faire capitalism based on his studies of decision making, called praxeology, in his magnum opus Human Action.

q2.quetsion_text: Mises was part of this school of economics, whose other members included Friedrich Hayek and Eugen von BÃ¶hm- Bawerk. It stresses individual choice in economics, and is advanced today by Lew Rockwell.

q3.quetsion_text: Another member of the Austrian School, Frank Fetter, criticized this economist for abandoning a theory he put forth in his 1907 book The Rate of Interest. He also developed debt-deflation theory.

lead_in: Artist Eleuterio Pagliano painted a contingent of Austrians retreating at a cemetery in this battle.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this June 24, 1859 battle whose carnage inspired Henri Durant to found the Red Cross.

q2.quetsion_text: Pagliano's painting depicts a group of these French soldiers climbing over a wall at the Cemetery of Solferino. These mainly Berber troops wore baggy pants and exotic headgear, and a group of these troops fought against Russia in the January Uprising of 1863 in Poland under Colonel Rouchebrune.

q3.quetsion_text: This temporary peace treaty was signed following the Battle of Solferino. In this agreement, Piedmont gained Lombardy from France and Austria maintained controlled over military fortresses in the Quadrilateral.

lead_in: Answer the following about the European revolutions of 1848, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: Lajos Kossuth led this country after it shook off Hapsburg rule, but forces under Russia's Nicolas I broke up its independent parliament.

q2.quetsion_text: This king was preceded by Charles X and was forced to abdicate in 1848 at the beginning of France's Second Republic.
q2.raw_answer: Louis-Phillipe I [do not accept or prompt on "Louis"]

q3.quetsion_text: Friedrich August Peter von Colomb put down the uprising among the "Greater" portion of this would-be country in 1848.

lead_in: This book's cover illustrated its concept of a sovereign leading a commonwealth by showing a giant king whose body is composed of many smaller men.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this book which states that life is "nasty, brutish, and short" in a state of nature and argues that a society bound together by a social contract should be governed by absolute rule.

q2.quetsion_text: Leviathan was written by this British political philosopher, who tutored Charles II.

q3.quetsion_text: The state of nature described in Leviathan is often described with this phrase. Either the four-word Latin phrase or its English translation is acceptable.
q3.raw_answer: war of all against all [or bellum omnium contra omnes; the Latin is the original, so accept other English translations like war of each against all, war of everyone against everyone, etc.]

lead_in: A character in this novel dies when a Hammond B-3 organ falls on him while setting up a speaking gig for a pre-famous Barack Obama. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this 2012 novel mostly set at Brokeland Records, an establishment owned by Archy Stallings and Nat Jaffe. It was written by the author of The Mysteries of Pittsburgh.

q2.quetsion_text: Telegraph Avenue was written by this author who wrote about "Jews with Swords" in Gentlemen of the Road and The Yiddish Policemen's Union.

q3.quetsion_text: The record store at the center of Telegraph Avenue is threatened by G Bad, who used to be in this profession. Roberta Muldoon was employed in this profession before undergoing a sex change in The World According to Garp.
q3.raw_answer: professional football player [or NLF player; accept more specific answers like Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback or Philadelphia Eagles tight end; prompt on "athlete"]

lead_in: This man fearfully hid in jars because he was afraid of the beasts his servant brought to him. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Greek ruler of Mycenae Tiryns whose cousin became his slave after murdering Megara.

q2.quetsion_text: Eurystheus first hid in the jar after Heracles slew this fearsome feline as part of his first labor. Heracles wore its invulnerable skin around after slaying it, which frightened Eurystheus.

q3.quetsion_text: Zeus inadvertently made Eurystheus king of Mycenae by wording a proclamation poorly under the influence of this goddess. Zeus subsequently threw this goddess of delusion from Mount Olympus.

lead_in: One work in this series is set amidst a thick fog and was painted from Saint Thomas' Hospital, while in another the artist attempted to show the sun "setting in an enormous ball of fire behind" the title buildings.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this series of works painted between 1900 and 1904 set amidst sunsets, stormy skies and other atmospheric conditions.
q1.raw_answer: Claude Monet's Houses of Parliament Buildings series

q2.quetsion_text: Monet affixed subtitles like "Symphony in Grey and Rose" to his paintings of this French cathedral.

q3.quetsion_text: They're not haystacks, but one of Monet's first series was of some of these objects on Belle-Ile. Courbet painted one at Hautepierre and Cezanne included many of them above ChÃ¢teau Noir and next to some trees in a 1904 landscape.

lead_in: This quantity is a measure of stiffness. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: What ratio of stress to strain along an axis holds for elastic deformations?
q1.raw_answer: Young's modulus [or tensile modulus; or elastic modulus; or big E]

q2.quetsion_text: This ratio measures the lengthening effect that occurs along the axis transverse to the applied load on a material. It's the negative ratio of transverse to axial strain.

q3.quetsion_text: The stress applied tangentially to the face of material is known by this term and usually denoted by the Greek letter tau.

lead_in: The Loisels spend ten years paying off a debt they incur after a ball at the Ministry of Education in this story.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this short story. At its end, Madame Loisel learns the object she went 36,000 francs in debt in order to replace was fake.

q2.quetsion_text: "The Necklace" was written by this man. He also wrote the story "Boule de Suif," in which passengers hypocritically shun a prostitute.

q3.quetsion_text: "The Necklace" is set in this city. This city is also the setting of a Victor Hugo novel about the bell-ringer Quasimodo.

lead_in: A chapter in this work entitled "The White Kitten" relates the story of Georgi Tenno, who escapes from the title location only to be recaptured after he refuses to kill innocent villagers.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this work that is comprised of experiences of 227 different people in the Soviet political prison system.

q2.quetsion_text: This man was the author of The Gulag Archipelago. He spent 10 years in the gulags, and lived in exile in the United States until he returned to Russia after the fall of the USSR.

q3.quetsion_text: Author Varlam Shalamov was sent to a gulag after he praised the works of this author, which include the novel The Village and the short story "The Gentleman from San Francisco."

lead_in: Towards the end of this novel the narrator of this work uses his nickname "Puffin" in order for his mother to recognize him.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this novel in which Christopher Banks returns to Shanghai during World War II, where he confuses an injured Japanese soldier for his childhood friend Akira.

q2.quetsion_text: This Japanese-British author of The Unconsoled and An Artist of the Floating World wrote When We Were Orphans. He may be better known for a novel about the butler Stevens called The Remains of the Day.

q3.quetsion_text: A song by Judy Bridgewater provides the title to this dystopian Ishiguro novel, in which Tommy and Kathy are raised to be "donors" at Hailsham.

lead_in: Bonus: for ten points each: answer some question related to Pascal’s triangle.

q1.quetsion_text: One can generate the terms in a row of Pascal’s triangle by applying this operation to two adjacent entries in the previous row. A capital sigma denotes repeated applications of this operation.

q2.quetsion_text: Another way to generate the nth row of Pascal’s triangle applies this function to n for the integers from 0 up to n, which creates the binomial coefficients. This function selects elements without regard to order.
q2.raw_answer: n choose r [or combination; accept any letter in place for r such as i or k]

q3.quetsion_text: The sum of all the elements in the nth row of Pascal’s triangle is equal to this function of n, accounting for the fact that each element in a set can either be included or not included in each combination.
q3.raw_answer: 2n [read “two raised to the power of n;” accept equivalents] <EC>

lead_in: This book describes sympathy as the faculty through which people can imagine themselves to feel the passions of others, and it explains that custom can only have limited influence on ethical judgment.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this book by Adam Smith which describes how human passions are mediated by an impartial spectator that allows people to consider their emotions from an external perspective.

q2.quetsion_text: Smith's thoughts on morality were influenced by this mentor and fellow Scotsman, who argued that people had a distinct sense devoted to morality in such works as A System of Moral Philosophy.

q3.quetsion_text: The Theory of Moral Sentiments was the first work to use this anatomical metaphor that Smith reused in his later The Wealth of Nations. It denotes how free choices of individual actors can aggregate into a socially desirable outcome.

lead_in: Bonus: This work was published in L’Aurore and addressed to Felix Faure. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this letter published in defense of Alfred Dreyfus, which accused the government of covering up his innocence and hiding the guilt of Ferdinand Esterhazy.

q2.quetsion_text: The Dreyfus affair divided the society of this European country, which was home to the author of J’accuse, Emile Zola. It was represented at the Paris Peace Conference by Georges Clemenceau.

q3.quetsion_text: Alfred Dreyfus was initially sentenced to life imprisonment on this French Guiana island.

lead_in: This politician's reputation was tarnished when troops led by him shot at participants in the Gordon Riots. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this English radical who was jailed in the Tower of London after authoring Issue no. 45 of The North Briton.

q2.quetsion_text: Wilkes was an enemy of this king, a member of the House of Hanover who faced the American Revolution. This man's insanity in later life is sometimes attributed to porphyria.

q3.quetsion_text: After issuing the Proclamation of Rebellion, George III did not even read this conciliatory petition addressed to him by the Second Continental Congress in hopes of preventing war.

lead_in: This man's third wife Isabel succeeded him after his death in 1974.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this Argentine leader, whose second wife, Eva, was wildly popular in his country.

q2.quetsion_text: Peron's Argentina provided a safe-haven for Nazis such as this man, who was entrusted with directing the "Final Solution." He was captured by Mossad agents and tried in Jerusalem.

q3.quetsion_text: This is the name given to the impoverished working-class supporters of Juan Peron. They got their name because they might not have worn a namesake piece of clothing.

lead_in: The works of these people were mostly composed in an alliteration-filled verse-form called "drottkvaett". For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these court bards, who chronicled such leaders as Harald Fairhair and Eiriker Hladajarl in such works as the Glymdrapa and the Vellekla.

q2.quetsion_text: Egil Skallagrimsson and Ulfr Uggason were skalds from what is now this modern-day country, the origin of NjÃ¡ls Saga. Famous authors from here include Snorri Sturluson and HalldÃ³r Laxness.

q3.quetsion_text: In this novel, Professor Lindebrock and his nephew Axel descend into the Icelandic volcano SnaefellsjÃ¶kull after a finding a runic cryptogram inside a Snorri Sturluson saga.
q3.raw_answer: A Journey to the Center of the Earth [or Voyage au centre de la Terre; or A Journey to the Interior of the Earth]

lead_in: Snowy owls and red crossbills frequently exhibit this type of growth, exciting for bird watchers who don't want to travel far.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this type of growth that occurs when the population of a species rises extremely high after its introduction to a new region, and then its subsequent crash and stabilization below the carrying capacity.
q1.raw_answer: irruptive growth [or Malthusian growth, or word forms of irruption]

q2.quetsion_text: Species that frequently undergo irruptive growth typically belong to the type of evolutionary strategy labeled with this letter, which is associated with a larger number of offspring, but a decreased propensity to reach reproductive age.

q3.quetsion_text: These very large land mammals epitomize K-selection, with the longest gestation period of any known animal with nearly 22 months for its Asian type. The ivory trade has seriously hurt the global population of these animals.

lead_in: Common examples of these materials include silicon and gallium arsenide. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify these materials with intermediate resistances between those of conductors and insulators. Intel uses them to make computer chips.

q2.quetsion_text: This term refers to the energy difference between the valence and conduction bands of a semiconductor. Energies in this region are forbidden outside of impurity-created traps and some other stuff.

q3.quetsion_text: This method of doping semiconductors is preferred to diffusion at large processing plants. It accelerates ions to high velocities using a high electric field, after which a drive-in step is required to complete the doping.

lead_in: Chamberland first iterated the fractal that arises from this conjecture.

lead_in: Answer some questions pertaining to vacuums, for 10 points each.

q3.quetsion_text: The low-pressure form of this deposition process can be said to occur under vacuum conditions. Said low-pressure form of this process is used to deposit high quality silicon nitride and polycrystalline silicon.

lead_in: Name some things involved in the synthesis and characterization of proteins,

q1.quetsion_text: The Strecker synthesis forms amino acids by attacking carbonyls with salts of this anion, which reacts with alkyl halides to form nitriles. The Nazis generated the toxic gas Zyklon B by reacting this anion with sulfuric acid.

q2.quetsion_text: An important protecting group in peptide synthesis is BOC, which contains an ester derivative of this bulky organic group. This group's steric hindrance allows its alkoxide to act as a strong base but not a nucleophile.

lead_in: These substances often consist of a weak acid and its conjugate base.

lead_in: In art this archangel of wisdom is typically depicted as carrying either an open flame or a book in one hand.

lead_in: Bulky groups oriented 60 degrees apart on these diagrams will have gauche interactions. For 10 points each:

lead_in: This work opens with a quote from Plato's Sophist that states "We, however, who used to think we understood it, have now become perplexed" in reference to the first title concept. For 10 points each:

lead_in: The 1906 San Francisco earthquake destroyed many immigrant records, leading to widespread fraud. For 10 points each:
