q3.quetsion_text: Following his time as dictator, Cincinnatus went back to this occupation, which was what he was doing when a delegation from the Senate found him to ask him to become dictator.

lead_in: Bonus: In Hebrew, these are called a ra’ashan. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify these noise-making devices, which are used to drown out the name of a certain minister of Ahasuerus who was eventually hanged on fifty-cubit high gallows of his own construction.

q2.quetsion_text: Graggers are typically used when Haman’s name is read aloud during this holiday, during which mishloach manot is given and Mordecai’s triumph is celebrated.

q3.quetsion_text: This book is read on Purim and mentions how Mordecai and his niece foiled a plot by Haman to massacre the Jews in Persia.

lead_in: Answer the following about films set in Vienna, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: In this film based on a play by Peter Shaffer, Antonio Salieri expresses great remorse for having  poisoned the young Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart. Its Neville Marriner-conducted soundtrack won a  Grammy.

q2.quetsion_text: This actor created the short film Vienna. In another film set in Vienna, his character delivers a  monologue noting that the only result of 500 years of peace in Switzerland was the invention of the  cuckoo clock.

q3.quetsion_text: Welles delivered that monologue in this 1949 film, the screenplay of which was written by Graham  Greene. This film stars the pulp fiction writer Holly Martin and has a soundtrack played entirely on the  zither.

lead_in: Answer the following about the 2014 midterm elections, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This Senator, the current Senate Minority Leader, is running for re-election and was opposed by Matt Bevin in a primary race.

q2.quetsion_text: This Louisiana Democrat and current chair of the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources is expected to face Bill Cassidy in a close race for re-election.

q3.quetsion_text: This California billionaire, who donated heavily to Terry McAuliffe in the 2013 Virginia gubernatorial race, has pledged to spend a hundred million dollars for candidates who support climate-change legislation in the 2014 elections.

lead_in: The "Golden Horseshoe" in this province contains over a quarter of Canada's population. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this province south of Hudson Bay. Its capital is Toronto, and it is also home to Ottawa, the capital of Canada.

q2.quetsion_text: This offshoot of Hudson Bay is between Ontario and Quebec. This bay's largest island is Akimiski Island, which, despite being so far south, is actually part of Nunavut.

q3.quetsion_text: This large prehistoric lake covered most of modern Manitoba, and was probably linked to Lake Ojibway, which covered most of modern Ontario. It was named after a Swiss scientist.
q3.raw_answer: Lake Agassiz [the scientist is Louis Agassiz]

lead_in: Rollo May and Paul Tillich introduced this kind of therapy to help patients develop the courage to deal with anxiety and take responsibility for their actions. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this type of therapy that Irvin Yalom argues should have the patient view the therapist as a "fellow traveler" in confronting the four givens of life: isolation, meaninglessness, mortality, and freedom.

q2.quetsion_text: This author of Man's Search for Meaning employed existential therapy principles to develop his own logotherapy. His attempt to gauge purpose was improved on by Crumbaugh and Maholick in their "Purpose in Life" test.

q3.quetsion_text: Frankl's approach was derived from his experiences surviving this historical event,. This event influenced later psychology studies like Milgram's obedience experiments to explain the actions of concentration camp guards.

lead_in: This "closely held" corporation is owned and operated by David Green and his family.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this craft store chain that won a 2014 Supreme Court case against the federal government over their opposition to birth control requirements in the Affordable Care Act.

q2.quetsion_text: Hobby Lobby and several organizations affiliated with the Catholic Church argued that requiring them to purchase health insurance covering birth control violated this type of freedom.

q3.quetsion_text: The Hobby Lobby case led many LGBT rights activists to call for religious freedom clauses to be omitted from this bill that would make it illegal to fire people for their sexual orientation.

lead_in: Bonus: Its inhabitants used steatite to create figurines, such as one of a seated man called “The Priest-King.” For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this ancient city, among the first to use a grid plan, which may have been established by Dravidian peoples fleeing from the Aryan migrations. It was located downstream from Harappa.

q2.quetsion_text: Mohenjo-Daro and Harappa were both cities of this early civilization located along a river valley located on the Indian subcontinent.

q3.quetsion_text: The Indus Valley Civilization belonged to this period of ancient society. This period came after the Stone Age, before the Iron Age, and is named after an alloy of copper and tin.

lead_in: Having to explain jokes tends to make them lose their humour value. Answer the following about the philosophy of laughter:

q1.quetsion_text: This thinker distinguished between der Witz, the comic, and humor in his The Joke and its Relation to the Unconscious, which claims that laughter releases nervous energy. He claimed that the psyche comprised the ego, superego and id in Beyond the Pleasure Principle.

q2.quetsion_text: This philosopher collected three essays on the comic in human life in his book Laughter. He argued that evolution was motivated by an Ã©lan vital in Creative Evolution and contrasted duration with clock-time in Time and Free Will.

q3.quetsion_text: Mikhail Bakhtin provides a revolutionary power theory of laughter in his work Rabelais and His World centered around two concepts, one which subverts the dominant order, and another which degrades the spiritual to the material. Name either.

lead_in: Answer some questions about pottery, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This type of unglazed earthenware was used to make an "army" of thousands of figures for the tomb  of Qin ["chin"] Shi Huang Di.

q2.quetsion_text: This country was home to the creator of a porcelain medallion with the legend "Am I Not a Man and  a Brother?" An extremely white kind of china made using bone ash was invented in this country.
q2.raw_answer: England [prompt on Great Britain or the United Kingdom]

q3.quetsion_text: This kind of East Asian pottery, many examples of which are found at Longquan, also gives its name  to a shade of jade-green.

lead_in: One work in this genre includes musical depictions of a linden tree, a frozen stream, and a hurdy-gurdy man.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this genre of works like Frauenliebe und -leben, and Faure's L'horizon chimerique.
q1.raw_answer: song cycles [or Liederkreis; or Liederzyklus; accept word forms like Cyclus von Liedern etc.; prompt on just "songs," "cycles," or "lieder"]

q2.quetsion_text: This Austrian composer wrote the song cycles Winterreise and Die schÃ¶ne MÃ¼llerin. Despite dying at 31, he wrote over 900 pieces, including the "Unfinished" symphony and the "Trout" Quintet.

q3.quetsion_text: This Beethoven work is often called the first song cycle. Its sixth song, "Nimm sie hin denn, diese Lieder," includes a reprise of the first song, "Auf dem HÃ¼gel sitz ich spÃ¤hend."
q3.raw_answer: An die ferne Geliebte, Op. 98 [accept either underlined part; or To the Distant Beloved; or An die entfernte Geliebte]

lead_in: Name some people who make brief appearances in the Iliad

q1.quetsion_text: Shortly before fighting Diomedes, this Trojan finds out that his grandfather Bellerophon had a bromance with Diomedes' grandfather Oeneus, so they exchange armor instead of fighting.

q2.quetsion_text: This "ugliest man at Troy" stands up to Agamemnon but gets the crap beaten out of him by Odysseus for daring to suggest that the war might be a stupid idea.

q3.quetsion_text: The war was in fact a stupid idea Â– it was launched solely to recover this beautiful wife of Menelaus who had been kidnapped by Paris

lead_in: The title figure of this book calls a rose a "convoluted red form with a linear green attachment."

q1.quetsion_text: Name this collection of case studies of neurological malfunction. The title essay is about "Dr. P," a music teacher suffering from visual agnosia.
q1.raw_answer: The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat

q2.quetsion_text: The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat was written by this neurologist. This herring enthusiast wrote about the effects of music on the brain in Musicophilia and most recently about his experience with mind-altering drugs in Hallucinations.

q3.quetsion_text: The title of Sacks' An Anthropologist on Mars comes from a phrase coined by this woman, an autistic animal science professor at Colorado State University whose work on livestock care is touchingly empathetic.

lead_in: Answer the following about an industrial process used to separate liquids with a small difference in boiling point. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Substances exit this process's namesake column at different locations depending on their boiling point, with substances with lower boiling points further to the top.

q2.quetsion_text: Fractional distillation is frequently used to refine crude oil, which is partly composed of these saturated hydrocarbons. They only have single bonds, and have the empirical formula C sub n, H sub 2n plus 2.

q3.quetsion_text: These mixtures cannot be separated by distillation without the help of an entrainer. Attempting to distill ethanol and water will only bring the mixture closer to one of these.

lead_in: In a speech, this man said that great decisions will be made not "by speeches and majority decisions" but "by blood and iron."

q1.quetsion_text: Name this longtime Prussian and German chancellor, who orchestrated the Franco-Prussian War and German Unification.
q1.raw_answer: Otto von Bismarck [or Otto Eduard Leopold von Bismarck]

q2.quetsion_text: Bismarck came to power under this King. Two failed assassination attempts on him were used as an excuse by Bismarck to pass anti-socialist laws.
q2.raw_answer: Wilhelm I [or William I, prompt on partial answer]

q3.quetsion_text: After Wilhelm I's grandson Wilhelm II came to power, Bismarck was forced to resign. His resignation was shown in a cartoon by John Tenniel with this title, referring to the poor decision to force Bismarck out.

lead_in: For 10 points each, answer the following questions about the development of historiography.

q1.quetsion_text: This man is often called the first modern historian for his thorough methodology and use of primary sources in his Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire, which he attributed to the decline of civic virtue and rise of Christianity.

q2.quetsion_text: As an Enlightenment historian, Gibbon was critical of the perceived intellectual and cultural backwardness of the Middle Ages, calling it this sometimes-pejorative term that originated with Petrarch's description of "dense gloom."

q3.quetsion_text: Some historians consider the term "Dark Ages" inaccurate under this reevaluation of orthodox historical views. This term is sometimes used to imply counterfactualism, although Deborah Libstadt distinguished this from denial.

lead_in: This phenomenon exists between the compounds n-pentane, isopentane, and neopentane, but not also with cyclopentane. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this phenomenon where compounds share the same molecular formula, but have different Lewis structures.

q2.quetsion_text: Benzene has multiple structural isomers, including one shaped like a triangular box and another with two cyclobutene rings joined together. Name either.

q3.quetsion_text: An NMR spectroscopy of a pure hydrogen gas sample will detect para-hydrogen but not ortho-hydrogen, which share this kind of isomerism. The property that this kind of isomerism is named after is pointing in opposite directions in para-hydrogen.

lead_in: One of these writings contains the maxim "What is done in love, is well done," and another expresses the author's desire to found an artists' colony in Southern France. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify these 844 writings, the majority of which were addressed to their author's brother Theo.

q2.quetsion_text: A staggering thirteen of van Gogh's letters were about this painting of his, which exists in three versions that differ in the placement of furniture and wall paintings in the title location within the Yellow House.

q3.quetsion_text: Van Gogh roped Gauguin into a "pact of silence" in the first letter he wrote after this incident, which he supposedly underwent so that he could give a prostitute a bizarre gift. Afterwards, he painted a famous bandaged self-portrait.
q3.raw_answer: cutting his ear off [or equivalent answers such as amputating his ear]

lead_in: These cells can be harvested from the inner cell mass of a blastocyst. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these pluripotent cells, which can differentiate into any of the three germ layers. The  harvesting of these cells from surplus attempts at in vitro fertilization is a source of controversy.
q1.raw_answer: embryonic stem cells [prompt on "stem cells"; prompt on "ESCs"; do not accept or prompt  on any other specific types of stem cells]

q2.quetsion_text: Unlike totipotent cells, embryonic stem cells are unable to differentiate into the cells that comprise  this organ. The umbilical cord connects the fetus to this organ during pregnancy.

q3.quetsion_text: Embryonic stem cells can form these benign tumors, which generally contain tissue from all three  germ layers. These tumors often contain hair or bone tissue, and, in rare cases, contain fully formed  organs.
q3.raw_answer: teratomas [do not accept or prompt on "teratocarcinoma"]

lead_in: Bonus: One work in this language recounts the exile of Siavash. For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this language in which Ferdowsi’s Shahnameh and the poems of Saadi were written.

q2.quetsion_text: Translated by Edward FitzGerald, this Persian “Book of Verses” describes “A Jug of Wine, a Loaf of Bread--and Thou” in one section.

q3.quetsion_text: The Rubaiyat was written by this celebrated poet and philosopher who lived in Iran during the reign of the Abbasid Caliphate.

lead_in: One theory about this disease states that it is caused by a lack of acetylcholine in the brain. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this neurodegenerative disease that mostly affects the elderly characterized by memory loss and mood swings, which can eventually lead to dementia.

q2.quetsion_text: This other degenerative disease results from a low production of dopamine in the brain, and results in tremors and impaired movement.

q3.quetsion_text: This fatal neurodegenerative disease is thought to be transmitted by prions, and is also thought to cause Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.
q3.raw_answer: Mad Cow Disease [accept Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy or BSE]

lead_in: The second of these periods in American history created the "burned-over district" in New York.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this term for periods of intense religious revival in American history. The first of these periods featured the successful ministries of men like Jonathan Edwards.
q1.raw_answer: Great Awakening [or First Great Awakening; or Second Great Awakening]

q2.quetsion_text: The Great Awakening was described in the writings of this American, who also published the successful Poor Richard's Almanac journal.

q3.quetsion_text: This famous British preacher was noted for his open-air preaching and revival meetings in the United States. Franklin wrote descriptions of this man's revivals in Philadelphia.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this 19th century composer who wrote almost all of his works for solo piano, including many etudes [ay-toods], mazurkas, and nocturnes. His etudes have been given nicknames such as Black Keys and Winter Wind.

q2.quetsion_text: Chopin [schoe-pan] also wrote several of these pieces that are in three four time, including the "Minute". Though these pieces were traditionally used for Austrian dances, Chopin's were meant for concert performances.

q3.quetsion_text: Chopin also wrote several of these pieces in three four time, including the "Military". These pieces were traditionally used for Polish dances.

lead_in: "Little" Charlie is carrying on an affair with a woman he believes to be his cousin in this play, which won the 2008 Pulitzer Prize for Drama.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this play by Tracy Letts in which a dysfunctional family gathers around the drug-addicted, sharp-tongued matriarch Violet Weston after her husband's disappearance.

q2.quetsion_text: A bell rings and resets the scene every time Bill fails at asking out Betty in Sure Thing, one of several short plays collected in All in the Timing, by this contemporary American playwright.

q3.quetsion_text: The 2011 Pulitzer Prize for Drama went to Bruce Norris for Clybourne Park, a response to this Lorraine Hansberry play about the Younger family.

lead_in: Because of a phenomenon known as Western intensification, this phenomenon is stronger than its counterpart, the North Atlantic Drift.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this phenomenon that transports warm water from its namesake body of water toward the western coast of Europe, keeping the British Isles slightly warmer.

q2.quetsion_text: The Gulf Stream is one of these phenomena whose flow is measured in units known as sverdrup, which are equivalent to 1 million cubic meters per second.

q3.quetsion_text: Deep water currents are not wind-driven. Instead, the movement of deep ocean water is referred to by this term, which is named for the two parameters that largely determine its movement.

lead_in: Identify some critically lauded videogames of 2013,

q1.quetsion_text: This game designed by Lucas Pope casts you as a border agent in the nation of Arstotzka. You have to do things like look for EZIC agents and decide when to accept bribes.

q2.quetsion_text: The 15 page long Wikipedia article on "List of accolades received by [this game]" has it winning Cheat Code Central's 7th Annual Cody Award for Best Xbox Game. You play as a former Pinkerton named Booker DeWitt in this game, which it set in the city of Columbia in 1912.

q3.quetsion_text: This best Ouya game was acclaimed for its use of local coop where each player try to kill each other with a finite supply of arrows in its battle royale mode. It was developed by Matt Thorson, and an expanded "Ascension" edition made it to PS4 and Steam.

lead_in: This emperor took over Yanqui and forces loyal to him win the Battle of Hulao. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this emperor who began the conquest of the Goguryeo Kingdom and was preceded by Emperor Gaozu.

q2.quetsion_text: Taizong worked with this Korean Kingdom to defeat the Goguryeo. This kingdom used the bone rank system and took over Korea after the defeat of the Goguryeo.

q3.quetsion_text: Jindeok, the ruler of the Silla when Taizong began his campaign, is notable for being one of these people. Another of these people ruled the Tang Dynasty shortly after the reign of Taizong and was named Wu Zetian.

lead_in: The conversion of this pigment's chromophore from an 11-cis to all-trans form upon light exposure causes its activation.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this pigment found in the rods of the retina. Binding of retinal to its identically named G protein coupled receptor is responsible for the perception of light.
q1.raw_answer: rhodopsin [or visual purple; accept specific forms like bacteriorhodopsin]

q2.quetsion_text: When activated, rhodopsin binds to this heterotrimeric G-protein, which continues the single cascade by phosphorylating GDP.

q3.quetsion_text: Transducin activates this molecule's phosphodiesterase, thereby cleaving and thus activating this secondary messenger. Levels of this compound are also increased by the activity of Viagra.
q3.raw_answer: cyclic GMP [or cyclic guanosine monophosphate; do not accept or prompt on "GMP"]

lead_in: These people are usually depicted as a bunch of Japanese pirates and their activity did increase during the Sengoku period, but they were from a diversity of East Asian backgrounds. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Give this term, meaning "dwarf bandits," collections of East Asian raiders who ravaged the Chinese coast in the 15th and 16th centuries. The Joseon targeted these people with the Gihae Eastern Expedition.

q2.quetsion_text: Wokou raids ranged as far south as this large non-European city on the Pearl River, where the later pirate Zheng Yi Sao ran a brothel after retiring. Arab and Persian pirates ransacked this city in an 878 massacre here.
q2.raw_answer: Guangzhou [or Canton; or Kwangchow; do NOT accept "Quanzhou"]

q3.quetsion_text: This Chinese dynasty was the first one that had to deal with mass wokou raids. Its other anti-pirate activities include sending Zheng He to crush pirates in Southeast Asia during his voyages.
q3.raw_answer: Ming dynasty [or Empire of the Great Ming; or Da Ming Di Guo]

lead_in: The letters "Kv.F" and the number 24 can be seen amongst the flags in this painting.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this 1914 painting by "the painter of Maine", Marsden Hartley. It was painted in memory of Hartley's friend Karl von Freyburg who had died in battle.

q2.quetsion_text: In Berlin, Hartley was influenced by this Russian Expressionist of various Compositions and Improvisations. One of his paintings names a group whose members included August Macke.

q3.quetsion_text: This other artist included a postage stamp and a thermometer in his 1914 work, Reservist of the First Division. The title Red Cavalry ride over a landscape of differently colored lines in a painting by this artist of Black Circle and Black Square.

lead_in: For 10 points each, answer some questions about American composers who depicted places in their music.

q1.quetsion_text: This composer included four taxi horns in the instrumentation for his tone poem An American in Paris.

q2.quetsion_text: This composer of Three Places in New England sought to capture the "spirit of transcendentalism" or some such crap in his Concord Sonata.

q3.quetsion_text: Aaron Copland wrote this one-movement composition depicting a dance hall, incorporating themes from the folk music of the title country.

lead_in: Taddeo Gaddi painted this scene below a Tree of Life for the refectory of Santa Croce.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this scene family painted by Leonardo Da Vinci in which Christ indicates that Judas will betray him.

q2.quetsion_text: A Last Supper with inlaid marble panels painted in was created by this Florentine painter, who also painted an equestrian statue of Niccolo Da Tolentino, and a notably foreshortened crucifixion for St. Apollonia.
q2.raw_answer: Andrea del Castagno [or Andrea Degil Impiccati]

q3.quetsion_text: Castagno painted a shield showing this figure as a young man, wearing a wind-blown red tunic. Caravaggio painted this figure holding a sword pointed towards his own groin while looking at a dripping and heavily bearded severed head he holds by the hair.

lead_in: Answer these following about practices introduced in Greek mythology, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: A chariot pulled by serpents helped Triptolemus travel around educating Greeks about this practice, which was the domain of Demeter.

q2.quetsion_text: This man was said to have introduced beekeeping to ancient Greece. When his bees were dying, the gods instructed him to leave out cattle carcasses, in which he later found hives of healthy bees.

q3.quetsion_text: Oeneus, a ruler of this city, introduced winemaking to parts of Greece. When Oeneus forgot to sacrifice to Artemis, Artemis sent a huge boar to this city that only Atalanta and Meleager could wound and kill.

lead_in: Bonus: One of his poems asks, “Who, if I cried out, would hear me among the Angelic Orders?” For ten points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this poet who wrote the Sonnets to Orpheus and a collection of ten poems called the Duino Elegies.
q1.raw_answer: René Karl Wilhelm Johann Josef “Rainer” Maria Rilke

q2.quetsion_text: This “Sturm und Drang” poet also wrote about Greek mythology in “The Gods of Greece” and wrote the poem Ode to Joy, which Beethoven would later use in his 9th symphony.

q3.quetsion_text: Both Rainer Maria Rilke and Friedrich von Schiller wrote in this language, which was also used by the Grimm Brothers in their popular folk tales such as “Hansel and Gretel” and “Snow White.”
